headline: The T Culture Issue
abstract: The worlds of culture and style stretch far and wide in the latest issue of T.
lead_paragraph: The worlds of culture and style stretch far and wide in the latest issue of T. There is Andrew Solomon’s profile of Deeda Blair, a medical philanthropist, fashion icon and social mover; Andrew O’Hagan on Miuccia Prada, the fashion designer (and also art curator, film producer and more); and Katie Roiphe’s look at the French intellectual Bernard-Henri Lévy and his new exhibition on the relationship between art and philosophy.

headline: U.S. Says It Pursues More Prosecutions on Indian Lands
abstract: The Justice Department said its rate of criminal prosecutions in Indian country had risen by more than 50 percent in the past four years, a period in which violent crime soared.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said this week that it had increased its rate of criminal prosecutions in Indian country by more than 50 percent in the past four years, a period in which violent crime on the nation’s Indian reservations has soared and tribes have complained of lawlessness.

headline: Bill Austin, Pro Bowl Guard, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Austin played for the 1956 N.F.L. champion Giants, coached the Green Bay Packers’ offensive linemen for Vince Lombardi’s power sweep and was twice an N.F.L. head coach.
lead_paragraph: Bill Austin, a Pro Bowl guard who played for the Giants’ 1956 N.F.L. champions, coached the Green Bay Packers’ offensive linemen for Vince Lombardi’s power sweep and was twice an N.F.L. head coach, died on May 22 in Las Vegas. He was 84.

headline: British Columbia Opposes Planned Oil Sands Pipeline
abstract: Environmental groups said that British Columbia, which has been concerned about spills, has probably doomed the pipeline.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A pipeline for exporting oil sands bitumen to Asia-bound tankers was dealt a severe blow on Friday when the province of British Columbia urged a federal review panel to reject the $6 billion plan.

headline: Mississippi: Civil Liberties Groups Sue Over Prison
abstract: A state prison for mentally ill inmates operates “in a perpetual state of crisis,” a federal lawsuit filed by the A.C.L.U. and the Southern Poverty Law Center alleges.
lead_paragraph: A state prison for mentally ill inmates is so poorly maintained that prisoners sell rats to one another as pets and defecate into plastic bags because toilets are broken, a federal lawsuit filed Thursday says. The East Mississippi Correctional Facility operates “in a perpetual state of crisis,” with inmates resorting to setting fires to receive medical attention, the class action suit filed by the A.C.L.U. and the Southern Poverty Law Center alleges. It claims that the prison, a privately run facility near Meridian, has ignored complaints for years from inmates who later went blind or lost body parts to amputation after not receiving proper medical care. A spokeswoman for the state Department of Corrections declined to comment.

headline: The Politics of Free Food
abstract: Virginia is for lovers of no-cost catering. Just look at the news from its very interesting off-year election.
lead_paragraph: Today, let’s talk about Virginia, host of the nation’s most interesting off-year election. True, the New York mayor’s race has been pretty frisky since we acquired Anthony Weiner as a candidate, but I’m still going with Virginia.

headline: Going Mobile: Pies That Really Roll
abstract: In New Jersey, pizza trucks cater private events, offering pizza fresh from their mobile ovens.
lead_paragraph: Each spring, George Triola invites his golf buddies and their families over for a backyard party at his home in Milltown, N.J., to celebrate the end of the Masters golf tournament. As the guests watch the finale on an outdoor TV, the beer flows, and most years, Mr. Triola, 35, grills hot dogs.

headline: Concern Grows as Group Disappears in Mexico
abstract: Eleven young people — seven men and four women — never made it home after a night out in the trendy Zona Rosa neighborhood of the capital.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Partygoers reveled inside a nightclub in the trendy Zona Rosa neighborhood here as the morning sun burned the asphalt outside.

headline: California: Marijuana Seller Takes Plea Deal
abstract: Matthew Davies, a medical marijuana store owner, abandoned a six-month legal battle against Washington and pleaded guilty to 10 charges of marijuana cultivation and distribution.
lead_paragraph: A medical marijuana store owner whose prosecution by the federal authorities highlighted vast disparities in how California and the Justice Department are responding to the medical marijuana industry abandoned a six-month battle against Washington on Friday and pleaded guilty to 10 charges of marijuana cultivation and distribution. The man, Matthew Davies, 35, had argued that his store in Stockton operated in accordance with California laws, after working extensively with accountants and lawyers before opening the business. But Benjamin B. Wagner, the United States attorney for the Eastern District of California, said, “Our investigation showed that it was all about the money.” Mr. Davies will serve a minimum of five years.

keywords: ['Identity Theft', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: A woman changed bank accounts and took other protective action after her wallet was taken, and yet bank tellers still handed a thief her money.
lead_paragraph: She was born and raised in New York City and is quick to add a preface to her story: Yes, she fully realizes she should have known better. But still. It is a stretch to say she could have seen coming what happened to thousands of her dollars in two different banks.

headline: U.S. Leaders for Olympics Mending Ties With I.O.C.
abstract: The United States Olympic Committee has made changes to satisfy the International Olympic Committee, bolstering a chance to host the 2024 Summer Games.
lead_paragraph: Like schoolchildren called to the principal’s office, two new executives for the United States Olympic Committee walked into the Westin Bayshore hotel in Vancouver to face International Olympic Committee officials. The U.S.O.C. and the I.O.C., at odds over how to split millions of dollars of revenue, had little mutual respect.

headline: An Elizabethan Cyberwar
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In confronting today’s cyberbattles, the United States should think less about Soviets and more about pirates.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — AS Barack Obama and China’s president, Xi Jinping, prepare to meet in California next week, America’s relations with China are feeling increasingly like the cold war — especially when it comes to cybersecurity.

headline: Woods Is Not in Top Form at the Memorial, but as Usual, He Makes the Cut
abstract: Tiger Woods, the defending champion, posted a 36-hole total of one-over 145, assuring that he will extend to 14 his streak of consecutive cuts made at the Memorial Tournament.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — Neither gusting winds nor searing heat nor fast greens nor slow play shall keep Tiger Woods from his appointed four rounds.

lead_paragraph: Don Oliver, who reached a nightly national audience as a correspondent covering major events for NBC News for more than 25 years, died on Tuesday in Spokane, Wash. He was 76.

headline: How Big Is That Park? City Now Has the Answer

lead_paragraph: A funny thing happened while backers and critics of a proposed Major League Soccer stadium were battling over 13 acres of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. Three hundred and fifty eight acres of the heavily used park seemed to disappear.

headline: Dramatic Scenes From Houston Fire
abstract: Friday may have been the deadliest day in the history of the Houston Fire Department, officials said, with four firefighters killed while battling a five-alarm blaze in a large motel.
lead_paragraph: Friday may have been the deadliest day in the history of the Houston Fire Department, officials said, with four firefighters killed while battling a five-alarm blaze that ripped through a large motel on the city’s busy Southwest Freeway. Five more firefighters were taken to area hospitals with injuries, but little information about their condition was available on Friday evening.

lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors introduced its revamped Chevrolet Malibu sedan on Friday — just a year after it put out the latest version of the car.

headline: Hunch About Bloomberg Brought Rivals Together
abstract: Suspicions that Bloomberg was monitoring bank executives never amounted to much until an official at Goldman Sachs called his counterpart at JPMorgan.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase are usually bitter rivals, competing for lucrative banking and trading business. But one day in April, the Wall Street titans found common ground: frustration with the Bloomberg news and financial data empire.

headline: Orioles’ Davis Emerging as Special Slugger
abstract: Baltimore first baseman Chris Davis, who was previously known for always striking out, led the majors with 19 homers through his first 53 games.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Before the Yankees and the Orioles began a three-game series at Camden Yards last week, Chris Davis, the Orioles’ starting first baseman, chatted with Robinson Cano. Davis playfully instructed Cano not to hit any home runs against the Orioles; Cano probably should have made the same request of Davis on behalf of the Yankees.

headline: Inquiry Into Obama and Bloomberg Ricin Letters Leads to Search of a Texas House
abstract: Federal investigators have questioned a man about letters laced with ricin that were mailed to President Obama and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, but no arrest has been made.
lead_paragraph: NEW BOSTON, Tex. — A quiet neighborhood in this small town in Northeast Texas has become the focus of the investigation into threatening letters laced with the deadly poison ricin that were mailed to President Obama and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, the authorities said Friday.

headline: Father Greeley, Defender of the Faithful
abstract: One of the most effective critics from within the Catholic Church spoke out early about the sexual abuse of children.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Andrew Greeley, who died this week in Chicago, gained fame and lots of money writing best-selling novels combining Catholicism, Irish America and sex.

headline: Untamed Melody
abstract: With words and homemade audio, the songwriter documents the birth of a few melodies and, hopefully, a song.
lead_paragraph: Lately I’ve been reading the memoirs of the 20th century Russian composer Dimitri Shostakovich. In one section, Shostakovich talks about Shakespeare, whose work was banned by Stalin. “Shakespeare speaks to us like a small child,” the composer writes. “When you talk to a child the words aren’t important. It’s what lies behind the words — the mood, the music.” He goes on: “When I speak to small children I often don’t delve in to the meaning of their babble I just listen to the timbres. It’s the same with Shakespeare. When I read Shakespeare, I give myself up to the flow. It doesn’t happen often. But those are the best moments. I read — and listen to his music.”

headline: Two Races in Two Days Add Up to Little Rest After Indianapolis 500
abstract: IndyCar will introduce its twin-bill format this weekend with two full-point, 70-lap road races on at the Dual of Detroit.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Helio Castroneves acknowledged that he was tired, then yawned and apologized to his onlookers.

headline: 4 Firefighters Are Killed in Houston Motel Blaze
abstract: Four firefighters died on Friday battling a five-alarm fire in Houston that began at a restaurant and ripped through a large motel.
lead_paragraph: Four firefighters died battling a five-alarm blaze that ripped through a large motel on a busy highway in southwest Houston on Friday, the authorities said. The Houston Fire Department said it was the single deadliest day in department history.

headline: The Gun Rampage Next Time
keywords: ['Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Gun Control', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Editorials']
abstract: Politicians should be as responsible in the face of tragedy as a new group studying emergency responses to mass shootings.
lead_paragraph: In a postscript to the Newtown school massacre in Connecticut, a trauma physician from Hartford Hospital has been meeting with experts from medicine, law enforcement and the military to plan better emergency responses to mass shootings so as to improve the chance for survival of gunshot victims. Just as wartime battlefields historically produce advances in trauma medicine, professionals in Connecticut and elsewhere in America where gun violence has become all too common are seeking to improve such emergency care — a development that concedes that future bouts of gun carnage are inevitable.

headline: What Makes the D.C. Circuit Different?
keywords: ['Appeals Courts (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Editorials']
abstract: The federal appeals court has an unusual national mandate and should have 11 active judges.
lead_paragraph: Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, is pushing a bill misleadingly called the Court Efficiency Act, which would eliminate three unfilled seats on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Next week, President Obama is expected to nominate three highly qualified lawyers for those seats, to bring the court to its full complement of 11 active judges. The Senate should confirm them quickly.

headline: Next Year’s Health Plan Rates
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'States (US)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Competition among insurers shows an ability to restrain growth in costs, disproving Republicans’ fear-provoking tale that the Affordable Care Act will drive rates up.
lead_paragraph: Republicans are doing their best to persuade Americans that the Affordable Care Act will drive health insurance premiums so high that consumers will experience “rate shock.” That fear-provoking tale seems much less credible now that the rates proposed by health insurers for individual coverage on the new health care exchanges have been made public in several states. For the most part, the premiums will increase only slightly or even decrease for individuals and family coverage on the exchanges, electronic marketplaces in which consumers choose among a variety of plans with differing benefits and costs.

headline: Teixeira and Youkilis Return to Lineup, Just in Time to Add Some Pop
abstract: Mark Teixeira and Kevin Youkilis returned to provide the Yankees some needed relief for their replacement players after a five-game losing streak knocked them out of first place.
lead_paragraph: A little over a week ago, when the Yankees were atop the American League East, some fans wondered if the team was somehow better without its injured stars. Lyle Overbay was proving to be one of the most clutch Yankees, and David Adams was showing potential at third base.

headline: Michigan Woman Killed in Syria War, Reports Say
abstract: The family and a close friend of Nicole Mansfield said the news delivered by the F.B.I. that she had been in Syria and was killed came as a shock.
lead_paragraph: About 4 a.m. on Wednesday, Janice Wilson got a Facebook message from the mother of a longtime friend, Nicole Lynn Mansfield, who was worried that she had not heard from her daughter since before Mother’s Day. She asked Ms. Wilson to please “do some homework” and help track her down.

headline: One Obstacle Won’t Budge in Japan’s Fight With Deflation
abstract: The Japanese government has made stemming deflation a priority, but its efforts so far have not affected everyday items, like a can of soda.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Vending machines stocked with sodas are ubiquitous here, tucked away, it seems, in every nook and cranny of the country. They are found along Omotesando, the tree-lined shopping avenue known as the Champs-Élysées of Tokyo, and their glow lights up the back streets of hot spring towns like Hakone. They are even atop Mount Fuji, Japan’s 12,000-foot, snow-capped mountain.

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Perched on a familiar dais, sitting on the verge of another trip to the N.B.A. finals, LeBron James took a moment to reflect, while his train of thought took a curious detour, to another time and place and state of mind.

keywords: ['Detainees', 'Torture', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Hunger Strikes']

headline: William Demby, Author of Experimental Novels, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Demby spent much of his career in Italy writing subtitles for Fellini and Rossellini movies.
lead_paragraph: William Demby, whose novels, written while he was an expatriate in Italy, challenged literary conventions and expectations of what a black writer should write about, died on May 23 at his home in Sag Harbor, N.Y. He was 90.

headline: A City’s Artistic Rebellion
abstract: “Leningrad’s Perestroika,” at the Zimmerli Art Museum in New Brunswick, explores how artists pushed beyond traditional mediums and boundaries in late-cold-war Leningrad.
lead_paragraph: A mention of the East Village in the 1980s carries a distinct cultural message: artists living in a gritty, post-punk universe, making art that critiqued mass media, consumerism and traditional art boundaries. It turns out that despite the Us-Versus-Them, Capitalism-Versus-Communism rhetoric of the late-cold-war period, Russian artists of that era were working in a very similar vein, albeit under different circumstances. You can see this in “Leningrad’s Perestroika: Crosscurrents in Photography, Video and Music,” an exhibition at the Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University in New Brunswick.

headline: Zimbabwe: Court Speeds Up Vote
abstract: Zimbabwe’s highest court ordered that national elections be held before the end of July, speeding up the expected timetable to choose a new Parliament and hold a presidential vote.
lead_paragraph: Zimbabwe’s highest court ordered that national elections be held before the end of July, speeding up the expected timetable to choose a new Parliament and hold a presidential vote. President Robert G. Mugabe hopes to win another term and end the uneasy power-sharing arrangement put in place after the 2008 election. The new Constitution approved in March requires extensive changes to electoral laws before a vote is held, which has led the opposition Movement for Democratic Change to push for elections later in the year. The opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai said that the court had “no power whatsoever to set an election date,” and that enough time must be allowed for voter registration and electoral reforms.

headline: Lebanon: Elections Postponed
keywords: ['Elections', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: Lebanon’s Parliament voted to delay elections, which had been scheduled to take place on June 16, for at least 17 months.
lead_paragraph: Lebanon’s Parliament on Friday voted to delay elections, which had been scheduled to take place on June 16, for at least 17 months. It is the first such delay since the end of Lebanon’s 15-year civil war in 1990. The Lebanese newspaper The Daily Star said the measure authorizing the delay was the result of the Parliament’s failure to agree on a new electoral law and “the worsening security situation in the country linked to the crisis in neighboring Syria.”

lead_paragraph: The national spelling bee spelled it wrong.

headline: Playing and Persevering at an Uncommon Level
abstract: After returning from a gruesome injury, the Penguins’ Sidney Crosby has scored seven goals with eight assists this postseason, a higher scoring rate than his playoff career average.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — The face of the N.H.L. has been rearranged, but Sidney Crosby is still smiling, undeterred. The Penguins’ Crosby has notched 7 goals and 8 assists in 10 playoff games, a higher scoring rate than his career average of 1.35 points per playoff game, the best among active players and No. 4 in league history.

headline: Circumcision Device Approved by World Health Organization
abstract: A nonsurgical circumcision device that relies on a rubber band was approved by the World Health Organization, opening the way for its widespread use in Africa.
lead_paragraph: A nonsurgical circumcision device that relies on a rubber band was approved by the World Health Organization on Friday, opening the way for its widespread use in Africa. The device, known as PrePex, is the only adult circumcision method, other than conventional surgery, to gain W.H.O. acceptance. Dr. Eric P. Goosby, the United States Global AIDS Coordinator, said that it would “truly help save lives” and that he was prepared to use funds from the President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief for it. For a heterosexual man in countries where AIDS is common, being circumcised lowers the chance of getting infected by about 60 percent. In the past few years, the United States has paid for more than two million circumcisions in Africa; the W.H.O.’s goal is 20 million by 2015. PrePex can be quickly put in place by a two-nurse team. The foreskin dies from the pressure of the rubber band in a grooved ring, and drops off or is clipped off a week later. The procedure uses only topical anesthesia and is safer than surgery.

headline: Organizing Black Soldiers
abstract: The federal government formed the United States Bureau of Colored Troops to enlist black troops.
lead_paragraph: For an army beset with unprecedented casualties resulting from Shiloh, Antietam, Fredericksburg and other bloody battles, the ability to tap into an entirely new pool of recruits was a godsend – which is precisely what arrived on Jan. 1, 1863, when the Emancipation Proclamation declared that persons previously held as slaves “will be received into the armed service of the United States.” But it took another five months before the federal government decided just how to do that.

headline: Georgia: Prosecutors Investigate Spending of Government Funds
abstract: Prosecutors in Georgia are investigating allegations that President Mikheil Saakashvili misused government funds, including more than $11,000 for Botox injections.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Georgia are investigating allegations that President Mikheil Saakashvili misused government funds, including more than $11,000 for Botox injections during visits to the United States in 2009 and 2011, according to local news reports. headline: Love and Angst, in Hair Products and Leather
abstract: “Grease,” an enduring tribute to adolescence, comes alive during its musical numbers at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport.
lead_paragraph: Admirers of more cerebral musicals may sometimes wonder why “Grease,” the nostalgic tribute to adolescent angst and blooming love at Rydell High in 1959, continues to find its way to numerous stages. The original Broadway production, which opened in 1972 and closed eight years later, set a longevity record for its time. It has been turned into a movie and had two major Broadway revivals and countless other productions. Its beloved songs, like “Summer Nights” and “Those Magic Changes,” are by now easily mistaken for iconic 1950s ballads instead of the fond sendups they were meant to be.

headline: Crossing 96th Street’s Great Divide
abstract: The blocks north of 96th Street on the East Side are intriguingly animated by contrasts and surprises.
lead_paragraph: Ninety-sixth Street was long the border between the Upper East Side and El Barrio, Spanish Harlem. To the north, the train tracks beneath Park Avenue leapt aboveground, and Carnegie Hill’s regular grid and uniform prosperity gave way to a patchwork of public housing and poverty. Today, the old divide is less visible, and the blocks to its north are intriguingly animated by contrasts and surprises.

headline: En Garde, All the Time
abstract: For Adrienne Jarocki, a 17-year-old international fencing champion from Queens, Sundays are a day to pursue her passion of competitive fencing, near home or abroad.
lead_paragraph: For Adrienne Jarocki, 17, an international fencing champion from Middle Village, Queens, Sundays are only partly a day of rest. She may not have classes at the Bronx High School of Science, but she is usually holding a saber — either at Sheridan Fencing Academy on the Upper East Side, where she has trained for three years, or in competition in the United States or abroad. Though she came to fencing on the late side, after getting tired of competitive ballroom dancing and the beauty pageant circuit — she was Miss New York Preteen 2008 — Ms. Jarocki won a silver medal at the Junior and Cadet World Championships in Porec, Croatia, in April, and will fence as a freshman at Harvard this fall. But first, she will graduate from high school on June 21 and spend a month in Poland, where her parents — Jaroslaw, 54, and Anna Jarocki, 47 — are from.

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It is a bittersweet anniversary.

headline: ‘People Think It’s Over’
abstract: Drugs may have prevented people with H.I.V. from dying of AIDS, but even as they reach the once-unthinkable age of 50, their lives continue to be ravaged by the virus.
lead_paragraph: Steve Schalchlin would be the first to tell you he lives in a time of miracles, and about how hard that can be. In 1995, as his body wasted away from AIDS, he took the limited time in front of him as a challenge: he would write songs, make amends, fill his remaining days with life. And by the end, with his digestive system shut down, his figure skeletal, he was ready to die. Then he won a lottery for a new AIDS drug that had been rushed through the approval process. Almost overnight his health began to return, and with it, another, more open-ended, challenge: life.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) TROUBLE WITH THE CURVE (2012) Clint Eastwood stars as Gus Lobel, a longtime scout for the Atlanta Braves whose eyesight is failing and whose job is threatened by a younger hotshot (Matthew Lillard) for whom baseball revolves around numbers and computers. But Gus has a secret weapon against the front-office man who would take him down with newfangled nonsense — and the washed-up pitcher (Justin Timberlake) sent by the Red Sox to check out a high school slugger (Joe Massingill): his daughter, Mickey (Amy Adams, above, with Mr. Eastwood), a lawyer whose eye for talent is almost as sharp as her gnarly dad’s used to be. “The pat and occasionally preposterous story is really just a pretext, a serviceable scaffolding for a handful of expert, satisfying performances,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Eastwood “has the good sense to realize that, much as we may adore him, we’d sometimes rather spend time with Ms. Adams, who somehow grows tougher, funnier, scarier and more charming with every role.” The film, Mr. Scott added, “may be an exhibition game, with nothing much at stake, but Ms. Adams brings the heat. She swings for the fence. Snags the line drive, tags the runner and makes the throw to the plate. Find your own metaphor.”

headline: A Housing Solution Gone Awry

lead_paragraph: In the early 1970s, the architect and city planner Oscar Newman came forth with a book and theory called “Defensible Space,” which relied in part on data from New York City public housing to propose a set of design solutions to the mounting problems of urban living.

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 1
abstract: German population fears; identifying factory fire’s victims; unemployment rises in Euro zone; and deflation may be ending in Japan.
lead_paragraph: NEWS It’s as if Leipzig, Hanover and Dresden had disappeared in the blink of an eye, statistically speaking. Germany, which has been deeply concerned about its rapidly dwindling population, released the results of its first census in nearly a quarter of a century on Friday and found 1.5 million fewer inhabitants than previously assumed. Chancellor Angela Merkel was already worried about the shrinking numbers of taxpayers and able-bodied workers. How future smaller generations will repay German debts, much less the mounting liabilities and guarantees meant to contain the euro-zone debt crisis, is a central question here. Germany had not conducted a single census count since reunification, not even an effort to tally those in the former East Germany after the Berlin Wall fell in 1989. The disappearance of 1.5 million people, equal to almost 1.9 percent of the population, only exacerbates the longer-term downward trend. Nick Kulish and Chris Cottrell report from Berlin.

headline: For Kerber, a Gritty Win in a Tough Draw
abstract: Angelique Kerber persevered in a three-set victory over Varvara Lepchenko. Her reward? A match again the onetime champion Svetlana Kuznetsova and, down the road, a potential encounter with Serena Williams.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The primal scream emanating from Angelique Kerber said it all. Relief, joy and pure adrenaline were all perfectly encapsulated in that one spine-tingling moment as she sealed a pulsating 6-4, 6-7 (3), 6-4 victory over the gritty Varvara Lepchenko in just over two and a half hours at Roland Garros. Tennis is a gladiatorial sport, and both women played out the final few games as if their lives depended on it.

headline: Why Big Data Is Not Truth

abstract: Don’t let the rhetoric fool you, a Microsoft researcher says: Big Data is a human tool, which means it is subject to all kinds of miscollection, misapplication and abuse. While it is being promoted as a kind of data-driven truth, it is not and it poses a threat to privacy.
lead_paragraph: The word “data” connotes fixed numbers inside hard grids of information, and as a result, it is easily mistaken for fact. But including bad product introductions and wars, we have many examples of bad data causing big mistakes.

lead_paragraph: The 1973 Endangered Species Act provides federal protection — breathing space, in a very real sense — to plants and animals threatened with extinction. Had this task been left to the states alone, almost none of the species that have returned to health would have done so.

headline: The Global Plight of Disabled Children
abstract: A new report from the United Nations shows the devastating effect of Senate Republicans who blocked ratification of a treaty to help disabled people around the world.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations report, “The State of the World’s Children,” underscores the moral bankruptcy of Senate Republicans who blocked ratification of a treaty to help disabled people around the world. There is scant data on how many children have such disabilities or how their lives are affected. One outdated estimate is that some 93 million children, one in 20 of those 14 or younger, live with a moderate or severe disability of some kind. The issue is how they might be helped to overcome their disabilities and become productive members of their societies.

headline: We Are Not Having A Serious Discussion, Obamacare Edition

lead_paragraph: I fairly often receive mail pleading with me to take a more even tone, to have a respectful discussion with people on the other side rather than calling them fools and knaves. And you know, I do when I can. But the truth is that on most of the big issues confronting us, there just isn’t anyone to have a serious discussion with. Ezra Klein offers a nice illustration of this point today, in his takedown of Avik Roy on Obamacare in California.

abstract: While the American medical system is famous for expensive drugs and heroic care at the end of life, a more significant factor in the nation’s annual health care bill may be the high price tag of ordinary services.
lead_paragraph: MERRICK, N.Y. — Deirdre Yapalater’s recent colonoscopy at a surgical center near her home here on Long Island went smoothly: she was whisked from pre-op to an operating room where a gastroenterologist, assisted by an anesthesiologist and a nurse, performed the routine cancer screening procedure in less than an hour. The test, which found nothing worrisome, racked up what is likely her most expensive medical bill of the year: $6,385.

headline: Does Great Literature Make Us Better?

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (AMC) THE KILLING With the killer of Rosie Larsen finally revealed at the end of the second season, this series — which was canceled and then revived — returns with a new case, which the network says will be solved in a single year. And while Sarah Linden (Mireille Enos, above) is no longer working as a Seattle detective, she is drawn back into that life by her former partner Stephen Holder (Joel Kinnaman). During a search for a runaway girl, he discovers a string of gruesome murders seemingly connected to an investigation she headed several years earlier. Peter Sarsgaard joins the cast as Tom Seward, the psychopath who was convicted in those murders and is just weeks away from execution. Still, even with new colleagues, victims and suspects, “Season 3 looks an awful lot like the first two: brooding clouds; menacing, slate-colored skies; and leaden seas are still featured players,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “The creators take a fresh start but cling to the sepulchral atmospherics that too often take the place of narrative. The series is still suspenseful, but the dread that once again follows Sarah through damp forests, deserted tenements and shadowy, rain-washed streets diminishes with overuse.”

headline: F.D.A. to Reconsider Restrictions on Diabetes Drug
abstract: In a highly unusual move, the agency has decided to reopen the case on Avandia and will ask a committee whether it should reconsider the restrictions on the drug.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, in one of the more notable drug-safety scandals in recent history, the diabetes drug Avandia was all but banned from use in the United States after researchers found that thousands of people had heart problems after taking it. Today, it is a drug of last resort for people with diabetes who are so sick that a heart attack is worth the risk.

lead_paragraph: HAMDEN, Conn. — Lawrence F. Gall, an entomologist at the Peabody Museum of Natural History at Yale, bushwhacked his way through the muddy thickets leading to the River Road colony here, the epicenter of what is believed to be the world’s only preserve dedicated to Magicicada septendecim, the 17-year periodical cicada.

headline: Gay, Hispanic, Adoptive: A Triple-Threat Family
abstract: “The Fosters,” making its debut on ABC Family, centers on an unconventional family: lesbian mothers, one mother’s biological son, adopted Hispanic twins and a foster daughter.
lead_paragraph: “The Fosters” is a conventional family dramedy about an insistently unconventional family: lesbian mothers (a white police officer and a black charter-school administrator), the officer’s biological son, adopted Hispanic twins and a foster daughter fresh out of juvie.

headline: Ripples of Rumination
abstract: Collectors, museum directors, curators and others take the temperature of contemporary art at an unusually thought-provoking Venice Biennale.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — They park their hulking yachts with names like “Lady Nag Nag,” “Wally’s Love” and “Sea Force One” on the choppy waters of the lagoon just outside the main entrance to the Venice Biennale. Every two years, scores of superrich collectors arrive here by sea, joined by museum directors, curators, artists and auction-house experts. They come to see and be seen and to take the temperature of contemporary art today.

headline: Sharing a Festive Touch Of Iceland and Korea
abstract: Either/Or, founded in 2004, opened its spring festival last week with pieces by Anna Thorvaldsdottir and François Rose, among others.
lead_paragraph: There are two schools of thought about how to proceed when confronted with unfamiliar music, particularly a new piece. One school embraces a kind of Zen approach: the listener faces each work with no predisposition or prejudice, accepting and interpreting whatever comes. The other endorses coming to the encounter armed with some basic knowledge: since composers haven’t worked in a single, common style for centuries now, comprehension and appreciation are enhanced by knowing where a creator was — geographically, temperamentally, stylistically — when a given piece emerged.

headline: Joining Forces for a Nostalgic Journey Through Jazz

lead_paragraph: The last thing that Wynton Marsalis’s “Swing Symphony” needed was another movement.

headline: How Obama Prevailed in 2012
abstract: In “The Center Holds,” Jonathan Alter charts President Obama’s road to re-election.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Alter’s revealing 2010 book, “The Promise,” provided a detailed look at President Obama’s first year in office, tracing his decision-making process on issues like health care reform and the Afghanistan war. Mr. Alter’s highly informed, energetically reported but often tiresomely familiar new book, “The Center Holds: Obama and His Enemies,” is less a sequel than a chronicle of the president’s fight to win re-election and his continuing battles with an obstructionist Republican party.

headline: Defying Naysayers, ‘Gatsby’ Proves a Box-Office Winner
abstract: Baz Luhrmann’s adaptation of “The Great Gatsby” has become the latest example of the Hollywood watchers miscalculating audience interest.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “If history is any indication,” a Forbes report read on May 3, “ ‘The Great Gatsby’ will bomb rather hard.” BoxOffice.com at one point projected very soft opening-weekend sales of about $24 million. Early on, several studios were so worried about the movie’s multiplex prospects that they passed on making it.

headline: Oklahoma Campus, Ravaged by a Tornado, Draws Attention to Storm Shelters
abstract: None of the 15 people at a Canadian Valley Technology Center were hurt after a tornado, but had it been a busy day the result may have been tragic.
lead_paragraph: EL RENO, Okla. — It takes imagination to picture the Canadian Valley Technology Center as it used to be. Hundreds of adults and teenagers packed the classrooms at the vocational education campus here in the daytime and evenings, studying the art of welding, cosmetology and graphic design and learning to fix airplanes and cars by working on actual airplanes and cars.

headline: As Harvey Struggles, the Mets Are Swept
abstract: The struggling Ike Davis showed signs of resurgence but the Mets dropped their third straight to the lowly Marlins.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Matt Harvey was not the Matt Harvey the Mets have grown accustomed to seeing this year. Neither was Ike Davis.

headline: Nonstop Screwball Antics, Choreographed and Less So
abstract: Yvonne Meier’s absurdist dance works “This is not a pink pony” and her “This is not a pink pony 2” were performed at the Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: The sounds of gunshots — and laughter — rang through the playhouse of Abrons Arts Center on Thursday as Yvonne Meier remounted her aggressively absurd 2006 work “This is not a pink pony.” The plastic deer onstage did not fall, but the three straight-faced screwballs did, many times. Then came the premiere of “This is not a pink pony 2.”

headline: Satire Born in the Face of Horror
abstract: In “The Last Cyclist,” a play that was written inside a Nazi concentration camp, all bicyclists — or anyone whose ancestors had anything to do with bicycles — face deportation or death.
lead_paragraph: “The Last Cyclist” isn’t participatory theater in any of the usual senses. No one is called up from Row C to answer trivia questions or dance a jig onstage. But if you’re attending this intriguing exercise in Holocaust history, you should plan to show up in character. To appreciate what you’re going to see, you need to be not a 21st-century theatergoer but rather a prisoner at Theresienstadt, the Nazi concentration camp near Prague.

headline: Turkish Leader Says Protests Will  Not Stop Plans for Park
abstract: Calling protesters “looters” and “bums,” Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said that plans to demolish a public park would continue, despite public opposition.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey dismissed the tens of thousands of protesters who battled for two days with police officers in the streets of Istanbul as “looters” and “bums” on Sunday. He vowed to push ahead with plans to demolish a public park — a trigger for the spasm of public anger that left Istanbul’s main commercial district strewn with graffiti and broken glass.

headline: If Chorus Lines Be the Food of Love

The program, directed and hosted by Mark Lamos, who wrote the script with Deborah Grace Winer, explores the ways in which Shakespeare’s plays and poems have been adapted not only for Broadway but also for jazz experiments and the movies.

headline: Non-prophet Economics
abstract: Models, not men.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago Noah Smith had a good piece on the many people who beat their breasts and loudly boast about having “predicted the crisis”. As he says, by and large, the louder the boasting, the thinner the evidence for any special achievement. And anyway, also as he says, there’s the question of what you’re predicting. The housing bust? The fall of Lehman? The sluggishness of the recovery?

headline: Wit, Poetry and Shadows
abstract: All three parts of the Shostakovich trilogy, choreographed by Alexei Ratmanksy, are being presented by American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House.
lead_paragraph: As Alexei Ratmansky’s fascinating, poetic, enigmatic and bittersweet new “Shostakovich Trilogy” proceeds, it includes overlapping expressions of ebullience, struggle, heroism, community, affection, wit, brilliance and inspiration — but also of fear, vigilance, alarm, apprehension and grief. And the movement, more than with any previous works by Mr. Ratmansky, is often powerfully charged by qualities of strain and tension; you notice how dancers move from one position to the next, sometimes as if the air is heavier than water, sometimes as if holding onto each other while the rest of life is pulling them asunder.

headline: The Geezers Are All Right
abstract: News flash: Social Security and Medicare aren’t doomed!
lead_paragraph: Last month the Congressional Budget Office released its much-anticipated projections for debt and deficits, and there were cries of lamentation from the deficit scolds who have had so much influence on our policy discourse. The problem, you see, was that the budget office numbers looked, well, O.K.: deficits are falling fast, and the ratio of debt to gross domestic product is projected to remain roughly stable over the next decade. Obviously it would be nice, eventually, to actually reduce debt. But if you’ve built your career around proclamations of imminent fiscal doom, this definitely wasn’t the report you wanted to see.

headline: Secrets and Leaks
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Where right meets left on freedom of the press.
lead_paragraph: CONGRESSMAN Ted Poe and I are not what you’d call kindred spirits. He’s a shrink-the-government-then-drown-it-in-the-bathtub Texas Republican, a global warming denier, an N.R.A. 100-percenter, a devout foe of abortion rights. He comes from a political tribe that regards the mainstream media as a hive of Bolsheviks. Yet Poe and I see eye to eye on one thing. He is the main House sponsor of a bill intended to protect journalists from being compelled to give up information about their government sources, even when the sources have divulged matters of national security.

abstract: The murky enterprise of harvesting what is called nonpublic information needs to be brought under control.
lead_paragraph: The harvesting of what is called nonpublic information is one of the secretive arts of Washington, where power resides in staying ahead of developments and profiting from inside information. The absolute masters of this murky enterprise have come to be known as political intelligence operatives — a growing specialty of former Congressional members and staffers and veterans of the executive branch who make regular rounds to schmooze with well-situated acquaintances and discover what is in the works that is not yet on the public radar.

headline: Protests in Turkey

headline: Time to Change Military Justice

abstract: Complaints about sexual misconduct at the service academies dramatize the need for reform.
lead_paragraph: In his commencement address at the United States Military Academy late last month, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel urged the newest graduates of the two-centuries-old academy to help stamp out the “scourge” of sexual assaults in the military. His call had special resonance. It had been revealed just days before that a sergeant responsible for advising cadets had been charged with secretly videotaping female cadets in the shower — just one of an alarming cascade of incidents in recent weeks evidencing the depth, frequency and sheer brazenness of the military’s sexual misconduct problem.

abstract: Steven A. Cohen’s SAC Capital Advisors, long under investigation, faces what could be billions of dollars in withdrawals by a Monday deadline. Prosecutors face a deadline of their own.
lead_paragraph: The embattled hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is bracing for investors to pull out as much as several billion dollars by a Monday deadline. Withdrawals have stepped up as a separate deadline looms for law enforcement officials investigating the firm.

headline: Rev. Dr. Roger L. Shinn, Theologian, Dies at 96
abstract: Dr. Shinn championed the ecumenical movement and argued for a sharper sense of ethical and social responsibility on the part of moderate Protestant churches.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Dr. Roger L. Shinn, an educator, administrator and author who championed the ecumenical movement and social activism in Protestant churches as their growth peaked in the 1950s and ’60s, died on May 13 at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 96.

headline: Yes, We’re Pregnant! Oxbow’s Dam and Sire Expecting Another Foal.
abstract: The dam Tizamazing and the sire Awesome Again have produced four winning racehorses, including the Preakness champion Oxbow.
lead_paragraph: Oxbow, the winner of last month’s Preakness Stakes, will have another full brother or sister next year. His dam, Tizamazing, was given an ultrasound Monday morning and was confirmed 14 days in foal to his sire, Awesome Again.

headline: In Georgia Town, Hints of More Diverse Future for Major Leagues
abstract: Three current major leaguers graduated from Redan High School, which has an enrollment that is 98 percent black and a baseball program that produces one of the school’s most successful sports teams.
lead_paragraph: STONE MOUNTAIN, Ga. — Greg Goodwin pointed to a striking baseball photograph on his office wall at Redan High School.

headline: Mayoral Candidates Wrestle Over Waste Removal
abstract: A waste transfer station on the Upper East Side has generated fierce opposition and set off a bitter war of words between two candidates.
lead_paragraph: It is the most local of local controversies, pitting New York City officials citing fairness against residents upset at the thought of garbage trucks clogging the streets. Yet late last week, the long-simmering dispute over a planned marine waste transfer station on the Upper East Side suddenly erupted in the mayoral campaign, setting off a bitter war of words between two of the leading Democratic candidates.

headline: Pressure Grows to Create Drugs for ‘Superbugs’
abstract: Experts are considering ways to speed the approval of new medicines to combat antibiotic-resistant infections, but high costs and safety concerns have complicated their efforts.
lead_paragraph: Government officials, drug companies and medical experts, faced with outbreaks of antibiotic-resistant “superbugs,” are pushing to speed up the approval of new antibiotics, a move that is raising safety concerns among some critics.

headline: Kuchar, Steady Across the Board, Cruises to His Second Win of the Year
abstract: Matt Kuchar hit all but one fairway in his closing four-under-par 68. He finished at 12-under 276, two strokes ahead of Kevin Chappell.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — Though he hid his discomfort behind a smile, the bristly stuff bothered Matt Kuchar. Not the unruly rough at Muirfield Village Golf Club, which swallowed one contender after another at the Memorial Tournament. Kuchar’s scraggly beard was his main irritant as he cruised to his second victory this year and the fifth of his PGA Tour career.

headline: A Paradise and a Prison
abstract: “Far From Heaven,” at Playwrights Horizons, is a musical adaptation of Todd Haynes’s film about Eisenhower-era repression.
lead_paragraph: When Kelli O’Hara sings the word “garden,” an arid landscape blossoms into lushness. This poetic note is sounded halfway through the first act of the generally prosy new musical “Far From Heaven,” which opened on Sunday night at Playwrights Horizons. And all your senses come to attention, the way they do on one of those days when an early, full-blown spring seems to have broken through winter without warning.

headline: Unsettling Moment of Truth for Heat
abstract: The Heat’s title defense is dependent on Dwyane Wade’s wobbly knee, Chris Bosh’s wilting confidence and LeBron James’s apparently wavering faith in his struggling co-stars.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Nerves and alliances have been frayed, anxieties heightened and an aura diminished. Across 11 days and 6 games of these Eastern Conference finals, the Miami Heat have been stress-tested and stretched to their limits by the Indiana Pacers and now face a trial they surely never anticipated: Game 7.

headline: Sorry, Eloise. No More Room Service.
abstract: In August, the New York Hilton Midtown will discontinue food and drink service to all 2,000 rooms. In its place will be a self-service kitchen stocked with grab-and-go items.
lead_paragraph: It is the perk that comes with expense accounts, the silver tray that wakes lovers in the morning, and the frequent indulgence of the superspy James Bond.

headline: Fighting the Image of the ‘Burning’ Borough
abstract: Though the Bronx has made progress from its time as a symbol of urban decay, it has not had much success in remaking its reputation.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx has been trying to remove the scorch marks from its name since the 1970s, when arson fires, rampant crime and poverty pushed residents out in droves; made the borough a national symbol of urban decay; and saddled it with the apocalyptic phrase, “the Bronx is burning.”

headline: Through a New Lens
abstract: Times coverage from the late 1960s and the 1970s shows the South Bronx as a crumbling, desolate and dangerous place. Ángel Franco, a Times photographer, revisited neighborhoods featured in that coverage to see how the view has changed.
lead_paragraph: Times coverage from the late 1960s and the 1970s shows the South Bronx as a crumbling, desolate and dangerous place. Ángel Franco, a Times photographer, revisited neighborhoods featured in that coverage to see how the view has changed.

headline: Jack Vance, Novelist of the Fantastical, Is Dead at 96
abstract: Mr. Vance wrote fantasy and mysteries, sometimes pseudonymously. But he specialized in science fiction, a label he disdained, and wrote a number of book series.
lead_paragraph: Jack Vance, who in dozens of fantastical novels created alternative worlds, past and present, imagining their alien societies in evocative detail, died on May 26 at his home in Oakland, Calif. He was 96.

headline: Robredo Remains Focused, and Stays Alive at Roland Garros
abstract: The Spaniard Tommy Robredo’s ability to comeback from two sets down against his more powerful countryman Nicolas Almagro lies in large part in his remarkable match temperament.
lead_paragraph: Watching Spain’s Tommy Robredo come back to win his third straight match after losing the first two sets and stun his more powerful countryman Nicolas Almagro, was to witness clay court tennis at its most sublime. Robredo rallied from 4-1 in the third set, 4-2 in the fourth, and 2-0 in the fifth — in one of the most remarkable matches I’ve ever watched — to advance at the French Open with a 6-7 (5), 3-6, 6-4, 6-4, 6-4 victory.

headline: China Is Reaping Biggest Benefits of Iraq Oil Boom

lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Since the American-led invasion of 2003, Iraq has become one of the world’s top oil producers, and China is now its biggest customer.

headline: After Ivanovic, Radwanska Expects Grueling Test From Errani
abstract: Agnieszka Radwanska outfoxed Ana Ivanovic to reach the French Open quarterfinals, but she expects a grueling test there from Sara Errani.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Agnieszka Radwanska lived up to her reputation as one of the most watchable players on the tour as she out-thought Ana Ivanovic on Sunday, producing a few contenders for shot of the tournament along the way.

headline: A Producer Who Knew When to Have Marilyn Monroe on Hand
abstract: Paul Libin, a longtime Broadway executive who worked closely with Arthur Miller, is receiving a Tony Award for lifetime achievement.
lead_paragraph: An enduring New York mystery is the sheeplike behavior of Broadway playgoers who line up by the hundreds outside theaters long before the curtain goes up. They have assigned seats. There is no reason for them to stand out there like robots. Nothing about this ritual makes sense.

headline: Stifled by Time’s Passage, Fewer Fans Visit the Bunkers’ TV Home
abstract: When the news arrived on Saturday that Jean Stapleton — best known for playing Edith on “All in the Family” — had died, only a few gawkers came out to reminisce.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, they came in droves: the fans who knocked on the door, begged to be shown around the living room, and snapped photos in front of the little row house in Queens that, on their television screens, anyway, belonged to Archie Bunker and his wife, Edith.

headline: Teacher Assessments Extending to Art and Gym
abstract: A new state system will include teachers of subjects that are not typically evaluated.
lead_paragraph: New York City students have grown accustomed to the restless routine of state tests in math and reading every year. But soon they will face assessments in subjects typically spared from standardized testing, including art, gym and foreign languages.

While sports also may place children at risk of injuries, most are preventable if participants, their parents and their coaches heed some well-researched safety measures.

headline: Rushing to Aid in Syrian War, but Claiming No Side
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: The Arab Red Crescent is overseen by the government, but its volunteers pursue their aid mission with vigorous neutrality, and some of them have paid a heavy price.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — Inside the cordon of government checkpoints that ring the Syrian capital, residents are used to the crack of outgoing mortar fire. Scores of shells fly each day from bases atop Mount Qasioun, overlooking the city. For most people, their impact is left to the imagination, as state-run news media contend they are hitting “terrorists,” rebels led by foreign fighters who are bent on destroying the ancient, diverse culture of Damascus.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 4:15 P.M. (Sundance) GALLIPOLI (1981) The director Peter Weir follows two fleet-footed young Australians (Mark Lee and Mel Gibson) as they journey from the countryside to Perth and into the disastrous World War I battle in the Ottoman Empire. Beginning with a footrace, “the film approaches the subject of war so obliquely that it can’t properly be termed a war movie,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “Besides, it is prettier than any war film has ever been, which makes its emotional power something of a surprise. Mr. Weir’s work has a delicacy, gentleness, even wispiness that would seem not well suited to the subject. And yet his film has an uncommon beauty, warmth and immediacy, and a touch of the mysterious, too.”

headline: Soups With Spinach, Five Ways
abstract: The world’s cuisines offer endless ways to use the season’s beautiful bunches of spinach in light and flavorful soups.
lead_paragraph: Last week, at a cooking class I taught with my friend and colleague Clifford A. Wright, we demonstrated different versions of the same Andalusian spinach and chickpea soup, a dish that is packed with spinach. Cliff uses lots of olive oil and cooks his for a long time, the way the authentic dish would be produced; I use less olive oil and add the spinach at the end because I prefer the flavor and look of spinach when it’s barely cooked.

headline: Buchholz Flummoxes Yanks, and a Storm Finishes Them

lead_paragraph: The way Clay Buchholz was pitching Sunday night, it seemed the only thing that could stop him was some kind of heavenly intervention, and that was close to what happened. Buchholz, the undefeated right-handed pitcher for the Boston Red Sox, was flashing his finest, most electric stuff, stifling the Yankees through five innings.

headline: An Icon and a Symbol of Two Nations’ Anger
abstract: The tug of war between Japan and South Korea over a religious statue that both countries claim has revived memories of atrocities and resentments that go back centuries.
lead_paragraph: TSUSHIMA, Japan — Over the centuries, this mountainous island in the strait separating Japan and Korea has seen some of the most violent episodes between those ancient Asian rivals, serving as a hide-out for pirates, a forward base for invaders and a desperate first line against attack. But in recent years that troubled history seemed hazily remote in Tsushima’s sleepy fishing hamlet of Kozuna, where villagers have gathered for generations in a tiny temple to pray before a statue of the Buddhist deity of compassion that is centuries old.

His body was found a few days after his death. More than three weeks later, the Jammu Tribune reported that the young man, who was living alone after his parents died some time ago, was mentally disturbed and had died of starvation after the state government’s relief department stopped his monthly stipend for unknown reasons.

headline: Revisiting a Rape Scandal That Would Have Been Monstrous if True
abstract: This Retro Report video looks at the fallout from false rape allegations made by an African-American teenager, Tawana Brawley, and her advisers, including the Rev. Al Sharpton.
lead_paragraph: The news reports at the time, in the late 1980s, were horrific. Tawana Brawley, a 15-year-old African-American girl from the New York City area, was said to have been abducted and repeatedly raped by six white men. She was found with “KKK” written across her chest, a racial epithet on her stomach and her hair smeared with feces. She was so traumatized, according to reports, that at the hospital she answered yes-or-no questions by blinking her eyes. Making the crime even more vile, if that were possible, she and her lawyers later claimed that two of the rapists were law enforcement officials.

headline: A Photographic Feast in the South of France
abstract: Portfolios from celebrated photographers — like the director Costa-Gravas and the urban landscape-master Gabriele Basilico — to innovative newcomers helps the Photomed festival of photography stand out among a wealth of photo events in the South of France in the summer.
lead_paragraph: Many photography festivals take place in southern France from the spring to fall, and the three-year-old Photomed, one of the newest and fastest rising, just opened in Sanary-sur-Mer, southeast of Marseille. The festival focuses on Mediterranean photographers and images, and is under the artistic direction of Jean-Luc Monterosso, founder and director of the Maison Européenne de la Photographie in Paris. Mr. Monterosso and his team have been successfully striking a balance between exhibiting big-name photographers — the edition this year includes Nino Migliori, Gabriele Basilico, Fouad Elkoury and the filmmaker Costa-Gavras — and showcasing the young and lesser-known, with the spotlight this year on Lebanon.

headline: Romancing the Brands
abstract: David Brooks is quite right to make fun of people who buy one kind of shoe rather than another because it gives them a morally feel-good sensation.
lead_paragraph: Regarding “The romantic advantage” (Views, June 1): It is pretty clear that David Brooks is only using the subject of China’s soulless brand names — which for most consumers are less important than the word “China” next to them, meaning “very good for the money with a slight risk of being unsafe” — to have a go at his beloved “bo-bo” class, an expression that Brooks himself minted but that caught on more here in France, where there are also lots of well-off people who go around looking like bums. This said, he is quite right to make fun of the semi-Socialists who buy one kind of shoe rather than another because it gives them a morally feel-good sensation, and also to point to the loftily “romantic” associations that advertising gurus astutely build into them.

headline: An iPhone Case for Your Earbuds
abstract: The new Sound Pockets Freedom case offers a built-in compartment for storing headphones neatly out of the way.
lead_paragraph: While smartphones and their cases tend to be neatly sleek, the earbuds and their cables are anything but. People try wrapping the buds around the phone, storing them in separate cases and winding them into little skeins, among other strategies.

headline: Racism, Unintended
abstract: Is asking Jewish and Arab children to visit an Israeli amusement park on different days a sensible way to limit tensions or sheer racism?
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Superland, an Israeli amusement park, is a land of separation. Last week Khaled Shakra, a school teacher, called the park’s front desk to set up a visit for his students. At first the receptionist proposed three dates, but when he said the school was from Jaffa, an Arab city, there was a silence. Shakra was put on hold and then told that the dates he had just been offered were already taken. An hour later he called again pretending to be a teacher from a Jewish school, and the dates were free.

headline: Why Haven’t the Marines Shown Stronger Support for Women?

abstract: There were 6 Facebook pages in existence, as of May 2013, devoted to promoting sexual violence, rape and degradation of female Marines.
lead_paragraph: As an Army officer, I worked with Marines in Iraq and was always impressed by their professionalism, combat readiness and physical strength. But recently, I learned some things about the Marine Corps that shocked and saddened me to my core.

headline: The Macroeconomics of European Disunion
abstract: Aggregate madness.
lead_paragraph: Wolfgang Münchau makes a point that isn’t new, but still gets overlooked too often: the euro area is, for practical macroeconomic purposes, a single unit — and one that doesn’t really do all that much trade with the rest of the world. Aggregate euro area policy, monetary and fiscal, should therefore be subject to more or less the same rules that apply to the United States.

headline: Vine, Twitter’s New Video Tool, Hits 13 Million Users
abstract: The feature, which lets people shoot and share bite-size, six-second looping video clips, has captured the imagination of users.
lead_paragraph: At the start of this year, Twitter introduced the mobile video app Vine, which let people shoot and share bite-size, six-second looping video clips. The service captivated users, who began making and uploading quirky short films, comedy bits and stop-motion animation, among other things.

headline: No Easy Fix for Insider Trading
abstract: James Surowiecki, in his column in The New Yorker, argues for faster disclosures of material information as a means of discouraging insider trading. The proposal, however, has drawn skepticism.
lead_paragraph: The government has made it a priority to root out insider trading, pursuing prominent hedge funds and securing dozens of convictions in recent years. And yet, a more comprehensive solution to end the illegal practice is elusive.

headline: Pacers Starters’ Minutes Negate a Weak Bench

lead_paragraph: The Miami Heat won 66 regular-season games, six more than any other team in the N.B.A. They had the league’s most potent offense and were captained by LeBron James, the N.B.A. most valuable player and consensus best player in the world.

lead_paragraph: Christine C. Quinn’s mayoral campaign will be graced by a touch of Koch after all.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘I’m Not Using the Word Love’
abstract: “I’m Not Using the Word Love” by Jameson, 23, from New York City, is the fifth of 12 winning poems in our fourth annual Found Poem Student Contest.
lead_paragraph: This poem, one of 12 winners of our fourth annual Found Poem Student Contest, was written by Jameson, 23, from New York City.

headline: The Hidden Costs of Starting a Company
abstract: What have you given up for your start-up?
lead_paragraph: I was at a StartupsUncensored event some time ago where a speaker, Jason Nazar, the founder and chief executive of Docstoc, said: “You can have your start-up and one thing. You can have your start-up and your health. You can have your start-up and your family. Or you can have your start-up and your significant other, but you can’t have multiples. If you try to have multiples, you’ll be poor at all of them.”

headline: From Dominant to Merely Mighty
abstract: The Miami Heat and the Chicago Blackhawks dominated their sports at the beginning of the season, but they have been tested in the N.B.A. and N.H.L. playoffs.
lead_paragraph: For some reason, the Miami Heat and the Chicago Blackhawks find themselves hitched together at the cosmic hip again this season. People were once debating their dominance — whether the Heat’s 27-game winning streak was more or less impressive than the Blackhawks’ season-opening 24-game point streak — and now they are openly wondering if this superteam business is not all it is cracked up to be. Because these two teams spent large chunks of the regular season and the early stage of the playoffs looking like the only big kids on the playground, and suddenly they are together at Six Flags with metal bars over their shoulders, bracing for the next big drop.

headline: Believe Your Ears: B.J. Thomas Is Still at It
abstract: I was surprised to see the pop-music singer playing on Jimmy Fallon’s show.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago I had “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” on the TV when, from the next room, I heard a voice from my adolescence: that of B.J. Thomas. He was about the most popular male singer in my pop-music-attuned house in the late ’60s and ’70s, and he was pretty big everywhere else, too, with chartbusting hits like “Hooked on a Feeling” and “Raindrops Keep Falling on My Head.” I hadn’t heard anything about Thomas in decades, and I wondered why Fallon was playing his records on the show, because the voice sounded just the same as it did on all his classics.

headline: In the Pursuit of Longevity
abstract: Two new books offer insights on trying to bend mind and matter to stop or reverse the ravages of time.
lead_paragraph: At some point between George Washington and Colonel Sanders, white hair and a cane turned from symbols of elegance to suggestions of decrepitude, and an industry was born. Not that the fountain of youth wasn’t always sought after. But to look young, think young, feel young — those are distinctly modern goals.

lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md. — The court-martial of Pfc. Bradley Manning, whose secret release of a vast archive of military and diplomatic materials put WikiLeaks into an international spotlight, opened here Monday with dueling portrayals of a traitor who endangered the lives of his fellow soldiers and of a principled protester motivated by a desire to help society who carefully selected which documents to release.

headline: F.D.A. Scientists Find No Serious Misconduct in Avandia Drug Tests
abstract: As an F.D.A. advisory panel revisits the debate around the diabetes drug Avandia, a report by staff scientists has found no fraud in its clinical trial.
lead_paragraph: A review of a disputed clinical trial on the safety of the controversial diabetes drug Avandia did not uncover serious misconduct or fraud, according to findings by scientists at the Food and Drug Administration that were made public Monday.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: May 31-June 2, 2013
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'School Shootings']
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, 70-year-old retired U.S. Army Lt. Col. Ralph Wald, who found his wife, Johnna Lynn Flores, 41, having sex with another man on their living room floor in Tampa in March, was acquitted of second-degree murder after invoking Florida’s Stand Your Ground law. His defense? He thought the man, 32-year-old Walter Conley, was raping his wife. In fact, Conley was later found to be Flores’s paramour, a fact that didn’t seem to faze his legal team one bit.

headline: Artificial Connections

lead_paragraph: Q. When you get a joint replacement, like a knee or hip, how exactly is the muscle attached to the artificial implant?

headline: Commuters Nearly Double Manhattan’s Daytime Population, Census Says
abstract: Every borough registers a decline in daytime population because of workplace patterns except Manhattan, where the population soars by 1.3 million, according to census figures.
lead_paragraph: If New York’s bars and restaurants seem crowded at night, consider this: during the day, commuters from the other boroughs and outside the city nearly double Manhattan’s population, from 1.6 million to 3.1 million.

headline: The Rectangled Square Puzzle

headline: Step Aside, Jon Stewart: John Oliver Prepares to Host ‘The Daily Show’
abstract: John Oliver, a seven-year veteran and correspondent on “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart,” talks about his preparations for a three-month guest-hosting stint and his efforts to book Queen Elizabeth II on the program.
lead_paragraph: For a little while on Thursday, while “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” was on hiatus, John Oliver had the offices all to himself. In an otherwise deserted conference room on Manhattan’s West Side, Mr. Oliver, 36, the British-born comedian and “Daily Show” correspondent, was dressed casually and lounging beneath a giant National Geographic map of the world. Asked how he was doing, he replied, “I’m fine.” He paused. “I’m excited.” Another pause. “I’m nervous.”

headline: Tony Awards: In Performance With Courtney B. Vance
abstract: The first in a special Tony Award series of “In Performance” videos, shot on location in New York, features Courtney B. Vance in a scene from the Nora Ephron play “Lucky Guy.”
lead_paragraph: For this year’s Tony Awards edition of In Performance, The New York Times ditched the studio and went on location. As always, the videos capture short excerpts of songs or monologues performed without costumes or makeup. But instead of using our regular backdrop, we asked selected Tony nominees to shoot a scene at a New York City locale that reflects the personality of their character and the spirit of their show. Where would a no-nonsense newspaper editor from the play “Lucky Guy” go to vent about a high-strung journalist? Where would a modern-day Cinderella spend a romantic afternoon with her prince? You get the picture.

Ford says the Explorer, Taurus, Flex, Fusion and police models – the Interceptor Utility and Interceptor Sedan – are included in the recall, as are the Lincoln MKS, MKT and MKZ.

Their final performance at the Royal Opera House will be in “Mayerling” on Wednesday, although they will remain with the company for a visit to Japan, with performances in Tokyo on July 11 and 12.

headline: For Kidd, a Tough End to a Brilliant Career

Jason Kidd was the ultimate point guard for much of his 19-year career in the N.B.A., but at the end of his one season with the Knicks, his magic was no more.

lead_paragraph: Oxbow’s pedigree is littered with big names — Deputy Minister, Mr. Prospector, Raise A Native. abstract: Frank R. Lautenberg’s death has left Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey with the chance to give away a Senate seat, but the decision is fraught with pitfalls.

Chris Christie of New Jersey with the kind of opportunity that politicians usually covet: the chance to give away a seat in the United States Senate. But the decision is fraught with pitfalls, none bigger than having to choose between improving his party’s fortunes in Washington and furthering his own political ambitions at home.

The festival runs through June 23 and it starts Monday at 7:30 p.m. with a party at The Park’s penthouse, 118 10th Avenue in Chelsea, with wine and live music. A series of dinners are scheduled at restaurants across the city that will feature food from the south of France, in particular the region of Languedoc-Roussillon, with dishes like cassoulet and cod brandade.

headline: Bill Cunningham’s On the Street, Spoke Spinners
abstract: No waiting for cabs or buses, or on sweaty subway platforms: just unlock one and pedal off
lead_paragraph: Always-rushing New Yorkers finally have a chance to discover the joy, freedom and speed of the new rental Citi Bikes. No waiting for cabs or buses, or on sweaty subway platforms: just unlock one and pedal off. Some have taken to scooters that can be folded up and carried into the office. Aside from the August closing of Park Avenue on Saturdays for cyclists, a few rules to follow: stay close to the curb, avoid pedestrians (who encroach on bike lanes at rush hour) and watch for cab doors being flung open. Despite the hazards, this pedaler, who has had about 30 bikes stolen, still enjoys the mobility of two wheels. Just don’t lock your own bike to a Citi Bike terminal.

headline: Checking Trees as Hurricane Season Starts
keywords: ['Homeowners Insurance', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Trees and Shrubs']
abstract: Homeowners’ insurance policies will typically cover damage when a tree falls on your home during a storm, but it is wise to take steps to deal with weakened trees beforehand.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane season began on Saturday, and the federal government is predicting an “active or extremely active” year. So if you live in a hurricane-prone area, now is a good time to inspect trees near your home for possible weakness that could lead to damage during a storm with strong winds.

headline: Graceful Aging and Loss in Paris
abstract: Novak Djokovic has had to cope with the death of his childhood coach and touchstone Jelena Gencic in the midst of the event he now wants to win more than any other.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For a French Open that has yet to have a major upset, it has surely been a tournament full of big surprises and big swings of emotion.

lead_paragraph: Like many of us, Atrios is still having fun with the hysterical WSJ screed against rental bicycles. Unusually for him, however, I think he fails to fully recognize the role of class in the whole discussion. He writes,

headline: Australian Teen Goes from Main Draw Upset to Junior Defeat
abstract: Nick Kyrgios of Australia, who used a wild card to craft an upset in the French Open first round last Monday, lost in the first round of the junior tournament, where he was the top seed.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was a rare moment of triumph for a junior player allowed into the men’s main draw at a major when Nick Kyrgios, 18, a wild card entrant from Australia,carved out a masterful three-set upset of Radek Stepanek of the Czech Republic in the first round of the French Open last week. But on Monday, Kyrgios found himself on the opposite end of an upset, when he lost in the first round of the junior championship, where he was the top seed.

lead_paragraph: As social media sites pursue advertising in a bid for new revenue, they are finding that they must simultaneously create a safe space for the advertisers they attract.

abstract: What can happen when your body doesn’t know its left from its right; the 17-year cicada as the stuff of nightmares; the Roving Runner picks up a Citi Bike.
