lead_paragraph: The Times’s David M. Halbfinger discusses the legacy of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who died Monday, and how Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark could benefit.

headline: Conservative Party Endorses Lhota for Mayor
abstract: The party’s leader said Joseph J. Lhota was  the only candidate who shared its positions on keeping taxes low and making New York City safe.
lead_paragraph: The Conservative Party of New York State endorsed Joseph J. Lhota, a Republican, for mayor on Monday, all but ensuring that Mr. Lhota and his chief rival for the Republican nomination, John A. Catsimatidis, will both carry their campaigns into the November general election.

headline: Growing Left, Growing Right
abstract: Our bodies start out symmetrical, but then things start moving. How this happens (and how it can go wrong) is a rich field of study.
lead_paragraph: One day in 1788, students at the Hunterian School of Medicine in London were opening a cadaver when they discovered something startling. The dead man’s anatomy was a mirror image of normal. His liver was on his left side instead of the right. His heart had beaten on his right side, not his left.

headline: Plastic Bags to Keep Premature Babies Warm
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Premature Babies', 'Shopping Bags', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: In poor countries, simple plastic bags are an alternative to the sterile plastic wrap used to regulate the body temperature of very premature babies in the United States, a study suggests.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, some very premature babies are swaddled in sterile plastic wrap to keep their body temperature from dropping dangerously. Now a study of newborns in Zambia suggests that the technique can be duplicated cheaply and effectively in poorer countries — using simple plastic bags.

headline: Ray of Light in European Economic Data
abstract: A slight improvement in economic data fed hope that the euro zone was just in a temporary downturn, and not stuck in a recession that could last years.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — In what passes for good news in Europe these days, a survey Monday showed that manufacturing in the euro zone was deteriorating more gradually than preliminary estimates had indicated. The slight improvement in economic data fed hope that the euro zone was in a temporary downturn and not stuck in a recession that could last for years.

headline: Disputed Banksy Work Brings $1.1 Million at Auction
abstract: A work of Banksy graffiti art, removed from a wall in Britain, was sold at auction.
lead_paragraph: In the latest and perhaps final installment of one of the art world’s most amusing controversies of 2013, “Slave Labor (Bunting Boy),” the satirical work stenciled by the graffiti artist Banksy on a wall in North London, was sold at a private auction held by the London-based Sincura Group — which describes itself as “concierge specialists who pride themselves on obtaining the unobtainable” — on Sunday for what the BBC reported was more than £750,000, or about $1.1 million.

headline: App Smart Extra: Timer Apps to Keep Track of Your Life
abstract: Timer apps for tablets and phones are more flexible than kitchen or wristwatch timers.
lead_paragraph: If you could have listened to the App Smart column the other week instead of just reading it, you’d have heard the tick-tock of timer apps counting down. Far more flexible than kitchen timers of old, or even wristwatch timers, timer apps for smartphones and tablets can be very useful in helping you keep track of all sorts of timings.

headline: Opening New Frontiers of Backyard Cookery
abstract: Meet a new gas-powered weapon to your outdoor cooking arsenal.
lead_paragraph: Meet a new gas-powered weapon to your outdoor cooking arsenal.

headline: Videos and Final Tweets From Storm Chasers Killed in Oklahoma
abstract: Dozens of videos posted online in recent years show the work of Tim Samaras, Paul Samaras and Carl Young, the highly respected storm chasers who were killed during a tornado in Oklahoma on Friday.
lead_paragraph: In his final post on Twitter, Tim Samaras, a highly respected storm chaser whose work has been featured on the Discovery Channel and in National Geographic, shared his concern on Friday about the “dangerous day ahead” for Oklahoma.

headline: Breaking Symmetry
abstract: A tiny pit lined with cilia helps the developing embryo distinguish left from right.
lead_paragraph: A tiny pit lined with cilia helps the developing embryo distinguish left from right.

headline: Frying Outdoors? It’s No Mistake
abstract: A propane burner can be a versatile addition to your outdoor cooking repertory.
lead_paragraph: Last year we became converts to gas. The odd thing about this is that we’ve spent 20 years and nine cookbooks very pointedly avoiding gas grills. So when we tell friends we have added a gas-powered weapon to our outdoor cooking arsenal, we get very skeptical looks.

headline: Mozart and Haydn? He’s Jazzed
abstract: Nicholas McGegan led the Orchestra of St. Luke’s in a concert of Mozart and Haydn on Saturday that had been long delayed by Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: A magical moment arrives in every concert I have seen involving the conductor Nicholas McGegan, and it comes before any music has been made. It happened on Saturday night as the Orchestra of St. Luke’s sat onstage at Carnegie Hall, ready for a program of canonical works by Mozart and Haydn. The stage door opened, and Mr. McGegan bounded out to the podium, beaming and exuding enthusiasm. This, not the opening bars of Mozart’s Symphony No. 29 in A (K. 201), was the real start of the concert, which turned out to be one of the most appealing, satisfying performances I have heard this season. (The concert was originally scheduled for last November, but was postponed because of Hurricane Sandy.)

headline: Jason Kidd Leaves the Game
abstract: Images of point guard Jason Kidd, who announced his retirement from the N.B.A. on Monday after 19 seasons.
lead_paragraph: Images of point guard Jason Kidd, who announced his retirement from the N.B.A. on Monday after 19 seasons.

headline: Men’s Use of Testosterone on the Rise
abstract: A new report shows that the number of older and middle-aged men prescribed the hormone has tripled since 2001, raising concerns about abuse and mistreatment.
lead_paragraph: The number of middle-aged men with prescriptions for testosterone is climbing rapidly, raising concerns that increasing numbers of men are abusing the powerful hormone to boost their libidos and feel younger, researchers reported on Monday.

headline: One Early Bird Restores Lineage of Another
abstract: The discovery of a pheasant-size fossil has prompted a re-examination of the entire lineage.
lead_paragraph: Since its discovery in 1860, Archaeopteryx was widely considered to be the earliest known bird. But in 2009 a team of scientists decided it was more dinosaurlike than avian. Because of its reptilian metabolism and growth rate (slower than that of a bird), the transitional species should be removed from the bird family tree, the scientists said.

headline: A New Baton for the Little Orchestra Society
abstract: James Judd, a British conductor, is taking over at the Little Orchestra Society, a New York ensemble.
lead_paragraph: James Judd, a British conductor who has been music director of the Florida Philharmonic – with which he made an acclaimed recording of Mahler’s First Symphony – and the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra, has taken over his first New York ensemble, the Little Orchestra Society. He succeeds Dino Anagnost, who led the orchestra from 1979 until his death in 2011, and is the third director in the ensemble’s history, which goes back to 1947, when it was founded by Mr. Anagnost’s predecessor, Thomas Scherman.

headline: Check In | A Hotel in Dallas Where the Art Is as Impressive as the Rooms
abstract: A spare-no-expense renovation of the Joule, in downtown Dallas, solidifies the city’s growing reputation as an unlikely arts mecca.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, Dallas philanthropists have carried out a Texas-size effort to reinvent their city as a contemporary art and architecture capital. Now, visitors drawn to destinations like the vast new  Warehouse, the Nasher Sculpture Center and the revitalized Dallas Museum of Art have an equally enticing place to stay. Thanks to a $78 million renovation and expansion by the local oil and real-estate magnate and film financier Tim Headington, the Joule Hotel is now the city’s go-to boutique hotel. But it’s also an art destination to rival its neighbors in the nearby Arts District.

headline: A Love Letter to New York, Written by Consensus
abstract: Chris Lightcap brought his band, Bigmouth, to the Cornelia Street Café for “Lost and Found New York.”
lead_paragraph: There’s a tacit understanding in jazz circles that one path to success involves a sturdy, identifiable working band, and that another rests on high concept, or at least a central idea. The bassist Chris Lightcap has long been associated with the first camp: each of his three albums has featured a version of the same group, with two tenor saxophones out front. He calls it Bigmouth — after his second album, released a decade ago — and uses the band to bridge the gap between the rougher hinterlands of postbop and its calm stylistic center.

headline: A Contemporary Dialogue With Beethoven’s Sonatas
abstract: Works by Peter Lieberson, an American composer who died in 2011, were explored at Mannes College’s Beethoven Institute.
lead_paragraph: Mannes College the New School for Music has offered an institute focusing on Beethoven for each of the past 12 years. This is the first season, the pianist Thomas Sauer said before a concert there on Friday, that Beethoven has shared the bill with a contemporary composer.

headline: Stamp! Clap! It’s Their 30th
abstract: To honor its 30th anniversary, Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana opened its season with a gala at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: For the company Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana to survive in New York, as it has, for 30 years, Carlota Santana, the co-founder and artistic director, must have made many sage decisions. But when the troupe opened its anniversary season at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday, one particular decision stuck out: her hiring of the dancer Ángel Muñoz.

headline: Another Butter Location
abstract: The NoHo restaurant will open an uptown version this summer.
lead_paragraph: Alex Guarnaschelli, Scott Sartiano and Richie Akiva,who have owned Butter on Lafayette Street in NoHo for 10 years, plan to open an uptown branch in July. The new restaurant, which will also be called Butter, will have a garden, and the owners plan to open that in about two weeks to take advantage of the season. They will serve cocktails and light food outdoors.

headline: However You Spell It, a Knaidel Tastes Good
abstract: The Queens teenager who won the Scripps National Spelling Bee last week by reciting one of the transliterations for a Yiddish word for dumplings has now eaten one.
lead_paragraph: Arvind V. Mahankali of Bayside, Queens, won the Scripps National Spelling Bee last week on the strength of his mastery of “knaidel,” a Yiddish word of German origin (and, it turns out, somewhat ambiguous spelling) for the dumplings that go into, among other things, matzo ball soup.

headline: Obama to Nominate 3 to Fill Posts on Key Appeals Court
abstract: By making his choices in a group, President Obama and his strategists are hoping to put pressure on Senate Republicans to confirm them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will nominate a slate of three candidates on Tuesday to fill the remaining vacancies on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, a White House official said Monday.

headline: Kerry Says U.S. Came Late to Syrian Peace Effort
abstract: The remarks by Secretary of State John Kerry carried the implication that the Obama administration had moved too slowly in its first term on the Syria crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States came “late” to efforts to find a political settlement to the war in Syria, Secretary of State John Kerry said Monday, as the crisis there deepened with the political uncertainty in neighboring Turkey.

headline: What Makes a Jewish Mother
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Children and Childhood', 'In Vitro Fertilization', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Parenting', 'Surrogate Motherhood']
abstract: A spiritual struggle for some women connected to children by birth, but not by DNA.
lead_paragraph: I was 42 when my husband and I began trying to have a child. Three years later, I finally accepted it wasn’t going to happen naturally. We narrowed our options to two: use eggs donated by another woman, or adopt.

headline: Tony Contenders in Battle of the Box Office
abstract: “Kinky Boots” and “Matilda” — both best musical nominees — are battling it out at the box office, while “Lucky Guy” is the top selling nominated play.
lead_paragraph: The new Broadway musicals “Kinky Boots” and “Matilda” may be the front-runners for the Tony Award for best musical to be announced on Sunday, but there’s no contest between the two shows at the box office so far. “Kinky Boots” has beaten “Matilda” nine out of the 13 weeks that they have been running head-to-head, including last week, when “Kinky Boots” grossed $1,340,238 while “Matilda” took in $1,157,633.

headline: A Renewed Effort to Rename a Street Honoring a Soviet Spy
abstract: A woman hopes to persuade the city to rename the block named for Samuel Dickstein, a congressman and Soviet spy, after Lillian Wald, the nurse who founded the Henry Street settlement house.
lead_paragraph: When Susan LaRosa became director of marketing for the Henry Street Settlement a few years ago, she peered out her window at the plaza below and wondered about its namesake: Who was Samuel Dickstein?

headline: Rising Aggression Against Turtle Conservationists Preceded Costa Rica Slaying
abstract: Costa Rican news reports show a pattern of rising violence before the murder of a turtle guardian.
lead_paragraph: The Tico Times in Costa Rica has been providing valuable updates since the murder late last week of Jairo Mora Sandoval, a 26-year-old guardian of sea turtle nests on Moín Beach on the country’s Caribbean coast near the town of Limón. Read on for an excerpt from the latest dispatch, which shows clearly that the threat to conservationists, including Sandoval, had been building before he was kidnapped, bound, beaten, shot in the head and left on the sand.

lead_paragraph: The Editorial Board would like your help. New York City is getting a new mayor, and we’re getting ready to decide — from a field of about a dozen candidates — who we think it should be.

headline: The Light Switches Are in Manhattan, the Power’s From New Jersey
abstract: At midnight, electricity generated west of the Hudson River began flowing seven and a half miles to New York for use by residents of public housing and government agencies.
lead_paragraph: Not that they would have noticed, but some Manhattanites are now using electricity imported from New Jersey through a new underwater connection.

headline: Continental Grain to Walk Away From Smithfield
abstract: The Continental Grain Company said that it had chosen to exit its roughly 6 percent position in Smithfield and wouldn’t challenge the pork company’s planned deal with Shuanghui International.
lead_paragraph: 5:19 p.m. | Updated One of Smithfield Foods‘ biggest investors plans to drop its fight against the pork processor in light of its planned $4.7 billion sale to a Chinese meat producer.

headline: Slathering on Sunscreen Shows Results
abstract: The study is the first to show an actual effect on the appearance of skin, courtesy of hundreds of people in Australia.
lead_paragraph: People who diligently use sunscreen every day can slow or even prevent for a time the development of wrinkles and sagging skin, a new study found. Although dermatologists have long told people to use sunscreen to prevent aging, this is the first research to show an actual effect on the appearance of skin, researchers said.

headline: Girl Group Just Wants to Be Famous (Again)
abstract: “The Alectrix,” on MTV, follows the fortunes of a struggling girl group, an outgrowth of the Electric Barbarellas.
lead_paragraph: The Electric Barbarellas was the name of a girl group and of an MTV reality show featuring the group that ran for six episodes in the spring of 2011. Both would have come and gone largely unnoticed, if Sumner Redstone hadn’t picked up the phone.

headline: In This Play Festival, There Are No Second Acts
abstract: The Ensemble Studio Theater’s festival of one-acts continues with the second of three series.
lead_paragraph: Ensemble Studio Theater’s annual one-act-play marathon is always entertaining and rich in solid performances, but each of the bills — Series A, B and C — often has one play that stands out. For Series B this year it’s “A Sunrise in Times Square,” by Sharr White (“The Other Place,” on Broadway). The play may be no better written than others on the program, but the marvelous performances by Julie Fitzpatrick and Joseph Lyle Taylor carry it to another level.

headline: Still Balanchine’s Students
abstract: The School of American Ballet is more firmly identified with the style of its founder than any other ballet school.
lead_paragraph: The three ballets performed by the School of American Ballet last weekend in its annual Workshop presentation were a heady infusion of beauty, consisting of pure dancing — nothing but dancing to music. The choreography for each was by Balanchine; the music was by Mozart, Ravel and Gounod and finely played by the Workshop Orchestra, conducted with élan by Daniel Capps. Attending the first of the three performances on Saturday afternoon, I regretted that the busiest period of New York’s ballet year prevented me from seeing the others.

headline: Microsoft Weighs Restructuring
abstract: Microsoft is considering mixing up the responsibilities of its top executives as it seeks to further its transformation into what Steve Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, calls a “devices and services company.”
lead_paragraph: Microsoft is considering mixing up the responsibilities of its top executives as it seeks to further its transformation into what Steve Ballmer, Microsoft’s chief executive, calls a “devices and services company.”

abstract: For some the coming of the 17-year cicada is less a marvel of science, more a nightmare scenario.
lead_paragraph: For some the coming of the 17-year cicada is less a marvel of science, more a nightmare scenario.

headline: Harmless, but They May Cause Paralysis
abstract: For people with an entomophobia, the sight or even the thought of the cicadas emerging along the East Coast can cause a panic attack.
lead_paragraph: In 2004, when the cicadas of Brood X crawled out of the ground in and around Washington, Lori Milani, then a full-time student, would not set foot outside her apartment. Terrified of insects, she shut her windows tight, sometimes with the blinds drawn, for five weeks. She stocked up on food, canceled her summer classes and had friends run essential errands for her.

headline: A Girl’s Secret Sin, Then Rarefied Exile
abstract: In Anton DiSclafani’s novel, “The Yonahlossee Riding Camp for Girls,” a Florida teenager is sent away to an elite boarding school because she has committed a mysterious sin.
lead_paragraph: The ingredients of Anton DiSclafani’s first novel, “The Yonahlossee Riding Camp for Girls,” sound as if they’d been plucked from two genres: the young-adult category and the historical romance. Ms. DiSclafani gives us an elite boarding school where wealthy debutantes perfect their riding skills and prepare for the big spring horse show; an impetuous, headstrong heroine, who often seems like a 1930s version of Scarlett O’Hara; and a mysterious accident that has left one teenager brain-damaged and two others guilty and haunted. In her story there are echoes of “A Separate Peace,” John Knowles’s 1959 prep-school classic about two friends on the eve of World War II, as well as of Curtis Sittenfeld’s more recent boarding school novel,  “Prep.”

headline: Microsampling Air Pollution
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Smartphones']
abstract: New portable sensors allow users, often citizen scientists, to record minuscule fluctuations in air quality in a neighborhood, on a floor of a building or in a bus.
lead_paragraph: Near the corner of Tillary and Jay Streets in Brooklyn, Michael Heimbinder stood near a blue mailbox, head down, poking at his smartphone. A graph appeared: a single line plotting ambient carbon monoxide exposure in the neighborhood.

headline: Maxwell’s in Hoboken to Close in July
abstract: The club’s owners cite a shift in Hoboken’s nightlife.
lead_paragraph: Maxwell’s, the Hoboken restaurant and bar that has been one of the most influential indie-rock clubs in New Jersey, is closing down at the end of July, The Star-Ledger reported.

headline: U.S. Cites Phone Calls in Apple Pricing Case
keywords: ['E-Books and Readers', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: The government presented evidence that executives of big book publishing companies discussed raising e-book prices at Apple’s behest before the introduction of the iPad.
lead_paragraph: The United States government said on Monday that there were 100 phone calls among top executives of the publishing industry in the weeks leading up to Apple’s introduction of the iPad in 2010, when they had to decide whether to sign on to a deal with Apple that would raise the prices of e-books.

headline: Finding a High-Yield Checking Account
abstract: Some smaller banks offer high-yield checking accounts, but there are often catches.
lead_paragraph: Interest rates on most savings and checking accounts remain anemic. But for those who are comfortable with electronic banking and who are active debit-card users, high-yield checking accounts offered by smaller, regional banks and credit unions can be a more lucrative option.

headline: At 90, Still Riveting the Mind’s Eye
abstract: Five exhibitions devoted to the vibrant geometric abstractions of Ellsworth Kelly, who turned 90 on Friday, are under way in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Ellsworth Kelly has been on earth for 90 years — his birthday was Friday — and he has been making abstract art for over 60 of them. Now the New York art world is treating him, and us, to a big party. His boldly colored, emblematic paintings and reliefs can be seen in five exhibitions around town. In unusually gorgeous terms, they attest to a lifelong fusion of austerity and high spirits, and a narrow yet deep exploration of pure colors and simple shapes.

headline: A Room of One’s Own — With a Tub
abstract: The ultimate boudoir for a modern woman should contain elements of a study, a dressing room and a bathroom.
lead_paragraph: I have an original design sketch by the legendary interior decorator Albert Hadley (above) that my mom gave me. It is my dream room: a luxurious hideaway that combines the dressing room and study with an oversize tub. If it were mine, I would have to be wrenched from the space. And some of the finer-heeled working mothers in London seem to feel the same. Last week I went with a friend to look at a potential new house where, on the second floor, there was a double reception room split by a central staircase. We instantly felt that the oversize space should become the master bedroom suite and devised the perfect boudoir floor plan on a napkin in Tom’s Deli after the viewing. The bath would go in the center of the room, opposite the fireplace. A folding screen would double as shelving for bath products on one side, and a bulletin board — covered in felt and trellised with ribbon — for the desk on the other side. It would also add an element of privacy, blocking the tub from the door that opens off the landing.

headline: Ancient Plants, a Cosmic Fund-Raiser, Atoms in Motion and More

abstract: Recent developments in health and science news. This week: reviving plants from the Little Ice Age, a crowdfunded space telescope and photographs of molecular change.
lead_paragraph: In science, popular ideas are often discarded once new evidence comes along, then revived in the face of still newer evidence. In the Observatory column this week, Douglas Quenqua reports on the long-running debate over whether the early winged creature Archaeopteryx ought to be considered a bird or a dinosaur. Paleontologists have gone back and forth on the issue, but the discovery of a dinosaur even older than Archaeopteryx has now given comfort to the bird camp.

headline: State Department Offers Rewards for Terrorist Leaders
abstract: The State Department announced that it was offering rewards for information leading to the location of the leaders of Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb.

The rewards, the first for the region, include $5 million each for the leader of the Qaeda regional franchise, Yahya Abu el-Hamman, and for Mokhtar Belmokhtar, the leader of a group that carried out a raid on a gas plant in Algeria that led to the deaths of at least 37 hostages, including 3 Americans. headline: Egypt: Activist Sentenced to Prison for Insulting Morsi
abstract: An Egyptian court sentenced an activist to six months in prison on Monday on charges that he insulted President Mohamed Morsi and circulated false news on television.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian court sentenced an activist to six months in prison on Monday on charges that he insulted President Mohamed Morsi and circulated false news on television. The prison sentence is the first for insulting the president since Mr. Morsi came to power last year. The activist, Ahmed Douma, was expected to post bail and be released on Monday pending the appeal of his case. He was arrested in April after calling Mr. Morsi a killer and criminal, which the court ruled could undermine state security. Egypt has seen a sharp rise in court cases for libel and blasphemy since the revolution in 2011.

headline: How Much Is Michael Bolton Worth to You?
abstract: There’s a reason scalpers have confused economists for decades.

The tickets, however, turned out to be fakes, and Arakelian, who was getting the evil eye from his girlfriend, approached a nearby police officer for help. But the officer said that he couldn’t do anything unless Arakelian could locate the scalper in the crush of people. By that point the scalper was long gone; Arakelian was embarrassed. Naturally, a minute later, he turned and shouted to no one in particular, “Who’s got two tickets?”

headline: Check In | A Venetian Palace With a View
abstract: The Aman Canal Grande, perched on the Grand Canal in the 16th-century Palazzo Papadopoli, is an example of Venetian neo-Renaissance and rococo architecture at its finest.
lead_paragraph: The 25-room Aman Canal Grande opens this month in Venice’s San Polo neighborhood. You would be hard pressed to beat its setting, perched on the Grand Canal in the 16th-century Palazzo Papadopoli, an example of Venetian neo-Renaissance and rococo architecture at its finest. The new hotel preserves much of the palazzo’s original artwork, including frescoes by the 18th-century Italian artist Giovanni Battista Tiepolo (now decorating the Aman’s Italian and Thai restaurants). San Polo itself is one of Venice’s less chaotic, residential districts, with the Rialto Market and the Scuola Grande di San Rocco a few minutes away by foot. Guest rooms have silk walls, twinkling chandeliers and views of private gardens. The hotel’s garden terrace faces onto the Grand Canal, and from the roof, when clear weather permits, you can see past Venice’s chimney pots and terra cotta rooftops all the way to the Swiss Alps.

But the official homages to the Jilin Baoyuanfeng Poultry Plant, where at least 120 people died this week in a fast-moving fire, now serve as little more than stark reminders of the blind eyes turned to the dangerous conditions facing many workers in China.

abstract: The protests in Turkey erupted over the planned destruction of a park, but they’re about government greed and authoritarianism.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — We are still keeping toll — of injuries and arrests, of nightly standoffs between demonstrators and police, of the points lost on the Turkish stock market. Throughout the country, the streets in large cities are littered with tear-gas canisters, shop fronts are covered in spray paint, and police cars lie overturned. A confederation of public workers’ unions has called for a general strike. Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the iron fist of Turkish politics for over a decade, now looks like a man grasping at straws.

headline: Wawrinka Proves Tireless in Stopping Gasquet in Fourth Round
abstract: Stanislas Wawrinka and Richard Gasquet staged an outstanding fourth-round match in the fourth round of the French Open, but Wawrinka used his stamina to wear down his opponent for victory.
lead_paragraph: Stanislas Wawrinka battled back from two sets down to defeat Richard Gasquet in fourth-round French Open match Monday that featured the two best one-handed backhands in the game. After Gasquet outplayed Wawrinka in the first two sets, Wawrinka settled in for the long haul, lengthening out points as he tried to break down his French rival. Wawrinka told reporters after the match, “When I was 2-0 down, I was thinking something really simple. I was thinking: point after point I was thinking to make him work, to make him work hard, because I know if he start to be a little bit tired, then he’s not doing so much with his racquet, he’s not pushing so much pressure.”

headline: The Hurdles to Reviving an Investment Bank Partnership
abstract: The activist investor Knight Vinke says UBS could adopt something like a partnership structure as part of its plan to split wealth management from investment banking. That’s overambitious at the moment, the author contends.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs’s initial public offering in 1999 seemed to hammer a nail in the coffin for the partnership model in investment banking. Now, the activist investment firm Knight Vinke is suggesting that UBS could adopt something like a partnership structure as part of its plan to split wealth management from investment banking. The breakup idea is overambitious today. Only with time, luck and possibly more capital could an employee-owned UBS investment bank be made to work.

headline: Bubbles With Bluefish, but Not Necessarily Champagne
abstract: With the savory flavors of fried fish, skip the cavas, sekts and proseccos to seek out good, dry sparkling wines with rich textures.
lead_paragraph: Bubbles go beautifully with fried foods, but bubbly doesn’t always have to mean Champagne. With these savory flavors, which will be deeper and more assertive if you choose bluefish, I would skip the cavas, sekts and proseccos to seek out a good, dry sparkling Vouvray, from the chenin blanc grape, which has a slightly richer texture than most Champagnes. Chenin blanc has a flavor that suggests a combination of lemon and honeysuckle that you feel as much as you taste; texturally it will meld well with the crisp panko crust. For a surprise twist, and particularly if you use bluefish, you could try a sparkling red, like a savory Lambrusco.  Just make sure the label says secco, for dry, and not amabile, for slightly sweet.

headline: The Little Land of Big Houses
abstract: Teardowns are common in this affluent Bergen County community, thanks to zoning that allows for larger homes to be built on smaller lots.

But Mr. Liau’s house holds another distinction: it happens to be one of the older models around — as residents of this affluent Bergen County community facing the Hudson seem to have a propensity for tearing down and rebuilding.

headline: Special Election Timing in New Jersey Points to a Weak G.O.P. Field
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie’s decision to schedule a special election for Senator Frank R. Lautenberg’s seat on Oct. 16 suggests that he evaluated the potential Republican challengers and did not like what he saw.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has scheduled an Oct. 16 special election to replace Frank R. Lautenberg, the Democratic senator who died on Monday. Mr. Christie will appoint a replacement for Mr. Lautenberg in the interim, but he has yet to announce his pick. His choice of timing for the special election, however, may indicate that he expects the Republican candidates to be weak.

headline: In Moscow, Mayor’s Move Could Mean Snap Election

He has about 250,000 color transparencies and slides, ranging in size from 35 millimeter to 8 by 10 inches, documenting the work of almost every important artist of the last 40 years and installations at some of the most influential galleries. And, yes, he’s giving them away.

The song was “Mayday,” and against both the coiled tension of its verses and the volcanic release of its chorus, Mike Patton bellowed or warbled or growled, with all the pique and derangement expected of him. He didn’t sound marooned so much as cynically above the fray.

But the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, which created the standard Yiddish transliteration now used in libraries around the world, holds that the correct spelling is “kneydl.”

headline: Filly Will Face the Boys, and Resemble Them
abstract: A filly named Unlimited Budget — a daughter of Street Sense, the 2007 Kentucky Derby winner — will line up alongside as many as 13 male rivals and do her best to become the winner of the grueling, mile and half marathon that is the Belmont Stakes.
lead_paragraph: It is not done lightly or often, leading a filly into the paddock of a Triple Crown race and hoping she is tough and fast enough to hold her own against the boys. And for good reason. Only three fillies have won the Kentucky Derby, five the Preakness Stakes and three the Belmont Stakes.

headline: Gov. Christie’s Quick, Costly Decision
abstract: The governor of New Jersey called for a special election to fill Frank Lautenberg’s Senate seat because it might give him a political advantage. But it will cost state taxpayers.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey had a straightforward choice in filling the Senate vacancy left by the death of Senator Frank Lautenberg on Monday. He could have added the Senate race to the general election on Nov. 5, the day he is up for re-election in what is expected to be an easy glide into a second term. Instead, he called for a special election on Oct. 16, a Wednesday, with a primary on Aug. 13 — a schedule that might give him a small political advantage but at considerable and needless cost to state taxpayers.

headline: Advise and Consent

lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, when President Obama made the unusual gesture of personally introducing his three nominees for the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, he said that Americans would consider it a “judicial crisis” if the Supreme Court were similarly shortstaffed. The president did not come right out and say it, but he should have: The severe breakdown in the process for approving federal judges in the Senate has been especially hard on that critically important appeals court.

headline: Getting to Know You

headline: Israel Lives the Joseph Story

lead_paragraph: How would you like to be an Israeli strategist today? Now even Turkey is in turmoil as its people push back on their increasingly autocratic leader. I mean, there goes the neighborhood. The good news for Israel is that in the near term its near neighbors are too internally consumed to think about threatening it. In the long run, though, Israel faces two serious challenges that I’d dub the Stephen Hawking Story and the Joseph Story.

headline: A Hunt for a Deadly Sniper From Two Perspectives
abstract: A corporal and a filmmaker recount their weeklong attempt to flush out a sniper during the 2010 assault on Marja in Helmand Province, Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: During the 2010 assault on Marja in Helmand Province, Afghanistan, Cpl. Thomas Gibbons-Neff was the leader of a Marine Corps scout sniper team that came under fire from a Taliban sniper. The sniper, like others in the area, had proved surprisingly effective, and Corporal Gibbons-Neff’s team was ordered to flush him out. Ben Anderson, a journalist and filmmaker, accompanied the team on the assault. The two became friends, and the following is their joint account of the weeklong hunt for one sniper, told from their different viewpoints on the battlefield.

headline: Food Matters | A Sweet Take on Modern Art
abstract: A chef’s new cookbook contains 27 painterly confections, from a Warhol gelée to a Matisse parfait, that were inspired by the collection at San Francisco’s Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: Caitlin Freeman, the pastry chef for Blue Bottle Coffee, has a new cookbook out inspired by the collection at San Francisco’s Museum of Modern Art, where Blue Bottle has opened a cafe. Both the cafe and museum will be temporarily closed starting this month as part of a massive expansion project, but in the meantime you can enjoy the book’s 27 painterly confections, from a Warhol gelée to a Matisse parfait. To help guide less experienced bakers, Freeman includes names and definitions for the equipment (think microplanes, piping bags and thermocouples) involved in recreating her desserts, as well as the back story behind every creation. SFMOMA’s Janet Bishop provides the curator notes. There is, for example, the “Build Your Own Newman,” a construction of chocolate sables based on the Abstract Expressionist Barnett Newman’s sculpture “Zim Zum I.” For her part, Freeman was determined to photograph her cookie replica alongside the original art, in this case an eight-foot-tall steel structure in the museum’s sculpture garden. That necessitated perching a sheet pan over the roof of the museum and assembling the pastry in what Freeman describes as “hurricane-force winds while simultaneously holding lighting equipment.”

headline: Panel Says Better Data Is Needed on Gun Issues
abstract: Public health researchers have long said that their work on gun violence has been complicated by a lack of data.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A panel of experts convened in response to the school shooting last year in Newtown, Conn., gave the federal government an ambitious set of priorities on Wednesday for research on guns, ending what experts said has been a 17-year hiatus in the study of gun violence after Congress took away federal money for the topic in the 1990s.

headline: Baseball Union Says Judgment Should Wait in Clinic Case
abstract: The Major League Baseball Players Association said the league was in the process of interviewing players for its investigation into the Biogenesis clinic.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball’s players union is cautioning against any prejudging of the sport’s current doping inquiry in light of the disclosure that Anthony Bosch, the head of a now-shuttered South Florida anti-aging clinic, has agreed to cooperate with baseball’s investigators.

headline: Surfing and Serenity on a Remote Philippine Island
abstract: A fabled break draws surfers to out-of-the-way Siargao, but waves are just part of the island’s appeal.
lead_paragraph: We sat facing a weathered wood pagoda set in an emerald sea, the perfect swimming distance from a private beach lined with crooked coconut trees. Grilled mahi-mahi that arrived via a banca, a Filipino fishing boat, just an hour earlier was seasoned with calamansi (a citrus fruit native to the Philippines) and served with grilled eggplant and squash from the resort’s organic farm, accompanied by a bottle of crisp white wine. Steps from the restaurant pavilion was our villa with its huge bed swathed in a white mosquito net, an open shower surrounded by local shiny white pebbles, and swinging outdoor daybeds. The pummeling of an unforgettable surfing session hours before made the idea of crawling back to such luxurious digs even more appealing.

headline: Top Hotels Look to the Next Frontier
abstract: Asian locations now dominate lists of the current and projected hot spots for luxury hotel and resort growth.
lead_paragraph: LIJIANG, China — Tourists from China’s crowded coasts have long considered this city of 1.2 million in the Himalayan foothills to be a scenic getaway.

headline: Ben Bernanke, Force of Nature
abstract: Interest rates are too high, not too low.
lead_paragraph: By any reasonable standard, the great failing of economic policy over the past 5 years — monetary and fiscal both — is that it has done too little. Output lies far below reasonable estimates of potential, meaning trillions of dollars of wasted resources; unemployment remains at levels that amount to personal, social, and possibly political catastrophe; inflation has been below target, and there are good reasons to believe that the targets are too low.

headline: The Great Civil War Lie
abstract: How the South convinced Britain that the Civil War was about trade, not slavery.
lead_paragraph: Civil War buffs have long speculated about how different the war might have been if only the Confederacy had won formal recognition from Britain. But few recognize how close that came to happening — and how much pro-Southern sympathy in Britain was built on a lie.

Now the rooftop has been planted with fig and apple trees, hops, strawberries, lavender and other herbs that the executive chef, David Garcelon, can use in the kitchen, and that the mixologist, Frank Caiafa, adds to drinks.

lead_paragraph: Samsung Electronics may have surpassed Apple to become the top smartphone maker in the United States in May, according to an analyst’s report. Sales of Samsung’s new flagship phone, the Galaxy S4, combined with its bigger-screen Galaxy Note II and the older Galaxy S III, lifted Samsung’s sales above Apple’s last month, the report said.

headline: Help for Traveling Pets
abstract: Animals traveling through Chicago on United Airlines can now stay in the carrier’s kennel at O’Hare International Airport.
lead_paragraph: Animals traveling through Chicago on United Airlines can now stay in 28 temperature-controlled enclosures at the carrier’s kennel at O’Hare International Airport. (Overnight stays are $100.) Staff members will walk and exercise pets, and groom and bathe them on request. The facility also has vans to transport pets to and from flights. The kennel is United’s third and is part of the airline’s PetSafe program for animals not eligible to travel in the cabin. The carrier operates similar facilities at airports in Houston and Newark.

headline: Compelling Series, but James Tilts Edge to Heat
abstract: Like the Heat with Tony Parker, the Spurs will try to keep LeBron James off balance by showing him a number of different defensive tactics during the N.B.A. finals.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. finals are saturated with story lines. A fifth title for the 37-year-old San Antonio star Tim Duncan would solidify his case for being his generation’s best player. A second straight title for LeBron James would cap one of the most dominant seasons in league history. The series pits the glitz and bombast of South Beach against the quiet diligence of the small-market Spurs.

headline: Palm-Size Fossil Resets Primates’ Clock, Scientists Say
abstract: A nearly complete skeleton of a creature that weighed less than an ounce dials back the primate fossil record by eight million years, paleontologists report.
lead_paragraph: A nearly complete skeleton of a tiny, ancient primate — one that weighed no more than an ounce, had a tail longer than its body and would fit in the palm of your hand — is the earliest well-preserved fossil primate ever found, dating back some 55 million years and dialing back the fossil record for primates by an impressive eight million years, a research team declared on Wednesday.

headline: A Magic Carpet Ride in a Venetian Palazzo
abstract: In an exhibition running concurrently with the Venice Biennale, the artist Rudolph Stingel has turned a palazzo owned by the Francois Pinault Foundation into a dazzling oasis.
lead_paragraph: As if the Venice Biennale didn’t offer enough art already between the Arsenale, the Giardini and the various national pavilions found on the crumbling side streets, there are also numerous palazzos that have been repurposed for parallel exhibitions mounted by some of the world’s pre-eminent private collections. The Francois Pinault Foundation owns two such mansion-seums on the Grand Canal: the industrial Tadao Ando-designed Punta Della Dogana and the quintessentially Venetian Palazzo Grassi. In the latter, the New York-based Italian artist Rudolph Stingel has created what may be the most sumptuous aesthetic experience on the island this year.

abstract: Maria Sharapova and Victoria Azarenka, who will meet in the French Open semifinals, have reputations not only as powerful ball-strikers but also as the game’s most high-pitched shriekers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Maria Sharapova and Jelena Jankovic have been battling each other since they were girls, after they were plucked from their homes and settled at the Bollettieri Academy in Florida to be turned into champions. Their relationship can be diplomatically described as frosty, and Jankovic has long existed in the considerable shadow of the more successful Sharapova.

headline: Racing Ambassadors Are Spreading the News About the Belmont
abstract: Even though there is not a Triple Crown on the line this year, there are still plenty of reasons to attend this year’s Belmont.
lead_paragraph: The Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes have come and gone, and with this, racing fans have also seen their hopes of a Triple Crown winner in 2013 shattered almost before they could even tell what had happened. Every year fans hope that after the Derby, that year’s winner will continue on and become a Triple Crown winner — something fans believe our sport desperately needs. No one said it was easy, and that is why no horse has completed the feat since Affirmed in 1978.

headline: In Besieged Area of Syria, Bitterness of Sunnis Points to Rending of Sects
abstract: As Hezbollah guerrillas from Lebanon and Syrian troops fought around Qusayr, many Sunnis declared the area’s social fabric had been destroyed.
lead_paragraph: NEAR QUSAYR, Syria — In the final days of their stubborn but increasingly hopeless stand against an overwhelming assault, Syrian rebels hid among the concrete shells of destroyed houses in the village of Hamediyeh, subsisting on olives and canned beans. They tried to sleep, without much success, in tunnels dug for shelter from government shelling.

headline: Trial Date Set for Former SAC Trader in Insider Case

lead_paragraph: Mathew Martoma, the former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, is set to stand trial on Nov. 4, almost a year after federal authorities charged him in what they called the largest insider trading case ever brought.

headline: Start-Up to Connect Home Appliances
abstract: Most makers of light switches, thermostats and other household appliances don’t have the expertise to build the Internet into their devices, nor can they afford adding a lot technology that significantly balloons the price of their products. Enter a start-up, Ayla Networks, which unveiled technology on Wednesday that it said would make bringing the Internet to ordinary devices more attractive for appliance makers.
lead_paragraph: One of Silicon Valley’s favorite buzz phrases is “Internet of things,” a catchall for everyday stuff like home appliances and light bulbs that are connected to the Internet. Nest Labs, a company founded by a former Apple executive that makes a smart thermostat, has brought cachet to the category and gotten a lot of other manufacturers thinking about how they can bring the Internet to their otherwise humdrum products.

headline: If You Drive on the Beach, Reduce the Air in Your Tires
abstract: Where it’s allowed, beach driving can be a great way to get you and your gear to some great out-of-the-way spots.Here are a few tips to avoid getting stuck.
lead_paragraph: It’s beach season, and in some locales that means beach driving. The video above is a good depiction of why it’s a good idea to air down your tires before driving on sand. Aired-down tires have a wider footprint and float better over soft sand than hard, fully inflated tires. A good place to start is 15 pounds per square inch.

headline: Kirna Zabête to Move to Larger Store in SoHo

Just inside the entrance of the 10,000-square-foot store at 477 Broome Street (Wooster Street), will be a wall of quotations in neon lights, the origins of which might have been Coco Chanel. Or maybe Carrie Bradshaw.

headline: How Bad Is European Youth Unemployment?
abstract: A crisis of “economic inactivity” is still a crisis.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column returned to what’s become a recurring theme of mine: The remarkable political quiescence of Europeans in the face of the economic devastation wrought by their rolling disaster of a currency union. In this case, my jumping-off point was what the Atlantic’s Derek Thompson calls “the scariest graph in the world,” which shows youth unemployment — for under-25-year-olds, that is — breaking 40 percent in Italy, 50 percent in Spain and 60 percent in Greece. So it’s worth saying something about the (fairly widespread) rejoinder that these numbers aren’t actually as bad as they look, because most young people are in school or training rather than looking fruitlessly for work. For instance, here’s the Financial Times’ Kate Allen, downplaying the youth-unemployment crisis:

headline: Proenza Schouler Updates Its First Collection
abstract: Proenza Schouler’s collection from 2003 is still popular. So the designers updated it for Barneys New York.
lead_paragraph: Observing some of their colleagues wearing pieces from the early days of Proenza Schouler recently, Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCollough had a thought. If it still looks good after 10 years, why not make it again?

headline: Finding Country Truths in Nature and in People
abstract: The Midwestern poet Tom Hennen evokes rural instincts and the natural world.
lead_paragraph: When I was a boy growing up in rural New Hampshire there were a few old men who always wore overalls and who lived out in the woods. And those men — Chief, Pop, Jake — knew where to find the best wild dandelion greens, sensed when the sucker fish were running the mill race, and squinted at the sky as if it were a baseball box score printed in the tiniest type.

headline: Is This Senegal’s Answer to ‘The Daily Show’?
abstract: In “Journal Rappé,” two West African musicians rap the news.
lead_paragraph: Even if you can’t decipher every word of the weekly YouTube show “Journal Rappé” — part music video, part news broadcast delivered entirely in French and Wolof by two Senegalese rappers — it’s worth checking out. Especially given that Senegal happens to be on Barack Obama’s itinerary when he makes his longest trip to Africa as president later this month. (Grist for the “Africa Rising” meme?)

headline: SAP’s Purchasing Power Play
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'E-Commerce', 'Enterprise Computing', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: SAP’s announcement that it had bought Hybris, an e-commerce software company, comes after the Salesforce purchase of ExactTarget. This is not as much a marketing deal, however, as a dream that mobile and cloud computing will blend online and offline, even retail and manufacturing.
lead_paragraph: SAP just did a big acquisition, along with a little head fake.

headline: Latest Resort Collections: Balenciaga, Altuzarra and Derek Lam
abstract: Resort collections from Balenciaga, Joseph Altuzarra and Derek Lam.
lead_paragraph: For Alexander Wang’s first resort collection for Balenciaga, presented Wednesday morning at the company’s new showroom on West 22nd Street, which was formerly a Balenciaga store, the designer took a trip to Getaria, in Spain, to visit the coastal city where Cristobal Balenciaga was born. Mr. Wang and members of the design studio toured the museum there to see some pieces that were not in the company’s own archives.

headline: Chefs on the Move
abstract: Changes at Krescendo and Gramercy Tavern.
lead_paragraph: Robert Moorman, who was at North End Grill, is the new executive chef at Krescendo, in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, which opened last fall and is owned by Nancy Puglisi. The original chef, Elizabeth Falkner, has left.

headline: The Middle Class Strikes Back
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Turkey’s government is a victim of its own success. The growing middle class it created is now demanding a voice.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — SINCE 2002, Turkey’s sound economic policies have made it a member of the Group of 20 and turned it into a majority middle-class society for the first time in its history. Yet this week’s huge protests show that the ruling Justice and Development Party, known as the A.K.P., has become a victim of its own success.

headline: Development Won’t Ensure Democracy in Turkey
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: Economic growth won’t end authoritarianism. Without a viable opposition party, democracy must advance by direct action instead.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — FOR the past few years, there has been a general optimism about Turkish democracy in Western capitals, especially in Washington, thanks to the economic strides made by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s Justice and Development Party, known as the A.K.P.

headline: Activists’ Stunt Livens Up a Routine Senate Session
abstract: About 15 protesters in the upstairs gallery showered New York State legislators with fake hundred-dollar bills to draw attention to calls for campaign finance reform.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY – There wasn’t much to see in the State Senate on Wednesday: the reciting of the Pledge of Allegiance, the honoring of a basketball player and a bunch of empty seats where elected representatives are paid to sit.

headline: Changes in Obama’s Foreign Policy Team
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama’s new foreign policy team is filled with some of his closest advisers and confidants, many of whom waited patiently for the top jobs during his first term.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s new foreign policy team is filled with some of his closest advisers and confidants, many of whom waited patiently for the top jobs during his first term.

headline: Therapy for Victims of Sexual Violence Shows Promise in Congo
abstract: A type of group therapy designed for trauma victims has proved helpful for survivors of sexual violence in the war-torn Democratic Republic of Congo, researchers report.
lead_paragraph: A type of group therapy designed for trauma victims has proved extraordinarily helpful for survivors of sexual violence in Democratic Republic of Congo, enabling women to overcome the shame, nightmares and terrifying flashbacks that had left them unable to work or take care of their families or themselves, researchers report.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Turkey, Bangladesh and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Turkey, Bangladesh and Germany.

headline: An Evening Dedicated to Charmers
abstract: The baritone Paulo Szot sang from “South Pacific” and “Man From La Mancha” at the New York Philharmonic’s gala concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: Orchestras sometimes use gala concerts as an occasion to ditch the Bruckner and Beethoven and focus on other genres, as the New York Philharmonic did on Tuesday evening with a lineup of Broadway, Brazilian and classical songs at Avery Fisher Hall. The program, “An Enchanted Evening With Paulo Szot,” featured the charismatic baritone in a range of repertory conducted by Ted Sperling.

headline: Charge Your iPad in Luxury
abstract: Strut, a company that makes grills and wheels for luxury cars, recently introduced an elegant charging system for the iPad.
lead_paragraph: Strut, a maker of grills and wheels for luxury cars, is seeking to add its touch of refinement to the iPad.

headline: Lessons for the Living, Courtesy of the Dead
abstract: “In the Flesh” takes place in a Britain where thousands of dead people have risen from their graves, wreaking havoc and causing a virulent anti-zombie backlash.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve avoided vampire/zombie television until now because you think it’s either dumb sci-fi or drippy romance aimed at teenagers, “In the Flesh,” a three-part mini-series that begins Thursday on BBC America, gives you a chance to find out just how well written and layered some of these shows are.

headline: Jewish Folk Songs, Set to Fela’s Afrobeat
abstract: The music on “Zion80,” a new album from a band led by Jon Madof, sets the songs of Shlomo Carlebach to Afrobeat rhythms.
lead_paragraph: As Jon Madof worked at his computer one Friday in 2011, doing the graphic-design job that supported his life as a guitarist, he listened to the Afrobeat music of Fela Anikulapo-Kuti. Then, with the Sabbath sundown nearing, he shut down his home office and began humming one of the Jewish religious songs made famous by Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach.

headline: In Store | Hedi Slimane’s Sleek New Saint Laurent Flagship
abstract: The controversial designer personally oversaw every last detail of the thoroughly modern new store in Soho.
lead_paragraph: For many, marble might conjure antiquity. But Hedi Slimane has put the majestic material to thoroughly contemporary use in the new Saint Laurent Paris flagship store in SoHo, which opened today. The brand’s first outpost downtown is part of Slimane’s revamp of the label, which until recently was known by the initials YSL. Black-and-white silk-marble panels flank the walls, lending an airiness and sophistication to the space, which also features 19th-century cast-iron columns and tin ceilings typical of the neighborhood.

headline: Countries Seek Entrepreneurs From Silicon Valley
keywords: ['Entrepreneurship', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Visas', 'Start-ups', 'Law and Legislation', 'Foreign Workers', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: As Congress debates immigration, countries like Canada and Australia are trying to lure foreign entrepreneurs. But there’s only one place they want to be.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A bold new billboard looms over U.S. 101, the highway that runs through the heart of the global technology industry. “H-1b problems?” it reads. “Pivot to Canada.”

headline: Open Trial to Select U.S. Team for Bermuda Bowl
abstract: The Open Trial taking place in Orlando, Fla., will select the two United States teams for the Bermuda Bowl in September.
lead_paragraph: The Open Trial taking place in Orlando, Fla., will select the two United States teams for the Bermuda Bowl in September. The semifinal draw for the unbeaten teams is Martin Fleisher, Michael Kamil, Zia Mahmood, Chip Martel, Michael Rosenberg and Chris Willenken against Warren Spector, Michael Becker, Curtis Cheek, Joe Grue, Fred Gitelman and Brad Moss; and Nick Nickell, Ralph Katz, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell versus John Kranyak, Gavin Wolpert, Kevin Bathurst and Kevin Dwyer.

headline: A Rainbow of Fragility
abstract: Mira Awad, a Palestinian Arab citizen of Israel, performed in a show, “Arabic Fusion,” at the Metropolitan Room on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: A line from the Sting song “Fragile” — “Nothing comes from violence/And nothing ever could” — became much more than a sad reflection on human nature when sung by the Arab-Israeli singer and songwriter Mira Awad at the Metropolitan Room on Tuesday evening. Ms. Awad, 37, who sings in Arabic and English and occasionally in Hebrew, was born in Rameh in Galilee to a Palestinian father and Bulgarian mother. She stars in “Arab Labor,” a popular Israeli television comedy about Jewish and Arab coexistence.

headline: Byron’s Gloomy Pirate Tale, With Bikini Tutus Added
abstract: American Ballet Theater’s production of “Le Corsaire,” an 1856 ballet based on Byron’s heroic poem, pulls together the work of several choreographers and even more composers.
lead_paragraph: Next year brings the bicentennial of Byron’s heroic poem “The Corsair” — a literary sensation that sold some 10,000 copies on its first day of publication. In foreign translations it so flourished over the next few decades that it prompted multiple stage adaptations, including an opera by Verdi (1848) and a Parisian ballet choreographed by Joseph Mazilier to music by Adolphe Adam (1856). Yet by one of the more perverse tricks of artistic fate, the most popular version of it today is a Russian ballet that contains nothing of Mazilier’s choreography or much of Adam’s music and in which Byron’s original poem, heavy with tragic emotion, is distorted into an absurd romp.

headline: Share Ideas on Travel With Kids in N.Y.C.
abstract: The Travel editors are looking for tips on negotiating New York City with kids.
lead_paragraph: Next week, the Travel section will start a new series of articles on traveling with children in big cities. The series will include tips on everything from unexpected kid-friendly attractions to basics like where to eat and find a bathroom.

headline: Taking the Rockabus to the Rockaways
abstract: What better time than Memorial Day to show support for one of the places hardest hit by Hurricane Sandy. Sun, sand and suds included.
lead_paragraph: What better time than Memorial Day to show support for one of the places hardest hit by Hurricane Sandy. Sun, sand and suds included.

headline: Sun, Sand and Suds
abstract: The return of the Rockabus is yet another sign that Hurricane Sandy has done little to unseat the Rockaways as the go-to beach for fashionable Brooklynites.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Memorial Day, as the sun broke through the wet blanket of a weekend, more than a dozen 20- and 30-somethings in striped tank tops and straw hats boarded a yellow school bus idling in a bleak parking lot in Williamsburg.

headline: The New Guy (With a Gun) at a Dream Beach House

lead_paragraph: “Graceland,” is a confusing title for a series that isn’t about Elvis Presley or Paul Simon in his South African period.

lead_paragraph: It turns out that Bhakti Sondra Shaye does windows. She also scours microwaves, refrigerators, dishwashers and closets.

headline: Fending Off the Bad Spirits
abstract: Domestic talismans that are also pleasing to the senses.
lead_paragraph: If you are a feng shui expert or, for that matter, a Jewish grandmother, you are likely to believe that a scrupulously clean and tidy home is the first defense against bad spirits. (No place to hide.) But even at the risk of cluttering, you may want to acquire a talisman or two. The following demon-repelling goods not only have the endorsements of ancient belief systems (in some cases, several), but they are also pleasing to the senses (in some cases, several).

abstract: The arty denizens of the neighborhood throw open their doors for the annual spate of exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: The arty denizens of the neighborhood throw open their doors for the annual spate of exhibitions.

abstract: Odd, ethereal or just tattooed, the arty denizens of Bushwick know how to open their doors.
lead_paragraph: Bushwick is not, as you may have read (and read and read), the coolest place in the universe, though for three days every year it may be the coolest place in the five boroughs.

headline: A Homestead for House Stalkers
abstract: A couple settle down (at least for now) in a passive-solar box in the country.
lead_paragraph: Listening to Jade-Snow Carroll and Ian Rasch talk about the 1,650-square-foot, two-bedroom passive-solar house they built two years ago amid rolling farmland here, one senses it is soon to become a memory rather than a place where memories will be made. If building a house is this much fun, they seemed to be saying, why not do it again?

headline: Beyond the ‘Palace,’ an International Tour in One City
abstract: “The Encyclopedic Palace,” the main show of the 55th Venice Biennale, is organized by the chief curator of the New Museum of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — Dark weather and high water were the backdrop to the start of the 55th Venice Biennale, an event that predictably combines enough cold cash and hot air to create a storm system of critical opinion. The main barometric indicator is always the big show that gives each Biennale its theme, and on this score, for the first time in years, there’s fairly smooth sailing.

abstract: An American couple make the trek every year to their house in the Andes.
lead_paragraph: An American couple make the trek every year to their house in the Andes.

headline: Rampant Blooms, but No Color
abstract: Amika: Hairdo Bar, a 700-square-foot styling-only salon with a floral motif, opens in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: Amika: Hairdo Bar, a two-story, 700-square-foot hairstyling salon, will open June 11 in Hong Kong. “We’re demystifying hair styling, making things faster and easier,” said Vita Raykhman, 31, the creative director of Amika, a Brooklyn hair products company. The Hairdo Bar, Amika’s first salon, will allow a woman to change her image in less than 40 minutes “without the commitment of a cut or a color,” Ms. Raykhman said. Customers will be offered a choice of 12 hair styles, with prices ranging from $24 to $70. Guy Zucker of Z-A Studio in Manhattan designed the space on a budget of $90,000 using the company’s flower-shaped graphic identity as an architectural motif. On the first floor, the birch plywood walls are cut into floral silhouettes, and flowers are printed on the wallpaper in the rear. Upstairs, the flower shape is applied to the booths. Hairdo Bar is at 8 Elgin Street, Hong Kong, 011-852-2291-0070. Three additional shops will open in New York City next year.

headline: Up in the Clouds
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: What makes a second home in the Andes worth the 4,300-mile trek? Charred guinea pig and great views.
lead_paragraph: CAÑAR, Ecuador — Most people aren’t willing to drive more than a few hours to get to a second home in the country.

headline: Darling of Cannes Now at Center of Storm
abstract: “Blue Is the Warmest Color,” lauded for its lesbian sex scenes, is now being criticized for those very scenes.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Last month the film “Blue Is the Warmest Color” was the toast of Cannes. A drama about young lesbian love, it was so celebrated for its explicit sex scenes that it won the festival’s top prize. Since then it’s being castigated for those very same scenes.

headline: An Ultramodern Island Draws on Italian Styling
abstract: Minacciolo, a company based in Treviso, introduces an all-black kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Minacciolo, the Italian interiors company, says its Mina kitchen is the ultimate accessory, but really it is an island unto itself — with cooktop, oven, dual dishwashing drawers, illuminated storage and refrigeration in a customizable package.

headline: Illustrator to City: It’s Personal
abstract: Peter Kuper, the cartoonist and graphic novelist, publishes a chronicle of his three decades in New York.
lead_paragraph: Peter Kuper, the cartoonist and illustrator, has tried to capture his three decades in New York, and the city itself, with “Drawn to New York” (PM Press; $29.95). “You can’t be comprehensive because it’s too big a piece of pie to swallow — or apple, rather,” Mr. Kuper said. Instead, he inks his own experiences, which seem informed by the twin responses shared by many New York transplants: anxiety and wonder. In one illustration, a lone man looks out from his darkened apartment and wonders how many people are having sex at that moment. Another panel tells the story of a long-ago night when Mr. Kuper and a friend scaled the suspension cables of the Brooklyn Bridge. The artistic styles change from page to page, mirroring the frenetic, unpredictable nature of the city. As Mr. Kuper said, “The thing I like about New York is the quality of feeling like you’re traveling at all times.”

headline: Contemporary Design Lands in Antiques Country
abstract: Fern Handcrafted Furniture joins the fray of modern design shops in Hudson, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Hudson, N.Y., is an antiques-hunter’s haven, but it is becoming more of a source of contemporary design as well, with the opening of Fern Handcrafted Furniture.

headline: Garage Band Ceramics
abstract: Paula Greif’s whimsical, wiggly, home-brewed designs.
lead_paragraph: Paula Greif’s whimsical, wiggly, home-brewed designs.

headline: Now What’s Her Line?
abstract: Paula Greif, the former art director of Mademoiselle, on the newest chapter in her storied life in art and design.
lead_paragraph: Paula Greif made some of the first music videos for MTV (on Super 8 film, no less) and designed album covers for Madonna, Debbie Harry and Paul Simon. Though she has been the art director of Mademoiselle and for Barneys New York, and worked with fashion photographers like Richard Avedon, Steven Meisel and Arthur Elgort, Ms. Greif was always a rocker at heart. When she was in the art department of Self magazine in the late ’70s, she spent her nights at CBGB and the Mudd Club, and slept under her desk at lunch. Now 60, she is making ceramics, animated porcelain and terra-cotta pieces that look like wiggly line drawings (you can find them occasionally on her Web site — be warned, she is frequently sold out — and at Beautiful Dreamers, a store in Williamsburg, Brooklyn). Ms. Greif calls her pottery “garage band ceramics” because of its handmade funkiness and because her new career has unfolded in a typically ad hoc, no-frills manner.

headline: New York’s Clueless Election Board Drags Out Ancient Machines
abstract: The Shoup machines were cranky when they were in full use. Imagine their troubles after years in storage.
lead_paragraph: New York City voters should be prepared to cast their ballots once again this fall on voting machines invented in the 19th century. State legislators were apparently close to a deal on Wednesday afternoon to allow New York City’s clueless board of elections to use the old mechanical machines for the city’s September 10 primary.

headline: Greek Regrets
abstract: The IMF has them.
lead_paragraph: The IMF has released a fairly remarkable piece of self-criticism (pdf) over policy in Greece. On a first read, the report seems to suggest two main failings on the IMF’s part: it failed to acknowledge early on that Greece simply could not repay its debt in full, and it vastly underestimated the economic damage austerity would inflict.

headline: Sales at Hable Construction, the Future Perfect and Others
abstract: Discounts on pillows, ceramics, accessories and more.
lead_paragraph: All in-stock pillows are 25 percent off at Hable Construction, through June 13 (a 14-by-18-inch Azul Waterfalls pillow, usually $65, is now about $49); the code SUMMER should be entered at check out, (817) 422-5313, hableconstruction.com.

headline: A Spiritual Center of Power Is a Required Stop on Iran’s Campaign Trail
abstract: Candidates in Iran’s presidential election next week are making political pilgrimages to Qum, a Shiite Vatican, hoping to secure the support of its influential clerics.
lead_paragraph: QUM, Iran — Qum, home to some of Iran’s most influential clerics, is not just Iran’s holiest city, but one of its most powerful, a Shiite Vatican in the desert that can make or break any Iranian political career. So it is not surprising that it has become a destination recently for almost all of the candidates in next week’s presidential election, seeking to sip from the cocktail of money, politics and religion that the city represents.

headline: The Tablet or Smartphone Becomes a Tutor for the Budding Artist
abstract: A number of apps provide step-by-step instruction in drawing, either directly on a smartphone or tablet or using pencil and paper.
lead_paragraph: The smartphone revolution, among other things, has put a camera in everyone’s pocket. This has led to an explosion in the art of photography — if you can call an Instagram self-portrait art. But smartphones and tablets have another ability that is genuinely arty: they can help teach basic drawing and sketching.

headline: Civil Disobedience on a Turkish Game Show
abstract: While most of Turkey’s journalists were carefully avoiding mention of the protests this week, the host of one Turkish game show found a way to raise the issue not once but 70 times.
lead_paragraph: While most of Turkey’s journalists were carefully avoiding mention of the tens of thousands of protesters who poured into the streets this week, in a show of deference to the government that enraged supporters of the demonstrations, the host of one Turkish game show found a way to raise the issue not once but 70 times during a broadcast on Monday night.

headline: Painting the Lily? He’s One Up on That
abstract: Putting his own painted designs on other people’s clothes is Delano Brown’s entry into the art world.
lead_paragraph: By the time Delano Brown showed up at his first New York gallery show, a model in a white dress had been waiting — silently, fiercely — more than an hour for his paint. She was doing such a good job of staring into the distance that the phenomenally well-appointed crowd filling the Smart Clothes Gallery on the Lower East Side stopped noticing her almost entirely.

headline: If You’re Not Going to Wear That …
abstract: Walk in My Closet lets you sell clothes you want to get rid of, and check out other people’s discards.
lead_paragraph: “What girl isn’t interested in seeing what her friend has in her closet?” So reasoned Ambre Dahan, the design director of Joe’s Jeans and now the founder, with Amandine Rohmer, of Walk in My Closet, a virtual wardrobe manager and shopping site. Like many of us, she and Ms. Rohmer often shared new purchases and outfits via text. The new site (walkinmycloset.com) and app, available on iTunes this week, streamlines the whole process. How it works: You download the app and shoot the items in your closet like a pro (it silhouettes them on a white background) and essentially create a boutique of everything you own. From there, you can make packing lists, sell things you never wear — for a 25 percent commission — and buy from other users, who include founding members like Charlotte Ronson, Irene Neuwirth and Julia Restoin Roitfeld. If you ever find yourself saying, “I don’t have anything to wear,” think of this as your new best friend.

headline: Bally Offers Mountaineer Reindeer Boots
abstract: Bally offers an updated version of the boots that conquered Everest 60 years ago.
lead_paragraph: It is one of the 20th century’s most memorable photos: the one Edmund Hillary took of Tenzing Norgay on May 29, 1953, standing at the summit of Mount Everest, the highest point on earth. Now, 60 years later, there is an answer to the question everyone — or at least one or two people — has been asking ever since: where can I get those chic reindeer boots? The answer is Bally, the Swiss company that in the ’40s began custom-making boots for serious mountaineers, among them the pair that Tenzing wore for his storied ascent. In honor of the anniversary of that climb — and the fact that the old-fashioned mountaineer has become a style model in men’s fashion — Bally is issuing a new version of the boots. The sole is lighter in weight and they lace more easily. But like the originals, they are available only by order, and they are still made of reindeer fur. They may never help you get to the top of a mountain, but, at $2,495, they will definitely get you to the tiptop of your credit card limit. Bally, 628 Madison Avenue; (212) 751-9082.

headline: Monoprice Introduces an LED Monitor
abstract: Monoprice, the Web retailer best known for its low-priced cables, continues to expand its product line with a low price 27-inch high resolution LED computer monitor.
lead_paragraph: Monoprice, the Web retailer best known for its low-priced cables, continues to expand its product line with a 27-inch high-resolution LED computer monitor it showed at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas last January. The price? $475, nearly a third less than many models with similar specifications.

headline: Sheer Garments Make a Tasteful Return
abstract: A sophisticated take on showing off your lingerie.
lead_paragraph: Despite the sheer number of sheer garments in recent runway collections, a public display of underwear still seems vaguely … well, amateur. But we’re getting past it. Bras, we’ve noticed, are now fully (and chicly) on display. There was Julia Restoin Roitfeld, who was out and about with an opaque bra under a beautiful sheer blouse; the model Hye Park, whose bra was visible under a sheer white shirt and tuxedo jacket; and the actress Stella Schnabel, who looked impeccable in all-white tailoring, including the underpinnings. What makes the looks winning is the juxtaposition of peek-a-boo sex appeal with sharp lines and volume. Instead of grungy, the effect is sophisticated and modern.

headline: Orlebar Brown Swim Trunks Use Paris Review Art
abstract: Orlebar Brown does another collaboration on men’s swim trunks, this time with The Paris Review.
lead_paragraph: The British pop-meets-prep swimwear label Orlebar Brown, known for its well-cut swim trunks, does the collaboration thing well. Already it has done limited editions with Monocle magazine and Alan Aldridge, the illustrator famous for his work with the Beatles, among other imaginative collaborations. The latest (and most highbrow) is a venture with The Paris Review, in which it is reprinting select archival cover illustrations on the classic Orlebar Brown midlength swim shorts. Included are a Kim MacConnel beach scene, titled “Ten Items or Less,” from the summer ’80 cover; Donald Sultan’s orange flowers from summer ’96; and a Leanne Shapton figure drawing from the spring 2011 cover. Any dad with an appreciation of cool men’s fashion or graphic design or literature will gladly take a pair on Father’s Day.

lead_paragraph: Bravo’s “Real Housewives” franchise has a global reach, inspiring versions in countries like Canada, Israel and Greece.

The boards of both institutions have approved the alliance in principle, though neither group will so far divulge specifics of the plan. Hazelden has a network of 10 treatment centers throughout the country.  Starting in 2014, Medicare and all insurance sold on Health Insurance Exchanges will be required to provide treatment for substance abuse under a provision of the Affordable Care Act.

It may be the martini-toned black-and-white cinematography, the soigné Southern California setting, or the combative courtship of Amy Acker’s angular, sharp-tongued Beatrice and Alexis Denisof’s grouchy, hangdog Benedick, but from its very first scenes, Mr. Whedon’s film crackles with a busy, slightly wayward energy that recalls the classic romantic sparring of the studio era.
