lead_paragraph: Around dusk on Feb. 17, Dr. Drew Pinsky was sitting at the computer in his hillside home in Pasadena, Calif., when he received an e-mail from a friend with some troubling news. Mindy McCready, a 37-year-old country singer and a star of the third season of “Celebrity Rehab with Dr. Drew,” a television show that made its debut on VH1 in 2008, had shot herself at her house in Heber Springs, Ark.

headline: Gunman Kills 4 in California Before He Is Killed

headline: Russians Dreaming in French
abstract: Flicker Alley’s box set “French Masterworks: Russian Émigrés in Paris 1923-1928” presents five films from the 1920s silent-film avant-garde.
lead_paragraph: After its early dominance of international film production was shattered by World War I, France never quite managed to sustain a studio system on the Hollywood industrial model. What the French achieved instead was an artisanal cinema built around independent producers, several of whom — like Adolphe Osso in the 1930s, André Paulvé in the ’50s and Anatole Dauman in the ’60s and ’70s — had tastes pronounced enough to establish identities for their firms. These maisons de production functioned more like book publishers than dream factories, attracting a certain kind of talent for individual productions rather than putting rosters of stars and filmmakers under contract for a steady stream of releases.

headline: The Dancing Life, Condensed
abstract: “Avalanche,” a work by Headlong Dance Theater, hints at the phases a dancer or actor goes through in a lifetime.
lead_paragraph: Headlong Dance Theater, a Philadelphia company, has never existed under a set of choreographic rules. Formed 20 years ago by David Brick, Andrew Simonet and Amy Smith (though Mr. Simonet left last year), the group has staged works in hotel swimming pools, explored the cult of Britney Spears and constructed a performance journey for one audience member at a time led by a cellphone.

headline: The Tinkling of the Keys, the Slapping of the Thighs
abstract: The Italian pianist Stefano Bollani took on Michael Jackson and Thelonious Monk in his Thursday set at Birdland, where he broke into thigh-slapping and a riff on the word “intro.”
lead_paragraph: Jazz musicians use their physical presence all the time in projecting an artistic persona, although it’s usually conveying muted concentration or communion, enveloping their instrument or listening to another’s with laser focus. Not too many jazz musicians in recent decades come close to physical comedy when they perform, as Fats Waller and Louis Armstrong did. There have been the Dutch players who poke fun at jazz convention with critical remove: Han Bennink and Misha Mengelberg and Willem Breuker. And then there’s Stefano Bollani, who isn’t much like any of them.

And it opened a sumptuous new concert hall, the 1,844 seat, $123 million Schermerhorn Symphony Center, in 2006.

headline: All in Harmony
abstract: At the New York Philharmonic, Carl R. Schiebler is the fixer for 106 performers, and keeps things running smoothly so rehearsals and performances are seamless.
lead_paragraph: As the New York Philharmonic’s orchestra personnel manager, Carl R. Schiebler keeps rehearsals running on time, tracks down substitutes and serves as fixer. Mr. Schiebler, 75, was the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra’s second hornist and later its personnel manager before coming to the Philharmonic in 1986. When he is not taking care of one of his 106 orchestra members, Mr. Schiebler splits his time between his apartment on the Upper West Side and Pleasantville, N.Y., where he lives with his wife, Noriko Whyte, a pianist and music teacher.

headline: A Le Corbusier Rooftop Gets a New Life as an Arts Space
abstract: The French designer Ora-Ito followed the legendary designer’s blueprints with exacting precision to restore the site atop a Marseilles apartment complex.
lead_paragraph: One of the greatest achievements of the pioneering architect and urbanist Le Corbusier is Cité Radieuse, an extensive apartment complex in Marseille, France, which he completed in the early 1950s. Often described as a “vertical village,” it has 337 apartments, a restaurant, a hotel, a bookstore and a nursery school. France classified it as a historical monument in the 1980s. When the building’s rooftop gym and solarium went up for sale in 2010, the French designer Ito Morabito, who goes by Ora-Ito professionally, purchased it as a collector might. “Like you buy a piece of art, but architecture,” he explained.

headline: A Season’s Last Concert Restores a Work’s Lost Passages
abstract: Thomas Crawford presented Mendelssohn’s “Reformation” Symphony on Tuesday at the American Classical Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: For all the sturdy proclamations and occasional bluster in Mendelssohn’s “Reformation” Symphony, the real drama occurs at moments when intense dynamism yields to blessed simplicity. Thomas Crawford, the founder and music director of the period-instrument American Classical Orchestra, made the most of one of those crucial junctures on Tuesday evening at Alice Tully Hall in the last concert of the ensemble’s 28th season but, by his own choice, pretty much missed another.

lead_paragraph: The defining mission of Le Poisson Rouge, the popular Greenwich Village club and cabaret, is to present all kinds of contemporary music. On successive nights you can hear an indie rock band, a jazz singer or a string quartet playing Xenakis.

headline: Retirement Risks of Bonds
abstract: Conventional wisdom says people should hold more bonds as they age. But ultralow interest rates have left many would-be retirees with a big problem: the chance that they will exhaust their bond portfolios before they die. The outlook is worse for people who retire earlier and withdraw more. Adding stocks to a portfolio increases the risk of big losses, but it also reduces the risk that you’ll outlive your money.
lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom says people should hold more bonds as they age. But ultralow interest rates have left many would-be retirees with a big problem: the chance that they will exhaust their bond portfolios before they die. The outlook is worse for people who retire earlier and withdraw more. Adding stocks to a portfolio increases the risk of big losses, but it also reduces the risk that you’ll outlive your money.

headline: Waving My Tweak Flag High
abstract: Even for the likes of Dylan and Jagger, a tiny lyric change can often make a big difference.
lead_paragraph: In my years of writing and performing songs I’ve come to realize that small, even accidental, lyric changes can greatly improve (or screw up) a song. Sometimes I notice it in my own songs; an accident of vocal delivery on stage one night might turn a light bulb on and then remain an integral part of a song forever, leaving me to lament that my officially released album recording is weaker than the currently performed version.

lead_paragraph: From sun-dried tomato wraps to agave-sweetened smoothies, restaurant chains are working to court an exceptionally particular generation — the millennials.

headline: Martian Rock Another Clue to a Once Water-Rich Planet
keywords: ['Mars (Planet)', 'Space', 'Curiosity (Mars Rover)', 'Opportunity (Mars Rover)', 'Clay', 'Rock and Stone', 'Water', 'Metals and Minerals']
abstract: The clay-rich rock, which scientists named Esperance, is one of the oldest rocks that the rover Opportunity has looked at during its nine and a half years on Mars.
lead_paragraph: The discovery of what appears to be a clay-rich rock on Mars adds to the portrait of the planet as one that once — in its youth, more than three and a half billion years ago — was a water-rich world with conditions amenable for life, NASA scientists said Friday.

headline: Safety Agency Shuts Down Discount Bus Line
abstract: Federal regulators, citing a variety of mechanical and operational violations, ordered the company that operated the Lucky Star line to take all of its buses off the road.
lead_paragraph: Passengers who paid $15 to ride Lucky Star buses between Chinatown in Manhattan and Boston were apparently lucky that they or their luggage did not fall onto Interstate 95 at high speed.

headline: Pierre Mauroy, Socialist Who Led Changes in France, Dies at 84
abstract: As France’s first Socialist prime minister after World War II, Mr. Mauroy pushed through what his party considered to be important reforms.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Pierre Mauroy, who as France’s first Socialist prime minister since the beginning of the Fifth Republic in 1958 pushed through some of the Socialist Party’s most important overhauls, died on Friday in a hospital near Paris. He was 84.

headline: David Simon, Creator of ‘The Wire,’ Debates N.S.A. Surveillance With Readers of His Blog
abstract: The former reporter behind “The Wire” suggested in a long blog post that “the national eruption over the rather inevitable and understandable collection of all raw data involving telephonic and internet traffic by Americans” was misguided.
lead_paragraph: David Simon, the former reporter behind the television drama “The Wire,” which President Obama calls “one of the greatest shows of all time,” came to the defense of his embattled fan on Friday, suggesting in a long post on his blog that “the national eruption over the rather inevitable and understandable collection of all raw data involving telephonic and Internet traffic by Americans” was misguided.

headline: Get Ready to Watch Some Big Destruction
abstract: An 11-story building on Governors Island is scheduled to be imploded on Sunday morning, and the action should be viewable from a distance, and here on City Room.
lead_paragraph: Here’s something fun to do Sunday morning. Get up early and watch a building be imploded in your pajamas. That is — watch it in your pajamas. The building is not in your pajamas. It is on Governors Island.

headline: Splits Appear in Policy ‘Troika’ Addressing Europe’s Financial Crisis
abstract: Throughout the crisis, chiefs at the European Union and the International Monetary Fund have been part of a policy-making triumvirate that also includes the European Central Bank.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — After a series of nightlong crisis meetings on Cyprus, the European Union’s economic policy chief, Olli Rehn, remarked that his wife had started complaining that he spent more time with Christine Lagarde, the head of the International Monetary Fund, than with her.

headline: She Rode Horses, Drove an S.U.V. and, the Authorities Say, Farmed Marijuana
abstract: Federal authorities say Andrea Sanderlin, 45, raised thousands of marijuana plants with state-of-the-art equipment in a Queens warehouse.
lead_paragraph: There were many mornings, the authorities say, when a gray Mercedes GL4 S.U.V. pulled out from a driveway on a wooded street in Scarsdale, N.Y., and cruised through the Bronx before ending up inside an ugly, brick-face building in an industrial stretch of Queens.

headline: More Space, and a Bigger Menu, Too
abstract: The Italian restaurant Modern, which moved to a new location in New Rochelle over the winter, offers a long list of dishes.
lead_paragraph: Modern, New Rochelle’s beloved pizza joint, moved this past winter from cramped quarters to a lofty space that was first a car showroom and later a restaurant supply store. As recorded on various social media sites, loyal patrons were variously elated and scandalized. But no one can dispute that the new home of this Italian-American emporium — with its vaulted ceiling, giant arched windows and granite floor — is a knockout.

headline: Scam Suspects Become the Victims
abstract: Using a bag filled with newspaper clippings and water bottles instead of cash, an elderly woman turns the tables in the elaborate Chinese blessing scam.
lead_paragraph: The scam’s elaborate setup began Monday afternoon with a simple question on a Chinatown sidewalk, and built itself up in a series of seemingly chance encounters and grave predictions. Grave in tone, but also as in coming from a dead person below ground.

headline: Homey Ambience, and a Changing Menu
abstract: At Picador, on Elm Street in New Canaan, some diners might choose to make a meal out of two or more of the tapas, or small plates, on the menu.
lead_paragraph: Picador, on Elm Street in New Canaan, may succeed where previous occupants of its tiny space have failed over the years. This new 31-seat restaurant, which opened around Thanksgiving, is minute, but charming, like dining in a private home, with copper tabletops, several framed wall mirrors, carriage lamps, and a banquette along the end wall piled with big puffy cushions. One wall is decorated with a display of colorful Spanish ceramic plates.

headline: Summer Shades of White and Rosé
abstract: Large crowds and a steady proliferation of lighter wines at a tasting last month indicate it is going to be a busy season on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: GIVEN THE NUMBER OF TASTERS last month at Brooklyn Uncorked, where only Long Island wines are sampled, vintners on the Island might expect a flood of summer visitors.

headline: Choice for U.N. Post Gets Israeli Vote of Confidence
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Samantha Power, who is facing some resistance from pro-Israel groups, was praised by the Israeli ambassador to Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Samantha Power, President Obama’s choice to be the next ambassador to the United Nations, is encountering resistance from pro-Israel groups for remarks she once made about Israel and the Palestinians. But on Friday, she got an unexpected vote of confidence from Israel’s representative in the United States.

headline: Flavors of the Andes, Everywhere
abstract: Surprises at Cuzco Peru include salchipapas (a platter of French fries and frankfurters) and Asian-inspired entrees reflecting a Chinese influence.
lead_paragraph: Corn is not only a staple of the food at Cuzco Peru in Lynbrook, but it also finds its way into one of the soft drinks: chicha morada, made from purple corn here flavored with citrus juice, cinnamon and tiny cubes of apple.

headline: Joey Covington, Rock Drummer, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Covington was a replacement drummer for Jefferson Airplane and a founding member of Hot Tuna.
lead_paragraph: Joey Covington, a drummer for the psychedelic rock band Jefferson Airplane in the early 1970s and a founding member of their bluesy spinoff Hot Tuna, died on Tuesday. He was 67.

headline: Don’t Forsake the Gray Wolf
abstract: The United States should not relax protections for the vulnerable species.
lead_paragraph: KETCHUM, Idaho — IT has been celebrated as one of the great victories of the Endangered Species Act of 1973. After several decades of federal protection, gray wolves — once nearly wiped out in the continental United States — have reached a population of roughly 6,100 across three Great Lakes states and seven Western states.

headline: Expansive Space, Portions and Flavors
abstract: Ria Mar, a Portuguese restaurant and bar in South River, is run by Manuel da Silva, who immigrated from Portugal in 1969, and his three children.
lead_paragraph: To visit the sprawling Ria Mar Restaurant and Bar is to step into a holiday of plenty: a vast restaurant with two separate dining areas; a sea of tables; endless plastic pitchers of sangria; poster-size pictures; and a wave-shaped installation covering an entire wall in both rooms.

headline: With Little Time Before Election, Senate Race in New Jersey Begins to Take Shape
abstract: Mayor Cory A. Booker will most likely face two congressmen in the Democratic primary, while Steven M. Lonegan is the only Republican to come forward.
lead_paragraph: The candidates for United States Senate in New Jersey have not even all declared themselves, but with a deadline to file petitions looming on Monday, the shape of the race to succeed Frank R. Lautenberg is already coming into view.

lead_paragraph: Perhaps the lone uncontested aspect of the sport of thoroughbred racing in America is that its history and its future are rooted in the states of Kentucky and New York. Their longstanding competition that will gain a new chapter with Saturday’s Belmont Stakes.

headline: An Invasion of 17-Year-Olds, Loud, Lusty and Six-Legged
abstract: As cicadas overrun signs, lawns and porches across the region, most homeowners seem resigned to wait out the few weeks of infestation.
lead_paragraph: There are a few acts of nature, such as the passage of Halley’s comet or the transit of Venus, that are so rare and so dramatic as to seem like metaphors for the virtues of patience itself. But of all of these, the arrival of the 17-year cicadas, the noisy insects that nestled under the earth for that length of time and recently awakened by the millions to spawn, may be the grossest.

headline: An Enchanted Evening Open to Possibilities
abstract: With romance, racism and a timeless score, the musical “South Pacific” at the John W. Engeman Theater creates a vibrant portrait of life during wartime.
lead_paragraph: Even before the cute siblings sing their playful “Dites-Moi,” and before the American nurse and the French plantation owner tenderly embark on their romance, the production of “South Pacific” at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport exudes a sense of open-ended possibilities. The simple but elegant set designed by Josh Zangen does it, with four hanging, slatted panels evoking airy Pacific island architecture, and four rattan-like borders framing the stage, one behind the other.

headline: A South Korean Stays in the Fairway and in Front
abstract: Chella Choi of South Korea leads Jiyai Shin and Morgan Pressel by a shot after a rain-delayed first round of the L.P.G.A. Championship.
lead_paragraph: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Continuing rain on Friday did not bother Chella Choi of South Korea, who took a one-shot lead at five-under 67 in the first round of the L.P.G.A. Championship.

headline: Richard Ramirez, the ‘Night Stalker’ Killer, Dies at 53
abstract: Most of the killings were committed by Mr. Ramirez before dawn during residential burglaries, and all were markedly coldblooded, involving savage beatings, mutilations and sexual assaults.
lead_paragraph: Richard Ramirez, who claimed to be inspired by Satan when he killed at least 14 people in the “Night Stalker” attacks that terrorized California in 1985, died on Friday in a hospital in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 53.

headline: Tech Companies Concede to Surveillance Program
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Negotiations with the government shed a light on how Internet companies like Facebook and Google interact with the spy agencies that look to their vast trove of information.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When government officials came to Silicon Valley to demand easier ways for the world’s largest Internet companies to turn over user data as part of a secret surveillance program, the companies bristled. In the end, though, many cooperated at least a bit.

headline: Fifes and Drums as Performance Art
abstract: Allison Smith’s installation at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum encourages re-examining American history as part of a wider culture.
lead_paragraph: Social practice is a relatively new term for art that puts less emphasis on objects made for individual contemplation and more energy into projects involving participation, activism or community organizing. Of course, plenty of artists were making art like this before critics and scholars christened it “social practice.” One such artist is Allison Smith, whose exhibition “Allison Smith: Rudiments of Fife and Drum” combines elements of craft, performance and participation and is currently on view at the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Ridgefield, Conn.

headline: In This Sport, Beware of Left Hooks, Jabs and Castling
abstract: Chessboxing, a combination of brawn and smarts, inevitably inspires puns like rook versus hook.
lead_paragraph: The title highlights a contradiction, pairing an intellectual activity in which the combatants never touch and a combat sport in which opponents aim fists at each other’s chins. There is chess. There is boxing. And then there is chessboxing.

headline: Video and Images From Scene of Santa Monica Shooting Spree
abstract: Residents, who reported hearing gunshots and seeing a bus with its rear and side windows shattered by bullets, captured videos from the scene and posted updates to Twitter.
lead_paragraph: The shooting spree in Santa Monica, Calif., on Friday, which left four people and the gunman dead, began on Yorkshire Avenue, where the Fire Department responded at 11:52 a.m. to a report of a structure fire, officials said.

headline: News of U.S. Surveillance Draws Anger of Activists and Militants Abroad
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Activists and militants expressed outrage over the disclosures about the global scope of American data mining and surveillance of private information conveyed over the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Mohamed al-Hadi, an antigovernment activist in Syria, had just received a Skype briefing from rebels about the Ming military airport near the northern city of Aleppo, a protracted battleground in the country’s civil war. Then he learned that the United States government had the ability to monitor that call, as well as a broad range of other information transmitted through the Internet.

headline: Weather Muddles Belmont Outlook
abstract: Rain has added another twist to Saturday’s mile-and-a-half Belmont Stakes, but several contenders should benefit from a wet track.
lead_paragraph: There will be no Triple Crown on the line for the 145th running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday and perhaps very little sunshine thanks to Tropical Storm Andrea. But there will be plenty on the line as the Kentucky Derby winner Orb has a chance to avenge his loss to Oxbow in the Preakness Stakes.

abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, June 8, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “Nobody is listening to your telephone calls.”

headline: Administration Says Mining of Data Is Crucial to Fight Terror
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Terrorism', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'Privacy', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The foiling of a 2009 plot to bomb the New York City subway  seemed to be the kind of success President Obama was referring to when he defended “modest encroachments on privacy” to protect the country.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In early September 2009, an e-mail passed through an Internet address in Peshawar, Pakistan, that was being monitored by the vast computers controlled by American intelligence analysts. It set off alarms. The address, linked to senior Qaeda operatives, had been dormant for months.

abstract: Four senators wrote a letter to the court asking it to provide summaries of its opinions on domestic spying, but the court resisted.  Here is the letter from the senators and the response from the court.
lead_paragraph: Four senators wrote a letter to the court asking it to provide summaries of its opinions on domestic spying, but the court resisted.  Here is the letter from the senators and the response from the court.

keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Terrorism', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Editorials']
abstract: Call logs and e-mail should be collected only for those under suspicion of terrorism.
lead_paragraph: Over the last three years, several measures were introduced in Congress that would have helped reduce or eliminate the abuses of communications surveillance revealed this week. Every one of them was voted down.

headline: The I.M.F. Admits Mistakes. Will Europe?
abstract: The International Monetary Fund says it was too optimistic about Greece’s debt and the effect of spending cuts.
lead_paragraph: The International Monetary Fund admitted this week that it made big errors in the first bailout of Greece three years ago, but it added that no matter what it did then the country would have suffered a deep recession. European Union officials, by contrast, still refuse to concede that their handling of the financial crisis has been deeply flawed.

headline: Many Rival Nations Surge Past the U.S. in Adding New Jobs
abstract: While the United States economy is performing relatively well, the nation has fared worse than six of the nine countries surveyed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics in job gains.
lead_paragraph: The American economy may be the world’s biggest, but when it comes to job creation since the recession hit at the end of 2007, it is far from a leader.

headline: What’s All the Fuss About Bikes?
abstract: There is a lot of unnecessary anxiety and hyperventilating over a bike-sharing program that is indisputably a good thing for New York City.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers will tolerate almost anything, including obvious inconveniences like overcrowded subways. Why, then, all the anxiety and hyperventilating over something that is indisputably a good thing: the short-term bicycle rentals that have become available in parts of the city?

headline: Happy Belmont Day
abstract: Dean Chang writes that “one particularly enduring, comfortable bond that I share with my parents is tied to one thing: gambling on horse racing.”
lead_paragraph: Saturday is not a particularly noteworthy day in my life; no birthdays or anniversaries to commemorate, no real attached significance at all.

headline: Racial Injustice in North Carolina
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Law and Legislation', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Editorials']
abstract: Repealing the state’s Racial Justice Act does not erase the irrefutable proof of bias in death penalty prosecutions.
lead_paragraph: The North Carolina Legislature repealed the state’s Racial Justice Act this week, and the Republican governor, Pat McCrory, is expected to sign the bill. But the state cannot erase the detailed and irrefutable proof of ugly racial bias that led a state trial judge to resentence four death row inmates to life without parole because of this statute.

headline: Collegial Charcuterie
abstract: The fare at Swine tends toward artisanal charcuterie and small-production wines and the clientele is varied.
lead_paragraph: Swine, a pork-based place at 531 Hudson Street in the West Village, is one of those establishments that pack a full menu of gastronomic trends into a fashionably monosyllabic name. On the one hand, the owners of the year-old restaurant have described it as a neighborhood dive and, indeed, there is a pinball machine beside the bar and a vintage Ping-Pong table in the basement playfully reclaimed for communal dining. On the other hand, the fare tends toward artisanal charcuterie and small-production wines. The clientele is similarly varied, including, on a recent evening, some European tourists, a liquor distributor and his date, and a group of seven lawyers who had dropped by to visit one of the proprietors, Cris Criswell, who, until three months ago, was working at their firm.

headline: Nuclear Power Plant in Limbo Decides to Close
abstract: Southern California’s San Onofre power plant had not run since radioactive steam escaped from damaged tubes in 2012, and the owners decided to close it permanently, citing the high cost of not running.

lead_paragraph: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — President Obama, midway through much-anticipated weekend talks with President Xi Jinping of China, said Friday night that there was no parallel between the cyberattacks on American businesses and government interests that it blames on China and the United States government’s surveillance of phone and Internet traffic to foil terrorists.

headline: ‘A Giant Among Pygmies’
abstract: Joe Durso doesn’t let his relatively low profile as a one-wall Brooklyn handball champion interfere with his self-confidence, or his trash-talking.
lead_paragraph: For 40 years, Joe Durso, 58, has been strutting and fretting upon the Seaside Courts next to the Boardwalk in Coney Island, the mecca of one-wall handball, and a place that claims Mr. Durso as perhaps its greatest and most frustrated player.

headline: How to Monetize Plagiarism
abstract: So Jonah Lehrer has a book deal. This is a column about second chances. Earned or not.
lead_paragraph: This is a column about Jonah Lehrer, the 31-year-old disgraced former New Yorker writer who recently — sigh — landed a contract for a book about love. (Yes, love.) But I want to start by recalling another disgraced former magazine writer: Stephen Glass.

headline: China: Arrests in Poultry Factory Fire
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Poultry', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The president of a poultry processing company and its general manager have been arrested in the factory fire that killed at least 120 people and injured at least 77 others this week.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Jilin Province have made two arrests in the investigation of a poultry factory fire that killed at least 120 people and injured at least 77 others this week, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency. One of the men arrested was Jia Yushan, owner and president of Baoyuanfeng, the poultry processing company. The second man arrested was Zhang Yushen, the general manager. The company’s bank account and the assets of Mr. Jia have been frozen, and the factory’s license has been revoked, according to the Xinhua report, which was published Thursday. Survivors of the fire described encountering locked doors that prevented many people from escaping. The factory had been hailed in recent years as a model enterprise by local officials, but the deadly accident underscored the lack of rigorous safety inspections by officials.

headline: Of Slippery Slopes
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Government monitoring of the communications of Americans is not a left-right thing. It is a right-wrong thing.
lead_paragraph: Maybe I’m a bit pessimistic when it comes to governmental paternalism and the unrelenting erosion of civil liberties, but I’ve always assumed that someone or something — including the government — is tracking, or could track, everything I do in an increasing virtual reality.

headline: Mets Add Another Game to Their Growing To-Do List
abstract: Friday’s game was the sixth Mets game postponed because of inclement weather. Rain, snow and cold temperatures have created a slew of postponed games this season.
lead_paragraph: Be it subfreezing temperatures, heavy snow or hammering rains, the Mets have faced Mother Nature’s worst this season.

headline: Peru: Ex-President Is Denied a Pardon
abstract: President Ollanta Humala said that he would grant a pardon to former President Alberto Fujimori, who is serving a prison sentence for human rights violations and corruption.
lead_paragraph: President Ollanta Humala said Friday that he had decided not to grant a pardon to former President Alberto Fujimori, who is serving a prison sentence for human rights violations and corruption. Mr. Fujimori, left, has tongue cancer and other health problems; his family had requested the pardon in October, saying it was justified for medical reasons. Mr. Humala, who ran against Mr. Fujimori’s eldest daughter, Keiko Fujimori, when he was elected in 2011, said that he reviewed material from doctors who examined Mr. Fujimori and took into account the nature of the former president’s crimes. A presidential commission had previously recommended against giving Mr. Fujimori a pardon. Mr. Fujimori was president from 1990 to 2000, when he led a successful fight against the Shining Path guerrilla group. In 2009 he was sentenced to 25 years in prison for overseeing death squads involved in two massacres that killed a total of 25 people.

headline: Bike Share’s One-Track App
abstract: The developers of the Citi Bike app have made a no-nonsense product whose primary concern is to get you riding as quickly as possible.
lead_paragraph: Ah, to ride a bike through the streets of New York! The wind in your hair, a stench in your nose, the invigorating fear that your legs will give out, causing you to tumble backward down the steep slope of the Williamsburg Bridge.

headline: The Blackhawks’ Bickell Outperforms Star Teammates
abstract: Bryan Bickell’s eight goals tie him with his Chicago teammate Patrick Sharp for the second most in the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When the Chicago Blackhawks won the Stanley Cup in 2010, left wing Bryan Bickell did not meet N.H.L. requirements to have his name etched on the trophy. Should Chicago win the Cup in 2013, he might also see his name hammered onto the Conn Smythe Trophy, awarded to the player judged most valuable to his team during the playoffs.

headline: Ex-Councilman in Capital Is Charged With Bribery
abstract: Michael A. Brown was charged with a single count of bribery for taking $55,000 from F.B.I. agents purporting to seek his help in gaining city certification as a local business.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former city councilor was charged with bribery on Friday after being accused of accepting cash from federal agents posing as business owners, rekindling attention to a long-simmering corruption inquiry of the District of Columbia government.

headline: Biking to Work, and Around It
abstract: Leslie Koch, president of the Trust for Governors Island, pedals there each weekend — but not before walking her dog, gardening and doing Pilates.
lead_paragraph: When Governors Island opened for the season last month, it meant a change of schedule for Leslie Koch: Until the island closes at the end of September, she works weekends, bicycling to the free ferry, then touring the island’s 172 acres on pedal power. Ms. Koch, 51, is the president of the Trust for Governors Island, a nonprofit organization created by the city in 2010. She never knows what she’ll find on her rounds. “If someone’s carrying something odd,” she said, “you just say it’s an art project, and usually you’re right.” She lives in a brownstone in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, with her husband, Douglas Grey, who produces entertainment for cruise ships, and an English golden retriever named Clara.

headline: Teixeira Is Making Life Easier for Cano at the Plate
abstract: With the Yankees’ switch- and power-hitting first baseman Mark Teixeira back from a wrist injury, Robinson Cano is seeing better pitches to hit.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — It wasn’t long after Robinson Cano slapped hands with Mark Teixeira at home plate after a three-run homer Thursday night that Teixeira turned his attention to the pitcher and followed with a blast of his own.

headline: Roll Tape, Curtain Up
abstract: The Theater on Film and Tape Archive tapes about 50 Broadway, Off Broadway and regional theater performances each year.
lead_paragraph: The Theater on Film and Tape Archive tapes about 50 Broadway, Off Broadway and regional theater performances each year.

headline: After the Final Curtain, Act II
abstract: The Theater on Film and Tape Archive records dozens of live performances each year in an effort to preserve the magic of live theater and give people the chance to see performances that otherwise would be lost to history.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Thursday evening, a blue-and-white GMC motor home with tinted windows was parked in front of the Stephen Sondheim Theater on West 43rd Street. Cables ran from it, up over the theater marquee, through a window, and down into the theater, where they plugged into three cameras set up to record the evening’s performance of “The Trip to Bountiful,” which has four Tony nominations heading into Sunday night’s awards ceremony.

headline: Want to Play at a Different College? O.K., but Not There or There
abstract: The use of transfer rules to eliminate many of an athlete’s preferred options illustrates the big-business mind-set of college sports and the control that coaches have over players.
lead_paragraph: When a quarterback decided last month to transfer to another football program after one season at Oklahoma State, he thanked the coach, who thanked him back. Here were two parties seemingly in mutual agreement, on good terms, headed for an amicable divorce.

headline: The Secrets of Nadal’s Success
abstract: For a while a couple of years ago, it seemed as if Novak Djokovic owned Rafael Nadal. But the Spaniard regrouped, and on Friday at Roland Garros he scored one of his most memorable victories.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, Novak Djokovic solved the riddle of Rafael Nadal on all three surfaces, besting Nadal on clay (Rome finals), grass (a decisive four-set victory in the Wimbledon final) and on hard courts (another solid four setter at Flushing Meadow). Nadal looked at once beleaguered and confused by Djokovic’s technical and tactical mastery, as if stymied by the puzzle of how to solve the Djokovic problem. One of Nadal’s favorite words at news conferences is “solutions,” but he seemed at a loss for words when he tried to explain how he was losing Grand Slam finals to someone other than Roger Federer.

headline: The Hazards of Hecklers
abstract: Mark Leibovich on prominent and recent cases of political heckling, and the risks that come from engaging hostile interlopers.
lead_paragraph: Mark Leibovich on prominent and recent cases of political heckling, and the risks that come from engaging hostile interlopers.

keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Speeches and Statements', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: As a senator, Barack Obama was a critic of the Bush administration,  saying it cast a “false choice” between liberty and security. As he engages in his own surveillance efforts, he has spoken of finding a balance.
lead_paragraph: As a senator, Barack Obama was a critic of the Bush administration,  saying it cast a “false choice” between liberty and security. As he engages in his own surveillance efforts, he has spoken of finding a balance.

headline: Less Than a Fair Share
abstract: A determination to embrace the new program turns to dismay as bikes prove hard to acquire and free helmets are squandered on some who can well afford them.
lead_paragraph: If you found yourself harboring skepticism or vague negativity toward the city’s newly initiated bike-sharing program, it is possible that you were suddenly moved to defend it after witnessing The Wall Street Journal’s recent video interview with Dorothy Rabinowitz, an editorial board member who spent four minutes making crazy-lady assertions about cycling’s hold on New York.

lead_paragraph: The Arab population in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is the latest in a series of Arab enclaves appearing in New York City.

lead_paragraph: People strolling for the first time on Northern Boulevard in Queens could be forgiven for thinking they had somehow been magically transported to Seoul.

headline: Harriet Tubman’s Great Raid
abstract: The hero of the Underground Railroad and her role in a mission to liberate hundreds of South Carolina slaves.
lead_paragraph: It is arguably the most beautiful scene ever recorded in war. Two Union gunboats, the Harriet A. Weed and the John Adams, converted ferryboats, churning up the Combahee River with their big side paddlewheels. Steam whistles signal, while in the bow of the Adams, a small, powerful woman is… singing. From all around, hundreds hear Harriett Tubman’s call and run for the boats, for freedom. At least 727 men, women and children escape, mothers carrying babies, including one pair of twins: the largest liberation of slaves in American history.

headline: Little Guyana in Queens
abstract: No place has acquired as intense a Guyanese flavor as Liberty Avenue, the lively commercial corridor that divides Richmond Hill and South Ozone Park.
lead_paragraph: No place has acquired as intense a Guyanese flavor as Liberty Avenue, the lively commercial corridor that divides Richmond Hill and South Ozone Park.

headline: As Bruins Reach Finals, Empty Feeling for Penguins

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The way the game was going, with goals at an absolute premium, the first one, whenever it came, seemed destined to be the only one. And so it was.

headline: After Brief Stumble, a Step Closer to Brazil

lead_paragraph: KINGSTON, Jamaica — The National Stadium here is nicknamed the Office, a place where the United States took care of business in stunning fashion on Friday night as frustration whipped into elation.

headline: Player Ratings: Jamaica 1, U.S. 2
abstract: Rating the performance of the American players in Friday’s World Cup qualifying match at Jamaica.
lead_paragraph: Three World Cup qualifiers without a defeat — two wins and a draw — with two home games to come. With a possible six points from those two (Panama and Honduras), the United States can probably book its reservations for Brazil. Seems like a long way from the angst and hand-wringing after the first game in the Hex, a loss at Honduras.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Nickelodeon) SAM & CAT Jennette McCurdy, who portrayed Sam Puckett on “iCarly,” and Ariana Grande, who played Cat Valentine in “Victorious,” team up in this crossover spinoff comedy about girls who meet cute in the back of a garbage truck, become best friends and roommates, and then go entrepreneurial with Sam & Cat’s Super Rockin’ Fun-Time Baby-Sitting Service. Above, from left, Cameron Ocasio, Ms. McCurdy and Ms. Grande in a scene from the show.

headline: China’s Export Growth Slows Amid Concern of Slowdown
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Chinese exports showed only modest growth in May, rising just 1 percent from a year earlier, officials said Saturday, an increase that was much lower than analysts’ expectations.

headline: 100 Percent of the Game Is Half Mental
abstract: David Ferrer advanced to the final by beating Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, who may have thought himself into defeat.
lead_paragraph: I thought of a wonderful little article by Allen Fox, the former Pepperdine men’s tennis coach who played at the highest levels of the game and has since become the eminence grise of sports psychologists, as I watched the immensely likeable and charismatic Frenchman, Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, play David Ferrer on Friday in a men’s semifinal at the French Open. Fox recounts the 2000 Wimbledon final between Patrick Rafter and Pete Sampras. Like all of Fox’s writings, the difficult and painful truths that tennis exposes are laid out like a cadaver awaiting a scalpel. Fox describes how each player allows the score — and their emotions relating to that score — to influence how they play and, even more importantly, their level of motivation as they compete in the match.

headline: A Rain-Soaked Kickoff to the Governors Ball
abstract: A deluge on Randalls Island shows how bad weather can make a music festival less than the sum of its parts.
lead_paragraph: The direst words on a concert ticket are “rain or shine.” They certainly were on Friday, the first of three days of the Governors Ball Music Festival on Randalls Island.

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 8
abstract: Europe on U.S. surveillance; the meaning of Taksim Square; business hopes in Myanmar; and tennis showdown in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Europe’s reaction Friday to news of a sweeping international digital surveillance program by the U.S. government ranged from the outrage of citizens and politicians to the muted envy of some law enforcement agencies on this side of the Atlantic. Privacy is an emotional issue in Europe, where memories of state-sponsored snooping by communist and fascist regimes still linger. And so the revelation Thursday that the U.S. National Security Agency had obtained routine access to e-mail, Web searches and other online data from many of the biggest U.S. Internet companies — whose users stretch far beyond U.S. shores — prompted hand-wringing about America’s moral authority. “If the U.S. complains about foreign governments spying and then it turns out it is doing the same thing — well, what are you complaining about?” said Yaman Akdeniz, a law professor at Istanbul Bilgi University in Turkey, where anger over restrictions on civil liberties has fueled anti-government protests. Eric Pfanner reports from Serraval, France and James Kanter reports from Brussels.

headline: Two Mariners Catch Fire as Kuroda Melts Down
abstract: Jason Bay and Brendan Ryan entered Friday with a mere 26 R.B.I. between them, but they drove in four in the fourth inning of the Mariners’ win over the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — With a mere 26 runs batted in entering Friday, Jason Bay and Brendan Ryan of the Seattle Mariners had fewer R.B.I. combined than three Yankees — Robinson Cano, Travis Hafner and Lyle Overbay — had individually. They were tied with Brett Gardner.

headline: Mandela Is Hospitalized Again, Deepening Worries Over Frailty
abstract: The former South African leader Nelson Mandela was in “serious but stable condition,” the government said.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Former President Nelson Mandela of South Africa was hospitalized early Saturday to be treated for a recurring lung infection, the South African government said. It was the fourth time in less than a year that the 94-year-old anti-apartheid leader has been hospitalized, deepening concern about his increasing frailty.

headline: The Weekend Word: Surveillance
abstract: Political news from today’s Times, plus a look at the weekly addresses and the latest happenings in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Times

headline: Serving Up Our 2013 Belmont Picks
abstract: The Rail’s contributors and a guest picker make their Belmont selections.
lead_paragraph: The Rail’s contributors welcome this year’s Belmont Stakes guest picker, the celebrity chef and horse owner Bobby Flay. Flay, the original guest picker on The Rail, was honored Thursday night with the Earle I. Mack Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation Champion Award, given to an individual for outstanding efforts and influence on thoroughbred racehorse welfare, safety and retirement. Flay, a newly appointed board member of the New York Racing Association, has raised hundreds of thousands of dollars for thoroughbred retirement and is an outspoken proponent of owner responsibility to their horses.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
abstract: A round-up of news from across India.
lead_paragraph: Jammu and Kashmir: An Indian soldier was killed Friday in an incident of unprovoked firing from across the cease-fire line with Pakistan near the Poonch sector, about 110 miles southwest of the summer capital, Srinagar, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Big Data Is Watching You
abstract: Slate’s new column on the interaction of Big Data with our daily lives.
lead_paragraph: A few days before the story broke about the National Security Agency mining the data of citizens using Verizon, I walked by a newsstand and saw an issue of Foreign Affairs that had a feature on Big Data. I bought it. When I got onto Metro North, the man across the aisle was reading a book, its title: “Big Data.” We were both reading print media, I thought to myself: No trace. Unless we paid with our credit cards? I checked my e-mail before diving into the feature in Foreign Affairs: An e-mail from a friend, telling me she had a story idea for me. About Big Data. No doubt, all the outraged electronic references so many of us are suddenly making back and forth to each other about Big Data (on Facebook, Twitter, etc.) are being mined by various private and governmental institutions, revealing, via syntax, frequency and context, not only how we’ll probably vote in 2016 but also what brand of hair conditioner we prefer.

headline: Urban Trees as Triggers, From Istanbul to Oregon
keywords: ['Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Environment', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Politics and Government', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: When leaders crack down in fights over scarce urban trees, trouble follows.
lead_paragraph: As street protests spread across Turkey following an initial clash between police and demonstrators over the imperiled sycamore trees of Gezi Park (a rare green patch in the sprawl of central Istanbul), I was reminded of “If a Tree Falls,” the fine Oscar-nominated documentary on the roots of the Earth Liberation Front (Dot Earth coverage).

headline: 3 Americans and an Italian Killed in Afghan Attacks
abstract: In one attack, an Afghan soldier opened fire on international troops serving with him in eastern Afghanistan, officials said, killing two American soldiers and a civilian. In the second attack, an Italian soldier was killed when a grenade was thrown at him.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two American soldiers and an American civilian working with them were killed in a so-called insider attack on Saturday in Afghanistan, officials said. In a second attack on international forces, an Italian soldier was killed when a grenade was thrown at him.

headline: Depressing Draghi
abstract: He can’t be that naive, can he?
lead_paragraph: A correspondent directs me, despairingly, to the last part of Mario Draghi’s latest press conference — and the correspondent is right, it does give cause for despair. Draghi is, after all, as smart and flexible an ECB president as we’re likely to get for a long time; quite possibly ever, because the euro might not last. Yet what he has to say about inflation manages to be wrong on multiple levels, and this kind of thing has to be damaging to ECB policy.

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Williams Wins French Open Title
abstract: Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova will meet in the final of a Grand Slam for the third time.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams captured her most elusive title, beating Maria Sharapova, 6-4, 6-4, to win her second French Open title and her 16th Grand Slam title over all. Williams, 31, won 11 years to the day after her first title at Roland Garros and is the oldest French Open champion in the open era.

headline: Following Up on Poverty Coverage in The Times
abstract: Some commentary and resources for those interested in a troubling topic, poverty.
lead_paragraph: I heard from many readers after I wrote last Sunday about The Times’s coverage of poverty. I’ve rarely received more feedback on a column, and I appreciate the many thoughtful comments and e-mails.

headline: Syrian Opposition to Sit Out Any Talks Unless Arms Are Sent, General Says
abstract: The proposal to hold talks in Geneva at a point when the Syrian opposition has suffered a bitter reversal has led many in the opposition to question the West’s strategy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Syrian opposition will not attend the proposed Geneva conference on the crisis in Syria unless rebel fighters receive new supplies of arms and ammunition, the top rebel military commander said Friday.

headline: Turkey Turns to Taksim
abstract: Michael Kimmelman examines why Istanbul's Taksim Square evolved into the urban fissure that is growing in Turkish society.
lead_paragraph: Michael Kimmelman examines why Istanbul's Taksim Square evolved into the urban fissure that is growing in Turkish society.

headline: Crisis Withdrawal Syndrome
abstract: Take pity on the poor bereft hawks.
lead_paragraph: Dean Baker complains, as he often does (and correctly so), about “reporting” on the fiscal outlook that reads a lot like editorializing — indeed, like a sponsored ad from Pete Peterson. But maybe he should show a bit of human sympathy: these guys are basically addicts trying to get off the stuff, and maybe it’s too much to expect them to go cold turkey.

headline: Early Leader in Polls Usually Wins New York Mayoral Primary
abstract: The early Democratic frontrunner in recent New York City mayoral races has a near perfect record in going on to win the party’s nomination, according to an analysis of polls conducted since 1989.
lead_paragraph: The early Democratic front-runner in recent New York City mayoral races has a near perfect record in going on to win the party’s nomination, according to an analysis of public opinion surveys conducted since 1989. If that pattern holds true in this year’s race, Speaker Christine C. Quinn of the City Council will very likely win the Democratic nomination in September. She has led in every primary poll conducted in 2013.

headline: U.S. and China Move Closer on North Korea, but Not on Cyberespionage
abstract: President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China ended two days of informal meetings, moving closer on pressuring a nuclear North Korea, but remaining divided over cyberespionage.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — Even as they pledged to build “a new model” of relations, President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China ended two days of informal meetings here on Saturday moving closer on pressuring a nuclear North Korea and addressing climate change, but remaining sharply divided over cyberespionage and other issues that have divided the countries for years.

headline: Chinese Link 47 Deaths in Bus Blast to a Suicide
abstract: Reports about the explosion aboard a bus in the southeastern city of Xiamen identified the man as Chen Shuizong, who was about 60 and unemployed.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — An unemployed man intent on killing himself set off an explosion that engulfed a bus in flames and killed 47 people in the southeastern city of Xiamen on Friday, according to reports on Saturday by state-run news organizations.

headline: Williams Rejoices, in French, After Winning 16th Grand Slam
abstract: Serena Williams won the French Open by topping the defending champion Maria Sharapova. At 31, she has won 16 Grand Slam singles events, and appears nowhere near finished.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Serena Williams has tried to master French, as she has finally mastered the French Open again. So after she had served five aces in her last seven service points to beat Maria Sharapova, 6-4, 6-4, in Saturday’s final, and had gone down on her knees and put her head to the clay in celebration, Williams kept up her recent habit of making her postmatch remarks to the crowd in the local language.

headline: Largely Forgotten Champion, No Longer Dispassionate, Will Return as Host
abstract: It pains David Graham, especially since he became a heart patient, to acknowledge that for many years, he treated golf as a matter of life or death.
lead_paragraph: WHITEFISH, Mont. — In the cedar dining room of Iron Horse Golf Club, David Graham sat with a glass of red wine and reminisced about his career, which included victories at the P.G.A. Championship and the United States Open. His eyes welled with tears as he talked about the illness that caused him to retire and forced him to confront his mortality.

headline: The Titles He Won, the Things They Lost
abstract: Just as Michael Jordan spent a decade dashing the title hopes of Patrick Ewing, Charles Barkley, and others, so too has Tim Duncan stymied the stars of his era.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — On the day he was hired as the Boston Celtics’ coach in May 1997, Rick Pitino had thick black hair, a swagger in his step and a pocket full of Ping-Pong balls stamped with Tim Duncan’s name.

headline: Variety: A Tasty Diagramless

lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I do love a good fruit salad, and that appears to be what Fred Piscop has in store for us today, especially in the southeast, where the sliced PEAR gets incorporated into a GRAPE ARBOR.

headline: Questions Linger About Death of Former Quarterback
abstract: Cullen Finnerty, one of the most successful quarterbacks in college football history, was found dead in the Michigan woods. That’s when the search for answers began.
lead_paragraph: BALDWIN, Mich. — The search started the night of May 26, a Sunday, when Cullen Finnerty went missing in the woods here, amid towering white pines and shrubby scrub oak trees and owls and white-tailed deer. By Monday morning, helicopters circled overhead as cadaver dogs combed through the brush below.

headline: Dumped by Mets, Perez Revives His Career as Mariner

headline: Some Baby Steps on Money Funds

headline: Ariel Kaminer Says What’s Meh
abstract: One of The Times’s dogged Metro reporters, and a former magazine Ethicist, assumes a new state of mind for a special assignment.
lead_paragraph: The Meh List continues its newsroom tour this week with a contribution from Ariel Kaminer. You may remember her as the magazine’s moral compass when she wrote weekly columns as The Ethicist. Now she’s a reporter on the Metro desk. But even the pressure of a daily beat could not prepare her for the speed of the Meh List. ” ‘Overnight’ sounded preposterous when you first asked me to write the list,” Kaminer wrote in an e-mail meditation on the grueling demands made of a Meh List columnist, “but it turns out meh is a psychological state that can be attained — by qualified experts, of course — and exited again in about 10 minutes.”

headline: Trying, and Failing, to Host an Alcohol-Free Party for Teenagers
keywords: ['ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Parenting', 'Parties (Social)', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: I thought I had discovered the secrets to preventing teen substance abuse at parties — until two uniformed police officers rang my doorbell.
lead_paragraph: When my 18-year-old son begged: “Mom. Please. Can we please have an end-of-summer party?” I wanted to be someone other than the humorless mother who had drug-tested him since he got caught with marijuana in eighth grade. After missing the signs of his pot smoking, and those of my former husband’s cocaine addiction years ago, my vow never to be duped again had put a damper on merrymaking.

headline: This Week in the Global Arts Guide
abstract: The Israel Museum in Jerusalem has brought together the work of 100 photographers whose work was influenced by their identities as immigrants and outsiders.
lead_paragraph: By choice or by necessity, photographers are quite often outsiders, and some of the best ones use that vantage to reveal the world anew. Propelled into unfamiliar environments, the 100 selected photographers in Displaced Visions: Emigré Photographers of the 20th Century at the Israel Museum in Jerusalem illustrate in their works how their status and native culture affected their vision of the world. On view are photos by Bill Brandt, Andre Kertesz, Tina Modotti, Man Ray, Robert Frank, Moholy-Nagy and Weegee, among many others. The show runs through Sept. 29.

headline: Lots of Nutrition in Tiny Packages: Itty-Bitty Grains and Seeds
abstract: Cooking with millet, teff, amaranth and chia seeds isn’t foolproof, but these recipes pay delicious dividends.
lead_paragraph: This week I worked with tiny grains and seeds: millet and teff, amaranth and chia seeds. These can be challenging, and I had a few starts and stops along the way until I came up with a collection of recipes I was pleased with, including some delicious, moist savory pancakes made with beet greens and cooked amaranth. I continued working with chia seeds; this time I didn’t soak them, and added them to whole-grain muffins and pancakes. That’s how I used to use chia seeds way back when, before they disappeared for a few decades from the whole-foods scene. You can raise the nutritional content of your whole-grain pastries and breads just by adding 3 or 4 tablespoons; along with their considerable nutrients, the seeds contribute interesting texture like that of poppy seeds.

headline: The Confidence Fairy, The Expectations Imp, and the Rate-Hike Obsession
abstract: A hope versus a plan.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong has a long meditation on policy that, surprisingly, includes some things I strongly disagree with. I guess I should start by saying that when he describes his fairly complacent view of macroeconomics on the eve of the crisis, he’s describing a view that many economists shared — but I wasn’t one of them. Japan’s troubles and the Asian financial crisis destroyed my faith that we had the business cycle under control; I wrote a whole book about the return of depression economics back in 1999.
