headline: Harvey Feeling Fine After Exiting Game With Back Tightness
abstract: If there was one positive for the Mets to take from Saturday’s marathon 20-inning 2-1 loss to the Miami Marlins it was that Matt Harvey did not turn out to be seriously hurt. Harvey, who exited Saturday’s game after the seventh inning with lower back tightness, will not miss a start
lead_paragraph: If there was one positive for the Mets to take from Saturday’s marathon 20-inning 2-1 loss to the Miami Marlins it was that Matt Harvey did not turn out to be seriously hurt. Harvey, who exited Saturday’s game after the seventh inning with lower back tightness, will not miss a start.

headline: At Theme Parks, a V.I.P. Ticket to Ride
keywords: ['AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: As stratification becomes more pronounced in all corners of America, theme parks have adopted a tiered model, with special access and perks for those willing to pay.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. — Theme parks have traditionally been the ultimate melting pots. Tourists, retirees, rowdy teenagers, families and fathers who would rather be golfing are all thrown together in an egalitarian experience in which the line for one is the line for all, and cotton candy is the food of the masses.

headline: Ex-Worker at C.I.A. Says He Leaked Data on Surveillance
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: A British newspaper identified its source as Edward Snowden, a former C.I.A. employee who has worked at the National Security Agency as a contractor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A 29-year-old former C.I.A. computer technician went public on Sunday as the source behind the daily drumbeat of disclosures about the nation’s surveillance programs, saying he took the extraordinary step because “the public needs to decide whether these programs and policies are right or wrong.”

headline: Animal Kingdom a Favorite in Britain Ahead of Royal Ascot
abstract: Animal Kingdom is fast becoming a favorite among the British betting public. He is a favorite in the ante-post betting markets for the Queen Anne Stakes (Group 1) on the opening day at Royal Ascot, being offered at 4-5 and even money in places.
lead_paragraph: Animal Kingdom is fast becoming a favorite among the British betting public. He is a favorite in the ante-post betting markets for the Queen Anne Stakes (Group 1) on the opening day at Royal Ascot, being offered at 4-5 and even money in places. Those are short odds for a foreign invader, in a race that is more than a week away. Britons love their ante-post wagering ahead of big events.

headline: Floods Hit Part of Budapest, as a German City Is Threatened
abstract: A wet spring has swollen rivers across Hungary, Germany, Austria and the Czech Republic, forcing evacuations, disrupting traffic and causing major damage.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — The Danube, which normally bisects Budapest as a gently rolling swath of silver, spilled over its banks Sunday, claiming the Hungarian capital as the latest victim of record floods in Central and Eastern Europe.

headline: Ranked No. 4, but Outside Big Four
abstract: David Ferrer will assume the fourth spot in the rankings, one ahead of his countryman Rafael Nadal, who beat him in the French Open final. But Ferrer remains outside the big four of men’s tennis.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It is one of the quirks of tennis that David Ferrer will wake up Monday morning ahead of Rafael Nadal by at least one measure. Just not the one that matters most.

headline: In a Twist on the Remix, Fans Recut TV Series
abstract: New viewing technologies have allowed fans of television series like “Arrested Development” and “Game of Thrones” to completely revise the sequence of scenes and then repost the series online.
lead_paragraph: When the new season of the television comedy “Arrested Development” was released on Netflix on May 26, Andy Gilleand, a 26-year-old student in Mishawaka, Ind., watched all 15 episodes in a single eight-hour session.

headline: Intelligence Agencies and the Data Deluge
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Politicians say intelligence agencies are just looking at the metadata, not the content, of traffic. But in many cases metadata matters more than content.
lead_paragraph: Political leaders including President Obama and Senator Dianne Feinstein in recent days have defended snooping on private communications by noting that intelligence agencies were not reading personal messages, but rather information about the messages. “This is just metadata,” Senator Feinstein said at a news conference. “There is no content involved.”

headline: ‘Kinky Boots’ and ‘Vanya’ Take Top Tonys
abstract: Dave Itzkoff and Charles Isherwood live blogged the 67th annual Tony Awards on Sunday night
lead_paragraph: Tonight Dave Itzkoff and Charles Isherwood live blogged the 67th annual Tony Awards on Sunday night, with others contributing photos and reports from the performance.

headline: Nadal Wins His Eighth French Open
abstract: Rafael Nadal defeated his fellow countryman David Ferrer in straight sets, becoming the first man to win a Grand Slam event eight times.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Nadal defeated his fellow countryman David Ferrer in straight sets, becoming the first man to win a Grand Slam event eight times.

headline: Skewered Again, That Erotic Page Turner
abstract: “Cuff Me! The Fifty Shades of Grey Unauthorized Musical Parody” joins a cottage industry devoted to E. L. James’s wildly successful novel.
lead_paragraph: How much sport can there be in taking aim at as big a target as E. L. James’s erotic novel “Fifty Shades of Grey”? That thought came to mind Wednesday night at the Actors Temple Theater, while I was watching “Cuff Me! The Fifty Shades of Grey Unauthorized Musical Parody.”

headline: The Nation’s Ballet Talent, From Pliant to Virtuosic
abstract: The Kennedy Center’s Ballet Across America series presented troupes from Pennsylvania, Washington and Sarasota, Fla.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The range of ballet at the Kennedy Center is unequaled anywhere else in America. Next year, for example, Russia’s leading two companies (the Mariinsky and the Bolshoi), New York’s top two (New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater) and three other major American troupes will all dance here. And the playing of the Kennedy Center Opera House Orchestra, though it is often coping with unfamiliar fare, surpasses that of any New York ballet institution.

headline: Emoting and Belting, From Holiday to Prince
abstract: The singer Morgan James performed material ranging from Billie Holiday to Prince at her show at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: What do you call a singer as heatedly compelling as Morgan James, who is currently playing Teena Marie on Broadway in “Motown: the Musical”? Somehow, the description “neo-white soul singer” sounds inadequate to evoke the steam she elicited last Monday from songs associated with Billie Holiday, Nina Simone, Prince and others at 54 Below.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Data to be released include wholesale trade inventories, job openings and labor turnover on Tuesday, and the Treasury’s monthly statement on the federal budget on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released include wholesale trade inventories, job openings and labor turnover, and the Small Business Optimism Index from the National Federation of Independent Business (Tuesday); the Treasury’s monthly statement on the federal budget (Wednesday); retail sales for May, initial jobless claims, weekly mortgage rates, the import price index, and business inventories (Thursday); and the producer price index, industrial production, and the University of Michigan’s preliminary consumer sentiment index (Friday).

headline: Inside the Russian Courtroom, With Artists on Trial
abstract: “Pussy Riot: A Punk Prayer” includes images that will be new to most American viewers, including scenes inside the trial of the women convicted of hooliganism.
lead_paragraph: The polished documentary “Pussy Riot: A Punk Prayer” champions the three women, members of the Russian feminist collective Pussy Riot, whose conviction on charges of hooliganism in 2012 became an international cause célèbre. It’s persuasive, but not as emotional or stirring as you might expect. The Pussy Riot story as presented here is largely about theater, and there’s a sense of distance while we watch one variety of performance after another — cultural, political, judicial — being played out.

headline: Take Quirky, Add Shrewd: Sparks Fly
abstract: “King & Maxwell,” a new detective series on TNT starring Jon Tenney and Rebecca Romijn, has a comic undertow.
lead_paragraph: “King & Maxwell,” a private-investigator series that begins Monday on TNT, has some zip to it, but whether it catches your interest might depend on how invested you already are in the various other guy-gal shows on television, because it looks exactly like them.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'States (US)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Schoenberg’s Bad Boy Turns 100, Too
abstract: The soprano Lucy Shelton offered a haunting, arresting interpretation of Schoenberg’s “Pierrot Lunaire” at Merkin Concert Hall.
lead_paragraph: Complaints are sometimes made about the manners of contemporary audiences, particularly regarding the use of cellphones during events. But modern listeners, given to polite ovations, are tame compared with their vociferous early 20th-century predecessors, who booed and hissed during the premiere of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring.” The centennial of that revolutionary work this season has overshadowed the 100th birthday of another groundbreaking score — Schoenberg’s “Pierrot Lunaire.”

headline: Two Koreas to Discuss Restoring Economic Ties
abstract: The agreement was a clear sign that North and South Korea were easing tensions and moving toward a thaw after years of recriminations that hit a peak earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North and South Korea agreed Monday to hold high-level government talks later this week to discuss reversing not only the recent suspension of their joint operation of an industrial complex in a Northern border town, but also other economic and humanitarian projects that faltered years ago amid tensions built by North Korean nuclear tests, international sanctions and threats of war.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: USA-1 Bermuda Bowl Selections
abstract: The USA-1 team in this year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship will be John Kranyak, Gavin Wolpert, Kevin Bathurst, Kevin Dwyer and a third pair to be chosen.
lead_paragraph: The USA-1 team in this year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship will be John Kranyak, Gavin Wolpert, Kevin Bathurst, Kevin Dwyer and a third pair to be chosen.

headline: Into the Lives of Three Deserters Who Did Not Have a Good War
abstract: In “The Deserters,” the historian and former ABC News foreign correspondent Charles Glass explores a subject that remained taboo for decades after World War II.
lead_paragraph: Stories about cowardice can be as gripping as those about courage. One tells us about who we’d like to be; the other tells us about who we fear we are.

headline: For Spurs, Every Game Is a Global Summit
abstract: San Antonio has nine players from outside the continental United States, leading one player to describe the team as the United Nations of the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — When the N.B.A. finals began here Thursday, basketball fans across the world were watching, whether it was early in the day or the middle of the night. So it was appropriate that one of the teams on the court was the San Antonio Spurs, with a roster including an N.B.A.-record nine players from outside the continental United States.

headline: Governors Ball Music Festival on Randalls Island
abstract: The festival got off to a rain-soaked start on Friday and then continued through the weekend with an assortment of rock, rap and electronic acts.
lead_paragraph: The festival got off to a rain-soaked start on Friday and then continued through the weekend with an assortment of rock, rap and electronic acts.

headline: Minimalist and Rich, in the Space Between Funk and Classical
abstract: Erykah Badu was backed by the Brooklyn Philharmonic and a rhythm section in two concerts over the weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Erykah Badu didn’t move much in the time she spent onstage at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Howard Gilman Opera House, in front of the Brooklyn Philharmonic and a rhythm section. She stood next to the conductor Alan Pierson in a top hat, high-heel boots, blue tights, heavy necklace, and a long coat, which she never took off. She occasionally made a slow, alert swivel toward the backup singers on her right, with a look of approval. Once she turned 90 degrees and methodically played a solo on a theremin, at her left. That was about it.

headline: From Chopin to Ethiopia, and Partway Back Again
abstract: Girma Yifrashewa, an Ethiopian pianist and composer, played classical fare and his own works at Issue Project Room in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: “Classical music is music without Africa,” Brian Eno bluntly declared in a 1995 interview published in Wired magazine. “It represents old-fashioned hierarchical structures, ranking, all the levels of control,” he said. An art-rock provocateur, Mr. Eno managed to patronize two cultures in a single blow, fetishizing a free-floating independence in African art that he found lacking in rigid European traditions.

headline: An Unusual ‘Goldberg’ and a Footnote to Some ‘Mystery’ Sonatas
abstract: The Met’s Museum Artists played Heinrich Ignaz Franz Biber and Bach at their final season concert at the museum.
lead_paragraph: Metropolitan Museum Artists in Concert ended its 10th critically acclaimed season on Friday evening with an attractive program of Bach and Heinrich Ignaz Franz Biber in the museum’s Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, then promptly closed up shop. That shop, at least.

headline: Weaned on CDs, They’re Reaching for Vinyl
abstract: Vinyl records almost disappeared after CDs were introduced, but they’re making a comeback — and a surprising number of LP buyers are young listeners.
lead_paragraph: Vinyl is growing out of its niche.

headline: Poet Laureate  for a Second Time
abstract: The Library of Congress will announce on Monday that Natasha Trethewey is to be appointed to a second one-year term as the United States poet laureate.
lead_paragraph: The Library of Congress will announce on Monday that Natasha Trethewey is to be appointed to a second one-year term as the United States poet laureate. In her second year Ms. Trethewey will travel the country for a series of reports exploring societal issues through poetry that are to appear on “The PBS NewsHour.” Ms. Trethewey is a professor of English and creative writing at Emory University in Atlanta. She is in the middle of a term as the poet laureate of Mississippi (where she is from), and is writing a memoir, which is due out next year.

headline: Five Key Parenting Lessons from ‘Game of Thrones’
abstract: Let it not be said that “Game of Thrones” holds no educational value: helpful lessons in how not to parent from the Starks and the Lancasters.
lead_paragraph: Sunday, June 9, 2013: As we have every other Sunday these recent months, tonight my husband and I will tuck in our two little girls, kiss their sweet faces goodnight, then rush downstairs to watch men and women get slaughtered.

headline: Casino Cry
abstract: Zhouquin Burnikel wins big.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — The seemingly perennial “PAT PAULSEN for President” campaign was the first time (in my lifetime, as least) that I can remember seeing humor used to poke fun at this country’s political machine. In those days before “The Daily Show” and “The Colbert Report,” it was a revelation to someone who, to put it politely, looks at things differently than her peers, and I remember even as a young child admiring the way Mr. Paulsen skillfully skewered the persona of the pompous politician, all the while being able to think on his feet as he improvised somewhat coherent answers to questions at live press conferences.

headline: Nestlé Adds Premium Brand in Still Water Arena
abstract: Ads for Resource, which are being introduced on Monday, are aimed at a stylish, higher income woman.
lead_paragraph: DRINKING tap water is essentially free, but even during the economic downturn, consumers have sprung for bottled water, with sales in the United States increasing 6.7 percent in 2012, to $11.8 billion, according to the International Bottled Water Association. Americans on average drank 30.8 gallons of bottled water, 5.3 percent more than in 2011.

headline: With Thunderous Blasts, a Governors Island Holdout Tumbles to Earth
abstract: The implosion of Building 877 on Sunday was the first such demolition in New York City since 2001, when a pair of 400-foot-tall natural-gas storage tanks was brought down in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In the clear, early morning sky above Governors Island, Building 877 was making its last stand.

headline: Obama and Xi Try to Avoid a Cold War Mentality
abstract: President Obama and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, emerged from talks determined to avoid the pitfalls of a rising power confronting an established one.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Xi Jinping, the Chinese leader, emerged over the weekend in California from their first lengthy talks declaring their determination to keep disputes over cyberespionage and territorial claims in the Pacific from descending into a cold war mentality and to avoid the pitfalls of a rising power confronting an established one.

headline: Having Seen Enough, Mets Demote Davis and Two Others
abstract: A day after playing a 20-inning marathon, the Marlins needed only 10 innings Sunday to put away the Mets for a two-game sweep.
lead_paragraph: If this was not the lowest point of Manager Terry Collins’s three-year stint with the Mets, then it was certainly close, he acknowledged shortly after sitting down for his postgame news conference.

headline: PBS Joins With Univision to Show a ‘Frontline’ Film
abstract: A Spanish-language version of “Rape in the Fields,” about sexual assault of migrant farm and packing plant workers, will be shown on Univision.
lead_paragraph: Viewers who miss the “Frontline” film “Rape in the Fields” on PBS on June 25 will be able to watch a version the following Saturday on another broadcast network — Univision. On that Spanish-language network, the film, which investigates the sexual assault of migrant farm and packing plant workers, will be broadcast as “Violación de un Sueño” (“Violation of a Dream.”)

headline: Beware of Hungarians Bearing Gifts
abstract: Bobbing and weaving to avoid sanctions.
lead_paragraph: Another Hungary post from my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, after the jump.

headline: Illuminating St. Paul
abstract: The artist Chris Larson built a life-sized replica of Marcel Breuer’s St. Paul house. Early Sunday, Mr. Larson set the piece ablaze in downtown St. Paul before a crowd of onlookers.
lead_paragraph: The artist Chris Larson built a life-sized replica of Marcel Breuer’s St. Paul house. Early Sunday, Mr. Larson set the piece ablaze in downtown St. Paul before a crowd of onlookers.

headline: Up in Flames
abstract: Chris Larson, an artist with an apocalyptic take on domesticity, has reproduced one of the most famous examples of modern architecture in Minnesota, only to destroy it.
lead_paragraph: Chris Larson, an artist with an apocalyptic take on domesticity, has reproduced one of the most famous examples of modern architecture in Minnesota, only to destroy it.

headline: Burning Down the House
abstract: Chris Larson, an artist in St. Paul, reproduced one of the best examples of high modernism in Minnesota, only to destroy it.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — At 2:15 a.m. Sunday, Chris Larson set fire to Chad Bogdan’s home. Or something that looked a lot like it. The two-bedroom house was unoccupied at the time. Mr. Larson had just finished assembling it a few hours earlier, on a vacant lot.

headline: CNN Rehires Kelly Wallace, Primarily as Digital Reporter
abstract: Ms. Wallace will be a digital correspondent, working primarily for CNN.com and appearing regularly on television.
lead_paragraph: CNN said it will announce on Monday the rehiring of Kelly Wallace, a former correspondent there, as it continues on a talent recruitment effort led by Jeff Zucker, who took over the cable news channel at the beginning of the year.

abstract: ABC Regional Sports and Entertainment Sales, New York, signed a sales and marketing agreement to collaborate on a digital out-of-home LED network in major cities around the country.
lead_paragraph: ABC Regional Sports and Entertainment Sales, New York, part of ABC National Television Sales, and Branded Cities Network, part of EL Media Holdings USA, Phoenix, signed a sales and marketing agreement to collaborate on a digital out-of-home LED network in major cities around the country. Financial terms were not disclosed. ABC National Television Sales is a division of the ABC unit of the Walt Disney Company.

headline: Work Is to Begin Soon on a Failed Meadowlands Mall
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Shopping Centers and Malls']
abstract: The Xanadu project has a new name — American Dream Meadowlands — a new owner and plans for an alliance with DreamWorks.
lead_paragraph: The empty shell of the enormous retail and entertainment complex in the New Jersey Meadowlands, formerly known as Xanadu, has served as a daily reminder of how outsize ambitions made it one of the most notorious examples of the real estate collapse.

headline: Obama Urged to Back Plan to List Owners of Shell Firms
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Tax Evasion', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Corporations', 'Money Laundering']
abstract: Anticorruption activists want the president to back public registration of shell-company owners, which they hope can deter tax evasion and money laundering.
lead_paragraph: Anticorruption activists have urged President Obama to back a plan to publicly register the owners of shell companies in the United States and around the world, a move they say is essential to thwart corrupt government officials, tax evaders and money launderers who rely on an opaque financial system.

headline: From the Original Six to the Final Two
abstract: For the first time since 1979, two Original Six teams — the Bruins and the Blackhawks — will duel for the right to splash Champagne into the Stanley Cup.
lead_paragraph: Hockey’s Original Six is staging a revival.

headline: Supporting Oil and Gas, but Resisting Encroachment
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Natural Gas', 'Drilling and Boring']
abstract: Oil and gas drilling helped revive the economy in Greeley, Colo., but a proposal to sink 16 wells next to a neighborhood of winding cul-de-sacs met an unlikely resistance.
lead_paragraph: GREELEY, Colo. — This is a town running on oil. From dawn till dusk, trucks carrying men and machinery rumble away for the oil and gas fields. New steakhouses and wine bars have popped up downtown. Energy companies help sponsor rodeos, blues concerts and other events. Tax revenues are surging.

headline: No Triple Crown, but Three Worthy Champions
abstract: The Kentucky Derby, Preakness and Belmont winners, along with their handlers, represent the good in horse racing and give the sport a summer to look forward to.
lead_paragraph: Short of witnessing a horse run into history, there wasn’t anything not to like about this Triple Crown season. The long-striding Orb took advantage of a wicked pace that collapsed the front-runners to capture the Kentucky Derby. The gritty Oxbow stole the Preakness Stakes with to a savvy ride by the leathery old jockey Gary Stevens.

headline: Violence Against Libyan Protesters Threatens to Undercut Power of Militias
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: After deadly weekend clashes, signs emerged that Libyans’ shock at the violence against civilians might weaken the influence of the groups’ leaders.
lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — Gathering here to bury nearly 30 civilian protesters killed the night before by a powerful militia, mourners said Sunday that they hoped a backlash after the massacre would finally cow Libya’s freewheeling brigades into submitting to the central government.

headline: Conservatives as Defenders of the Media
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A Justice Department inquiry of a Fox News reporter has spurred outrage from some reliable critics of the press.
lead_paragraph: The conservative pundit Glenn Beck took the lectern at a conference center on Manhattan’s East Side last Thursday to accept the Freedom of Speech Award for his commentary on TheBlaze television network and his syndicated radio show.

headline: Outpost on Pampas Where Jews Once Found Refuge Wilts as They Leave
abstract: In the 1940s, Moisés Ville had 5,000 people, four synagogues and a theater for Yiddish-language troupes. But now, the Argentine town appears ready to fade into history.
lead_paragraph: MOISÉS VILLE, Argentina — At its height in the 1940s, this outpost on Argentina’s grasslands had four synagogues for a population of 5,000, a theater for Yiddish-language acting troupes, a newspaper filled with feverish debates about the creation of the state of Israel and saloons where Jewish gauchos galloping in from the pampas could nurse a drink alongside fellow cowhands.

headline: Harvey Is Fine After Tightness in Back
abstract: Matt Harvey, who left Saturday’s loss with tightness in his lower back, said Sunday he felt fine. He is expected to start Thursday on regular rest.
lead_paragraph: If there was one positive for the Mets to take from Saturday’s 20-inning loss to the Miami Marlins, it was that Matt Harvey was not seriously hurt.

headline: Loan Dispute Threatens a Countercultural Soapbox
abstract: A building on Bleecker Street in Manhattan, known for decades as a nerve center of the Yippies, is now the subject of foreclosure proceedings.
lead_paragraph: It was Wednesday night, also known as Yippie Soapbox Night, at 9 Bleecker Street and some of the old gang was gathering. Outside the building, David Peel, a 1960s troubadour known for an ’80s anthem of sorts with the refrain, “Die Yuppie Scum,” was reminiscing about the Grateful Dead.

headline: His Skills Diminished, a Star Finally Reaches a Pinnacle
abstract: Tracy McGrady, a seven-time All-Star and two-time scoring champion, has been simulating LeBron James  in practice for the San Antonio Spurs.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Tracy McGrady’s sleepy eyes always belied his explosive first step and premier skills. But injury and erosion awakened him to the fickle realities of fate and left observers wondering if the eyes had turned from sleepy to sad.

headline: Two Traders in Gossip Go Toe to Toe
abstract: Nikki Finke of Deadline Hollywood, feared in the industry for having the best gossip, was said by a longtime competitor to have been fired — a blog report that turned out to be false.
lead_paragraph: For close readers of the entertainment trade press, the story that rocketed around Hollywood a week ago offered a familiar and juicy tableau. Citing unnamed sources, the exclusive, headlined “Shocker,” suggested that a powerful, unruly star in the entertainment industry had been fired by a boss who had finally had enough.

headline: Data-Driven Tech Industry Is Shaken by Online Privacy Fears
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy']
abstract: In Silicon Valley, dismay at revelations about government monitoring has led some to call for disclosure of companies’ involvement.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The dreamers, brains and cranks who built the Internet hoped it would be a tool of liberation and knowledge. Last week, an altogether bleaker vision emerged with new revelations of how the United States government is using it as a monitoring and tracking device.

headline: Resisting by Raising a Glass
keywords: ['ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Drinking has become intertwined with  broader complaints in Turkey, where Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan has said that “religion demands” curbs on alcohol.
lead_paragraph: ISPARTA, Turkey — After retaking Taksim Square in Istanbul after hours of ugly street battles with police officers firing tear gas this month, many of the haggard protesters cracked bottles of Efes beer and raised them in a mock toast to their prime minister, who had recently pushed through a law to curb drinking.

headline: Rebranding of Ici Radio-Canada Is Criticized
abstract: Critics were especially upset over dropping the word Canada from the on-air identification, and some suggested Quebec separatism was a factor.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — From its beginning almost 76 years ago, Canada’s government-owned, French-language radio and television broadcaster has been closely linked to its on-air identification: “Ici Radio-Canada.”

headline: After Drought, Rains Plaguing Midwest Farms
abstract: In many areas of the Midwest, one extreme has given way to another, as flooded pastures have delayed planting or washed away young shoots.
lead_paragraph: NORBORNE, Mo. — About this time last year, farmers were looking to the heavens, pleading for rain. Now, they are praying for the rain to stop.

headline: A Look at Erving, but Only Part of Him
abstract: “The Doctor,” a new documentary about Julius Erving on NBA TV, delves into his amazing feats on the court and may make fans smile or cry, but it leaves out significant information.
lead_paragraph: Julius Erving emerges from “The Doctor,” a new documentary (Monday, 9 p.m. Eastern, NBA TV), as he would like to be portrayed: as an arrestingly beautiful player, a hang-time levitator, a slam-dunk specialist and a soaring eagle of the A.B.A. and N.B.A.

headline: Apple Enters Net Radio’s Busy Field
abstract: The company is expected to unveil a streaming music service and other software, including a refreshed mobile operating system, at the opening of its annual developers conference Monday.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is known for making some of the finest hardware in the world, but one of its biggest stumbling blocks has been services that rely on an Internet connection.

headline:
Senate Digs In
for Long Battle
Over Immigration Bill
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: The immigration debate enters a crucial phase this week, as Republicans contend with internal divisions over whether to support a bill that could help mend their party’s standing with Latinos.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After seven months of steadily building momentum, the push for a comprehensive overhaul of the immigration system enters its most crucial phase this week in the Senate, where Republicans remain divided over how much to cooperate with President Obama as they try to repair their party’s standing among Hispanic voters.

headline: The Ghosts of Europe Past
abstract: The European Union closely resembles a formation that many citizens thought they had left to the dustbin of history: the Holy Roman Empire.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England — THE cheerleaders of the European Union like to think of it as an entirely new phenomenon, born of the horrors of two world wars. But in fact it closely resembles a formation that many Europeans thought they had long since left to the dustbin of history: the Holy Roman Empire, the political commonwealth under which the Germans lived for many hundreds of years.

headline: Room Service, Please
abstract: A room-service attendant. The lifting of the cloche. Silver ice bucket, Champagne chilling. Those were the days. And those days are gone.
lead_paragraph: THERE’S a knock at a hotel door. A table is wheeled in, and on it stands a silver ice bucket with a bottle of Champagne. The room service attendant smiles and backs out of the room to the sound of a marriage proposal being accepted, a cork exploding.

headline: A Conservative Case for Prison Reform
abstract: Conservatives known for being tough on crime should now be equally tough on failed, too-expensive criminal programs.
lead_paragraph: MANASSAS, Va. — CONSERVATIVES should recognize that the entire criminal justice system is another government spending program fraught with the issues that plague all government programs. Criminal justice should be subject to the same level of skepticism and scrutiny that we apply to any other government program.

headline: Sudan Says Pipeline Shutdown Is ‘Reversible’
abstract: The announcement by Sudan’s information minister on Sunday suggested that the country was seeking to ward off another escalation in tensions with South Sudan.

headline: What’s Next for Social Security?
abstract: Benefits are shrinking while retirement needs are growing.
lead_paragraph: The trustees of Social Security recently reported that the retirement system can pay full benefits until 2035, when it will be able to pay about three-fourths of promised benefits. That is not a crisis. It is a manageable problem.

headline: In Memoriam, Close the Terror Gap

headline: Governor Cuomo Fights for Women
abstract: Senate leaders, however, are blocking an abortion rights provision from coming to a vote.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York, who coaxed legislators into allowing same-sex marriage two years ago, has challenged them to broaden and strengthen the rights of women, including abortion rights. Should he persuade the Legislature to go along, he would stand in striking contrast to Republican governors across the country who are doing just the opposite.

headline: Horrendous Abuse in Mississippi Prisons
abstract: Under the federal Constitution, the state is responsible for its prisoner’s safety and well-being, and it is failing.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the Southern Poverty Law Center and the American Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit in federal court on behalf of the inmates — many seriously mentally ill — at the East Mississippi Correctional Facility. The conditions shock the conscience and, as the complaint charges, have “cost many prisoners their health, and their limbs, their eyesight, and even their lives.”

headline: The Myth of ‘Just Do It’
abstract: The idea that thinking interferes with doing is often taken for granted. But the realities at the highest levels of athletic and artistic performance are more complex.
lead_paragraph: Yogi Berra, the former Major League baseball catcher and coach, once remarked that you can’t hit and think at the same time. Of course, since he also reportedly said, “I really didn’t say everything I said,” it is not clear we should take his statements at face value. Nonetheless, a widespread view — in both academic journals and the popular press — is that thinking about what you are doing, as you are doing it, interferes with performance. The idea is that once you have developed the ability to play an arpeggio on the piano, putt a golf ball or parallel park, attention to what you are doing leads to inaccuracies, blunders and sometimes even utter paralysis. As the great choreographer George Balanchine would say to his dancers, “Don’t think, dear; just do.”

headline: Japan Is a Model, Not a Cautionary Tale
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Along many dimensions — greater income equality, longer life expectancy, lower unemployment, and greater investments in children’s education and health — Japan has done better than the United States.
lead_paragraph: IN the five years since the financial crisis crippled the American economy, a favorite warning of those who have urged forceful government action, myself included, has been that the United States risked entering a long period of “Japanese-style malaise.” Japan’s two decades of anemic growth, which followed a crash in 1989, have been the quintessential cautionary tale about how not to respond to a financial crisis.

headline: The Big Shrug
abstract: Depression becomes the new normal.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been in this economics business for a while. In fact, I’ve been in it so long I still remember what people considered normal in those long-ago days before the financial crisis. Normal, back then, meant an economy adding a million or more jobs each year, enough to keep up with the growth in the working-age population. Normal meant an unemployment rate not much above 5 percent, except for brief recessions. And while there was always some unemployment, normal meant very few people out of work for extended periods.

headline: Grouping Students by Ability Regains Favor in Classroom
abstract: Placing students in clusters according to ability, a tactic once rejected over concerns that it fostered inequality, has re-emerged in classrooms all over the country.
lead_paragraph: It was once common for elementary-school teachers to arrange their classrooms by ability, placing the highest-achieving students in one cluster, the lowest in another. But ability grouping and its close cousin, tracking, in which children take different classes based on their proficiency levels, fell out of favor in the late 1980s and the 1990s as critics charged that they perpetuated inequality by trapping poor and minority students in low-level groups.

headline: 120,000 Years of Tumors
abstract: A tumor found in the rib of a 120,000-year-old Neanderthal specimen is the earliest of its kind in the human fossil record, a new study reports.
lead_paragraph: A Neanderthal who lived more than 120,000 years ago had a tumor in a bone, the earliest of its kind in the human fossil record, a new study reports. The tumor, which was discovered in the rib of a Neanderthal specimen found in present-day Croatia, is described in the journal PLoS One.

headline: Unraveling the ‘Game of Thrones’ Finale
abstract: There was an awful lot of story to unravel in the last episode of the show’s third season.
lead_paragraph: For “Game of Thrones” it was the calm both before and after the storm. In its Season 3 finale on Sunday night, HBO’s popular fantasy series gave its fans a breather after the graphic slaughter that punctuated the previous week’s episode and inspired countless reaction videos. Oh, there was violence (spoilers ahead): the pint-size warrior Arya Stark claimed her first kill, the Wildling raider Ygritte put some non-lethal arrows into her former boyfriend Jon Snow, and there was some real unpleasantness involving Theon Greyjoy’s anatomy. But by “Game of Thrones” standards it was a tea party.

headline: Devaluing Human Capital

headline: Blue-Collar Friendship Down at the Shipyard
abstract: Dan Gordon and Michael Condron star in “The Boat Factory,” a play set at the shipyard where the Titanic was built.
lead_paragraph: The actor Dan Gordon is an ideal stage ambassador for Northern Ireland. Burly, affable and self-deprecating, he puts a warm face on a region too well known for sectarian violence. His one-man show “A Night in November” (written by Marie Jones) depicted a Belfast Protestant who cheers for the Irish soccer team at the 1994 World Cup in the United States. “The Boat Factory,” which he wrote and performs with Michael Condron as part of the Brits Off Broadway series, celebrates the sprawling Harland & Wolff shipyard, a once world-renowned institution, perhaps most famous as the birthplace of the Titanic. In multiple roles, Mr. Gordon and Mr. Condron vividly provide a collective portrait of labor in postwar Belfast.

headline: Balanchine Revealed in a Dance Inside a Play

lead_paragraph: “Nikolai and the Others,” Richard Nelson’s new play at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, recreates one very particular milieu of Russophone exiles in America just after World War II. The characters include Nikolai — better known to posterity as the composer Nicolas Nabokov — the painter Sergei Sudeikin; Sudeikin’s ex-wife, Vera; and her second husband, Igor Stravinsky. They swirl around the choreographer George Balanchine (Michael Cerveris), who is at work with Stravinsky in preparing the ballet “Orpheus.” Though the play has its problems, I would want it to be seen by anyone interested in Balanchine and his choreography.

headline: Live From St. Petersburg (With Popcorn)
abstract: The live broadcast of the Mariinsky’s “Swan Lake” was shown in 55 countries on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: You’ll hunt in vain for a good production of the full-length “Swan Lake” among America’s leading ballet companies. Although this work’s whole spirit belongs in the medieval age of chivalry, all too often it’s set in the Tudor or Victorian eras. And large swaths have been badly rechoreographed, notably the final act. So it’s restorative to see a live broadcast of one of the world’s finest productions, that of the Mariinsky Ballet in St. Petersburg. Broadcast in cinemas in 55 countries on Thursday night, this should have been more restorative than it proved. But its virtues are considerable.

headline: Iran: Candidate Drops Out of Presidential Campaign
abstract: A conservative former Parliament speaker ended his presidential campaign on Monday, narrowing the field of contestants to seven.
lead_paragraph: A conservative former Parliament speaker ended his presidential campaign on Monday, narrowing the field of contestants to seven in a move that appeared aimed at strengthening the candidacies of fellow conservatives and reducing any chance that a moderate could win. The departure of the former speaker, Gholam Ali Haddad Adel, left four other conservatives on the ballot, with four days left the election. Mr. Haddad Adel, who is related by marriage to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, exhorted followers to vote for one of the other conservative candidates to avoid a possible runoff. The presumed front-runner is Saeed Jalili, Iran’s nuclear negotiator and a prominent disciple of the ayatollah, who has warned against showing any sign of weakness in Iran’s nuclear dispute with the West.

headline: Greece: Ex-Official’s Relatives Fined for Bank Deposits

lead_paragraph: Greece’s financial crimes squad has traced more than six million euros, or nearly $8 million, in undeclared assets in the bank accounts of four relatives of a former finance minister, George Papaconstantinou, who is being investigated for his handling of a list of some 2,000 wealthy Greeks with Swiss bank accounts, a source of much-needed potential tax revenue untapped by the authorities. The four people face fines of about $13 million, said an official of the crimes squad. The development appeared to strengthen the case against Mr. Papaconstantinou, who became the focus of a parliamentary investigation in January after prosecutors revealed that the names of four of his relatives had been removed from the original list of depositors. Last week, Greek lawmakers voted to widen the investigation of Mr. Papaconstantinou.

headline: A New York Perfumer Finds an Unlikely Source of Inspiration
abstract: The new unisex fragrance by Aedes de Venustas is based on the look — not the scent — of a rare Israeli wildflower.
lead_paragraph: This Saturday, a little over a year after introducing its namesake signature fragrance — a combination of rhubarb and Madagascar vetiver — the Greenwich Village boutique-turned-perfumer Aedes de Venustas will release its much-anticipated follow-up. Teaming up this time with the German perfumer Ralf Schwieger, whose clients include the likes of Frédéric Malle and Hermès, the brand’s co-owners Karl Bradl and Robert Gerstner attempted to capture the essence of a rare flower to create the unisex aroma Iris Nazarena. “The inspiration was an iris that grows only in the mountains of Nazareth,” said Bradl, who discovered the species through art on a postcard. “It is a protected wildflower, so we could not harvest or remove the flower.” What’s more, iris flowers don’t actually have a scent — typically, only their roots do — so the team had to get creative. The fragrance they created, according to Bradl, is inspired by the “color, texture and pattern of the blossom.” The result is decidedly not floral. Instead, the eau de parfum has a powdery quality, with musky hints of clove and star anise, evoking burning incense — a signature note in the olfactory repertory of Aedes de Venustas, whose house line includes a scented room spray and candles. The effect is like a visit to an officers’ club from a bygone era, all smoky wood, aged leather and classic men’s cologne.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 1 P.M. (Sundance) L’AMOUR FOU (2011) The French couturier Yves Saint Laurent, below, may have been surrounded by intense beauty, both in the atelier and at home, yet he was said to be joyful only twice a year: on the days a new collection was shown, usually to boisterous acclaim. But within 24 hours, the euphoria had evaporated. Pierre Bergé narrates this documentary about Saint Laurent, his partner in business and in life for a half-century until the designer’s death in 2008. The “crazy love” of the title refers not so much to their relationship but to Saint Laurent’s obsessions with objects, from the artworks — including Picassos, Matisses, Braques and a treasured Brancusi that were sold at a 2009 Christie’s auction — to the perfect houses, which he collected passionately. (All of the rooms in one were named after characters from Proust.) “Much of this stately, rather detached biography,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times of this documentary from Pierre Thoretton, “is pornography for the eye (not the body).” Of Saint Laurent’s depression, he added, “To realize that you may have the world while still feeling as if you have nothing is to experience a closer encounter with the void than most of us are likely to have.”

headline: The Healer Behind the Belmont Winner of 1963
abstract: On June 8, 1963, Chateaugay, owned by Darby Dan Farm, trained by J. P. Conway and ridden by Braulio Baeza, won the Belmont Stakes at Aqueduct. A year earlier he had a condition that inhibited his oxygen intake.
lead_paragraph: On June 8, 1963, Chateaugay, owned by Darby Dan Farm, trained by J. P. Conway and ridden by Braulio Baeza, won the Belmont Stakes at Aqueduct. With wind down the backstretch, he finished the one-and-one-half-mile race in 2:30.20 seconds, establishing a track record for that distance. Before this race, there was no track record at Aqueduct for this distance. Chateaugay went off the second choice at 9-2, beating the favorite Candy Spots, who went off at 1-2. While many in the crowd were disgruntled by Chateaugay’s win, probably few were surprised because he was the second favorite. And probably only a very few were actually amazed by Chateaugay’s accomplishment.

headline: Invisible Men
abstract: For Guantánamo detainees, the prison library offers a rare means of escape.
lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — The prison library here is housed in a prefabricated building behind chain-link fencing and razor wire inside Camp Delta, an older, largely disused wing of the complex. Inside, the place has the feel of a branch library, with several rooms of books divided by language and genre — but its patrons may not browse the stacks. Instead, the chief librarian, a civilian who asks to be identified as “Milton” for security reasons, or an aide fills plastic bins with about 50 books and takes them to each cellblock once a week. If they obey prison rules, the 166 detainees may peer at the spines through the slots in their doors and check out two titles at a time, or make specific requests.

headline: The Sacking of Darien
abstract: Robert Gould Shaw, the 54th Massachusetts and the destructive raid on a small Georgia town.
lead_paragraph: Near sunrise on June 11, 1863, Confederate outposts noticed a flotilla of ships rounding Doboy Sound and steaming up the Altamaha River toward Darien, Ga. Settled on a picturesque bluff above the river in 1736, Georgians had once known Darien as a thriving port and financial center. During the early 19th century, however, Savannah absorbed most of Darien’s economic activity; by the time of the Civil War, a visitor to Darien could still see slaves loading timber and cotton at the wharves, but he or she would more likely notice the town’s quaint colonial charm.

headline: The Great (Gay) Novelist You’ve Never Heard Of
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Homosexuality']
abstract: The forgotten saga of John Horne Burns and his intemperate World War II masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: Great war novels inevitably follow great wars, and in literary circles following World War II, everyone was wondering what would be the successors to “A Farewell to Arms” and “All Quiet on the Western Front” — and who would write them. But when John Horne Burns, age 29, in his small dormitory suite at the Loomis School in Windsor, Conn., on the night of April 23, 1946 (Shakespeare’s birthday, at that), finished “The Gallery” — “I fell across my Underwood and wept my heart out,” he later recalled — he was convinced he had done just that, and more. “ ‘The Gallery,’ I fear, is one of the masterpieces of the 20th century,” he wrote a friend.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American Civil Liberties Union sued the Obama administration on Tuesday over its “dragnet” collection of logs of domestic phone calls, contending that the once-secret program — whose existence was exposed last week by a former National Security Agency contractor — is illegal and asking a judge to stop it and order the records purged.

headline: A Doubles Windfall: Federer and Haas Hit the Grass Together
abstract: At the start of the grass court season, tournaments like the Gerry Weber Open in Halle Westfallen, Germany find themselves with a star-studded doubles field, which included Roger Federer teaming with Tommy Haas.
lead_paragraph: HALLE WESTFALEN, Germany — Because singles players will often enter a doubles field after the tennis tour shifts to a new surface just for the extra practice, the Gerry Weber Open found itself with an unusually talented doubles field this week.

headline: A Family on the Run From Population Enforcers
abstract: Ma Jian’s new novel, “The Dark Road,” follows members of a Chinese peasant family as they go on the run, evading population enforcers and hoping to give birth to a son.
lead_paragraph: In the Chinese countryside, where, the saying goes, heaven is high, and the emperor is far away, the phrase “family planning” has taken on a sinister connotation.

headline: Essay: Medication Continues to Stifle America’s Triple Crown Hopes
abstract: A veterinarian writes that an understanding and appreciation of the science of equine behavior are necessary to elucidate how raceday Lasix impoverishes the medical welfare of racehorses.
lead_paragraph: It is no coincidence that there has not been a Triple Crown winner since the administration of raceday Lasix became the standard for Kentucky Derby runners some 35 or so years ago. An understanding and appreciation of the veterinary science of equine behavior are necessary to elucidate how raceday Lasix impoverishes the medical welfare of racehorses, and why permissive raceday and day-before medication should be banned in American horseracing to protect the heath and welfare of the racehorses and the sport.

headline: Few Wash Hands Properly, Study Finds
abstract: Researchers found that among those who used public toilets in one college town, 10 percent did not wash their hands at all, and almost a quarter used no soap. Only 5 percent washed for longer than 15 seconds; the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends rubbing vigorously with soap and water for at least 20 seconds.
lead_paragraph: Did you wash your hands properly after you used the toilet? Probably not, a new study suggests.

headline: 2013 Fantasy Football: Top 10 Quarterbacks

abstract: These hearty pancakes freeze well and make a good breakfast.
lead_paragraph: If you’re trying to work more grains and seeds into your diet, a pancake can be a good home for them. These are hearty pancakes – 3 make a good breakfast – with nice texture.

headline: In Brussels, Frites Are More Than Just Fries
abstract: When is eating French fries a job? When the Frugal Traveler is in Brussels, and he goes in search of a deep-fried taste of the Belgian capital’s culture.
lead_paragraph: Meeting a doctor at a frites stand in Brussels was fortuitous, in an enabling-poor-behavior sort of way. “It’s obvious that French fries are not very healthy, but that doesn’t mean that you should not have them at least once a week,” said Philippe Wuyts, a psychiatrist I found in line at Frit Flagey, one of the more famed spots for fries in the Belgian capital. “Even as a doctor I would recommend for everybody to have at least one portion.”

lead_paragraph: Expanding its stable of audio products, Sol Republic recently introduced a line of low-priced in-ear headphones called Jax.

abstract: Foxwoods’ owners announced an accord with a developer, and other groups want to build projects, but all require a change in the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: Casino fever has hit the Catskills, again.

headline: Restaurant Report: Lolla in Singapore
abstract: Good luck getting a seat at this tapas bar, which was named one of the hottest restaurants in the world earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: Just a five-minute walk from the din of Singapore’s Chinatown, the once-vibrant Club Street-Ann Siang Road dining enclave is enjoying a revival. A raft of restaurants and clubs is riding the upswing, and one of the hardest tables to book is Lolla, a new kid on the block that made Zagat’s 2013 “10 hottest restaurants in the world” list. What you wouldn’t necessarily know on arrival: Lolla is the permanent shopfront incarnation of Lolla’s Secret Supper, a guerrilla-style underground supper club founded in 2008 by Pang Hian Tee.

headline: G.M. and BMW Adopt D.C. Electric Car Charging
abstract: By cutting out the bottleneck caused by converting A.C. to D.C. for battery charging, new technology allows faster E.V. charging.
lead_paragraph: General Motors and BMW say they are moving ahead with technology that can give electric cars an 80 percent charge in 20 minutes. Charging time is a major problem in a car that can travel only 100 miles or less between charges.

headline: As Senate Begins Debate, Organized Labor Makes Immigration Push

lead_paragraph: As the Senate opens debate on an overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws, organized labor is picking up the pace of its advocacy for the bill.

lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: An Invitation to a House on a Greek Island
abstract: A new memoir by the Swiss artist Christian Brechneff recalls a slower and more simple time on a Greek island.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of books arrive at The New York Times Magazine every day. Books that whimper for attention: See me. Read me. Love me. Most of them end up on a counter in the 6th-floor mailroom, forlorn as puppies in an animal shelter. I rescued one book in prepublication form last week: “The Greek House: The Story of a Painter’s Love Affair With the Island of Sifnos,” a memoir by the Swiss artist Christian Brechneff (with Tim Lovejoy).

headline: Broadway Mainstays Will Be Part of Encores! Off-Broadway Series
abstract: Raul Esparza and Anika Noni Rose are among the stars of the inaugural production, “The Cradle Will Rock.”
lead_paragraph: City Center’s Encores! series may be exploring Off Broadway this summer, but Broadway talent is coming along for the ride. Tony winner Anika Noni Rose and nominees Raul Esparza, Judy Kuhn, Danny Burstein and Da’Vine Joy Randolph are among those starring in “The Cradle Will Rock,” the inaugural show in the new Encores! Off-Center series. The production, directed by Sam Gold, will run July 10 to 13.

lead_paragraph: When the Evanston Northwestern Healthcare Corporation merged its two hospitals with the neighboring Highland Park Hospital just north of Chicago 13 years ago, the deal was presented as an opportunity to increase efficiency and improve the quality of patient care.

headline: Romantic, Quirky or Funky
abstract: North Carolina Dance Theater, Ballet Austin and Dance Theater of Harlem performed in the third segment of “Ballet Across America” at the Kennedy Center in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Because each program of the “Ballet Across America III” season at the Kennedy Center here features three American companies, every performance is attended by partisan supporters keen to signal their delight in the offering by their team. On Sunday afternoon I caught Program C, the final segment of last week’s three-part event. Ovations were lusty for North Carolina Dance Theater, Ballet Austin and Dance Theater of Harlem.

headline: Letting Go Is Hard to Do When It’s the Old Manse
abstract: In the Mint Theater’s revival of “A Picture of Autumn,” N. C. Hunter’s 1951 play, a family struggles with elderly parents who cling to their crumbling mansion.
lead_paragraph: Removing an aged parent or grandparent from a home that’s no longer safe or convenient is never easy.

headline: Playing Dead, With Aplomb
abstract: Marcelo Gomes and Diana Vishneva of American Ballet Theater danced the title roles in “Romeo and Juliet” at the Metropolitan Opera House.
lead_paragraph: In any production of “Romeo and Juliet” there is a lot of playing dead. At the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday, when American Ballet Theater performed its first “Romeo” of the season, one of the unmoving corpses near Juliet in the crypt was played by a guest star: Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a New York Democrat. She was perfect. That doesn’t quite count as news, but it was noteworthy in a performance of predictable excellence. Kenneth MacMillan’s 1965 “Romeo” is a reliable construction, and Monday’s cast looked comfortable in roles played many times before.

headline: How to Fill a Melting Pot
abstract: A working-class neighborhood in the Bronx with a housing stock almost as diverse as its population.
lead_paragraph: New York has immigrants from 148 countries, at least by the city’s count, and it seems a number of the more successful ones eventually make their way to Allerton, whose diversity stands out even in an extremely multicultural field.

headline: Living in Allerton, the Bronx
abstract: The neighborhood is especially diverse, made up of hard working immigrants, proud of their homes.
lead_paragraph: The neighborhood is especially diverse, made up of hard working immigrants, proud of their homes.

headline: Brothers Who Make Electronica by Hand
abstract: The intensely private Scottish electronic-music duo, Boards of Canada, has released “Tomorrow’s Harvest,” its first album since 2006.
lead_paragraph: Boards of Canada thrive on making themselves scarce. A duo of brothers from rural Scotland, Mike Sandison and Marcus Eoin, the group has been releasing electronic music since the mid-1990s — music that eludes most standard pop notions of electronica and has built a fiercely dedicated following among fellow musicians and producers.

headline: A Year Later, the Missed Opportunity of the JOBS Act
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Small Business']
abstract: The recent I.P.O. of the upscale grocer Fairway is an illustration of the real forces that drive the market for offerings.
lead_paragraph: More than a year ago, Congress passed legislation that its supporters said would help revive new company offerings. Now, the market for initial public offerings is starting to heati up, but the law, the Jump-Start Our Business Startups Act, or the JOBS Act, has had little to do with it.

headline: A Nearly Instant Picnic
abstract: You can take advantage of picnic weather even if you don’t have a wicker basket and cold fried chicken on hand.
lead_paragraph: You can take advantage of picnic weather even if you don’t have a wicker basket and cold fried chicken on hand.

headline: A Ballet Master Full of Light and Shadows
abstract: On his 30th season as ballet master in chief of New York City Ballet, Peter Martins has shown how puzzling a figure he is.
lead_paragraph: The 2012-13 season of New York City Ballet that ended at the David H. Koch Theater was a milestone in several ways. At age 66, Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief, has weathered 30 years at its helm. He may well end up lasting longer than the 35 years enjoyed by the company’s founding ballet master, George Balanchine. In the past year Mr. Martins has also presented three world premieres by a new choreographer, Justin Peck. All of them — “In Creases,” “Year of the Rabbit” and “Paz de la Jolla” — are at least good; and “Rabbit” really does seem to be the most exciting new ballet since Alexei Ratmansky’s “Concerto DSCH.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Web Page No. 1 and Amazon in China
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. For Tuesday, selections include trying to crack a forgotten password guarding a historic Web page and Amazon trying to sell e-books in a land where most people don’t buy them.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Pan Bagnat, the Perfect Picnic Sandwich
abstract: When it comes to picnics, we can do better than a loaf of bread and a wedge of cheese. Melissa Clark shows why the pan bagnat is the ideal sandwich for outdoor summer dining.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Interior Department is failing to collect tens of millions of dollars in lease payments for coal mining on federal lands, according to an agency inspector general’s report released Tuesday.

headline: The Ants Will Love You

lead_paragraph: There’s nothing wrong with a tuna fish sandwich eaten in an air-conditioned kitchen on a summer afternoon. But there’s something special about that same sandwich nibbled on a picnic blanket in the park.

headline: Academy’s Troubles Shadow Key Report
abstract: A blue-ribbon commission’s report to Congress on the state of the humanities arrives amid disturbing allegations against one of its members.
lead_paragraph: When a much-anticipated report defending the beleaguered liberal arts is released on Capitol Hill next week, it will come amid bad news beyond the usual lamentations about declining enrollments, slashed budgets and the perceived unemployability of English majors.

headline: U.S. Blacklists Fund-Raisers for Hezbollah
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']

lead_paragraph: Retribution against Hezbollah for helping the Syrian government fight rebels intensified on Tuesday, as the United States blacklisted four fund-raising operatives and warned of further steps to choke the group’s financing.

headline: Hauling Your Feast to the Picnic
abstract: There are many options ranging from fancy picnic baskets to heavy-duty canvas totes, empty but for what you fill it with.
lead_paragraph: This week’s column focuses on the joys of picnics, and features recipes for three dishes that are easy to make, but not too fussy to haul to the park and eat on a blanket. One of the recipes is for a pan bagnat sandwich, which I show you how to make in this video.

headline: Three’s a Trend | The Desert Deco Aesthetic Takes Over Resort
abstract: The season’s collections showcased an unlikely collision of warm, dusty shades with graphic glamour.
lead_paragraph: Numerous resort shows — including Derek Lam, Bottega Veneta and Michael Kors — made use of bold, 1920s-inspired color blocking in unexpected earth tones on easy day-wear pieces. The result was sporty elegance, with a hint of urban safari.

headline: Asking Environmentalists Not to Fear the Reactor
abstract: The documentarian Robert Stone lines up experts to advocate nuclear energy in his new film, “Pandora’s Promise.”
lead_paragraph: Early in “Pandora’s Promise,” Mark Lynas, a British environmental activist, walks around the ghostly environs of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in Japan, near the second-worst nuclear disaster in history. There, amid spookily forsaken homes and cars, he talks about the 2011 earthquake and tsunami, as well as the meltdowns, and says he understands why people are afraid of nuclear power. Wearing a white Tyvek suit and knotting his forehead, he occasionally pauses to take a radiation reading with a meter no bigger than a cellphone. “So, are you still pro-nuclear?” asks a man off camera, presumably the director Robert Stone. Mr. Lynas squints at his interlocutor and asks, “Are you still pro-nuclear?”

headline: In Fields and Hives, Zooming In on What Ails Bees
abstract: The documentary “More Than Honey” focuses on the world’s troubled bee population and how it’s being threatened.
lead_paragraph: If bees were to disappear from the globe, mankind would have four years left to live. That assertion, attributed to Albert Einstein but perhaps apocryphal, is voiced in “More Than Honey,” a fascinating but rambling documentary about the decimation of the world’s bee population through the phenomenon known as colony collapse disorder.

headline: Branch Falls on Tourist as She Walks Through Central Park
keywords: ['Trees and Shrubs', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Travel and Vacations']

lead_paragraph: A 59-year-old tourist from Indiana was seriously injured on Tuesday afternoon when she was struck by a falling tree branch in Central Park, the authorities reported.

lead_paragraph: In the wake of the exposure of two classified surveillance operations, most Americans expressed disapproval about the United States government’s collecting phone records of “ordinary” Americans. Yet, most showed little concern about their own Internet activities or phone calls’ being monitored.

headline: Thrilling New Chance to Get Queasy Is Planned for Coney Island
abstract: A replacement for the Thunderbolt roller coaster will carry riders up to 65 miles an hour in various directions and open next year, the city announced.
lead_paragraph: It won’t exactly be THE Thunderbolt, but it will definitely be the Thunderbolt: The city announced on Tuesday that a new roller coaster would open on Coney Island next year on the site of the old Thunderbolt, the roller coaster that once rivaled the Cyclone and makes a famous appearance in “Annie Hall.”

headline: Behind Kanye’s Mask
abstract: Kanye West talks about his career and his new album, “Yeezus.”
lead_paragraph: Malibu, Calif. — From Shangri-la Studio here you can see the Pacific Ocean just over the fence lapping calmly at Zuma Beach. And this compound is just as Zen, with recording equipment set up in various locations, including an old bus and a spotless white house with all the mirrors removed.

headline: Blackhawks Replace Stalberg With Bollig in Game 1
abstract: The move may mean that Coach Joel Quenneville was not pleased with Viktor Stalberg’s play, or that he could be embracing a bigger lineup against the imposing Bruins.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Viktor Stalberg wore a white jersey at practice Tuesday afternoon and a scowl afterward. For the second time this postseason, Stalberg, the speedy Blackhawks winger, appeared to have caught the ire of Coach Joel Quenneville and is headed for the bench, the latest instance coming ahead of Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals against Boston Wednesday.

headline: A Sexual-Assault Measure to Be Cut From Military Bill
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Carl Levin, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said he would exclude the measure offered by Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, a fellow Democrat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a striking showdown between Senator Carl Levin, the chairman of the Armed Services Committee, and a member of his own party, Mr. Levin said on Tuesday that he would remove a measure aimed at curbing sexual assault in the military from a defense spending bill.

headline: City Argues to Overturn Ruling That Prevented Limits on Sugary Drinks
abstract: After a judge barred New York City from restricting sales of the large drinks, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s administration asked an appellate court to approve the rules.
lead_paragraph: One justice asked if the city might limit scoops of ice cream. Another posed repeated questions about the nutritional content of an average milkshake. A lawyer, possibly hungered by the proceedings, raised the issue of steak size at Peter Luger.

headline: Top Three Will Tee Off in Rare Unit
abstract: The top three golfers in the world — Tiger Woods, Rory McIlroy and Adam Scott — will be in the same group in the first two rounds of the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: ARDMORE, Pa. — Rory McIlroy, who recently moved to South Florida from Northern Ireland, has become an avid Miami Heat fan. Like most of his neighbors, he admires LeBron James, who happens to be a friend; he respects Dwyane Wade; and he wonders half the time what Chris Bosh is thinking.

headline: Tomic Loses While His Father Watches
abstract: A month after the ATP banned the elder Tomic from being credentialed at tournaments, he had a second row seat and stayed for most of his son’s loss to Benjamin Becker.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Bernard Tomic said he didn’t know his controversial father, John, was watching his match on a grey Tuesday at the Aegon Championships in west London.

headline: Ethics Panel Fines Lopez $330,000 in Harassment Case
abstract: The fine was the largest ever issued by the legislative panel, whose scathing report had outlined former Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez’s history of sexual harassment of female staff members.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Accusations of sexual misconduct have already cost Vito J. Lopez his job as a state assemblyman and his reputation. Now that misconduct will reach into his campaign coffers as well.

headline: Canadian Conflict Grows Out of Quebec Soccer Federation’s Ban on Turbans
abstract: The national governing body has suspended the local federation, which cited safety concerns in refusing to comply with a directive permitting players to wear turbans and other types of headwear.
lead_paragraph: The newest intersection of soccer and cultural controversy has an unusual address — Canada.

headline: Arturo Vega, Shepherd for the Ramones, Dies at 65
abstract: Mr. Vega was often called the fifth Ramone for serving as the punk band’s spokesman and logo designer.
lead_paragraph: Arturo Vega, who was often called the fifth Ramone for serving as spokesman, logo designer, T-shirt salesman, lighting director and omnipresent shepherd for the Ramones, the speed-strumming punk quartet that helped rejuvenate rock in the mid-1970s, died on June 8 in Manhattan. He was 65.

headline: Earlier Denials Put Intelligence Chief in Awkward Position
abstract: The discovery that the National Security Agency routinely collects information on American citizens has left the Obama administration struggling to explain previous statements that seem, at best, misleading.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, intelligence officials have tried to debunk what they called a popular myth about the National Security Agency: that its electronic net routinely sweeps up information about millions of Americans. In speeches and Congressional testimony, they have suggested that the agency’s immense power is focused exclusively on terrorists and other foreign targets, and that it does not invade Americans’ privacy.

headline: In a Town of Tough Crowds, García Is Taking a Conciliatory Approach
abstract: Trying to put his feud with Tiger Woods behind him, Sergio García keeps displaying gracious behavior at the U.S. Open in suburban Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: ARDMORE, Pa. — After shaking hands with Tiger Woods on Monday, Sergio García again displayed gracious behavior on Tuesday at Merion Golf Club, signing autographs at the driving range, making small talk, trying hard to win friends and influence people.

headline: Damien Hirst’s Spot Prices

lead_paragraph: A chart of the individual spot paintings sold and their price ranges, by year.

headline: Insurers Inflating Books, New York Regulator Says
abstract: New York regulators say life insurers are putting policyholders at risk and could cause another taxpayer bailout.
lead_paragraph: New York State regulators are calling for a nationwide moratorium on transactions that life insurers are using to alter their books by billions of dollars, saying that the deals put policyholders at risk and could lead to another taxpayer bailout.

headline: If Patriots Have Plan for Tebow, It’s a Secret
abstract: Tim Tebow was at the start of a Patriots’ three-day minicamp, but Coach Bill Belichick did not say how he planned to use him.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Bill Belichick smirked when he observed the unusually large news media contingent gathered for the start of the New England Patriots’ three-day minicamp.

headline: In a Shift, Interest Rates Are Rising
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Interest Rates', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The interest rate charged by lenders has been going down for most of the time since the early 1980s, but there are signs that will not last.
lead_paragraph: It has been a reliable fact of life for investors, corporations and ordinary borrowers: interest rates, for the most part, keep heading lower.

headline: Immigrants Reach Beyond a Legal Barrier for a Reunion
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Deportation', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Three young immigrants who grew up in the United States and call themselves Dreamers reunited at a border fence in Arizona with their parents, who had been deported.
lead_paragraph: NOGALES, Ariz. — Three young immigrants had a jubilant and painful reunion here on Tuesday with parents who had been deported from the United States, sharing hugs through the steel bars of the border fence that separates this American town from its Mexican twin.

headline: Healing the Overwhelmed Physician
abstract: Doctors also need help making sense of the latest medical studies.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — DURING an 1817 visit to Florence, the French author Marie-Henri Beyle, known by the pen name Stendhal, was seized by palpitations, dizziness and a feeling of being overwhelmed by the abundance of great art surrounding him; an Italian psychiatrist later coined the term Stendhal syndrome to describe this phenomenon.

headline: The Price of the Panopticon
abstract: Pervasive N.S.A. surveillance may pose unforeseen dangers.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — THE revelation that the federal government has been secretly gathering records on the phone calls and online activities of millions of Americans and foreigners seems not to have alarmed most Americans. A poll conducted by the Pew Research Center over the four days immediately after the news first broke found that just 41 percent of Americans deemed it unacceptable that the National Security Agency “has been getting secret court orders to track telephone calls of millions of Americans to investigate terrorism.”

headline: Russia Passes Bill Targeting Some Discussions of Homosexuality
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Law and Legislation', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Gay rights advocates say that the bill is a signal of societal acceptance of discrimination that will likely be picked up by violent antigay groups.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Russian Parliament passed a bill on Tuesday that imposes a fine for what it calls propagandizing “nontraditional” sexual relationships among minors, in the latest in a wave of socially conservative new rules here.

headline: Giving up Tuna? Breathing Is Next
abstract: Regulating mercury emissions would also decrease the presence of other harmful toxins.
lead_paragraph: If you’re like most people (including me, up until a month or two ago), you know that tuna and other top-of-the-food-chain fish contain unsafe levels of mercury and that childbirth-age women and nursing mothers, especially, are warned off these fish. What you don’t know, probably (I didn’t), is the mercury’s source, or how it gets in these fish.

headline: Hirst Counts the Dots, or at Least the Paintings
abstract: Damien Hirst has answered a long-running question in the art world: How many of his spot paintings are there, anyway?
lead_paragraph: Damien Hirst’s spot paintings — some with dots about the size of pinholes, others 60 inches across — have long been celebrated, and disdained, for a certain anonymous, machinelike industrial uniformity.

headline: Blowing a Whistle
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Privacy', 'Whistle-Blowers']
abstract: Respecting and caring about civil liberties means supporting the government programs needed to prevent another 9/11.
lead_paragraph: I’m glad I live in a country with people who are vigilant in defending civil liberties. But as I listen to the debate about the disclosure of two government programs designed to track suspected phone and e-mail contacts of terrorists, I do wonder if some of those who unequivocally defend this disclosure are behaving as if 9/11 never happened — that the only thing we have to fear is government intrusion in our lives, not the intrusion of those who gather in secret cells in Yemen, Afghanistan and Pakistan and plot how to topple our tallest buildings or bring down U.S. airliners with bombs planted inside underwear, tennis shoes or computer printers.

headline: When Patients and Suspects Just Don’t Fit

She kept reminding herself that she felt secure in her decision. “I knew that that was going to be the right-wrong thing to do,” she told me later. “I was ready for it.”

lead_paragraph: Here’s something you don’t see every day: the wounds left by bullets after a shooting.
