Sitting next to her husband, she calmly pointed out the hole in her left shoulder. She held up her bloody shirt – what was left of it – and the yellow bruises all over her arms were clearly visible. Her right ear was bandaged, having been grazed by a bullet that whizzed uncomfortably close to her head.

headline: 36 Hours in Oslo
abstract: A visit to Norway’s capital could drain your wallet, but given everything you’ll find there, you might consider it a bargain.
lead_paragraph: Has Oslo priced even itself out of the city? These days, the most appealing areas in the famously expensive Norwegian capital lie on the periphery of the city center, in its newly trendy neighborhoods — hip Grunerlokka to the northeast, glamorous Tjuvholmen to the southwest — and beyond, in the glorious landscapes of the Oslo Fjord and the sprawling northern forests. Granted, downtown still harbors a version of “The Scream,” by Norway’s best-known painter, Edvard Munch, whose birth 150 years ago is being celebrated here all year. But more buzz now surrounds the dazzling architectural landmarks — the sinuous art museum that opened last year and the angular opera house — anchoring the city’s renewed waterfront. Today, to properly explore Oslo’s finest attractions, expect to wander widely.

headline: Red Square Bike Share
abstract: Moscow has a new public bike-share program.
lead_paragraph: Moscow has a new public bike-share program. Thirty-two mobile solar-powered docking stations opened earlier this month with about 220 bikes. More docking stations are planned by the end of the year. The program was developed by the city with the Bank of Moscow. Other recent bike-friendly amenities include bike racks on public transportation, parking structures and new cycle paths. Cyclists can register by the day, week, month or season, starting at 100 rubles (about $3) a day, and are then charged 60 rubles (about $1.85) every hour. The first 30 minutes are free. Registration is available at the program’s Web site (velobike.ru); an English-language version is planned.

headline: Cheetahs’ Secret Weapon: A Tight Turning Radius
abstract: A study shows that the large feline’s key to hunting success is not its speed but its skill at leaping sideways, changing directions abruptly and slowing down quickly.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has watched a cheetah run down an antelope knows that these cats are impressively fast. But it turns out that speed is not the secret to their prodigious hunting skills: a novel study of how cheetahs chase prey in the wild shows that it is their agility — their skill at leaping sideways, changing directions abruptly and slowing down quickly — that gives those antelope such bad odds.

headline: Lincoln Answers His Critics
abstract: The story behind the president’s famous letter to Erastus Corning.

headline: A Glimpse of Where Chicago Hockey Was in 1934
abstract: An article in The Chicagoan in 1934 profiles Maj. Frederic McLaughlin, the Hawks’ mercurial owner.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Here is a bit more Original Six lore as we await Wednesday night’s opener of the Chicago-Boston Stanley Cup finals. We turn to the University of Chicago Library and its online copy of the Oct. 1, 1934, issue of The Chicagoan, a magazine of the period that was meant to be the Second City’s version of The New Yorker, and the article “Falconer McLaughlin: The Boss of the World’s Champion Black Hawks.”

headline: Paul Westerberg on How to Write an Ending
abstract: To fade or not to fade?
lead_paragraph: That quirky, lovable riff on songwriting that Paul Westerberg wrote for The Times recently got me thinking of a tip that I picked up from him many years ago. Not personally. It was from an article in Musician, a long-gone magazine that I was addicted to as a teenager. I remember Westerberg talking about how he often wrote a brand-new part at the end of his songs because when he was a kid listening to the radio, it bugged him when the tunes just repeated and faded out. So lazy! Why stop being creative before the song was over? Throw something new in there, man, give people a reason to listen to the end.

headline: Annabel Tollman: The Calm Amid Fashion’s Storm
abstract: Colleagues and friends reflect on the life of the stylist Annabel Tollman, who they say was an exception to the Jungle Law of the fashion industry.
lead_paragraph: The core code of conduct governing fashion can sometimes be characterized as jungle law. According to the unspoken rules of the business, the person you had dinner with last night might, if it is expedient, cut you dead at a fashion show the following morning. Somehow this ugly reality is found usual and acceptable.

headline: The Great Assimilation Debate
abstract: Pondering immigrant progress as the Senate debates immigration reform.
lead_paragraph: Now that the immigration bill is actually moving through the Senate, it seems worth returning to the debate over recent patterns in immigrant assimilation that I discussed in a column back in April. That piece made the point that while today’s second-generation immigrants still seem to be making real gains compared to their parents, there’s a fair amount of evidence showing a subsequent stall-out in advancement — both educational and economic, and particularly noticeable among the descendants of immigrants from Latin America — that leaves later generations stuck well short of full integration into the American middle class. If true, this would lend credence to the worry, common among immigration reform skeptics but apparently rarer among United States senators, that the accelerated pace of low-skilled immigration contemplated by the current legislation might be a recipe for ever-greater socioeconomic stratification.

headline: Study Shows Pill Prevents H.I.V. Among Drug Addicts
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Medicine and Health', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Research', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: Drug-injecting addicts who took an antiretroviral pill were half as likely to become infected with H.I.V. as those who did not, completing a body of evidence that such treatments can prevent AIDS in every group at risk.
lead_paragraph: Drug-injecting addicts who took a daily antiretroviral pill were half as likely to become infected with H.I.V. as those who did not, a major new study has found, providing the final piece of evidence that such treatments can prevent AIDS in every group at risk. Earlier clinical trials showed that the therapy can sharply reduce the risk of H.I.V. transmission from mother to child, and in gay and bisexual men and heterosexuals.

headline: Unproductive Finance

As he pointed out, the social value of that extra second would be minimal; but the private rewards could be huge.

Still a student in a Columbia University-Juilliard School joint-degree program, Mr. Tao has earned an Avery Fisher Career Grant, a Gilmore Young Artist Award and eight consecutive Ascap Morton Gould Young Composer Awards, to name only a few of his accolades.

headline: Beat Publication Celebrates Rock’s Cast of Characters
abstract: Beat, a new music publication from England, celebrates rock’s cast of characters.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to believe that Beat, a free print publication with top fashion photographers shooting its covers, actually exists, let alone exists under the radar. The twice-yearly newspaper out of East London can be spotted just behind the counter at Bookmarc and Opening Ceremony. Founded by the D.J. and writer Hanna Hanra, Beat makes you feel like a fan again. “I was tired of how boring and beard-strokey music magazines were,” Ms. Hanra said. “And tired of how style magazines would only feature a band if they thought they were cool or looked cool. What I wanted was a stylish music magazine.” What she created is a celebration of music and its intriguing cast of characters. (The cool factor is way high.) The latest issue, below, includes interviews with Zachary Cole Smith of the band DIIV, shot by Ryan McGinley, and another with the cover girl Sky Ferreira, shown above, shot by Letty Schmiterlow. Order back issues on thebeatjuice.com (you want the whole collection), and look for its official debut in the United States in September.

headline: Band of Outsiders Introduces Map-Print Shirt
abstract: Band of Outsiders introduces a map-print shirt for men.
lead_paragraph: For his fall collection for Band of Outsiders, Scott Sternberg took inspiration from a childhood fantasy of building a city from scratch. Maps became a key graphic reference, leading him to the multimedia artist Sam Durant, whose work explores social and political themes and who had a 2011 show that drew on cartography. Mr. Durant offered access to some of his imagery, which made its way onto this boyish slim-fit oxford-cloth shirt. Dad might not buy this one for himself, so you should give it to him for his special party shirt.

headline: Nektar De Stagni Creates Playful Bracelets
abstract: Nektar De Stagni creates playful bracelets.
lead_paragraph: The way Nektar De Stagni, a jewelry designer in Miami, sees it, “design is about the playful balance of contrasting materials and ideas.” That means this bracelet with freshwater pearls and smiley-face emoticon beads, $114; others with tiny gold and glass beads, $80; and a gold ring with a peacock pearl inset with a smiley in black pavé diamonds, $644. They’re not your grandmother’s pearls, but believe your granddaughters will appreciate them one day.

headline: Cesar Chavez Film to Avoid Immigration Debate
abstract: The backers of a new film about the Mexican-American activist Cesar Chavez are largely avoiding the overriding Latino issue of the moment — immigration reform.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For Participant Media, a nine-year-old Hollywood company with a fondness for films about social issues, the political minefield is comfortable terrain. In the recent past, the company plunged “Lincoln” into the fracas over partisanship, used “The Help” to highlight the plight of domestic workers and made “Promised Land” as a call for environmental action.

lead_paragraph: Bars for beer geeks tend toward sober pedantry. But Torst, an ambitious bar that opened in March, doesn’t let its serious beer menu get in the way of the Brooklyn scene.

They are pushing for a rapid negotiation of a trade agreement with the United States aimed at expanding commerce and creating jobs.

Once you had a second kid, you immediately left, so the kids could run around outside.”

lead_paragraph: ARDMORE, Pa. — Given a one-night break from parenting duties last year, Brandt Snedeker and his wife, Mandy, decided to watch “Moneyball” in their Nashville hotel room. Before it was half over, Snedeker’s wife was asleep and he had awakened the possibilities for taking his golf career to another level.

Or thousands of wild orchids blooming in the bogs that were paved over to build Kennedy Airport. Or carpets of pyxie moss flourishing in the Pine Barrens of New Jersey.

Or (why miss the boat?) is there an opportunity to create a fresh interpretation of resort, as Raf Simons demonstrated in May with his first Dior resort show?

She enlisted her interior designer, Bachman Clem, to work with her selling vintage children’s designs, and Kinder Modern was born.

headline: ‘Michigan Modern’ Opens at the Cranbrook Art Museum
abstract: An exhibit of the design that shaped the country starts on June 14.
lead_paragraph: The state that was the center of both the automotive and furniture industry for most of the 20th century has never been given due regard for its design influence. That’s the premise of “Michigan Modern: Design that Shaped America,” which opens on June 14 at the Cranbrook Art Museum in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Curated by Gregory Saldaña and Monica Ponce de Leon, the exhibition features well-known innovators like Eliel and Eero Saarinen, Florence Knoll and Henry Ford. But dozens of less-known figures also get to shine, including the textile designer Marianne Strengell, whose aluminum rug for Alcoa will be on view, and the architect William Muschenheim, whose 1954 home in Ann Arbor is shown here. A map room highlights every Michigan city that has made a design contribution, from Grosse Pointe to Kalamazoo. Through Oct. 13: (248) 645-3320 or cranbrook.edu.

Georgis.” The monograph, published last month by the Monacelli Press, manages to turn the polite conventions of design books upside down.

abstract: The nun set fire to herself during a religious ceremony is still alive and in a hospital, according to reports from Tibetan advocacy groups and Radio Free Asia.
lead_paragraph: A Tibetan nun who self-immolated on Tuesday in Sichuan Province in China during a religious ceremony is still alive and in a hospital, according to reports from Tibetan advocacy groups and Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the United States government. The nun set fire to herself near Nyatso monastery in Tawu County. Free Tibet said about 3,000 monks from 60 monasteries had gathered to take part in a debate festival.

headline: New Party Picks Putin as Leader
abstract: The All-Russian People’s Front, a political group, chose President Vladimir V. Putin as its leader on Thursday at its founding convention.
lead_paragraph: The All-Russian People’s Front, a political group, chose President Vladimir V. Putin as its leader on Thursday at its founding convention. The group, created two years ago in preparation for national parliamentary and presidential elections, is seen as a potential replacement for United Russia, the party that controls Parliament but is increasingly unpopular with the public. Mr. Putin, speaking at the event in downtown Moscow, said the All-Russian People’s Front would operate above politics. The anticorruption blogger Aleksei A. Navalny branded United Russia as “the party of swindlers and thieves” — a moniker that has stuck.

headline: Venezuela Review Confirms Vote
abstract: A government review of electronic voting results from Venezuela’s recent election has been completed and confirmed the victory of President Nicolás Maduro, the head of the National Electoral Council said.
lead_paragraph: A government review of electronic voting results from Venezuela’s recent election has been completed and confirmed the victory of President Nicolás Maduro, the head of the National Electoral Council announced this week. Mr. Maduro, the handpicked successor of former president Hugo Chávez, who died in March, won by just 1.5 percentage points. Tibisay Lucena, the electoral council president, announced the completion of the audit on Tuesday. The review was begun at the request of the losing candidate in the April 14 election, Henrique Capriles Radonski. But Mr. Capriles refused to take part in the review, calling it a sham.

headline: Egypt’s Ex-Security Chief Is Acquitted
abstract: An Egyptian criminal court acquitted the former chief of a Mubarak-era security service of charges that they destroyed documents that could have implicated members of their feared apparatus in crimes.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian criminal court acquitted the former chief of a Mubarak-era security service and 40 other officers on Wednesday of charges that they destroyed documents that could have implicated members of their feared apparatus in crimes. Protesters who stormed the State Security headquarters in Cairo and Alexandria after the revolution in 2011 found piles of shredded and burned documents. The armed forces, which ran the country after President Hosni Mubarak stepped down, took control of the facilities and later dissolved State Security, replacing it with a new internal security service.

headline: Record Corn and Soybean Yields Are Predicted
abstract: The Department of Agriculture estimated that 14 billion bushels of corn will be produced this year, but late planting may reduce the harvest.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The government is predicting record corn and soybean yields this year despite intense spring showers that have delayed planting, damaged crops already in the ground and prevented farmers from sowing all of their seeds. But the projections are based on estimates made before the heavy rains came about how many acres of crops will be planted.

headline: Chief Executive Linked to I.M.F. Official Faces Inquiry
abstract: Stéphane Richard, the chief executive of France Télécom, is being investigated on suspicion of organized fraud, according to the Paris prosecutor’s office.
lead_paragraph: French prosecutors said Wednesday that Stéphane Richard, the chief executive of France Télécom, would be formally investigated for his role in a politically charged case that has already shined an uncomfortable spotlight on his former boss, Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund. Mr. Richard has denied wrongdoing. He is being investigated on suspicion of organized fraud, according to the Paris prosecutor’s office. Investigators are examining a 2008 arbitration case in which Bernard Tapie, a businessman, was awarded $535 million to settle a dispute with Crédit Lyonnais, a state-owned bank. Mr. Tapie had been a career Socialist, but he switched his allegiance in 2007 to the center-right party led by the president at the time, Nicolas Sarkozy. Acting on a complaint from Socialist deputies, prosecutors began an investigation to learn if Mr. Tapie might have received special treatment in the case, which Mr. Tapie denied. They are also trying to understand why government officials did not challenge the outcome despite indications of possible anomalies in the procedure. At the time of the arbitration, Mr. Richard was chief of staff to Ms. Lagarde, who was Mr. Sarkozy’s finance minister from 2007 to 2011. Ms. Lagarde has herself come under suspicion for allowing the arbitration.

headline: Police Agencies Are Assembling Records of DNA
abstract: Local law enforcement agencies have moved into what had been the domain of the F.B.I. and state crime labs, and the trend is expected only to accelerate after a recent Supreme Court decision.
lead_paragraph: Slowly, and largely under the radar, a growing number of local law enforcement agencies across the country have moved into what had previously been the domain of the F.B.I. and state crime labs — amassing their own DNA databases of potential suspects, some collected with the donors’ knowledge, and some without it.

headline: Barbara Vucanovich, 91, Dies; Served Nevada in Congress

lead_paragraph: Barbara Vucanovich, who traveled from New York to Reno, Nev., in 1949 to get a quick divorce and ended up staying and becoming the first woman to be sent to Congress from Nevada, serving seven terms in the House as a conservative Republican, died on Monday at an assisted-living facility in Reno. She was 91.

headline: Band of Heavy Weather Ravages Midwest

lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — An enormous string of thunderstorms whipped through the Upper Midwest on Wednesday and barreled toward the Atlantic Coast overnight and into Thursday, blanketing a vast swath of the country with high winds, large hail and rain. More than a dozen tornadoes were reported throughout the Midwest on Wednesday, from Iowa to Indiana.

lead_paragraph: MUMBAI— Few places in congested Mumbai are as unexpected and uplifting as its racecourse, a 225-acre expanse located near a sweep of coastline in the island city. Built on the swampy flats of Mahalaxmi in 1883, the racecourse hosts a 2,400-meter (2,600-yard) track for the annual races, as well as tony restaurants and South Mumbai’s only helipad. But it’s the oval of green – and the inner walking track – that brings people here every day for a dose of open sky and earth.

headline: Cities of God

Standing at a clear plexiglass podium, a woman of about 40 is making a speech. Human participation alone, she says, “does not have the ability to reverse the darkness”; only the light from faith in God can. “Which is why we are gathered here today, and I, Alicia Margarita Arellanes Cervantes, give Monterrey, Nuevo León, to our Lord Jesus Christ, so that his kingdom of peace and blessings may be established.”

headline: Lincoln Center Theater Announces New Season
abstract: A new play by the Pulitzer Prize winner Bruce Norris and a new Broadway production of “Macbeth” starring Ethan Hawke will open the theater’s 2013-14 season this fall.
lead_paragraph: Lincoln Center Theater will open its 2013-14 season this fall with the world premiere of “Domesticated,” a new play by the Pulitzer Prize winner Bruce Norris (“Clybourne Park”), and a new Broadway production of “Macbeth” starring Ethan Hawke, the theater announced on Thursday. The season will also include Tony Award winner James Lapine’s adaptation of Moss Hart’s autobiography “Act One,” and a new play by Anthony Giardina about a political doyenne in Washington, D.C.

headline: Helping Older Americans Avoid Swindles
abstract: A new educational tool from the F.D.I.C., called Money Smart for Older Americans, aims to help people protect themselves against financial abuses.
lead_paragraph: The financial exploitation of older Americans is of growing concern as the population ages. Anyone can be targeted for fraud, but older people are particularly vulnerable because they may be isolated or lonely, or suffer from cognitive impairments. The simple sketches arranged by the Israeli artist Michal Rovner tell the story of loss, fear and hope through the eyes of the 1.5 million children killed in the Nazi Holocaust.

headline: Business and Pleasure, Imported
abstract: AC Hotels by Marriott, a joint venture of Marriott International and the Spanish group AC Hotels, will be coming to North America.
lead_paragraph: Since it began in 2011, AC Hotels by Marriott, a joint venture of Marriott International and the Spanish group AC Hotels, has tried to attract young, design-minded, tech-savvy business travelers across Europe with features including lounge-like lobbies that serve cocktails and libraries with wide work tables and free Wi-Fi. This month Marriott International announced plans to import the brand to North America, a move that follows the company’s recent announcement that it will team with the parent company of the furniture maker Ikea to create Moxy, a chain of budget hotels across Europe. The company said it plans to open its first hotel in 2014, with San Diego, New York and Miami, above, as candidates.

headline: Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner
abstract: Sarah Smiley, a military wife and writer, finds that her 11-year-old son has his own unexpected story to tell.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, I interviewed Sarah Smiley for the magazine, for a profile that ran with the headline “Confessions of a Military Wife.” Sarah’s husband, Dustin, a naval pilot, was based in Pensacola, Fla., and I spent a few days with her there, along with her sons, Ford and Owen, then 4 and 2. Sarah was 29, and the author of “Shore Duty,” a nationally syndicated weekly newspaper and magazine column with two million readers. She wrote about everything from spouse club (all the spouses were women) to meddling mothers-in-law. Her warm, straightforward style was a refreshing change from the orders and protocol of the navy, and she had just published a memoir, “Going Overboard: The Misadventures of a Military Wife.”

abstract: Dealing with issues of a suddenly tolerant father, an entertainment news blackout, housekeeping inequality and the slow trickle of gifts.
lead_paragraph: I am a lesbian in my early 30s. That is, until he met his new girlfriend, who happens to have a gay son. Now, like magic, my partner and I are honored guests whenever we visit. I’d like to slap him across the face for his transparent, new acceptance. But I am hoping you have a better way to handle this.

headline: I’ll Have What She’s Having
abstract: Daniel Bergner argues that bias has obscured the existence, strength and significance of female sex drive.
lead_paragraph: Galen of Pergamum, the great physician and medical researcher of antiquity, was one of many learned men of his time who believed that women had to have an orgasm during sexual intercourse for conception to occur. For 1,500 years this was the scientific consensus. How could we have continued to believe in the necessity of female orgasm when there must have been all kinds of evidence to the contrary? No one is sure, according to Daniel Bergner. When it comes to the study of female sexuality, scientists have tended to see what they expect, or want, to see, and there are fewer established facts than you would think. “Despite all the powers of contemporary science,” Bergner writes, “the seemingly straightforward anatomical question, is there a G spot? remains unanswered.”

headline: Lone Star
abstract: A multigenerational saga follows the fortunes of one Texas clan.
lead_paragraph: Bad historical novels — which is to say, most historical novels — are bad in exactly the same way: stuffed with the usual rogues’ gallery of historically certified villains, they’re banal costume dramas, predestined in their epiphanies and as insufferable in their virtue as a teenage vegan. The past is mere stage set for a morality play with a foregone conclusion. The heroes may wear hoopskirts or codpieces, but they possess the latest in glittering modern consciences. The Rebel drummer boy, for instance, discovers his affinity with the escaped slave instead of shooting him. Readers are made to feel superior to their ancestors. They think: We wouldn’t have been Confederates, Nazis, Pharisees, Canaanites, Phalangists, Visigoths and so on. And we certainly wouldn’t have pranced about in a codpiece.

The program, “Swinging With the Big Bands,” repeated on Thursday, was the season finale of his Jazz at Lincoln Center series exploring the intersection of jazz and popular song, With fresh creative input, the series has blossomed into a finely balanced fusion of entertainment, historical erudition and first-rate musicality.

headline: A Veteran Player Introduces Himself As a Rookie Coach

They talked about finding a front-office role, or maybe a broadcasting gig, or just stepping back and spending time on a golf course. But the subject soon turned to coaching.

headline: Relief Pitcher
abstract: You can do better than just another mimosa.
lead_paragraph: There are some people who adore brunch and plan every weekend around it like a sacred rite. And then there are those who loathe it with equal fervor. I see merits in both points of view. I’m not going to wait in line for eggs Benedict and mimosas at a cafe, but bringing friends together earlyish in the day, at home, promotes a particularly low-key kind of leisure, with none of the formality of a dinner party. You don’t have to dress up. You might still have many daylight hours ahead to hit the beach (or to get work done, if you must). You could also get a pretty decent buzz.

headline: An Exacting Art, Delighting in Every Petal and Pistil
abstract: “Gardening by the Book,” an exhibition of botanical volumes at the Grolier Club, stirs the senses while offering an intriguing look at intellectual history.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a thought experiment. In one room is a beautiful flower in a vase — an exotic orchid, say. In an adjacent room is a watercolor of that flower, executed with extraordinary technical and observational skill. You can enter only one room. Which do you choose?

headline: Twinkly Totems of Fame, Theirs for the Taking
abstract: “The Bling Ring” was inspired by the true story of affluent Hollywood teenagers who broke into celebrities’ homes to steal luxury items.
lead_paragraph: In her last two movies — the sublime “Somewhere” and the seductive “Marie Antoinette” — Sofia Coppola has focused her rigorous attention on characters living inside bubbles of privilege, fairy tale precincts where the invisible magic of wealth and power makes wishes come true. Stephen Dorff’s drifting movie star and Kirsten Dunst’s capricious young queen both lead pampered existences of a kind that make them easy objects of envy and resentment, but Ms. Coppola examines them with detached, quiet sympathy, refusing to mock or judge. She anatomizes the spiritual conditions of people who might have seemed to be case studies in shallow, carefree materialism.

Because then you would see that the head is pieced together out of beige and white Lego blocks, their studs protruding. Leonardo’s “Mona Lisa,” on display nearby, has a smoother surface, composed of 4,573 “bricks” (as they are called by aficionados), but you’d never mistake it for the original — the overall effect is more allusion than illusion.

headline: Where Being Gay Is a Life-and-Death Struggle
abstract: The documentary “Call Me Kuchu” chronicles the struggles of the gay rights movement in Uganda, and its prime mover, David Kato, who was bludgeoned to death in January 2011.
lead_paragraph: As you listen to Ugandan politicians and preachers rant against homosexuality in the documentary “Call Me Kuchu,” a chilling sense of reliving the past sets in. “Kuchu” is a synonym for “queer” in Uganda. It is commonplace in many African countries nowadays for homosexuality to be denounced as an un-African disease imported from abroad. But as this movie shows, in rallies and workshops conducted by visiting American evangelicals like Lou Engle and Scott Lively, virulent homophobia is the real import.

headline: Elite Assassins Wield Spinning Blades That Slice Off Heads
abstract: Andrew Lau, best known for the “Infernal Affairs” trilogy, goes back in time and dreams up new ways of killing in “The Guillotines.”
lead_paragraph: Swords flash and heads roll, spin and bounce in “The Guillotines,” a sumptuous tale about bad men and good, peasants and rulers and what happens to a movie when it is sliced and diced into progressively more forgettable itty bits. Directed by Andrew Lau, best known in the United States for the terrific “Infernal Affairs” trilogy, the new movie takes place during the Qing dynasty, China’s last imperial era. Guns are the latest looming threat, though their danger is largely dwarfed by the man on the throne, Emperor Yongzheng (Wai-keung Lau), who ruled from 1722 to 1735.

headline: The Condemned Man and His Two Burdens
abstract: Sergei Loznitsa’s “In the Fog” follows a suspected Nazi collaborator toward his fate in a Russian forest.
lead_paragraph: Not long into the haunting, haunted, beautifully shot “In the Fog,” a film about fate and free will, a wrongly accused man meets his executioners. The condemned, Sushenya, insists that he’s innocent, but fails to convince his would-be exterminators, Burov and Voitik. It’s World War II, and the men are traveling through a Russian forest: a time and a place in which good and evil appear as unambiguous as the Nazi occupiers and partisan fighters creeping through the trees. Sushenya appears resigned to his doom and even asks, with unnerving calm, if he should bring a shovel. Yet when the men stop at a proposed execution site, he also complains that the area floods. And so they move on.

Hurried out of the gate, Paynter took control of Friday’s allowance race early while being put under pressure from Majestic City. Coming off the turn, Paynter was allowed to draw away and won under mild encouragement by more than four lengths, earning a 114 Beyer speed figure.

headline: Turning Up the Voices From the Background
abstract: The documentary “20 Feet From Stardom” seeks to rewrite the history of pop music by focusing attention on voices at once marginal and vital.
lead_paragraph: The song that plays over the opening titles of “20 Feet From Stardom,” Morgan Neville’s new documentary, is Lou Reed’s “Walk on the Wild Side,” a provocative choice and also an appropriate one. The notorious lyrics of the chorus — “and the colored girls sing/doo, da-doo, da-doo, doo doo doo doo ... ” — establish the movie’s subject and also its reason for being. This generous, fascinating documentary about the careers of backup singers, most of them African-American women, seeks to rewrite the history of pop music by focusing attention on voices at once marginal and vital.

headline: Reading Marx in Tehran
keywords: ['Elections', 'Political Prisoners', 'Torture', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Iran’s Islamic revolution has forgotten about the working class.
lead_paragraph: IRAN’S presidential election on June 14 will be neither free nor fair. The candidates on the ballot have been preselected in a politically motivated vetting process that has little purpose other than ensuring the election of a compliant president who will be loyal to Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. Regardless of the outcome of the vote, the most urgent challenge for both the next president and Ayatollah Khamenei will be to confront a rising tide of discontent resulting from a rapidly deteriorating economic situation.

abstract: The naked dominance of today’s success ethic has contributed to a loss of cultural dynamism, maybe even social stagnancy.
lead_paragraph: About a century ago, Walter Judd was a 17-year-old boy hoping to go to college at the University of Nebraska. His father pulled him aside and told him that, though the family had happily paid for Judd’s two sisters to go to college, Judd himself would get no money for tuition or room and board.

headline: Department of Energy’s Crusade Against Leaks of a Potent Greenhouse Gas Yields Results
abstract: An effort at the Department of Energy has stanched leaks of sulfur hexafluoride equivalent to 1.1 million tons of carbon dioxide.
lead_paragraph: Every year, the United States Department of Energy’s far-flung operations generate millions of tons of climate-warming greenhouse gases. By tightening valves, replacing worn gaskets and such, Josh Silverman and the department’s engineers have managed to cut the annual leaks of one gas by about 35,000 pounds.

headline: 1-Iron, Made Famous by Hogan, Is Largely Absent
abstract: A golf club that Ben Hogan used to help him win a major title in 1950 has found a second use: as a line of demarcation, dividing generations.
lead_paragraph: ARDMORE, Pa. — Sixty-three years before the most utilitarian stick in any player’s bag at Merion Golf Club became the umbrella, Ben Hogan ennobled the 1-iron with a 213-yard second shot on the 18th hole during the final round of the 1950 United States Open.

headline: Florida: Zimmerman Jury Will Be Sequestered
abstract: Jurors in the murder trial of George Zimmerman will be sequestered, Judge Debra S. Nelson ruled Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Jurors in the murder trial of George Zimmerman will be sequestered, Judge Debra S. Nelson ruled Thursday as jury selection continued for a fourth day. The judge’s ruling came after a request from the defense. Lawyers from both sides told the judge they expected the trial to last two to four weeks. Mr. Zimmerman, a neighborhood watch volunteer, is charged with second-degree murder in the death of an unarmed teenager, Trayvon Martin.

headline: A Brilliant Book Illustrator Who Broke the Rules
abstract: “Far Out Isn’t Far Enough” is a portrait of the acclaimed book illustrator Tomi Ungerer, who ruffled feathers with his subversive art.
lead_paragraph: Brad Bernstein’s captivating documentary “Far Out Isn’t Far Enough” is a portrait of an illustrator, Tomi Ungerer; a time, largely the 1950s and ’60s; a place, New York City (mostly); and an industry, children’s book publishing. It is also a record of a man’s tormented youth, his broad artistic impulses and the price he paid for following them.

headline: Bloomberg Calls Court Monitor for Police a ‘Terrible Idea’
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said of the Justice Department’s arguments in favor of a monitor: “I don’t know what experience they have in the streets of New York City.”
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Thursday criticized recommendations by the Justice Department in the federal suit over the stop-and-frisk tactic, calling its embrace of a court-appointed monitor for the New York Police Department, should the city lose the case, a “terrible idea.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Which Genes Can Be Patented?
abstract: The United States Supreme Court ruled against patenting genes, but allowed cDNA to be patented. In this video, the medical reporter Gina Kolata explains the difference.
lead_paragraph: The United States Supreme Court ruled against patenting genes, but allowed cDNA to be patented. In this video, the medical reporter Gina Kolata explains the difference.

headline: Who Will Succeed President Ahmadinejad?
keywords: ['Elections', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: The election gives the United States a fresh diplomatic opportunity to avoid a dangerous confrontation over Iran’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: Even before the vote on Friday, Iran’s presidential election has to be seen as deeply flawed. The Guardian Council that vets candidates disqualified more than 600 potential contenders, including Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a former president. Only six names are on the ballot, all men who are acceptable to the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s real power. Reformers who led protests after President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad’s fraudulent 2009 re-election remain under house arrest, and there has been a new crackdown on newspapers, political activists and foreign journalists.

headline: A Loud Message to the N.Y.P.D.
abstract: Federal officials finally spoke out on stop-and-frisk and urged use of an independent monitor if the program is found unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: After years of sitting on the sidelines, the United States Justice Department has finally made itself heard in the federal civil rights lawsuit by New Yorkers who say the Police Department has been illegally detaining hundreds of thousands of people on the streets each year based not on suspicious behavior but on race.

headline: Clarity on Patenting Nature
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Editorials', 'Breast Cancer', 'Ovarian Cancer']
abstract: The Supreme Court correctly found that there can be no monopoly rights on human genes.
lead_paragraph: In a unanimous ruling on Thursday, the Supreme Court correctly resolved one of the most important and complex disputes in a generation involving the intersection of science, law and commerce. The justices held that human DNA isolated from a chromosome cannot be patented because it is a product of nature.

headline: Keep the Women’s Rights Bill Intact
abstract: State Legislators are trying to chip away at Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s excellent bill that strives for equality for women in New York.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has proposed an excellent 10-point bill to protect women’s rights in New York State. The problem now is that legislators are trying to chip away at his effort, piece by piece, nibble by nibble.

headline: How Money Affects Morality
abstract: A study by researchers at Harvard and the University of Utah finds that the simple idea of money makes people more likely to subordinate their ethical standards.
lead_paragraph: From Judas Iscariot, who betrayed Jesus for 30 pieces of silver, to Bernard L. Madoff to the standard member of Congress fighting tirelessly to further the interests of campaign donors, human history is full of examples of money’s ability to weaken even the firmest ethical backbone.

headline: Quotation of the day for Friday, June 14, 2013
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, June 14, 2013.
lead_paragraph: “I’m a human here in this country now; I didn’t feel like I was before.”

headline: Young Indian Slackers, Biding Their Sweet Time
abstract: The Hindi comedy “Fukrey,” directed by Mrighdeep Singh Lamba, follows the tribulations of four young Delhi-ites.
lead_paragraph: A tale about loafers told at a loafer’s pace, the Hindi comedy “Fukrey” follows the tribulations of four young Delhi-ites. Directed by Mrighdeep Singh Lamba, the movie takes a good hour or so to introduce our moderately engaging heroes and their moderately engaging predicaments, before involving them in a chuckleheaded caper.

headline: García Endures Roller-Coaster Round at U.S. Open
abstract: Sergio García was seven over par after eight holes, but he rallied to finish at three-over 73 in the first round of the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: ARDMORE, Pa. — Sergio García’s play was as erratic as the weather Thursday at the United States Open. He scored a double bogey and a quadruple bogey early in the first round, and received some heckling, before he recovered somewhat to finish at three-over-par 73.

headline: South African President Visits Mandela
abstract: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa visited former President Nelson Mandela in the hospital on Thursday, saying that Mr. Mandela’s health had improved but that he remained in serious condition.
lead_paragraph: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa visited former President Nelson Mandela in the hospital on Thursday, saying that Mr. Mandela’s health had improved but that he remained in serious condition. “Madiba’s health continues to improve but his condition remains serious,” Mr. Zuma said, referring to Mr. Mandela, 94, by his clan name. Mr. Mandela was admitted to the hospital on Saturday to be treated for a recurrence of a lung infection. He has been in poor health for several years and suffers from lung ailments as a result of contracting tuberculosis during his 27 years as a political prisoner. It is Mr. Mandela’s fourth hospitalization since last December.

headline: F.B.I. Changes Course on Information Sharing
abstract: F.B.I. officials acknowledged  that in the aftermath of the Boston Marathon bombings they had changed procedures for sharing information about people who have been investigated for links to extremists.
lead_paragraph: F.B.I. officials acknowledged Thursday that in the aftermath of the Boston Marathon bombings they had changed procedures for sharing information about people who have been investigated for links to extremists. Under the new procedures, all case agents will be alerted when a person who is in one of the government’s databases travels, regardless of whether an investigation of the person is still open. Previously, only the heads of local terrorism task forces were alerted about such travel. In the aftermath of the bombings, it was not clear whether an agent who had investigated one of the bombers in 2011 had been informed that he had traveled to Russia. F.B.I. officials have said that if the agent had been informed, it probably would not have led the agent to reopen the investigation.

headline: At Hearing, 3 Mayoral Candidates Advocate Rent Freeze
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Landlords', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Christine C. Quinn, Bill de Blasio and John C. Liu spoke at an emotional hearing on proposed increases in New York City that pitted tenants against landlords.
lead_paragraph: At the Rent Guidelines Board public hearing on Thursday, much of the theater and drama were as always: tenants insisting that the proposed increase at rent-stabilized apartments in New York City was far too high, and landlords complaining that it was far too low.

headline: After Patent Ruling, Availability of Gene Tests Could Broaden
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Biotechnology', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Breast Cancer', 'Ovarian Cancer', 'Tests (Medical)']
abstract: The Supreme Court’s decision in effect ends a nearly two-decade monopoly by Myriad Genetics on genes that correlate with increased risk of some cancers.
lead_paragraph: Almost immediately after the Supreme Court ruled that human genes could not be patented, several laboratories announced they, too, would begin offering genetic testing for breast cancer risk, making it likely that that test and others could become more affordable and more widely available.

headline: Cuomo Agrees Not to Lower Pay Rates for Groups That Serve Disabled
abstract: Under the deal between lawmakers and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, part of a budget cut will be restored if there is no other way to avoid reducing reimbursement rates for nonprofit providers for people with developmental disabilities.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Faced with lingering concerns about one of the most contentious elements of the current state budget, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has acquiesced to legislation that would protect nonprofit organizations that provide services for people with developmental disabilities from possible cuts to their reimbursement rates.

headline: Man With a Power Tool Keeps Raising the Body Count
abstract: “Hatchet III,” the latest installment in the Hatchet series, follows Victor Crowley as he wields his murderous power tool.
lead_paragraph: When the title of a movie consists of a number and the name of a tool, expectations are likely to be pretty low. So it feels somewhat incongruous to call “Hatchet III” a disappointment. Yet it is, because the earlier installments in this franchise showed flashes of wit. This one — although, like its predecessors, written by Adam Green — is too busy with limb-severings and gunfire to bother being intelligent.

headline: Feeling at Home at Merion Golf Club
abstract: Merion, the site of the U.S. Open, is surrounded by residential neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: ARDMORE, Pa. — The Merion Golf Club is shoe-horned into a tightly spaced residential neighborhood, so players know the logistics and some of the day-to-day details are going to be different than the average PGA Tour tournament.

headline: Nicaragua Approves Building Its Own Canal
abstract: Lawmakers granted a Hong Kong company the right to build a $40 billion cross-country shipping canal that could compete with the Panama Canal if it is ever built.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Nicaraguan lawmakers moved one step closer to fulfilling a national dream on Thursday, granting a Hong Kong company the right to build a $40-billion cross-country shipping canal that could compete with the Panama Canal — if it is ever built.

headline: Secret Court Ruling Put Tech Companies in Data Bind
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: In 2008, a ruling by a surveillance court said to be against Yahoo discouraged technology firms from fighting data requests from the government.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a secret court in Washington, Yahoo’s top lawyers made their case. The government had sought help in spying on certain foreign users, without a warrant, and Yahoo had refused, saying the broad requests were unconstitutional.

headline: Guardians of Peru’s Treasures Stake Out Post Office to Block Smuggling
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Smuggling', 'Auctions', 'Black Markets', 'Mummies and Mummification', 'Postal Service and Post Offices']
abstract: A Culture Ministry team is trying to keep Peru’s ancient riches from being spirited out by mail, battling a depletion that began nearly 500 years ago with the Spanish conquest.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — Gladiz Collatupa, an archaeologist, once stashed six mummies at her parents’ house for safe keeping. That was when she dug for artifacts in the dirt of Peru, rich with the leavings of past cultures like the Inca and the Moche. Now she digs through packages at the post office instead, searching for ancient treasure being smuggled out of the country.

headline: Family Secrets Unravel All in a Day’s Work
abstract: Complications pile up when a young woman goes searching for a father she hasn’t seen since childhood in Erin Greenwell’s small-town comedy, “My Best Day.”
lead_paragraph: A daughter finds her estranged father and sister, and romantic love gets a reality check all on the same busy Independence Day in Erin Greenwell’s genial small-town comedy, “My Best Day.” A gently wry sense of humor about human foibles and some well-turned exchanges keep the proceedings drifting along pleasantly enough, until characters start convening for the requisite heart-to-hearts and making-up.

headline: Diary of a Hitler Aide Resurfaces After a Hunt That Lasted Years
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Nuremberg War Crimes Tribunal (1945-49)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: The journal of Alfred Rosenberg, dating from 1936 through 1944, was lost but never forgotten, and federal investigators have tracked it down.
lead_paragraph: Pages from the diary of a chief Hitler aide, Alfred Rosenberg, missing since the conclusion of the Nuremberg trials of Nazi leaders nearly 70 years ago, were briefly displayed on Thursday for the first time by the federal investigators who helped recover them. The diary, handwritten on loose-leaf pages with entries dating from 1936 through 1944, is likely to offer new insights into the decision to exterminate the Jews, infighting among top Nazi officials and the plunder of Europe’s art, said scholars at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington.

headline: Study Gauges Value of Technology in Schools
keywords: ['E-Learning', 'Education (K-12)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'National Assessment of Educational Progress', 'Mathematics', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: A review of federal data found that technology investments in schools had not changed the nature of education.
lead_paragraph: With school districts rushing to buy computers, tablets, digital white boards and other technology, a new report questions whether the investment is worth it.

headline: Arkansas: Exxon Is Sued Over March Pipeline Spill
keywords: ['Pipelines', 'Oil Spills', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Water Pollution', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The federal Department of Justice and Arkansas filed a complaint on Thursday against Exxon Mobil over an oil spill involving the company’s Pegasus pipeline.
lead_paragraph: The federal Department of Justice and Arkansas filed a complaint on Thursday against Exxon Mobil over an oil spill involving the company’s Pegasus pipeline. The complaint, filed in federal district court in Little Rock on behalf of the Environmental Protection Agency and Arkansas’s environmental quality department, asserts that the spill continues to pollute waterways and that Exxon did not promptly repair the pipeline, which carries heavy Canadian crude. The pipeline ruptured in Mayflower on March 29, and the complaint says many residents of the 22 homes evacuated have been unable to return. The plaintiffs are seeking damages under clean water laws. An Exxon Mobil spokesman said the company had yet to review the complaint and would continue to cooperate with government agencies.

headline: Eye-Opening Start for Mickelson at U.S. Open
abstract: After flying overnight from San Diego, a sleep-deprived Phil Mickelson shot a three-under 67 in the first round. Play was suspended with Luke Donald, through 13 holes, in the lead at four under.
lead_paragraph: ARDMORE, Pa. — The first time Phil Mickelson finished second at the United States Open was in 1999, when he lost to Payne Stewart by one stroke, a defeat made easier to swallow by the fact that he was about to become a father. The following day, Mickelson’s wife, Amy, gave birth to a daughter.

headline: Father Takes the Stage; Daughter, the Court
abstract: Father and daughter, art and athletics, with Charles Ives as a fantastical referee in Jessica Dickey’s “Charles Ives Take Me Home,” at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater.
lead_paragraph: The pioneering American composer of the title serves as referee between a father and daughter in “Charles Ives Take Me Home,” a slight but inventive new play by Jessica Dickey that opened on Thursday at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater. Although he died in 1954, well before the play’s events take place, Ives and his ministrations in the emotional tug of war between John Starr (Drew McVety) and his daughter, Laura (Kate Nowlin), make a kind of spiritual sense. The father-daughter conflict arises from their differing passions — music and sports — and Ives was a gifted amateur athlete and a composer of genius.

headline: Bruno Bartoletti, Maestro Who Shaped Lyric Opera of Chicago, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Bartoletti was considered a superb interpreter of the 19th- and early-20th-century music of Italian masters.
lead_paragraph: Bruno Bartoletti, the Florentine maestro who as principal conductor and artistic director of Lyric Opera of Chicago helped shape its reputation both for stellar productions of Italian masterpieces and for adventurous modern works, died on Sunday, the day before his 87th birthday, in Florence.

headline: Words After ‘Oh Well’
abstract: Friday with Patrick Berry.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I was psyched when I looked over this grid by Patrick Berry. Oh boy, a pair of double stacks, I thought, and they have to be great because, you know, Patrick Berry.

headline: Bus-Fare Protests Hit Brazil’s Two Biggest Cities
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Buses']
abstract: The protests have been notably unruly in Brazil’s largest city, São Paulo, where police officers arrested dozens of protesters on Thursday night. Demonstrations also took place in Rio de Janeiro.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Protests by an increasingly forceful movement coalescing against increases in bus fares shook Brazil’s two largest cities on Thursday night, the fourth time in a week that activists have taken to the streets in demonstrations that have been marked by clashes with security forces.

headline: Cabdriver Fatally Stabbed by Passenger in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: The taxi crashed into parked cars during the confrontation and a man and a woman were seen fleeing afterward, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A taxi driver was fatally stabbed in the eye by a passenger while driving in Brooklyn on Thursday, causing the cab to crash into two parked cars during the evening rush, the police said.

headline: Hunting for Monster Waves Far Out on the Sea
abstract: Two Australian buddies who are professional surfers go out to sea in search of newer and bigger waves.
lead_paragraph: From the seminal “Endless Summer” to “Step Into Liquid” to “Riding Giants,” surf documentaries burnish a man-at-one-with-nature mythology all their own. “Storm Surfers 3D,” the latest in a series of films about two Australian big-wave hunters and tow-in surfing, feels something like a breed apart.

headline: Syria’s Death Toll
abstract: The United Nations used counts from Syrian human rights groups and a government database to establish the war’s death toll.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations used counts from Syrian human rights groups and a government database to establish the war’s death toll.

headline: Bloomberg Reporters’ Practices Become Crucial Issue for Company
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Many people claim the company encourages its news operation and business side to work together.
lead_paragraph: Most journalists dream of uncovering government corruption, landing a big interview or winning a Pulitzer Prize. But those are not the goals that Thomas F. Secunda, who co-founded Bloomberg L.P. in 1982 with Michael R. Bloomberg, has in mind.

headline: Car Trouble of the Unexpected Kind
abstract: Nearly all the action and drama happens in a rental car in “Vehicle 19,” a film by Mukunda Michael Dewil.
lead_paragraph: Since “Vehicle 19” takes place largely inside a car, let’s use a road analogy to dissect it. At a pivotal point, it takes the wrong fork in the road.

headline: Freshpet Dog Food Promotes Products Sourced in the U.S.
abstract: The refrigerated dog food maker takes a patriotic turn in a new campaign to highlight its fresh ingredients.
lead_paragraph: IN 2006, when Freshpet introduced dog food that required refrigeration, a novelty in the pet food aisle, retailers were skeptical that they should remodel to accommodate the free refrigerators the brand offered. But after widespread pet food recalls in 2007 linked to contaminated wheat gluten from China, consumers and retailers both warmed to the brand’s promise of fresh ingredients without preservatives, and distribution today has grown to about 9,200 stores, including Walmart, Target, Whole Foods and Petco.

headline: Solution to His Love Problems?: Baby Formula
abstract: A Paris illustrator tries to win back his ex-girlfriend through unorthodox means in “The Stroller Strategy,” directed by Clément Michel.
lead_paragraph: In “The Stroller Strategy,” Clément Michel’s forgettable French comedy of redemptive responsibility, a Paris illustrator in his 20s named Thomas tries to win back his ex-girlfriend, Marie, through unorthodox means. When a neighbor’s baby ends up in his care, he uses the kid to get Marie’s attention. His efforts try her patience and ours.

headline: Clinton Project Promotes ‘Open Badges’ Online Credentials
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'E-Learning', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Former President Bill Clinton announced a project on Thursday to expand the use of Open Badges — online credentials that employers or universities can use in hiring, admissions, promotions or awarding credit.
lead_paragraph: Working with Mozilla, the MacArthur Foundation and a consortium interested in virtual learning, former President Bill Clinton announced a project on Thursday to expand the use of Open Badges — online credentials that employers or universities can use in hiring, admissions, promotions or awarding credit. The badges serve as credentials that can help self-taught computer programmers, veterans returning to civilian life and others show skills they learned outside a classroom. At the Clinton Global Initiative America meeting in Chicago Thursday, DePaul University and the Information Technology Industry Council pledged to incorporate badges into their hiring, admissions or credentialing.

headline: Yankees Are Swept, Falling to A’s in 18 Innings
abstract: Nate Freiman singled home a run to give the A’s a victory in a series finale that lasted 5 hours 35 minutes. The Yankees scored twice in the first inning and then went 17 innings without a run.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — As the innings flickered by Thursday, heads drooped in the outfield, shadows lengthened, and the stands slowly thinned out, as did the bullpens. One by one a stream of relatively unknown pitchers jogged in from the bullpens to help prolong a game that defied closure for more than five hours.

headline: Harold J. Cromer, Vaudeville Duo’s Stumpy, Is Dead
abstract: Mr. Cromer, who was in his 90s, was part of Stump and Stumpy, a comedy team that played the black theater and nightclub circuit from the 1930s to the ’50s, including the Apollo Theater in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Harold J. Cromer, a hoofer and comedian who as Stumpy, half of the vaudevillian duo Stump and Stumpy, performed antic dance routines in clubs around the country after World War II and later on television, died on June 8 at his home in Manhattan. He was in his early 90s.

headline: Conservatives Urged to Back Immigration Overhaul
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Foreign Workers', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The former governors Jeb Bush of Florida and Haley Barbour of Mississippi want conservatives to argue that immigrants are essential for economic growth.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The former governors Jeb Bush of Florida and Haley Barbour of Mississippi, two of the Republican Party’s most outspoken advocates of overhauling the nation’s immigration laws, urged conservatives on Thursday to “change the conversation” on immigration by arguing that immigrant workers, both high-skilled and low-wage, are essential for economic growth.

headline: Joan H. Parker, 80, Mystery Writer’s Muse, Dies
abstract: Ms. Parker, the widow of Robert B. Parker, was a fund-raiser and an educator.
lead_paragraph: Joan H. Parker, the widow of the mystery writer Robert B. Parker and the inspiration for one of his most independent heroines, died on Wednesday in Boston. She was 80.

headline: Debating Stricter Immigration Enforcement
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization']
abstract: The House Judiciary Committee mulls provisions of the SAFE Act, which would criminalize many illegal immigrants.
lead_paragraph: As the Senate prepares to debate a path to citizenship for more than 11 million immigrants in the country illegally, the House Judiciary Committee argued in an open hearing on Thursday the nuances of a bill that would turn millions of those immigrants into criminals overnight.

headline: Private Preschools See More Public Funds as Classes Grow
abstract: Across the country, states and districts are increasingly funneling public funds to religious schools, private nursery schools and a variety of nonprofit organizations that conduct classes.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The preschoolers who arrived at school early for free breakfast on a recent morning quietly ate granola bars and yogurt as middle school students recited part of the rosary over the public address system.

headline: South Carolina Soul-Searching on Welfare of Children
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Group Homes', 'Sex Crimes', 'Foster Care']
abstract: The state is reviewing its child welfare system in the wake of a lawsuit by a boy who was raped in a home to which he was sent by the state.
lead_paragraph: By the time he was 11, the boy from rural South Carolina had already had more trouble than any child should.

headline: Nets Couldn’t Pass Up Hiring of Kidd
abstract: Despite his lack of coaching experience, Jason Kidd is sure to generate excitement the Nets desperately need.
lead_paragraph: From the moment Jason Kidd threw his ball in the game — a perfect bounce pass, no doubt — the Nets just knew they had lucked into the kind of slam dunk that would electrify the crowd. They were smitten by the notion of their onetime point-guard savior as their new coaching savant.

headline: In Park Slope, Years of Snipping
abstract: Joseph’s Haircutting Salon, operated by Joseph Volpicell,  an Italian immigrant, has become a fixture in the the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Joseph’s Haircutting Salon, operated by Joseph Volpicell,  an Italian immigrant, has become a fixture in the the neighborhood.

headline: Doug Bailey, G.O.P. Political Consultant, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Bailey founded The Hotline, a digest of political news, distributed by fax, that became an indispensable tool of the political trade in the pre-Web 1980s and ’90s.
lead_paragraph: Doug Bailey, who helped define the expanding role of political consultants in the 1960s and ’70s and later founded The Hotline, a digest of political news, distributed by fax, that became an indispensable tool of the political trade in the pre-Web 1980s and ’90s, died on Monday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 79.

headline: Of Shakespeare and Superheroes
abstract: There’s enough plot in Eric Rosen and Matt Sax’s “Venice,” the action-flooded new musical at the Public Theater, to fill a whole year in a Marvel comics series.
lead_paragraph: There’s enough plot in Eric Rosen and Matt Sax’s “Venice,” the action-flooded new musical at the Public Theater, to fill a whole year in a Marvel comics series. Though it borrows some of its story from Shakespeare’s “Othello” and much of its tone from apocalyptic movie blockbusters like “The Dark Knight Rises,”  this tale of a once-and-future civil war still seems to translate into two-dimensional panels as you watch it.

headline: For Decades, Cutting Hair and Winning Fans
abstract: Once you get a haircut at Joseph Volpicelli’s place in Park Slope, one customer says, “you don’t want to use anyone else.”
lead_paragraph: There has been a barbershop at 97 Seventh Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, for literally longer than anyone can remember.

headline: How Pixar Developed ‘Art’ for ‘Monsters University’
abstract: “Monsters University,” the prequel to “Monsters, Inc.,” has several new characters, including Art, a purple longhaired hippie-esque monster majoring in new-age philosophy.
lead_paragraph: For the 2001 comedy “Monsters, Inc.” Pixar Animation Studios devised all manner of squishy, creepy, cuddly, fuzzy, wobbly creatures to populate that tale of monsters who harness the energy of human screams to power their city. Now, the film’s prequel, “Monsters University,” opening June 21, takes its familiar lead characters — the short, green, one-eyed Mike and his tall, furry sidekick, Sully, back to school.

headline: Bruins’ Task After Triple-Overtime Defeat: Restore Focus and Fluids
abstract: The Blackhawks and the Bruins were exhausted after Game 1 of the finals, but Chicago’s Patrick Kane said his team would have an easier recovery because it was victorious.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals, a physically demanding and mentally exhausting battle of attrition, began Wednesday night and ended Thursday morning, with the Chicago Blackhawks celebrating a 4-3 triple-overtime victory over the Boston Bruins. The teams combined for 117 shots, 120 hits and 1,523 shifts in the fifth-longest game in finals history. Nineteen players logged more than 30 minutes of ice time.

headline: Lack of Local Revenue Limits Federal Money for Health Projects
abstract: The federal government’s financing of 1,100 experimental projects in Texas is pegged to funds raised by 20 regions.

headline: A Fat Dad Father’s Day
abstract: Father’s Day was not only about spoiling my dad but also about coming together as a family — using the recipes that had conjured fond memories from my parents’ past and creating new ones together.
lead_paragraph: My dad was never a morning person. No matter how many alarm clocks he would set, nothing could ever wake him. My mom often had to squirt him with cold water and I would have to tickle him under the chin so he could get to work on time. When he was little his mother, my Bubbe Mary, used to leave for work early. One morning while my dad was sleeping, there was a grease fire in a neighbor’s apartment, and my father slept through the sirens, the screaming and the firefighters breaking down the front door of his building.

headline: Women in Nepal Suffer Monthly Ostracization
abstract: In far western Nepal, menstruating women are exiled each month, leaving them vulnerable to rape and other horrors.

Barely looking at her baby, she glanced around the mud walls at the place she was raped. It was not strange for her to be in this space, haunted as it was with violent memories, because she still sleeps here each month when she is menstruating.

headline: The Big Five Orchestras No Longer Add Up
abstract: The notion of the “Big Five” American symphony orchestras seems to have lost its relevance in an ever more international music world.

Someone writing in The New York Times would refer to the Big Five American orchestras: the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, the Cleveland Orchestra, the New York Philharmonic and the Philadelphia Orchestra. And within hours, Peter Pastreich, the respected executive director of the San Francisco Symphony from 1978 to 1999, would beard The Times’s overseer of classical music — at the time, me — by telephone or e-mail, complaining that the term Big Five had long since outlived whatever usefulness it may once have had.

headline: Can a Juror Ever Fudge the Truth?
abstract: The ethics of disclosing or masking bias during jury selection.
lead_paragraph: About 15 years ago, while living in St. Louis, I was summoned for jury duty. The defendant was charged with two counts of murder. During jury selection, I was asked if I supported the death penalty. I don’t. I’m unalterably opposed to capital punishment. But I feared that potential jurors who did not support the death penalty could be automatically disqualified by the prosecution. So I said I agreed with capital punishment. That way, if it came down to it, I might help spare the defendant from execution. But this violated the oath I had taken to tell the truth. Was it ethical for me to lie in order to possibly spare the life of this defendant? NAME WITHHELD

headline: I Was Too Clever to Quit Smoking
abstract: Could a hypnotist fool me?
lead_paragraph: One central paradox of the smoker’s life is that, despite swallowing an almost comically flagrant deception, most smokers like to regard themselves as pretty smart people. Step outside any bar or restaurant, nip around the back of a conference room at coffee time, and you’ll see them: a bitter huddle of smarter-than-thou smokers, shooting down society’s sacred cows. Want to know how many people died while exercising last year? Ask a smoker. Think smoking kills you? Think again. Every smoker you meet will tell you about their Aunt Jenny or Uncle Steve who sucked back 90 a day and lived to be 100, and even then died only because their houses fell on them. No delusion or hypocrisy escapes the smoker’s gaze. Except, of course, his own.

headline: Can We Imagine the Life of a Terrorist?
abstract: A steady proliferation of books and films try to make sense of what drives suicide bombers. But few get it right.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, suicide bombings were still rare events. The political scientist Robert Pape counted a global total of 315 attacks from 1980, when they were first established as a modern terrorist method, through 2003. In the following two years, that number doubled. Today, the total is more than two thousand, and each day seems to bring news of more. Yet the tactic has not lost its power to shock and horrify. There has been a steady proliferation of efforts to make sense of it, not just among academics and policy wonks, but by novelists, filmmakers and artists the world over. John Updike (whose penultimate novel was “Terrorist”) and John le Carré may be better known in the West, but there are dozens of others who have tried to dramatize the world of violent jihad, including the Algerian novelist Yasmina Khadra and the Moroccan writer Mohammed Achaari.
