headline: Struggles Behind Him, a Poet of El Barrio Embraces Life
abstract: Earlier this year, Jesus Melendez, known as Papoleto, could not sleep because of a financial crisis. But after a story on his plight was published, his life changed.
lead_paragraph: Inside a cluttered living room six stories above East 111th Street in El Barrio, the sounds of construction crews and laughing children gave way to the strains of “Nessun Dorma,” the Unknown Prince’s aria from Puccini’s “Turandot.” Jesus Melendez sat at his computer, transfixed, his folded hands touching his lips.

headline: Wade’s Performance Calls to Mind His Form in ’06 Finals
abstract: Dwyane Wade scored more than 30 points for the first time since March 4, and added six rebounds and six steals in Miami’s Game 4 victory.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Dwyane Wade had just spent 40 minutes slashing and scoring and dominating, recalibrating expectations for him and his Miami Heat teammates, and so all he seemed to want late Thursday was a quiet moment to himself. Away from the cameras and the boom mikes and the rap music pulsing at the other end of the locker room, Wade looked down and closed his eyes. He folded his hands and propped up his head with his thumbs.

headline: In I.P.O., CDW to Fall Short of Boom-Era Valuation
abstract: The CDW Corporation disclosed plans to price its initial public offering at $20 to $23 a share, valuing the entire company at about $3.6 billion at the midpoint of that range, or half of what its owners paid for it in 2007.
lead_paragraph: When the CDW Corporation goes public, it is likely to be worth significantly less than what its private equity owners paid in boom times six years ago.

headline: Bonnaroo 2013: Mumford & Sons Cancels Its Saturday Concert
abstract: A second headliner, the rapper Earl Sweatshirt, also canceled after coming down with pneumonia.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Organizers at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival here were Informed on Thursday that Mumford & Sons, the festival’s Saturday headliner, had to cancel — not surprising, as the band’s bassist, Ted Dwane, was recently hospitalized for a blood clot in the brain, and the band had canceled other performances this week. (The band also canceled its performances next week at the Telluride Bluegrass Festival in Colorado and at the Cricket Wireless Amphitheater in Bonner Springs, Kan., and on a positive note, announced on Friday morning that Mr. Dwane had been released from the hospital.)

headline: From Fish, Birds and Ants, Undead Hordes
abstract: For “World War Z,” his zombie spectacular, the director Marc Forster sought to create legions of the undead that move together like a collective organism.
lead_paragraph: As a boy growing up in Switzerland, the director Marc Forster was obsessed with the way fish and birds, moving together, gracefully coalesced into a single organism, the multitudes swarming seamlessly as one.

headline: Federer Starts His Day With a Double Bagel
abstract: It was only Roger Federer’s second career 6-0, 6-0 win, which may come as a surprise given his near decade of tennis dominance and his 902 victories.
lead_paragraph: HALLE WESTFALEN, Germany — Roger Federer was given an unusually early start Friday at the Gerry Weber Open, set to play his quarterfinal against the German wild card Mischa Zverev at noon.

headline: The Gun Report: June 14, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The Gun Report is not the only Web site sounding the drumbeat on gun violence. Daily Kos has a feature, “Another Day in the (Gun Crazy) U.S.A.,” which was also started at the end of January. Penned by Tom Begnal, the blog tracks gun deaths via news clips and lists them by city, minus biographical details. There’s the interactive list that we quote at the end of each report, curated by Slate and @GunDeaths. And there’s the Huffington Post, which has launched an entire vertical dedicated to cataloging the stories of gun violence victims and survivors.

headline: Updates on Election Day in Iran
abstract: The Lede is following developments in Iran on Friday, where voters went to the polls in the first presidential election since the disputed contest in 2009.
lead_paragraph: The Lede followed developments in Iran, where voters went to the polls on Friday in the first presidential election since the disputed contest in 2009, as they unfolded. (For details on Saturday’s dramatic conclusion, see the next post on this blog.)

headline: Salzburg Festival, Losing Artistic Director to La Scala, Cuts Short His Term
abstract: Alexander Pereira, who is to take over as general manager of Teatro alla Scala in 2015, will be leaving the Salzburg Festival earlier than expected.
lead_paragraph: When Alexander Pereira was appointed last week as general manager of Teatro alla Scala, starting in 2015, the presumption was that he would remain in his current post, artistic director of the Salzburg Festival, until his contract ended in 2016. But the notion of a one-year overlap did not sit well with the festival’s board, which has decided to let him go at the end of September 2014.

headline: Wheelies: The Ask and You Shall Receive Edition
abstract: According to a study, women are more likely than men to get discounts on auto repair. Another study concludes that in-car infotainment is dangerous.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Feelings?
abstract: A self-professed sociopath (noncriminal) describes her charm, intelligence and absence of emotion.
lead_paragraph: As a teenager, M. E. Thomas — a fittingly egotistic pseudonym — was “so uniquely accomplished, talented and charming that I was naturally included on everyone’s list of people to know.” She went to indie movies and drummed in a rock band. Her friends idolized her. “Musicians are expected to be narcissistic and outrageous,” she writes. “You’re supposed to scream and dance wildly.” Nobody suspected that the screaming and the wild dancing were indicative not of awesomeness but of sociopathy.

headline: Bloomsday Memories
abstract: Notable fans of “Ulysses” recall the ways they have spent June 16 in years past.
lead_paragraph: Today is Bloomsday, when readers worldwide celebrate Leopold Bloom’s Dublin wanderings on June 16, 1904, in James Joyce’s “Ulysses.” To mark the event I asked a few notable fans of Joyce’s masterwork for memories of their own Bloomsdays.

headline: Visible Men
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Inside a Massachusetts prison, a creative-writing class experiences the power of words and stories.
lead_paragraph: The sliding door buzzes and rumbles open. The guard calls out: “Come on, you’re next.” I stand up from the waiting area pews, where I have stowed my bag, watch and jewelry in a locker, and step forward. I enter the trap, a room between outside and inside worlds. I turn my pockets inside out, remove my shoes, walk through the metal detector and receive an ultraviolet stamp on my wrist. Every few months for 12 years, I have visited a Massachusetts prison to teach creative writing to a group of locked-up men.

headline: Known Unknowns
abstract: Ascertaining the meaning of the ancient script Linear B becomes a detective story.
lead_paragraph: On March 30, 1900, during the excavation of the Palace of Knossos on the island of Crete, site of the legendary labyrinth from which Daedalus and Icarus took flight, workmen unearthed a clay tablet inscribed with an unknown script. Some of the characters of the script looked like the letters of an alien alphabet, others like alien hieroglyphics. In the following weeks and months workmen unearthed more tablets, several hundred of which had fallen from a floor above into a terra cotta bathtub.

headline: They’ve Come Undone
abstract: Two inexplicable tragedies leave a tight-knit family reeling in Elizabeth Hartley Winthrop’s third novel.
lead_paragraph: It has been nine months since Joan Jacobs’s beloved 17-year-old daughter, Sophie, took her own life by driving onto the railroad tracks in front of an oncoming train. At home in Maryland, Joan, a novelist, feels “Sophie’s absence has slowly woven itself into the fabric of reality.” Desperate for normalcy, she returns to a former sanctuary, the family’s summer house on Cape Ann, with the remains of her wounded clan: her husband, Anders, and their two younger girls, Eve and Eloise. But, somewhat oddly, Joan hasn’t realized that this historically happy place will issue fresh reminders of their loss. Once there, she is again forced to struggle with the mystery of why her daughter killed herself.

headline: The Cancer Monologue
abstract: Eve Ensler describes her personal and political struggles.
lead_paragraph: Eve Ensler is an activist, playwright and author with a reputation as a fearless champion of women — attesting to their pain and their joys, but most of all celebrating their stories. Ensler’s signature play, “The Vagina Monologues,” is a series of soliloquies that seek not only to honor and demystify women’s bodies but to reclaim that most intimate of possessions, a woman’s self seen through her own eyes. Its voices are tough, tender, hilarious and heartbreaking.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WE ARE ALL COMPLETELY BESIDE OURSELVES,  by Karen Joy Fowler. (Marian Wood/Putnam, $26.95.) This surreptitiously smart novel’s big reveal slyly recalls a tabloid headline: “Girl and Chimp Twinned at Birth in Psychological Experiment.”

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: MY POETS,  by Maureen N. McLane. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.) Part autobiography and part free-form criticism, this charismatically subversive book includes essays on poets canonical (Shelley, Dickinson) and contemporary (Fanny Howe, Louise Glück), as McLane tells how she learned to embrace the ambivalence of her own taste in poems and in people.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Colum McCann says that in writing about Frederick Douglass for his novel “TransAtlantic” (at No. 13 on the hardcover fiction list), he saw surprising parallels to President Obama.
lead_paragraph: THE SLAVE AND THE PRESIDENT: “Trans­Atlantic,” Colum McCann’s new novel about the longstanding ties between Ireland and America, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 13.

headline: Ask Well: How Often to Exercise
abstract: A reader asks: Does it really matter if I work out three days in a row, rather than spreading my exercise through the week?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Good-Luck Charms
abstract: First- and second-generation American girls make their own way in these tales.
lead_paragraph: Like many first-generation hyphenated Americans, I bore a murky cultural identity throughout my childhood. The daughter of Polish-born parents displaced by World War II, I carried my heritage as both a burden and a source of pride. Encountering, later, Cynthia Kadohata’s stirring novels focusing on cultural assimilation, and the beautifully understated picture books by the Asian-American writer and illustrator Allen Say, who documents the conflicting emotions of Japanese immigrants and first-generation Japanese-­Americans, I recognized the bittersweet richness of this kind of split heart.

headline: The Other Side
abstract: Two teenage protagonists strain against expectations in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Driving down from her Lebanese mountain village, 15-year-old Faten catches her first glimpse of the wide Mediterranean horizon. A daydream flickers past: “What if she opened the car door and ran towards the sea?” But she is her father’s prisoner, on her way to a life of servitude with a wealthy family in Beirut during the civil war.

headline: Now What?
abstract: Two foreign policy figures criticize, from differing directions, President Obama’s program.
lead_paragraph: For two years, Vali Nasr traveled to Pakistan and Afghanistan with Richard C. Holbrooke, the Obama administration’s special envoy to the region. One of Holbrooke’s first trips included India, where his domain was supposed to reach, and which was integral to solving the problem at hand. The Indians rebuffed the envoy, in part because they judged he knew little about the country. But mostly, they did not want anything to do with a mission that included India’s enemy, Pakistan. It was a rough start, and Holbrooke’s responsibility was reduced to two countries: AfPak, as he affectionately called his portfolio.

headline: Cry Wolf
abstract: In Benjamin Percy’s novel, the misunderstood lycanthrope population is being persecuted. And they’re not going to take it anymore.
lead_paragraph: A man boards an early-morning flight from San Francisco to Portland, Ore. Although dressed for business, in a charcoal suit and wingtips, he carries nothing in his briefcase “except some pens and a day-old newspaper.” Visibly nervous and sweating profusely, he deflects his seatmate’s attempts at small talk. Once the plane is airborne, he excuses himself to the restroom from which, moments later, comes a “drawn-out guttural rumbling.” The door flies open; he has transformed into a werewolf. He proceeds to tear apart the passengers, all but one. Elsewhere in the skies above America, the same thing is happening aboard two other aircraft. Of the three, two manage to land; the third crashes outside Denver, “a fiery smear in a wheat field.”

headline: Life and Limb
abstract: Carl Hiaasen’s “Bad Monkey” is another misadventure in the annals of greed and corruption in South Florida, “the Medicare-fraud capital of America.”
lead_paragraph: Any fears that Carl Hiaasen might be mellowing are put to rest by BAD MONKEY (Knopf, $26.95), another rollicking misadventure in the colorful annals of greed and corruption in South Florida. As “the Medicare-fraud capital of America,” this is the promised land for those erstwhile “mortgage brokers, identity thieves, arms dealers, inside traders and dope smugglers” who have found more lucrative careers in the health care racket. One swindler, Nicky Stripling, made millions billing Medicare for nonexistent motorized scooters he called Super Rollies. But his luck must have run out, because a tourist trolling for blackfin tuna near Key West has hauled in a hairy (and slightly chewed) human arm traceable via DNA to Stripling.

lead_paragraph: An unusual groundswell of support from House Republicans for a Massachusetts liberal’s measure is a stark example of changing sentiments on Afghanistan.

headline: The Mother of All ‘Housewives’
abstract: Without the dysfunctional Louds in “An American Family” and the riveting real-life drama of their household, televised by PBS in 1973, there may never have been the reality TV landscape.
lead_paragraph: It all began with “An American Family.” Without the dysfunctional Louds and the riveting real-life drama of their household, televised by PBS in 1973, there may never have been an MTV “Real World,” any “Real Housewives,” “Bachelors” or other inescapable figures from the reality TV landscape.

headline: The Pope and the ‘Gay Lobby’
abstract: The presence of gay prelates at the Vatican has long been considered an open secret. Now it’s not a secret at all.
lead_paragraph: The presence of gay prelates in the Vatican hierarchy has long been considered one of Rome’s open secrets. Now it’s not a secret at all. At a private audience on June 6, Pope Francis was quoted as saying: “The ‘gay lobby’ is mentioned, and it is true, it is there…We need to see what we can do.”

headline: A Summer Home in New York: Some Like It Hot
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Summer (Season)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: While Manhattanites fight traffic to escape the city in summer, a rare breed of part-timer is breezing in from the other direction.
lead_paragraph: During the sweltering summer months, many affluent people flee Manhattan for the Berkshires, the Hamptons, the Jersey Shore — anywhere they won’t melt. After all, the city’s busy streets and climbing skyline do not call to mind the traditional joys of summer: long, sunny days on the sand and in the surf, star-laden nights lighted by campfires and fireflies, the smells of freshly cut grass and slightly singed marshmallows.

headline: Man of Moment in the 1920s
abstract: A Criterion release of Harold Lloyd films, including the classic “Safety Last!” (1923), and the shorts anthology “Accidentally Preserved” celebrate comedy of the silent era.
lead_paragraph: ‘Safety Last!’

headline: The Choice Blog’s Valediction
abstract: The Times has discontinued The Choice blog, which was created in 2009 to help students demystify college admissions and financial aid.
lead_paragraph: The Times has discontinued The Choice blog, which was created four years ago to help students demystify college admissions and financial aid. Although we will no longer update the blog’s monthly college checklists, virtual guidance office sessions, and student posts, these evergreen resources will still be available in our online archives.

headline: The Secret Buried Cars of North Carolina’s Core Banks
abstract: Back when beach driving was completely unregulated, people would leave cars on the beach for fishing, then abandon them when they died. Some still remain.
lead_paragraph: HARKERS ISLAND, N.C. – Driving on the beach isn’t the most environmentally savvy of activities. Vehicles leak nasty fluids, driving them in saltwater sends huge chunks of iron and steel more quickly to the scrap heap, and their deep tire ruts make it difficult for baby sea turtles to reach the ocean as they scramble across the sand from freshly ruptured nests.

headline: The Real War on Reality
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Philosophy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The outsize role of private intelligence firms and their willingness to manufacture “truth” constitutes a sort of epistemic warfare.
lead_paragraph: If there is one thing we can take away from the news of recent weeks it is this: the modern American surveillance state is not really the stuff of paranoid fantasies; it has arrived.

headline: U.S. Pushes Agencies to Free Up Spectrum
abstract: The government said it would invest $40 million in the next year and $60 million more over the next five years to find ways to share lightly used airwaves.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three years after President Obama laid out an ambitious plan to double the country’s supply of airwaves for use in high-speed wireless Internet service, the White House on Friday announced efforts intended in part to spur participation by government agencies that have been slow to join the cause.

headline: An East Village Developer’s Name Game
abstract: A developer hopes to draw attention to a new condo by naming a section of the East Village where the building is located, but buyers are already attracted to its pricing.
lead_paragraph: As New York neighborhoods get sliced and diced like onions into increasingly small sections, a scrap of Lower Manhattan has now become the “Northwest East Village” — that is, if one is to believe the developers of a condominium there called the Jefferson.

headline: PKNY Folds Up Its (Drink) Umbrellas and Moves On
abstract: The Lower East Side tiki bar originally known as Painkiller has lost its lease, and the owners plan to open another spot.
lead_paragraph: Call it Painkiller. Call it PKNY. Either way, call it a day. Because, by July’s end, the semi-subterranean tiki bar on the Lower East Side that has gone by two names — but has rarely gone unnoticed — is shuttering after a tumultuous three-year run.

headline: All the Rage | The Countless Creepy Faces of Art Basel
abstract: One of the most alarming visual themes to emerge from the Swiss fair was an emphasis on grotesque representations of the human visage.
lead_paragraph: Some might argue that trying to identify a prevailing trend at a show as sprawling and diverse as Art Basel — the original, Swiss edition of the semiannual art fair, which hosts 300 galleries across 300,000 square feet and spans the last century of contemporary art — is a fool’s errand. Shortly after the show opened on Tuesday, an informal survey of artists and gallerists produced a list of observed motifs that included the return of abstraction, ’90s acid-house colors, large works in wood and even worms (“No, really, I just saw two of them in a row,” one architect insisted).

headline: Kim Deal Leaves the Pixies
abstract: In a statement, the other band members said that Ms. Deal will always be welcome to return to the group.
lead_paragraph: Kim Deal, the longtime bassist and singer for the Pixies, has left the band. The other three members — Black Francis, Joey Santiago and David Lovering — released a statement on Friday confirming her decision and wishing her well. “Despite her decision to move on, we will always consider her a member of the Pixies, and her place will always be here for her,” said the statement, which was posted on the band’s Facebook site.

keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Energy and Power', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: A “very serious person” and “dirty hippy” talk climate change.
lead_paragraph: David Roberts of the green blog Grist and I have a constructive, if sometimes prickly, relationship as nodes in the network of online communicators focused on human-driven climate change.

lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon has long had a complicated relationship with private equity. Since taking over as chief executive of JPMorgan Chase in 2005, Mr. Dimon has gradually reduced the bank’s exposure to the risky business of buying and selling companies.

headline: Overcoming Your Negativity Bias
abstract: Learning to put your attention where it serves you best requires the same sort of deliberate practice necessary to build any new skill, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Does this sound familiar? You’re feeling a bit uneasy – say, a tightness in your chest or a rumbling in your stomach. You search your mind for the cause, and you think of something unsettling that happened in the office yesterday, a difficult conversation you need to have or a deadline you’re facing on a project. Before you know it, worries are mounting in your mind, one feeding on the next.

headline: Pinned Down at Port Hudson
abstract: The Union’s death-defying raid on the impregnable garrison on the Mississippi Rover.
lead_paragraph: Confederate artillery and infantry fire roared from the formidable defenses of Port Hudson, La., on June 14, 1863. Shot and shell raked the rough-and-tumble terrain where Union forces were pinned down after a failed assault, caught between the lines and unable to advance or retreat.

headline: A Rebel Filmmaker Tilts Conservative
abstract: “Pandora’s Promise,” a documentary advocating nuclear energy, has been screened at festivals that, its maker feels, support the opposing position.
lead_paragraph: The director Robert Stone likened his discovery of nuclear power’s positive potential to hearing the Sex Pistols for the first time: both opened worlds of possibility for him. It’s a challenging comparison, but not surprising coming from Mr. Stone, who is trying to upend beliefs and expectations with his documentary “Pandora’s Promise.”

headline: Recall Roundup: Honda, Chrysler, G.M., Mercedes and Yakima Issue Recalls
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The companies issues recalls for minor safety problems, none of which have generated crash or injury reports.
lead_paragraph: Honda will recall about 18,000 of its 2006-7 S2000 and 2006 Acura RSX models because of a braking problem, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Honda said some components of the brake booster were manufactured outside of factory specifications and could reduce power brake assistance over time.

abstract: Alison Riske, 22, of Pittsburgh, is 16-3 at the Birmingham, England, tournament as a pro, and all 10 of her career wins in WTA Tour-level main draw matches came there.
lead_paragraph: Unlike athletes in team sports who play about half their games in one location, tennis players never get to compete in the same place for more than a couple weeks a year.

abstract: Joe Manganiello, who plays a werewolf in the HBO series, will star opposite René Augesen in a Yale Repertory Theater production.
lead_paragraph: Joe Manganiello, whose buff physique has been amply displayed as a werewolf on HBO’s “True Blood” and as a stripper in the film “Magic Mike,” will wear (and take off?) the most famous T-shirt in American theater when he plays Stanley Kowalski in Yale Repertory Theater’s production of “A Streetcar Named Desire.”

lead_paragraph: EVERY day, news releases and books cross my desk that promise success in all sorts of areas — getting a job, getting a better job, managing your employees, managing your boss, managing your relationships.

headline: Tech Pushes to Keep Its Spoils in Immigration Bill
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Foreign Workers', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Visas']
abstract: The technology industry this week dispatched executives and entrepreneurs to buttonhole lawmakers and rallied people to mount a digital campaign on Congress.
lead_paragraph: Keen to hold on to its winnings in a landmark Senate immigration bill, the technology industry this week put on what one lobbyist called “a full court press” on Capitol Hill, dispatching executives and entrepreneurs to buttonhole lawmakers and rallying people in the industry to dispatch e-mails, telephone calls and Twitter messages to Congress.

headline: Espada Sentenced to 5 Years for Stealing From Nonprofit
abstract: Pedro Espada Jr., the Bronx politician who was convicted of stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars from a health care network, portrayed himself as a victim.
lead_paragraph: In his final hours of freedom on Friday, Pedro Espada Jr. fought the way he has for years, crying foul against his perceived persecutors, knocking his accusers with accusations of his own and eschewing all blame. It was a dizzying spectacle that constantly surprised and somehow, once again, landed him in trouble.

headline: The Home-Cooked Challenge: A Week Without Prepared Foods
abstract: Our family won’t eat any prepared foods or restaurant meals next week. What does that mean?
lead_paragraph: My commitment for next week: Our family will give up prepared foods — all of them — in favor of meals and snacks we prepare ourselves. Why? Like Jane E. Brody, personal health columnist for the Well blog, I’m drawn inexorably to the conclusion that we would eat better as a family if we ate less prepackaged food and managed our own portions rather than gobbling up all that appears on the restaurant plate.

headline: Michigan Attorney General Says Detroit Museum Could Not Sell Art
abstract: The Michigan attorney general has released an opinion that says the Detroit Institute for the Arts could not sells any of its art as part of a bailout plan for the financially troubled city.
lead_paragraph: In a detailed formal opinion, the Michigan attorney general said the art collection of the Detroit Institute of Arts is held in charitable trust for the people of Michigan and could not be sold by the city to help settle some of its billions of dollars in debts.

headline: For Adam Goldman, a Place That Isn’t Out to Get Him
abstract: The creator, director and star of the web series, “The Outs,” lives in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Adam Goldman lives in one of those Brooklyn prewar buildings near Prospect Park where the buzzer doesn’t always work, and the vestibule and lobby doors are frequently left unlatched. “But I feel safe here,” said Mr. Goldman, the creator, director and star of “The Outs,” the cultish online TV series that chronicled the dissolution of a romance between two gay 20-something men in contemporary Brooklyn. “This apartment is a step up.”

headline: Seeking Exposé, Students End Up in Handcuffs
abstract: Two journalists from West Islip High School on Long Island set out to examine school security measures, but they were prosecuted for trespassing and their article was quashed.
lead_paragraph: “As the cold metal cuffs were tightened around our wrists,” the article began, “it was clear that we were in way over our heads.”

headline: In Golf, Moments Good and Bad Are Well Remembered
abstract: Perhaps more extraordinary than the skill of many of the world’s top golfers is their ability to remember shots from weeks or even years before.
lead_paragraph: ARDMORE, Pa. — When Luke Donald arrived at the United States Open, having played two practice rounds a week earlier, he remembered the name of Scott, the local golf pro who had assisted him. He reminisced about Jack, a caddie at Merion Golf Club for 30 years. He even recalled Dolly, noting that she had served lunch there for more than three decades.

headline: FIFA Seeks to End Quebec Soccer’s Ban on Turbans
abstract: FIFA, soccer’s world governing body, inserted itself into the dispute on Friday with a statement calling the Quebec federation’s ban on turbans inappropriate.
lead_paragraph: The governing body for international soccer sought to end a Canadian stalemate Friday, releasing a statement that said the Quebec Soccer Federation’s ban on players wearing turbans was inappropriate and that such headwear is acceptable.

If the mining company Cloud Peak Energy has its way, many more trains will cross the prairie to far larger proposed export terminals in Washington State.

abstract: With his border security plan, Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, has emerged as the most polarizing figure on the issue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One week into the Senate’s immigration floor fight, Senator John Cornyn of Texas has emerged as one of the most polarizing figures on the issue: a Republican leader from a border state brandishing a border security plan that he says is meant to salvage the measure but that is seen by others as a surreptitious attempt to scuttle it.

headline: G.O.P. Spendthrifts Preserve Government Expansion
abstract: Republicans in the House want to keep doling out $1.6 million per prisoner per year at Guantánamo Bay.
lead_paragraph: The small-government, fiscally prudent Republicans in the House have voted to preserve a significant expansion of government power — and to keep spending nearly $1.6 million per prisoner per year at the Guantánamo Bay detention camp. They did all that in just a few hours.

headline: New George Benjamin Opera Is Commissioned
abstract: The Royal Opera in London commissioned Mr. Benjamin to compose his third opera. Martin Crimp is to write the libretto.
lead_paragraph: The Royal Opera, in London, has commissioned the composer George Benjamin to write his third opera, which will have its premiere at Covent Garden in spring 2018. The as-yet-untitled work will have a libretto by the prolific playwright Martin Crimp.

keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: President Obama should be careful about being dragged into the brutal Syrian war.
lead_paragraph: President Obama boxed himself into a corner when he said last year that Syria’s use of chemical weapons against its people would be crossing a “red line” that could prompt a direct American response. Now that the United States has concluded with “high confidence” that President Bashar al-Assad has crossed that line, Mr. Obama had to follow through on his threat. As The Times reported, the administration has decided to begin supplying the rebels with small arms and ammunition.

lead_paragraph: The Harperley Hall duplex created by Madonna Ciccone way back in a former century, when she and Sean Penn were a hot item and she was very much a Material Girl on the rise in the matter of shrewd real estate acquisitions, sold for $16 million in the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Where We Are Shapes Who We Are
abstract: What we do — and therefore, to some extent, who we are — is often shaped by where we are.
lead_paragraph: IN the early 1970s, a team of researchers dropped hundreds of stamped, addressed letters near college dorms along the East Coast and recorded how many lost letters found their way to a mailbox. The researchers counted each posted letter as a small act of charity and discovered that students in some of the dorms were more generous than others.

headline: A Wider View of India’s Foreign Policy Reveals Clear Strategy
abstract: There are many reasons why India’s foreign policy remains something of an enigma to analysts, scholars, and reporters — both in India and abroad.
lead_paragraph: Shinzo Abe has ruffled quite a few feathers since his return as Japan’s prime minister in December. His cabinet ministers’ visit in April to the controversial Yasukuni Shrine, which honors Japan’s war dead, was condemned by China and South Korea, and in no time, Japan became the target of North Korean saber-rattling and American finger-wagging.  So it ought to have elicited more surprise when Abe’s soft-spoken Indian counterpart, Manmohan Singh, plainly declared his comfort with his host’s worldview on a recent visit to Tokyo.

headline: Polls Show Chemical Weapons Affect Public’s View on Syria
abstract: Polls have found that public support for intervention in Syria increases sharply under circumstances where it is confirmed that the Assad regime used chemical weapons.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration, which had long resisted sending weapons to antigovernment forces in Syria’s civil war, has decided to supply them with small arms after concluding that the troops of President Bashar al-Assad have used chemical weapons against them, according to American officials.

headline: An Old Hand at Only 26
abstract: The French conductor Lionel Bringuier, who made his New York Philharmonic debut in 2009 at the age of 22, led a full program with the orchestra by himself on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The precocious French conductor Lionel Bringuier, all of 26, took the podium at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday to lead the New York Philharmonic in an impressive program. It is not often that a conductor of any age can bring out the musically daring elements of a crowd pleaser like Dukas’s “Sorcerer’s Apprentice.” To those who remember Mr. Bringuier from his New York debut in 2008, when he conducted the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, also at Avery Fisher Hall, he must have seemed almost a seasoned maestro in comparison. He has certainly been rising fast, making appearances with major international orchestras. He takes over as chief conductor of the distinguished Tonhalle Orchestra in Zurich next year and is just completing his sixth and final season as resident conductor with the Los Angeles Philharmonic. Mr. Bringuier made his official debut with the New York Philharmonic in 2009, conducting the chamber ensemble in Britten’s “War Requiem,” a performance led overall by Lorin Maazel. But this was his first time conducting the full orchestra on his own.

headline: Paul Cavaco: Finding the Look That Suits His Age
abstract: For Paul Cavaco, sneakers, jeans and T-shirts have been the standard, but it’s a style he’s trying adapt for 61.
lead_paragraph: Paul Cavaco, 61, a founder of Keeble Cavaco & Duka (today known as the fashion public relations agency KCD) and a former fashion director at Vogue and Harper’s Bazaar, has been the creative director of Allure magazine for almost 14 years. He was born and raised in New York.

lead_paragraph: In July 2010, Jean Ann Douglass appeared in a puppet play about a gorilla, a man and a chimpanzee. She played the left arm of the gorilla.

headline: How to Avoid an Estate Battle After You Die
abstract: Battles over two wills signed by Huguette Clark, the heiress to a copper fortune who died in 2011 at 104, offer lessons even for people who don’t have $300 million estates.
lead_paragraph: It might seem that a woman who died at 104 after spending 20 years in a hospital despite being healthy enough to live in one of her three stately homes, accumulated a vast collection of dolls and preferred to communicate in French even though her father had been a United States senator would have little to teach the rest of us.

headline: Where the Bridal Bouquet Is All Around You
abstract: Longing for a garden wedding? It helps if you’re prepared to take a leap of faith and have a big green thumb. Or you can just rent the place.
lead_paragraph: The ever-present risk of a thunderstorm or insect swarm aside, for those who delight in moonlight and stars, the first day of summer or the dazzle of a fall day, nothing will do but a garden wedding.

headline: A Quick Search Ends in the Village
abstract: Jean Z. Poh and Giordano Contestabile wanted a home in a vibrant neighborhood, but they had to make up their minds in a hurry.
lead_paragraph: A three-year stint in downtown Seattle was more than enough for Jean Z. Poh and Giordano Contestabile. They couldn’t wait to move to New York.

headline: Defining Real Estate Broadly to Avoid Corporate Taxes
abstract: Iron Mountain, an information storage company, is a great example of how companies are trying to qualify as real estate businesses to take advantage of tax benefits, the author writes.
lead_paragraph: Shares of the information storage company Iron Mountain dropped about 15 percent last week on the news that the I.R.S. was “tentatively adverse” toward at least one aspect of its plan to convert into a Real Estate Investment Trust, or REIT. The primary legal issue appears to be whether Iron Mountain’s racking storage units qualify as real estate assets.

headline: New Jersey Declares Clarence Clemons Day
abstract: A resolution signed by Gov. Chris Christie dedicated Jan. 11, Mr. Clemons’s birthday, to honor the saxophone colossus.
lead_paragraph: Here’s further proof that in New Jersey the members of Bruce Springsteen’s band are folk heroes akin to knights of the round table: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has signed a resolution declaring Jan. 11 to be Clarence Clemons Day, wire services reported. That day was Mr. Clemons’s birthday.

headline: In Student Housing, Luxuries Overshadow Studying
abstract: As developers try to outdo the amenities that their competitors offer in college towns, concern is growing about the academic and social consequences of upscale off-campus student housing.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, Mo. — Brenden Heiland had breathed the vanilla lavender-scented clubhouse air. He had seen the beach volleyball court, toured the game room equipped with billiards, Ping-Pong and air hockey tables, and learned with delight of the Friday pool parties with a D.J., free food and snow cones, spiked with rum for those of age.

headline: Toppling Spain at European Under-21s Will Be a Tall Order
abstract: Spain has been a worthy favorite at the European Under-21 Championships in Israel, but Italy and the Netherlands could pose a stiff challenge.
lead_paragraph: It may not be the Champions League or the World Cup but the Under-21 European Championship always proves a great showcase for tomorrow’s star players. And with the group stage complete, this year’s tournament in Israel is not without its standout players and performances. Some of those expected to shine have not disappointed, but other more unfamiliar players and teams are also making a name for themselves. All the while, the question of experience has become a major theme of the competition.

headline: Daughter to Dad: ‘Girlie’ Pajamas, Please
abstract: My 5-year-old loves Spider-Man, so I was stunned when she refused to wear her Spidey pj’s to pajama day at gymnastics.
lead_paragraph: My daughter loves Spider-Man — the Peter Parker version, the movie version, not the young comic book hero of Chris Huntington’s recent essay. While we don’t know why, I suspect it’s the love interest as much as her favorite colors. Whenever there’s a scene between Peter Parker and Mary Jane, she has a tentative, all-encompassing smile. Maybe that’s me projecting adult emotions on a 5-year-old, but no other superhero or franchise sticks like Spider-Man: T-shirts, boxers, sweatshirts, her favorite shoes, her favorite drinking glass, her favorite car, her favorite puzzle, the action figures on her night stand that she rearranges before bedtime, her pajamas.

headline: Looking for Clementine Hunter’s Louisiana
abstract: Heading north from Baton Rouge, the author goes in search of the world that inspired arguably the state’s most beloved artist.
lead_paragraph: Some three hours’ drive from Baton Rouge, in the northwest corner of Louisiana, lies the curving Cane River, and along it, fields planted with cotton, soy, corn and pecans, worked today by machinery. But when Clementine Hunter, arguably the state’s most beloved artist, was born on Hidden Hill Plantation in the 1880s, slavery was an institution of living memory, and most African-Americans, including Clementine and her family, worked as field hands. In the artist’s case, she picked cotton on Hidden Hill (which has been renamed Little Eva Plantation) and then, when her family moved, at Melrose Plantation. It was there that, in her 50s, Clementine Hunter picked up a paintbrush and embarked on what became a remarkable career.

headline: Escaping to ‘Bangkok’s Green Lung’
abstract: Bang Krachao, an island oasis across the river from Bangkok’s concrete jungle, is emerging from its time warp, adding bike tours and boutique hotels.
lead_paragraph: Falling coconuts, papaya groves, Buddhist temples, nine-foot-long pythons and miles of bike-friendly elevated sidewalks snaking through the jungle:  Welcome to Bang Krachao, a smog-free, government-protected oasis of green that the mighty Chao Phraya River wraps around.

headline: On the Scillies, Exotic Gardens, Windswept Ruins
abstract: These islands off the tip of Cornwall hold one of the densest concentrations of archaeological sites in Britain — but history isn’t the only reason to venture there.
lead_paragraph: Through the mist, I could make out the empty beaches and crystal clear water surrounding St. Mary’s, the largest of the Isles of Scilly. The view from the airplane window hinted at what draws the visitors who flock there to windsurf, sail, watch gig races and spot the seaside fauna — puffins, gray seals — that make the islands their home.

headline: In Utah, a 100-Mile Trek With a 4-Year-Old Boy
keywords: ['Hikes and Hiking', 'Goats', 'Camps and Camping', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Parenting']
abstract: The author, his young son, two hiking companions and four goats go on a 10-day adventure in the Utah mountains.
lead_paragraph: We roared across the Wyoming-Utah border at sunset; windows down, stereo cranked, muffler cracked. Behind the wheel was a well-tattooed, pierced 24-year-old. Riding shotgun, a 44-year-old writer with three-day-old stubble (that would be me). And in the back, buried beneath coloring books and blankets, a cherubic boy. We were all three in search of goats.

headline: The Unspoken Stigma of Workplace Flexibility

abstract: Women who take advantage of flexible work schedules may be viewed as not committed to work, but men may be penalized even more.

Or perhaps you want to reduce your hours for a while to care for an aging parent. How would you be perceived if you raised your hand for one of these options?

He’s in one of his busiest periods since his 2011 debut, “Blue Slide Park,” entered the Billboard charts at No. 1, the first independent album to do so in 16 years. headline: Automakers Push Back Against Consumer Protections
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Consumer Protection', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Car buyers are being pushed into agreeing to use binding arbitration to resolve disputes. Consequently, the automakers say, consumers may not use class-actions or lemon laws to get restitution.
lead_paragraph: When the transmission in Sarah and Scott McKinney’s 2004 Audi A6 failed after five years, the repair cost thousands of dollars. Audi wouldn’t cover it, the McKinneys say, though the problem was a common one — so widespread that it later became the subject of a federal class-action suit.

headline: A Sudden Outbreak of Annoying Noises
abstract: A roundup of the latest technical service bulletins that highlight solutions to numerous automotive problems.
lead_paragraph: Ford F-150 pickups with clunking driveshafts and Toyotas with noisy brakes are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: Rough Road Ahead, but a Robot Driver Takes It in Stride
abstract: Robots have long been on auto assembly lines, but Ford is now using them in place of human drivers on test tracks.
lead_paragraph: ROMEO, MICH. — A Ford Transit van slams its way over concrete obstacles in a test of durability here at the automaker’s proving grounds some 40 miles north of Detroit. The continuous on-road torture is punishing and could wreak havoc on both chassis-components and a driver’s spine, but this test driver doesn’t mind.

headline: U.S. Allies Weigh Response to Chemical Weapons Charge
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'No-Fly Zones']
abstract: Syria said the Obama administration was “full of lies” in alleging the use of chemical weapons, and American allies were trying to decide what to do.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Syrian government on Friday denounced the Obama administration’s assertion that Syrian forces had used chemical weapons as “full of lies,” even as the American’s finding produced strong reactions around the world.

headline: Seeing in the Dark
abstract: Alex Trochut’s art brought me nostalgia, of childhood sensations recalled, and the thrill of a first-time experience.
lead_paragraph: The designer Alex Trochut typically expresses himself through typography or illustration — or a merging of the two — and those skills were on display in the magazine a few months ago in his illustrated headline for one of our feature stories. But he has ventured far beyond those familiar applications in his new project, “Binary Prints,” which was inspired by and features as its subjects electronic musicians like James Murphy, Caribou, Four Tet and Damian Lazarus. Trochut’s posters can be seen at this Web site created for them and in an exhibition that opens this week in Barcelona.

headline: Small Grains, Big Nutrition
abstract: Small grains can pack a big nutritional punch, writes the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman, who this week continued her exploration into cooking with grains.
lead_paragraph: Small grains can pack a big nutritional punch, writes the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman, who this week continued her exploration into cooking with grains. She writes:

headline: Mujadara: One Pot or Two
abstract: A Middle Eastern lentils and rice dish, with hot sauce or yogurt.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s A Good Appetite column and in the accompanying video, I refer to the Middle Eastern lentils and rice dish called mujadara as a one-pot meal. That’s how I learned how to make it: by cooking the lentils and rice together in the pot.

headline: No Pritzker Prize for Denise Scott Brown
abstract: The jury for the architecture prize declined to retroactively honor Ms. Scott Brown for work she did alongside her design partner and husband, Robert Venturi, who won the award in 1991.
lead_paragraph: The Pritzker Prize jury will not revisit its decision to exclude the architect Denise Scott Brown from the 1991 prize given to her design partner and husband, Robert Venturi, with whom she worked side by side.

headline: Luke Janklow: Not Exactly Bookish
abstract: The agent Luke Janklow may be the last man having fun in the industry. You may have read about some of it in the tabloids.
lead_paragraph: It was a breezy afternoon in early June, and Luke Janklow, the heir apparent to the powerful literary agent Morton L. Janklow, was trying to recall what he had been up to the last month. “I don’t go out that much,” he said, opening the calendar on his computer in his 13th-floor office overlooking Park Avenue.

headline: About Last Night | Jason Wu Hosts a Summer Soiree for the Young Friends of ACRIA
abstract: Good friends and fashion-industry vets, such as the designer Kate Young and the models Daria Strokous and Liu Wen, gathered for the designer’s fund-raiser on Thursday.

headline: Open Trials for the Bermuda Bowl
abstract: The winners of the open trial in Orlando, Fla., this month were young, and they have added two “old-timers” for the championship in September in Bali, Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: The winners of the open trial in Orlando, Fla., this month for the Bermuda Bowl world championship were young. Kevin Dwyer is 24; John Kranyak, 29; Gavin Wolpert, 30; and Kevin Bathurst, 34. They have added two “old-timers” for the championship in September in Bali, Indonesia: Steve Weinstein, 49, and Bobby Levin, 55.

headline: Greek Broadcaster Fights Closure
abstract: A court decision expected Monday might lead to temporary revival of ERT, even as a prosecutor begins investigating the broadcaster’s finances.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The Greek government might come under pressure to reopen the state broadcaster, ERT, as one of the country’s highest courts weighs an appeal by a union representing more than 2,600 of the broadcaster’s employees.

headline: Researchers Find Biological Evidence of Gulf War Illnesses
abstract: New findings are bolstering the view that mysterious symptoms in Persian Gulf war veterans are fundamentally biological in nature, as opposed to psychological, the result of combat stress.
lead_paragraph: In the two decades since the 1991 Persian Gulf war, medical researchers have struggled to explain a mysterious amalgam of problems in thousands of gulf war veterans, including joint pain, physical malaise and gastrointestinal disorders. In some medical circles, the symptoms were thought to be psychological, the result of combat stress.

headline: CUNY Leader’s Retirement Comes With Paid Sabbatical and Teaching Job
abstract: Chancellor Matthew Goldstein will get his full salary during his first year off and for five months of unused sick time, and then he will have a $300,000 job at CUNY.
lead_paragraph: For a scholar, it is the dream retirement benefit: a full year just to read and write, with no committee meetings in sight. For Matthew Goldstein, a mathematician who will step down this summer as chancellor of the City University of New York, that year comes with an added nicety: a $490,000 salary, the same amount he is earning this year.

headline: Doomed Health Reform
abstract: Collapse is imminent, and always will be.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Carroll has a fun piece full of quotations about how an expansion of health coverage is doomed to failure, doctors will refuse to participate, and so on. What makes it fun is that the health expansion in question is Medicaid, and all of the quotes are from 40 or more years ago. As he says, after quoting from a 1969 article,

headline: Differing Views on Privacy Shape Europe’s Response to U.S. Surveillance Program
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Social Networking (Internet)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: While it is too early to know whether large numbers of Europeans will stop using American Internet services, the official European reaction has been loud and angry.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Olaf Storbeck, a German columnist, has decided to “ditch Googlemail b/c Prism,” he wrote on Twitter. A London-based writer for Reuters, he is now a customer of Swissmail, a Swiss provider that charges a fee, and he says he is tinkering with a VPN, a virtual private network of the kind used by many corporations.

headline: Oh, for the Days of a Courtly Vampire’s Love
abstract: “True Blood,” the Southern gothic supernatural soap opera, which begins its sixth season on HBO on Sunday, signals an effort, or at least a wish, to return to simpler story lines.
lead_paragraph: Back at home in Bon Temps, La., momentarily safe from attack by vampires hungry for her tasty fairy blood, Sookie Stackhouse recalls the simple days of white dresses and well-mannered, if fanged, admirers. “I want to be that girl again,” she says, wearily. Fans of “True Blood,” hearing their heroine speak that line in the show’s Season 6 premiere on Sunday night, can only reply, Amen, sister.

headline: Music in Istanbul Is Intermission for a Protest
abstract: When Davide Martello hauled a grand piano into Taksim Square in Istanbul and started playing, protesters and the police alike shared hours of calm.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — After days of being the target of tear gas and police water cannons, protesters in Gezi Park, in Taksim Square here, were tense on Wednesday night, girded for conflict. Instead they got a piano performance.

headline: Friday Night Music: More Zaz
abstract: Still not in English.
lead_paragraph: What’s funny is that the lyrics aren’t all that different from Paula Abdul’s The Way That You Love Me. But somehow, even though that was actually one of Paula Abdul’s better hits, I like this a whole lot better …

headline: The Rotunda That Dazzles
abstract: The Guggenheim’s James Turrell exhibition opens Friday, perfectly timed to the summer solstice
lead_paragraph: The Guggenheim’s James Turrell exhibition opens Friday, perfectly timed to the summer solstice. Part of a countrywide celebration of Mr. Turrell’s light-and-space art (solos have already opened at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art), it’s among the most eagerly awaited shows of the season.

headline: Brooklyn Talent on a New Screen
abstract: The fifth annual BAMcinemaFest, Brooklyn’s celebration of independent cinema, kicks off Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The fifth annual BAMcinemaFest, Brooklyn’s celebration of independent cinema, kicks off Wednesday, offering its customary eclectic assortment of documentaries and narrative features. The festival, running until June 28, continues to showcase Brooklyn talent, this year including the filmmakers Shaka King (“Newlyweeds”); Eliza Hittman (“It Felt Like Love”); and Zach Clark (“White Reindeer”).

headline: Nourishing Cocoon at Lincoln Center
abstract: Lincoln Center Theater’s LCT3 program for emerging artists is having a lustrous moment, with this year’s Pulitzer Prize for “Disgraced,” which it presented last fall.
lead_paragraph: Lincoln Center Theater’s LCT3 program for emerging artists is having a lustrous moment, with this year’s Pulitzer Prize for “Disgraced,” which it presented last fall, and a Pulitzer finalist in “4000 Miles,” from two seasons before.

headline: Experimenting on All Sides
abstract: Summer dance has mercifully improved since Sam Miller took over as the president of the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council.
lead_paragraph: Summer dance has mercifully improved since Sam Miller took over as the president of the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. For this season’s River to River Festival, Mr. Miller, who is always thinking of ways to invigorate the dance world, has selected 12 choreographers — including Luciana Achugar, Vanessa Anspaugh, Reggie Wilson and Souleymane Badolo — to show works over a two-year period. It’s an experiment, as much for the artists as it is for audience members.

headline: Drinking Buddies on the Road Again
abstract: “Tripping Out With Alie & Georgia,” is the latest foray into cocktail wizardry on the Cooking Channel, making its premiere Friday night at 10:30.
lead_paragraph: You might not instinctively choose as drinking buddies two women who found fame with the McNuggetini: vanilla vodka shaken with a chocolate milkshake, poured into a martini glass rimmed in barbecue sauce and adorned with a Chicken McNugget. Or, “dinner, dessert and booze in one chalice of multitasking,” proclaims Alie Ward in the video that earned her and Georgia Hardstark a gig as the Cooking Channel’s “Classy Ladies.”

headline: Random Acts of Performance
abstract: If, as Shakespeare said, all the world’s a stage, it’s even truer that all New York City’s a concert hall.
lead_paragraph: If, as Shakespeare said, all the world’s a stage, it’s even truer that all New York City’s a concert hall. Hardly a day goes by when you won’t stumble upon spontaneous music in the city’s parks and public spaces.

headline: The Pendulum of Country
abstract: If you’re looking for a fight on an almost-summer night, you could do worse than the Hunter Hayes show.
lead_paragraph: If you’re looking for a fight on an almost-summer night, you could do worse than the Hunter Hayes show. There won’t be fisticuffs, per se — only a battle for the soul of country music. Mr. Hayes is, depending how you look at it, the logical endpoint of several years of country de-toughening or a welcome reframer of the genre for those who find Luke Bryan too stern. Mr. Hayes’s self-titled 2011 debut album is sneaky, though: basically a savvy teen-pop heartache opus in light Music Row outerwear.

headline: From ‘I Hate Her’ to Icon
abstract: Alison Arngrim, who became famous as the evil Nellie Oleson on “Little House on the Prairie” nearly 40 years ago, has turned into a gay icon.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Cher, Dolly, Madonna, Barbra, Bette. Ask someone to name a gay icon, and one or all of those names would come to mind.

headline: E.P.A. Backs Out of Role in Palisades LG Headquarters
abstract: In the face of opposition from the Metropolitan Museum of Art and environmentalists, the Environmental Protection Agency has changed its mind about cooperating in the building of a complex for LG Electonics atop the New Jersey Palisades.
lead_paragraph: In a rare about-face, the Environmental Protection Agency has withdrawn its involvement in the construction of a new corporate headquarters to be built in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., on the grounds that its height would disrupt “the natural beauty of the Palisades.”

headline: A K-9 Graduation
abstract: A ceremony marked the completion of training for eight police dogs and they went on active duty with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
lead_paragraph: A ceremony marked the completion of training for eight police dogs and they went on active duty with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

headline: A K-9 Graduation
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority Police Department’s canine unit held its graduation ceremony on Friday at Grand Central Terminal’s Vanderbilt Hall on Friday. Eight dogs were added to the active duty force.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority Police Department’s canine unit held its graduation ceremony on Friday at Grand Central Terminal’s Vanderbilt Hall on Friday. Eight dogs were added to the active duty force.

headline: Urgently Trying to Get Messages to Audiences
abstract: The Julie Ruin, led by Kathleen Hanna, and Body/Head, with Kim Gordon of Sonic Youth, made intriguing, urgent music at the Northside Festival in Brooklyn on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: The life of a song doesn’t necessarily end at the conclusion of its recording, or of a live performance of it. Songs have intended ears, targets in their cross hairs. Sometimes, to understand a song, to really hear it, it helps to know where and how it’s meant to land.

headline: Questcor Pays $135 Million to Acquire Rights to a Competitor’s Drug
abstract: The pharmaceutical company, which sells a treatment for immune-related ailments at $28,000 a vial, bought a much cheaper alternative of the drug.
lead_paragraph: A pharmaceutical company that has reaped huge profits by selling a 60-year-old drug for $28,000 a vial has eliminated the most obvious threat of competition from a much cheaper drug by acquiring the rights to it.

headline: In the Footsteps of Clementine Hunter
abstract: The artist lived her entire life in Louisiana, and her work flowed from her environment.
lead_paragraph: The artist lived her entire life in Louisiana, and her work flowed from her environment.

headline: Ecuador Legislature Approves Curbs on News Media
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The measure, long sought by President Rafael Correa, would impose fines for coverage deemed by regulators as unfair.
lead_paragraph: When President Rafael Correa of Ecuador won re-election this year, and for the first time captured a majority in the National Assembly, he vowed to push forward with major proposals that had been stalled in his earlier terms. On Friday he gained a victory that he had long coveted when the Legislature passed a law regulating the news media, which he says will force news organizations to act fairly and which opponents say will quash freedom of expression.

headline: Player in Leaks Case, Out From Behind Camera
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: The documentarian Laura Poitras says her role in the leaking of American surveillance programs was “not something I was seeking out.”
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Alex Gibney recalled bumping into his fellow documentarian Laura Poitras at the airport last year, when they both happened to be taking the New York-to-London flight.

headline: The Meaning of Daring
abstract: The dance-theater artist Patricia Noworol teams up with the German hip-hop company Renegade for “?Culture” at Danspace Project.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Patricia Noworol, who grew up in Poland and moved to Germany as a teenager, is fond of emotional and physical extremes. In the United States premiere of “?Culture,” performed at Danspace Project on Thursday, she is the queen bee. She perches on a high ladder wearing a hot pink robe while shrieking into a microphone, dances topless under strobe lights and lectures the audience about arts financing.

headline: How Flexible Is Your Employer?
abstract: This week’s Your Money column looks at how workers are perceived if they use a more flexible work arrangement, and particularly at how those perceptions differ among men and women.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Your Money column looks at how workers are perceived if they use a more flexible work arrangement — say, working early and quitting early, or cutting back on hours when caring for an elderly parent.

headline: Unwelcome Innovation Earns Gamers’ Jeers
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Xbox (Video Game System)', 'E3 Media and Business Summit']
abstract: At E3, a video game trade show where novelty is prized, Microsoft drew resentment for its plans to monitor gamers’ use of resold games.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Even though new video game systems depend on technological innovation, players are a conservative lot, suspicious of change. That partly explains why they gave a sustained ovation for old-fashioned games on disc during a Sony presentation this week here at the industry’s trade show, E3.

headline: Laurie Anderson’s Wall-to-Wall Summer
abstract: Ms. Anderson has some superhuman multimedia tasks before her this summer, including a collaboration with the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei.
lead_paragraph: Laurie Anderson has a disarming way of making intense levels of activity seem matter-of-fact, even laid-back. In a spacious room on the upper floor of her TriBeCa duplex, with a glorious view of the Hudson River, she briefly looked over the shoulder of an assistant who was editing a video recording of the Chinese dissident artist (and, lately, musician) Ai Weiwei, with whom Ms. Anderson will perform, via Skype, at the Luminato Festival in Toronto on Sunday. She then padded down a spiral staircase to her studio, where, one afternoon this week, her stage equipment — a small keyboard, an iPad, a MacBook and her trademark electric violin — was powered up and ready for rehearsal or experimentation.

headline: No False Advertising Here
abstract: Farm to Table Bistro serves mostly organic fare that you can trace to its origins.
lead_paragraph: The name says it all. But even if you didn’t know what Farm to Table Bistro was called, you could see immediately that this Fishkill restaurant fits right into the movement for locally sourced eating.

headline: BMW Announces Details and Prices for the 2014 4 Series Coupe
abstract: Scheduled to arrive in showrooms this year, the two 4 Series Coupes will hit 60 m.p.h. in the 5s and can be had for less than $50,000.
lead_paragraph: BMW released details — and photos — of its 4 Series Coupe on Friday, just in time for the weekend. So here they are, the 428i and 435i models, available in three different trim levels: Luxury, Sport and M Sport. Predictably, the Luxury trim caters to fancy gadgets, while the Sport and M Sport are tailored to the speed freaks amongst BMW’s customers.

headline: U.S. Agencies to Develop Standards for Bed Rails
abstract: The move for voluntary guidelines disappointed advocates for regulation of the product, which has been linked to the deaths of elderly patients.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration and the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced on Friday that they have called for a committee to update voluntary standards for adult portable bed rails, which have been linked to the deaths of hundreds of elderly patients.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 14
abstract: Watch a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a building implosion on Governors Island, pedestrians in the rain in Manhattan and an invasion of cicadas on Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a building implosion on Governors Island, pedestrians in the rain in Manhattan and an invasion of cicadas on Staten Island.

headline: Song for My Father
abstract: For Father’s Day, the singer of The Red House Painters and Sun Kil Moon shares an unreleased song, an homage to his father’s survival and painful past.
lead_paragraph: I have been writing and singing songs for over half my life. And as I get older I’ve noticed that the things I write about have changed. I’m 46 now and I find myself writing a lot about middle age. I don’t take life for granted as I once did. When I see my hometown Ohio area code light up on my phone, I sometimes worry it might be “that call.” My mom is an older lady now. She had a knee replacement and her hair is turning white and she’s having a harder time getting around. My dad is 80 and he’s one of two siblings left out of nine.

headline: A Vineyard With a View (and Food, Too)
abstract: At the Sharpe Hill Vineyard restaurant, visitors find that there is more to dinner than just dinner.
lead_paragraph: At some restaurants, being there is the real feast. So it is with the restaurant at Sharpe Hill Vineyard, which Steven and Catherine Vollweiler opened two decades ago in a quiet corner of Connecticut’s Quiet Corner, the northeastern part of the state.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Darned If They Do
abstract: Men answer the question: wear socks or expose your ankles?
lead_paragraph: Men answer the question: wear socks or expose your ankles?

headline: The Next Storm: New York Prepares, but the Rest?
abstract: The Nature Conservancy in New York and the Center for Biological Diversity discuss Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s initiative.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Dosas, Big and Bigger
abstract: Chennai Dosas in Hicksville has what seems like thousands of items, and the star is the dosa, a South Indian staple.
lead_paragraph: It’s a puzzle to a chicken tandoori and lamb biryani gal like myself that the typical dosa joint has 6,000 items on the menu. Four thousand of these items are made of rice and lentils, sometimes with spices and sometimes with “special” spices. And the star among these items is the pancake. I was tempted to say “the humble pancake,” but there is nothing humble about a dosa. Bragging rights go to the dosa that can overhang its plate by the most inches. Or feet. This is not an exaggeration. Not much of one, anyway.

headline: Helping Syria’s Rebels
abstract: A reader writes that the United States’ action is overdue.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Gay Lobby’ in the Vatican
abstract: John Hirsh, a professor at Georgetown, hopes that along with the promised investigation comes a “newly charitable outreach to all.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot:  Cyberwarlord for the U.S., and Power Strips on the Road
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday’s selections include the general who has been building our military cybercapabilities, and Volvo’s research into powering electric cars with strips in the road.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: After $98,000 Crime at Tiffany, Security Tips From a Pawnshop
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Pawnbroking', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: A clerk at EZ Pawn’s flagship store on Lexington Avenue divulges her secret to thwarting heists after a thief steals $98,000 worth of jewelry from Tiffany & Company.
lead_paragraph: Tiffany & Company has been selling jewelry in New York City since 1837, but it would seem the famous name could learn a thing or two from an uptown clerk named Mattie Simon in East Harlem, and, in particular, what happens when she calls out for a cup of black coffee.

headline: Greedy Gardeners
keywords: ['Gardens and Gardening', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Urban Areas', 'Bees', 'Insects', 'Sustainable Living', 'Flowers and Plants']
abstract: The activists campaigning for urban farms should not forget the wildflowers, bees and butterflies that are critical to our survival.
lead_paragraph: ROOFTOP vegetable gardens were one thing, but the urban agricultural movement has gone a step too far. A new brand of activists want to incorporate fruit trees into the fabric of city life by turning our limited green space into woody groves filled with apples, cherries and plums. One group, the Guerrilla Grafters, has gone so far as to graft the branches of fruit trees onto street-side ornamental trees in San Francisco.

headline: Wheeler, Mets Pitching Prospect, to Face Braves on Tuesday
abstract: The 23-year-old Zack Wheeler, a Georgia native, will pitch the second game of a split doubleheader in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: The Mets will have plenty of decisions concerning their rotation once the prized prospect Zack Wheeler joins the staff next week. But the first of those decisions was officially made Friday when Mets Manager Terry Collins confirmed that Wheeler would be pitching the second game of Tuesday’s split doubleheader in Atlanta. The Mets ace Matt Harvey will pitch the opener.

headline: Nuclear Plants, Old and Uncompetitive, Are Closing Earlier Than Expected
abstract: Even reactors still licensed to operate may close, because the price of the electricity they generate doesn’t warrant costly repairs and maintenance.
lead_paragraph: Washington — When does a nuclear plant become too old?

headline: Judge Rejects Fort Hood Shooting Suspect’s Defense Strategy
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Terrorism']
abstract: A military judge said Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan’s claim — that he had carried out the shooting rampage at Fort Hood to protect Taliban leaders from American soldiers — had no merit.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — Days after the Army major charged in the Fort Hood shooting rampage here in 2009 argued that he had carried out the attack to protect Taliban leaders from American soldiers, a military judge effectively tossed out his defense, ruling on Friday that the claim had no legal merit.

headline: With Treetop Trail, Philadelphia Zoo Opens Grounds to Prowlers
abstract: An expanding network of trails will let creatures great and small roam around to bring them closer to visitors and raise conservation awareness.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Near the entrance to the Philadelphia Zoo, a new, long tubular cage hangs about 20 feet above the ground, twisting through trees and around buildings as it leads into the zoo’s densely packed campus.

headline: A Peaceful Piano Protest
abstract: With his piano parked at Taksim Square in Istanbul, the pianist Davide Martello led protesters in a rendition of The Beatles’ ”Let It Be.”
lead_paragraph: With his piano parked at Taksim Square in Istanbul, the pianist Davide Martello led protesters in a rendition of The Beatles’ ”Let It Be.”

headline: Close to Nature, and Perfection
abstract: The rustic touches at Agricola reflect its closeness to local produce from farms, including one belonging to the owner.
lead_paragraph: Never mind that a restaurant named Agricola, the Latin word for farmer, has a distinctly manufactured feel.  (A design firm and a branding firm were hired to create the rustic American effect.) The restaurant is a beautiful place in which to dine, and many of the dishes are, or are on their way to becoming, excellent.

headline: Judge at War Crimes Tribunal Faults Acquittals of Serb and Croat Commanders
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Frederik Harhoff of Denmark, a judge at the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, suggested in a letter that the court’s president, an American, pressured judges in recent verdicts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A judge at the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague has exposed a deep rift at the highest levels of the court in a blistering letter suggesting that the court’s president, an American, pressured other judges into approving the recent acquittals of top Serb and Croat commanders.

headline: A Chinese Push for Urbanization
abstract: China is contemplating a drastic plan to move 250 million rural residents into towns and cities over the next dozen years.
lead_paragraph: China is contemplating a drastic plan to move 250 million rural residents into towns and cities over the next dozen years.

headline: Bad Idea, Mr. President
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Intervention in Syria won’t help. It will prolong a civil war while destabilizing the region and endangering core U.S. interests.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — ACCORDING to Bill Clinton, Barack Obama risks looking like a “fool” if he decides not to intervene militarily in Syria’s continuing civil war. Likening the situation to his decision to intervene in Kosovo in 1999, Mr. Clinton said Tuesday that if he hadn’t used force to stop Serbia’s campaign of ethnic cleansing, critics might have said: “You could have stopped this by dropping a few bombs. Why didn’t you do it?” Mr. Clinton believes that Mr. Obama could end up looking like a “total wuss” if he doesn’t intervene. And it seems he’s going to act.

headline: New Bridge Over Danube Helps Dissolve Old Enmities
abstract: Leaders and locals on Friday celebrated a $340 million bridge over the Danube that should foster trade and ties between Romania and Bulgaria.
lead_paragraph: VIDIN, Bulgaria — The European Union hardly basks in popular favor these days. But in this isolated corner of the bloc’s poorest periphery, leaders and locals on Friday celebrated a tangible benefit of membership — a $340 million bridge spanning the Danube that should help strengthen trade and ties between two impoverished members, Romania and Bulgaria.

headline: Events in Westchester
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: In Colorado, Nature Takes a Fiery Toll Despite a Community’s Efforts to Prepare
abstract: After hundreds of homes were razed in Black Forest, Colo., officials are examining what can be done to curb the destruction caused by wildfires.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — For years, families in Black Forest, Colo., did what they could to keep the flames at bay. They scooped up pine needles and trimmed low-hanging branches around their homes. They chopped down saplings and hauled dead trees to the community mulcher.

headline: A Search for Sexual Freedom Gone Awry
abstract: The Schoolhouse Theater’s lighthearted production of “Last of the Red Hot Lovers,” which first opened on Broadway in 1969, brings back those days with a clear eye and a warm heart.
lead_paragraph: There is a rumor going around that in the 1960s any reasonable adult in search of casual sex could find it in a New York minute. headline: Locust Moon
abstract: On a cloudy late spring night, the dim glow of a tree’s fading white blossoms.
lead_paragraph: I saw the first fireflies of June the other night. They looked a little aqueous, as if they were phosphorescing in a liquid darkness. I watched them with pleasure, wishing I were bioluminescent myself. It wasn’t the darkness of the night that bothered me. It was the way it had become dark. Usually, even on cloudy evenings, I can feel the light rising skyward from the pastures, retreating with the sun. But that night it seemed as though the farm was gradually sinking deeper and deeper in a tide of shadows.

For the Rieder family, fervently unobservant even in its own Jewish faith, Christianity stood at an alien distance.

headline: Prison Sentence for 2 Musicians Who Released Album of Protest Songs
abstract: The album has 12 songs, among them ones that praised the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of the Tibetans, and the scores of Tibetans who have set themselves on fire since 2009 to protest Chinese rule.
lead_paragraph: Two Tibetan musicians detained about a year ago by Chinese security officers have each been given a two-year prison sentence, according to Free Tibet, an advocacy group based in London. The two musicians, Pema Trinlay, 22, and Chakdor, 32, from Ngaba in Sichuan Province, produced an album called “The Pain of an Unhealed Wound.” The album has 12 songs, among them ones that praised the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of the Tibetans, and the scores of Tibetans who have set themselves on fire since 2009 to protest Chinese rule. The singers were sentenced in February, but news of the punishments has only now begun to emerge, Free Tibet said in its news release on Thursday. About 120 ethnic Tibetans in Chinese-ruled regions have self-immolated. Many of the monks who set themselves on fire came from the Kirti Monastery in Sichuan Province on the eastern edge of the Tibetan plateau. The monastery has been in conflict with the Chinese authorities since 2008, during a widespread Tibetan uprising.
