headline: A Birthplace of Ships, Transformed
abstract: The city turned the site of the Brooklyn Navy Yard into an industrial park, and today it seems to be a model of eco-friendly adaptive reuse.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Navy Yard dates to 1801, when an entrepreneurial shipbuilder named John Jackson sold his land on Wallabout Bay, in the East River, to the federal government. At the yard’s peak in World War II, 70,000 men and women worked there. But it never recovered from a severe postwar decline, and the government closed it in 1966. The city turned the site into an industrial park, and today it seems to be a model of eco-friendly adaptive reuse. Only Building 92, which houses an interactive museum and job center, is regularly open to the public, but tours by bus and bicycle allow visitors to see the campus. To get there, take a bus to Flushing Avenue, the F train to York Street or ride a bike — if you don’t have one, there are Citi Bike stations nearby.

headline: Louisiana: One Killed and Five Hurt In Second Chemical Plant Blast
abstract: One person was killed and eight people were injured in a chemical plant explosion in Donaldsonville, La., on Friday night, the state police said.
lead_paragraph: One person was killed and five people were injured in a chemical plant explosion in Donaldsonville, La., on Friday night, the state police said, a day after another fatal explosion at a chemical plant in the neighboring town of Geismar. The two explosions did not appear to be related. Friday’s was caused by a truck offloading material at the C. F. Industries plant, which produces nitrogen, among other chemicals, for fertilizers, said Lt. John Cannon of the Louisiana State Police.  The Thursday explosion, at a plant owned by Williams Companies Inc., based in Tulsa, Okla., killed two people and injured dozens. The Labor Department’s Occupational Safety and Health Administration is investigating the blast at the plant, which makes ethylene and propylene, highly flammable gases.

headline: A Myanmar in Transition Says Little of Past Abuses
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Men who were at the helm of a repressive government have moved on easily in a democracy, in part, because there have been few calls for trials or war crimes tribunals.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — The former head of military intelligence, once feared and loathed for the torture his agents inflicted, now runs an art gallery. Myanmar’s former dictator, U Than Shwe, is reportedly enjoying a peaceful retirement in a secluded compound, while family members who grew rich during his military rule live luxurious lifestyles that contrast with the crippling poverty that afflicts most of the country. And a former top general in what was one of the world’s most repressive governments, U Thein Sein, is president, hailed both inside the country and abroad as a great reformer. He has been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize.

headline: Redesign for Living

lead_paragraph: Vishaan Chakrabarti, 47, has been a force in New York real estate for decades, working as director of the Manhattan office for the Department of City Planning and later as a senior executive at the Related Companies. Now he is the Marc Holliday associate professor of real estate development and the director of CURE, the Center for Urban Real Estate, at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation. He is also a partner at SHoP Architects, and recently published his first book, “A Country of Cities: A Manifesto for an Urban America.” Despite his many hats, Mr. Chakrabarti finds time on Sundays to work with his wife, Maria Alataris, also an architect, on renovations for their home near Union Square and to relax with their 5-year-old daughter, Avia, and 11-year-old son, Evan. The family lives on the top floor of a co-op on West 17th Street and was recently joined by a Havanese puppy, Hero.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE DARK KNIGHT RISES (2012) In this final installment in the director Christopher Nolan’s trilogy, Christian Bale stars as Batman, who has now retreated into the shadows — and his playboy alter ego, Bruce Wayne, who has gone into seclusion at Wayne Manor — years after the death of his foe Harvey Dent and the woman both men loved. Now Bane (Tom Hardy, above left, with Mr. Bales), an overmuscled brute who wears a mask that supplies him with a pain-relieving gas, is intent on destroying Gotham City. Bruce must also contend with Selina Kyle (Anne Hathaway), a cat burglar in search of a clean slate. Gary Oldman is back as Commissioner Gordon, and Michael Caine as Alfred, the Wayne family butler. “After repeatedly sending Batman down Gotham’s mean streets, Mr. Nolan ends by taking him somewhere new,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, choosing the film as a critic’s pick. “That’s precisely the point of a late sequence in which he shifts between a multitude of characters and as many locations without losing you, his narrative thread or momentum.” Like the scenes-within-scenes from his last movie, “Inception,” she said, “the controlled fragmentation works on a pleasurable, purely cinematic level.” But, Ms. Dargis added, “it also serves Mr. Nolan’s larger meaning in ‘The Dark Knight Rises’ and becomes his final say on superheroes and their uses because, as Gotham rages and all seems lost, the action shifts from a lone figure to a group, and hope springs not from one but many.”

headline: IHT Quick Read: June 15
abstract: Syrian rebels weigh prospects; war crimes tribunal rift; Argentines turn from beef; trade deal in Europe; and a new Airbus jet.
lead_paragraph: NEWS As a group of rebels gathered in an apartment in Aleppo, Syria’s largest city, debating the value of the United States’ decision to provide them with weapons, government forces nearby began pounding an opposition-held neighborhood. The opposing events led the group to focus on a question asked on Friday by many in Syria’s beleaguered opposition: Would the promised aid come in time, or would be it be too little, too late? An older rebel who leads a few dozen fighters on one of the front lines in Aleppo was skeptical. “I’ll believe that America is helping us when I see American arms in my group’s hands, not statements and food baskets,” said the 40-year-old fighter, who calls himself Abu Zaki. headline: I Know What You Think of Me
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'E-Mail', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Hearing other people’s uncensored opinions of you is an unpleasant reminder that you’re just another person in the world.
lead_paragraph: Recently I received an e-mail that wasn’t meant for me, but was about me. I’d been cc’d by accident. This is one of the darker hazards of electronic communication, Reason No. 697 Why the Internet Is Bad — the dreadful consequence of hitting “reply all” instead of “reply” or “forward.” The context is that I had rented a herd of goats for reasons that aren’t relevant here and had sent out a mass e-mail with photographs of the goats attached to illustrate that a) I had goats, and b) it was good. Most of the responses I received expressed appropriate admiration and envy of my goats, but the message in question was intended not as a response to me but as an aside to some of the recipient’s co-workers, sighing over the kinds of expenditures on which I was frittering away my uncomfortable income. The word “oof” was used.

headline: Egypt’s Perilous Drift
abstract: Egypt is a mess. But there is hope in the young environmentalists.
lead_paragraph: MARSA ALAM, Egypt — ON Tuesday, I visited a bakery in Cairo’s dirt-poor Imbaba neighborhood, where I watched a scrum of men, women and children jostling to get bread. You have to get there early, because the baker makes only so many subsidized pita loaves; he sells the rest of his government-subsidized flour on the black market to private bakers who charge five times the official price. He has no choice, he says, because his fuel costs are spiking. You can watch the subsidized-flour bags being carried on shoulders out the side door. “This is the hardest job in Egypt,” the bakery owner told me. Everyone is always mad at him, especially those who line up early and still leave with no bread.

headline: A Song for the Exonerated

lead_paragraph: Having lost 16 years in prison on a wrongful conviction for rape and murder, Jeffrey Deskovic opted for the simple exuberance of karaoke to celebrate the master’s degree he earned late last month from John Jay College of Criminal Justice. “I enjoyed singing ‘Live to Tell,’ ” he says of his graduation visit to a loud and friendly bar.

headline: A Judicial Travesty in Egypt
abstract: The conviction of 43 employees of foreign nonprofit groups sends a chilling message to Egyptians who want to work for democratic change.
lead_paragraph: Human rights in Egypt have remained under attack even after the 2011 revolution that ousted President Hosni Mubarak. Still, it was a shock when the Cairo Criminal Court convicted 43 employees of foreign nonprofit groups, including 16 Americans, on criminal charges and gave them prison sentences of one to five years.

headline: Racially Biased Arrests for Pot
abstract: The “war on marijuana” has become a war on minorities.

headline: Don’t Blame the Work Force
abstract: The belief that a skills gap is the cause of today’s high unemployment is mostly corporate fiction.

headline: Can’t Hide in the Cloud

And to a great degree, consumers have traded privacy for convenience — like having Web retailers store your credit card number to save you some typing on your next order.

abstract: For the past 15 years, I’ve helped raise a thoughtful, spirited young woman who is not my biological or adopted daughter. So, am I a “real” father? I’ve wrestled with that question, and Father’s Day always brings it into sharp relief.
lead_paragraph: I came out long before gay men yearned for weddings, much less baby showers. In 1979, when I was 22, New York offered young men like me many freedoms, including the freedom to not have to propagate. Like many other gay men — and like many straight men — I had not been close to my own father. I could not imagine wiping runny noses, attending parent-teacher conferences or playing Candy Land.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (49); 10 P.M. (13) INSPECTOR LEWIS, SERIES VI: DOWN AMONG THE FEARFUL A new round of this show, a “Masterpiece Mystery!” stalwart, begins as Inspector Lewis, the long-suffering detective played by Kevin Whately — in what may be his final season as he embarks on a sabbatical — and his sidekick, Detective Sgt. James Hathaway (Laurence Fox, above center, with Mr. Whately, right, and Sanjeev Bhaskar), investigate the murder of a psychic who is an Oxford psychology fellow. Rebecca Front reprises her role as their boss, Chief Superintendent Innocent, and Clare Holman is the winsome pathologist Laura Hobson, whose languorous courtship with Lewis the show promises to resolve. “Knowing that this might be the last hurrah, the writers and directors have given these episodes a valedictory quality that edges up to but doesn’t cross the line of mawkishness; the final, silent fade-out is both moving and appropriately modest,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “And Lewis is always Lewis. In the first episode of ‘Inspector Morse,’ he begged off a trip to the pub with his alcoholic boss because it was his night with the kids. As ‘Inspector Lewis’ comes to a close, he’s ready to give up the whole grind to spend more time with them. You never really believe it when American TV cops say that, but after a quarter-century, we can trust Lewis.”

headline: Bean Salads for Summer
abstract: Even when winter’s comforting stews no longer sound appealing, versatile beans of almost any variety can still be the backbone of a light, fresh meal.

As the weather heats up and our hunger for comforting stews gives way to a desire for lighter fare, beans can still be the backbone of a meal, but I’m more inclined to make them the focus of a main dish salad than a simmering ragout. I love the way they soak up tart salad dressings and the way their velvety textures play against the crunch of other salad ingredients, like fresh green beans, celery or fennel.

abstract: The Postal Service played cuts from its only album, “Give Up,” in a concert at the Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: The Postal Service isn’t having many second thoughts about its only album, “Give Up,” which was released in 2003. “Thank you so much for coming to this tiny little venue to see us play some music from 10 years ago,” Benjamin Gibbard, the band’s lead singer, said when the group performed on Friday night. The place wasn’t tiny; it was the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, and the arena was sold out for the first of two shows there. It’s at least an order of magnitude larger than the places the Postal Service played when it last toured a decade ago — a sign of the band’s continually spreading influence.

headline: Twin Seers, Conflicted and Cocky
abstract: “Sisterland,” a new novel from Curtis Sittenfeld, centers on identical twin sisters with psychic powers who have chosen contrasting lifestyles.
lead_paragraph: The high-concept gimmick at the heart of Curtis Sittenfeld’s 2008 best seller, “American Wife,” was a heroine modeled on the first lady Laura Bush, from her involvement as a teenager in a car accident that left a close friend dead, to her marriage to the wisecracking black-sheep son of a prominent political family who ends up becoming president and presiding over a calamitous war in the Middle East.

headline: One Deal That Led to the USA-1 Bermuda Bowl Team
abstract: The open trial earlier this month selected the two teams to represent the United States in this year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship.
lead_paragraph: The open trial earlier this month selected the two teams to represent the United States in this year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship.

headline: Two Groups Rekindle Fight Over Anne Frank
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: A lawsuit has exposed a fight between two organizations with diverging ideas of how to preserve the young diarist’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — In a letter to her grandmother in 1940, composed before she went into hiding here, 11-year-old Annelies Frank recorded a detail that surely seemed of little consequence at the time.

headline: Making Science Attractive for Women
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Japanese universities are pushing to increase female enrollment in science and technology, despite a culture that pushes most women toward the humanities.
lead_paragraph: Japanese universities are pushing to increase female enrollment in science and technology, despite a culture that pushes most women toward the humanities.

headline: A Latter-Day American Answer to Stravinsky’s ‘Rite of Spring’
abstract: Mark Morris’s adaptation of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring” had its debut at the Ojai North festival in California last week.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Mark Morris, the first dance figure to be artistic director of the annual Ojai Festival, has chosen a repertory that largely emphasizes American composers: notably, Henry Cowell, John Cage and Lou Harrison. In Ojai, Calif., Mr. Morris’s dancers performed a selection of the works he has made to their music over the decades; he also conducted concerts.

headline: TimesTalks Luminato Festival Video: Joni Mitchell
abstract: The singer, songwriter and painter Joni Mitchell talks with The Times’s chief pop music critic, Jon Pareles, about her work and her life.
lead_paragraph: The singer, songwriter and painter Joni Mitchell (“Both Sides Now,” “Blue,” “Court and Spark,” “Hejira”) and the drummer/bandleader Brian Blade, one of her frequent collaborators, talk with The Times’s chief pop music critic, Jon Pareles, about Ms. Mitchell’s work and life on the occasion of a concert at Massey Hall in Toronto, “Joni: A Portrait in Song,” in celebration of her 70th birthday this year.

headline: Inflation Nation Not
abstract: But nobody learns anything.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong has a fairly long, intricate piece keying off what looked like a prediction by John Cochrane, early in the Great Recession, that the Fed’s expansion of the monetary base would lead to high inflation. Brad spends a fair bit of time on various excuses — was it really a prediction? — but I think that’s beside the main point, which is that all the people predicting high inflation four years ago were right to do so, given their models. And the lesson of low inflation — a lesson most of them refuse to learn — is that their models were wrong.

headline: Venturing Into Bop Territory, Armed With Renditions of Standards
abstract: The Italian jazz pianist Rossano Sportiello emphasized the pop-classical connection while paying tribute to George Shearing.
lead_paragraph: The Italian jazz pianist Rossano Sportiello and his trio belong to a conservative tradition that treats jazz as a kind of chamber music closely aligned with classical keyboard. George Shearing, the pianist who they honored in the show “The Smiling Piano: A Tribute to the Artistry of Jazz Piano Icon George Shearing” on Saturday evening at the Café Carlyle, belonged to the same school. The emphasis is on refinement, scrupulously avoiding harsh textures and grating dissonances to conjure pleasurable languor.

headline: In Oscar’s Home, the Ritual of Picking Its Next President Gets Under Way
abstract: Don’t call it a “campaign” for president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. But the contenders are lining up and alliances are quietly being sealed.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In theaters, it’s blockbuster season.

headline: Back at the Whitney, Tinkering With Perception
abstract: Robert Irwin’s installation “Scrim Veil — Black Rectangle — Natural Light,” last seen on the Whitney Museum’s fourth floor in 1977, will be back through Sept. 1.
lead_paragraph: The artist Robert Irwin took over the fourth floor of the Whitney Museum of American Art in 1977 with a single work that became a kind of legend, though many visitors at the time failed to see it. “People would step out of the elevator, say, ‘Hmm, empty room,’ and hop back in before the doors shut,” Mr. Irwin recalled recently.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Data to be released includes housing starts and leading economic indicators in the United States, as well as earnings from FedEx and Carnival.
lead_paragraph: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week includes housing starts and consumer prices for May (Tuesday); and leading economic indicators, existing home sales for May and initial jobless claims (Thursday). International data will include the euro-area trade balance (Monday); British inflation (Tuesday); and the Bank of Japan quarterly flow of funds report (Wednesday). The World Wealth Report, an annual survey of millionaires by RBC Wealth Management and Cap Gemini, will be released on Tuesday.

headline: Military Suppliers Push for Europe-Made Drone
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Defense Contracts', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Aircraft']
abstract: The proposal, a joint effort of EADS, Dassault Aviation and Finmeccanica, is intended to reduce dependence on U.S. and Israeli manufacturers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Three of Europe’s top military contractors urged the region’s governments on Sunday to support a joint program to develop a reconnaissance drone to reduce dependence on American and Israeli manufacturers.

headline: English Gavels Resound in a Trove Headed to Yale
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Books and Literature', 'Legal Profession', 'Manuscripts', 'Archives and Records', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Yale University has acquired a vast and renowned collection of English lawbooks and legal manuscripts assembled by the barrister Anthony Taussig.
lead_paragraph: A pocket-size 14th-century handwritten copy of Magna Carta, the first book on the legal rights of women published in England, letters from the 18th-century jurist William Blackstone and papers belonging to a real-life London lawyer praised by Charles Dickens’s fictional yes-man Uriah Heep are among the highlights of a rich trove of rare legal books and manuscripts just acquired by Yale University.

headline: Call It ‘The Green Card of Figaro,’ With Thanks to Mozart
abstract: In Morningside Opera’s “¡Figaro! (90210),” an adaptation of Mozart’s “Nozze di Figaro,” Figaro and Susana are undocumented Mexican workers.
lead_paragraph: “¡Figaro! (90210),” Morningside Opera’s blasphemous, brilliant new adaptation of “Le Nozze di Figaro,” owes Peter Sellars an even greater debt than it does Mozart and Da Ponte.

headline: Anniversary Celebrated With Range and Resolve
abstract: For the fifth anniversary of the club Le Poisson Rouge, the group Alarm Will Sound played pieces whose creation spanned the past 10 years.
lead_paragraph: When Ronen Givony, a music director at the Bleecker Street nightclub Le Poisson Rouge, welcomed the audience to a performance by the new-music ensemble Alarm Will Sound on Saturday night, he said it was fitting that a concert on the fifth anniversary of the club’s opening should focus on music by Caleb Burhans. Mr. Burhans, a composer, multi-instrumentalist and vocalist, has performed there more often than any other artist. By Mr. Givony’s admittedly rough count, the event was Mr. Burhans’s 125th Le Poisson Rouge appearance.

headline: Monica Germino Puts Electronics and Violin Together, and Myriad Sounds Ensue
abstract: The violinist Monica Germino, accompanied by electronics, performed several works at the Austrian Cultural Forum.
lead_paragraph: For more than two centuries the preferred duo partner of the violin was the piano. With its powerful sound and polyphonic possibilities it was like the male dancer in a pas de deux who acts as a foil for the violin’s more supple, slender tone and allows it to soar. During a recital and workshop at the Austrian Cultural Forum on Thursday and Friday, the American-Dutch violinist Monica Germino presented the fruits of a very different partnership: violin and electronics.

headline: Easy to Catch
abstract: After the Sunday puzzle, Johanna Fenimore and Andrea Carla Michaels restore my faith in solving.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, this one just restored my faith in my ability to solve. After yesterday’s puzzle , I really needed it.

headline: Illegal Crossings Along the Texas Border
abstract: The Rio Grande Valley Sector of the Texas border with Mexico has become the most active site of illegal crossing attempts, with 55 percent more apprehensions so far this fiscal year than during the same period last year.
lead_paragraph: The Rio Grande Valley Sector of the Texas border with Mexico has become the most active site of illegal crossing attempts, with 55 percent more apprehensions so far this fiscal year than during the same period last year.

headline: LinkedIn Builds Its Publishing Presence
keywords: ['Social Networking (Internet)', 'Careers and Professions', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: LinkedIn’s Influencers program, which consists of people in leadership positions posting about their lives and careers, has transformed viewer engagement on the site, its chief executive said.
lead_paragraph: LinkedIn came of age as the staid social media platform for business professionals: reliable, utilitarian and, well, boring.

headline: Archivists in France Fight a Privacy Initiative
abstract: Privacy guardians in Europe want the ability to erase some online material, known as “the right to be forgotten,” but archivists and historians object.
lead_paragraph: SERRAVAL, France — As a European proposal to bolster digital privacy safeguards faces intense lobbying from Silicon Valley and other powerful groups in Brussels, an obscure but committed group has joined in the campaign to keep personal data flourishing online.

headline: Bloomberg Plan Aims to Require Food Composting
keywords: ['Compost', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Recycling of Waste Materials']
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has built a name for pushing ambitious causes in New York, is rolling out a plan to begin requiring residents to collect their food scraps.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has tried to curb soda consumption, ban smoking in parks and encourage bike riding, is taking on a new cause: requiring New Yorkers to separate their food scraps for composting.

headline: Future of 3-D TV Murky as ESPN Ends Channel
abstract: ESPN’s move spurred a debate about whether anyone would be left watching in 3-D television soon, and whether anything would be available worth watching.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, 3-D was hailed as the next big thing in television, the logical successor to high definition. But viewers in the United States did not buy the hype, and now the eye-popping format is seen as an expensive flop.

headline: Choice of Health Plans to Vary Sharply From State to State
keywords: ['States (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Some states have attracted an array of insurers for their exchanges, while options in other states may be limited.
lead_paragraph: When a typical 40-year-old uninsured woman in Maine goes to the new state exchange to buy health insurance this fall, she may have just two companies to choose from: the one that already sells most individual policies in the state, and a complete unknown — a nonprofit start-up.

headline: Big Lead Evaporates, but Yankees and Rivera Win Duel
abstract: Mariano Rivera struck out Albert Pujols with the bases loaded after the Angels threatened with a five-run ninth, saving a strong performance by C. C. Sabathia and the Yankees offense.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — For eight superb innings, it looked as if the Yankees would salvage the final game of their trip with ease, gliding to the end of a challenging West Coast swing with a blowout win to help soothe their mounting anxiety.

headline: Mandela’s Absence Is Felt, if Not Addressed
abstract: The residents of the village where Nelson Mandela grew up seem determined to press ahead with life as normal, but there is plenty of anguish over his ailing condition.
lead_paragraph: QUNU, South Africa — At the Methodist church here in Nelson Mandela’s home village — a scatter of brightly painted houses amid rolling hills — the ladies’ choir held its weekly practice, sending strains of gospel melodies into the surrounding fields. An out-of-town couple were married at the heritage center that bears Mr. Mandela’s name, in a joyous ceremony that featured swinging hips, sharp suits and sparkling high heels.

headline: Success of Cuomo’s Plan for More Casinos Relies on His Power of Persuasion
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo must convince the Legislature, the voters and even developers, some of whom are not particularly keen on investing in gambling upstate.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — If Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s plan to expand full-scale casino gambling in New York is to become a reality, he is going to have to hit a three-part parlay.

headline: Phoenix Finds Its Way to Water
abstract: While others have grappled with water shortages, the arid city has managed to avoid being parched.
lead_paragraph: While others have grappled with water shortages, the arid city has managed to avoid being parched.

abstract: Health insurers are applying to offer individual coverage on the new Affordable Care Act exchanges for Oct. 1.
lead_paragraph: Health insurers are applying to offer individual coverage on the new Affordable Care Act exchanges for Oct. 1.

headline: An Arid Arizona City Manages Its Thirst
abstract: There is a certain curiosity about the way water is used in Phoenix, which gets barely eight inches of rain a year but is not necessarily parched.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The hiss of sprinklers serenades improbably green neighborhoods early in the morning and late at night, the moisture guarding against the oppressive heat. This is the time of year when temperatures soar, water consumption spikes and water bills skyrocket in this city, particularly for those whose idea of desert living includes cultivating a healthy expanse of grass.

headline: China Dissident Says He’s Being Forced From N.Y.U.
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Law Schools', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Chen Guangcheng, the legal advocate, said he was being forced to leave the university over concerns that his activism was harming its relationship with China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chen Guangcheng, the dissident legal advocate whose escape from house arrest to the American Embassy in Beijing last year provoked a diplomatic crisis, said he was being forced to leave New York University over concerns that his activism was harming the university’s relationship with China.

headline: Faltering Economy in China Dims Job Prospects for Graduates
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Graduating seniors say that few are finding jobs, and that some offers extended over the winter are being rescinded, as the Chinese economy falters.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A record seven million students will graduate from universities and colleges across China in the coming weeks, but their job prospects appear bleak — the latest sign of a troubled Chinese economy.

headline: Death Be Not Decaffeinated: Over Cup, Groups Face Taboo
abstract: An informal group called Death Cafe meets monthly in New York to bat around philosophical thoughts on death and dying. It’s one of many such gatherings that have sprung up around the country.
lead_paragraph: Socrates did not fear death; he calmly drank the hemlock. Kierkegaard was obsessed with death, which made him a bit gloomy. As for Lorraine Tosiello, a 58-year-old internist in Bradley Beach, N.J., it is the process of dying that seems endlessly puzzling.

headline: Czech Premier to Resign Amid Scandal

abstract: Prime Minister Petr Necas of the Czech Republic said Sunday that he would resign, following a corruption scandal involving a senior aide.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Prime Minister Petr Necas of the Czech Republic said Sunday that he would resign, following a corruption scandal involving a senior aide. The resignation, which he said he would submit Monday, plunged the country into a period of political uncertainty.

headline: A San Antonio Graduate Program That Churns Out N.B.A. Coaches
abstract: Mike Budenholzer, the next coach of the Atlanta Hawks, is the latest Spurs assistant to enhance his career under the tutelage of Coach Gregg Popovich and General Manager R. C. Buford.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Mike Budenholzer has observed the San Antonio Spurs’ success from many vantage points during his 19 years with the team — from the video room, where he landed his first job with the Spurs, to the bench, where he now sits next to Coach Gregg Popovich.

headline: Big News Forges Its Own Path
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Crowdsourcing (Internet)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Major news stories increasingly find their own digital path, and no one feels the need to work with the traditional power players to make it happen.
lead_paragraph: During a visit to Toronto last week, I noticed the entire city was pivoting around a story by Gawker, a site that has a broad range of interests, but at its core is dedicated to detailing the running silliness of life in Manhattan.

headline: Our Schools, Cut Off From the Web
abstract: Educational achievement, a healthy population, political participation and economic opportunity depend in significant ways on how we structure and manage our spreading digital frontier.
lead_paragraph: ON June 6, at a middle school in Mooresville, N.C., President Obama set a goal of high-speed Internet in nearly every public school in America in five years. It was a bold and needed pronouncement — except that in 1996 President Clinton said virtually the same thing, calling for libraries and classrooms to be “hooked up to the Information Superhighway by the year 2000.”

headline: Turkey’s False Nostalgia
abstract: Turkey’s past is no model for a democratic future. Earlier leaders, including Ataturk, were just as authoritarian as Erdogan.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — THE demonstrators who have filled the streets of Istanbul and other Turkish cities for nearly three weeks complain that Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s Justice and Development Party, known as the A.K.P., has adopted an increasingly authoritarian attitude that threatens basic freedoms. They also resent his tendency to meddle in the personal lives of citizens — by condemning abortion or trying to control the sale and consumption of alcohol.

headline: Living With the Surveillance State
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Privacy']
abstract: We’ve gotten used to being watched. But who watches the watchers?
lead_paragraph: MY colleague Thomas Friedman’s levelheaded take on the National Security Agency eavesdropping uproar needs no boost from me. His column soared to the top of the “most e-mailed” list and gathered a huge and mostly thoughtful galaxy of reader comments. Judging from the latest opinion polling, it also reflected the prevailing mood of the electorate. It reflected mine. But this is a discussion worth prolonging, with vigilant attention to real dangers answering overblown rhetoric about theoretical ones.

headline: Fight the Future
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Unemployment']
abstract: On the dangers of fiscal science fiction.
lead_paragraph: Last week the International Monetary Fund, whose normal role is that of stern disciplinarian to spendthrift governments, gave the United States some unusual advice. “Lighten up,” urged the fund. “Enjoy life! Seize the day!”

headline: The Forgotten 50,000
abstract: The next New York City mayor will inherit an overlooked emergency: homelessness
lead_paragraph: More than 50,000 New Yorkers slept in city homeless shelters and on the streets last night. About 21,000 were children. These numbers are huge and appalling, higher than they were in 2002, when Mayor Michael Bloomberg took office, higher than in the dismal days of the fiscal crisis, the Reagan ’80s and the surly administration of Rudolph Giuliani.

headline: That Extra Hurdle at the Airport
abstract: A new report seriously questions whether the behavioral detection program is objective or worth the cost.
lead_paragraph: Beyond wending through airport security minus shoes and belt, tens of thousands of American travelers have been singled out in line during the last six years to be chatted up by “behavior detection officers” working for the Transportation Security Administration.

headline: Merion Golf Club Stands Up to Fears of Its Frailty
abstract: If Merion proved to be heartless to some favorites, humbling Tiger Woods, it stood up to lashing rain and dire warnings about its course, and even showed compassion to other players.
lead_paragraph: ARDMORE, Pa. — As rain lashed Merion Golf Club last Monday, alarm rose with the water. Whitecaps lapped in the creek at the 11th hole! Trout swam in the flooded bunker! The course was more pillowy than Phil Mickelson! Time to bring out the octopus pants!

headline: Schooling Ourselves in an Unequal America
abstract: To regain our lead in educational achievement, we’ll have to work from the bottom up.
lead_paragraph: Averages can be misleading. The familiar, one-dimensional story told about American education is that it was once the best system in the world but that now it’s headed down the drain, with piles of money thrown down after it.

headline: For Sixth Time, Mickelson Wins Only Sympathy
abstract: No one has finished second at the United States Open as often as Phil Mickelson. He has had the lead with three holes left and has lost. This time, he trailed by a stroke.
lead_paragraph: ARDMORE, Pa. — Phil Mickelson’s Sunday at the 113th United States Open began with fans singing “Happy Birthday” to him as he appeared on the practice range at 2:20 p.m. Almost exactly five hours later, the fans in the grandstand behind the 18th green cheered, chanted and stomped their feet as Mickelson walked toward them.

abstract: Responses from liberals and others to Richard A. Viguerie’s Op-Ed essay, “Conservative Case for Prison Reform.”

headline: As U.S. Plugs Border in Arizona, Crossings Shift to South Texas
abstract: A shift in the front line of the battle against illegal crossings has intensified debate over an immigration overhaul; some say a Texas influx shows the need to prioritize border security.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A surge in migrant traffic across the Southwest border into Texas has resulted in a milestone: the front line of the battle against illegal crossings from Mexico has shifted for the first time in over a decade away from Arizona to the Rio Grande Valley of South Texas.

headline: To U.S. Soccer Team, Home Field Is an Ever-Changing Thing
abstract: Discussions of settling on a permanent stadium for the team rarely get anywhere, the federation president says, because the idea “doesn’t make much sense.”
lead_paragraph: On the list of places hosting important World Cup qualifying matches this year, there is Wembley in London, there is Estadio Azteca in Mexico City, and there is Rio Tinto Stadium in the home of “Big Love.”

headline: Niels Diffrient, Industrial Designer Who Blended Form and Function, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Diffrient combined elegance and efficiency in everyday objects, and even office chairs like the award-winning Freedom Chair.
lead_paragraph: Niels Diffrient, an industrial designer who combined elegance and efficiency in everyday objects, including telephones, cameras, airplane interiors and, late in his life, office chairs that adjusted themselves to whoever sat in them, died on June 8 at his home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 84.

headline: Transportation Chief Talks of Giving the Public More Public Spaces
abstract: Janette Sadik-Khan, New York City transportation commissioner, said world-class cities have beautiful, safe public spaces where people can gather and relax.
lead_paragraph: A wary look fell upon Janette Sadik-Khan when conversation over breakfast turned suddenly to the protests in Taksim Square in Istanbul. Where, that look said, was this going?

abstract: Winning numbers for June 16, 2013.

headline: Release the Facts About the I.R.S. Scandal
keywords: ['Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Editorials']
abstract: House Republicans talk about a White House connection, despite evidence to the contrary. It’s time they released the transcripts from their investigation.
lead_paragraph: For Republican leaders in Congress, the Internal Revenue Service scandal always had a higher purpose. They had no interest in fixing the clear management problems at the agency, or tax-exemption laws so vague they are an invitation to misinterpretation, leading to the singling out of Tea Party groups for special scrutiny. All they wanted was a connection to the White House, no matter how slim, so they could accuse President Obama and his administration of using the tax agency as a political weapon.

headline: Reversal for Rangers: Vigneault Puts Offense First, With a Dose of Humor
abstract: Alain Vigneault, who is expected to be the Rangers’ next coach, will have to awaken the Rangers’ ability to score.
lead_paragraph: Alain Vigneault, expected to be introduced as the next Rangers coach in the coming days, comes to New York as the antidote to John Tortorella.

headline: Kerry Associate Chosen for Post on Closing Guantánamo Prison
abstract: Cliff Sloan, a lawyer with a varied career in government, is expected to be named the next envoy to the military jail on Monday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Monday is expected to name Cliff Sloan, a Washington lawyer and confidant of Secretary of State John Kerry, as the new diplomatic envoy for the shutdown of the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, an official said on Sunday.

headline: Under Pressure, Stewart Shifts Company’s Focus
abstract: After posting a loss in the first quarter, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia redesigned its print and digital offerings in hopes of returning to profitability.
lead_paragraph: To follow Martha Stewart, even briefly, is a test of endurance. On a recent afternoon, Ms. Stewart wrapped up posing for a photo shoot for Martha Stewart Halloween magazine at her company’s Manhattan headquarters, as makeup artists briskly wiped glitter off her cheeks and disassembled her fairy-godmother bouffant. She hopped off her makeup chair and sprinted into the neighboring studio to check on a Martha Stewart Weddings cover photo shoot featuring $50 million worth of engagement rings.

headline: Budget Cuts Reach Bone for Philadelphia Schools
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Deep budget cuts have Philadelphia school officials worrying about how to make do without aides, secretaries, counselors, monitors, coaches or money for new books or paper.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — When a second grader came to the Andrew Jackson School too agitated to eat breakfast on Friday, an aide alerted the school counselor, who engaged him in an art project in her office. When he was still overwrought at 11, a secretary called the boy’s family, and soon a monitor at the front door buzzed in an older brother to take him home.

headline: U.S. Seems Eager for Nuclear Talks With Iran’s New Leader
abstract: President Obama’s top foreign policy aides said they planned to press Hassan Rowhani, Iran’s president-elect, to resume negotiations over his country’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s top foreign policy aides said Sunday that they planned to press Iran’s newly elected president to resume the negotiations over his country’s nuclear program that derailed in the spring.

headline: In Overtime, Bruins’ Coach Keeps Things Simple
abstract: The Boston Bruins are 5-2 in overtime games this postseason. The advice of Coach Claude Julien is always the same: “Don’t play on your heels.”
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Boston Bruins Coach Claude Julien, who loves his job but hates the attention that comes with it, is a man of very few words at one of the most important junctures of a hockey game: the beginning of overtime.

headline: Sexual Trafficking, Up Close and Personal
abstract: “Roadkill” is an unsettling site-specific theater piece about sex trafficking that is staged on a bus and in a town house in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The girl on the bus had been promised summer and sunshine, she says, and it is cool and clammy on this wet evening in June. But Mary, 14 years old and fresh from Nigeria, is willing to forgive this new, exciting city its disappointing weather. If she has any suspicion that what awaits at the end of her journey will be beyond forgiveness, she does not betray it.

headline: New Governor Is a Shock to Some Inside Egypt
abstract: The new governor of Luxor, Adel Asaad Khayyat, comes from the political arm of an Islamist group that once carried out terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s Islamist president appointed a new governor of Luxor on Sunday who comes from the political arm of an Islamist group that once carried out terrorist attacks that killed dozens of tourists, soldiers and police officers in the same city.

headline: At 89, Astor’s Son Wouldn’t Be the Oldest in Prison
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Wills and Estates', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: Anthony D. Marshall is scheduled to surrender this week to begin serving a prison sentence for stealing millions of dollars from his mother.
lead_paragraph: Having exhausted all appeals of his conviction for stealing millions of dollars from his mother, Anthony D. Marshall, the octogenarian son of the philanthropist Brooke Astor, is scheduled to surrender this week to begin serving a prison sentence of one to three years.

headline: The Faulty Logic of the ‘Math Wars’
abstract: The “reform” strategy for teaching math that has taken American schools by storm lacks a claim to the progressive values that are its chief selling point.
lead_paragraph: There is a great progressive tradition in American thought that urges us not to look for the aims of education beyond education itself. Teaching and learning should not be conceived as merely instrumental affairs; the goal of education is rather to awaken individuals’ capacities for independent thought. Or, in the words of the great progressivist John Dewey, the goal of education “is to enable individuals to continue their education.”

headline: Mainstream Pop Amid Smaller, Obsessive Passions
abstract: Saturday at Bonnaroo started with the explosive and recondite and opened out gradually, over about twelve hours, into open, cool-headed, mass sing-alongs.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — Saturday at Bonnaroo started with the explosive and the recondite and opened out gradually, over about 12 hours, into open, cool-headed, mass sing-alongs. At 2:15 p.m. the hip-hop band Death Grips, from Sacramento, Calif., obscure and assaultive in word and sound, appeared on one of the smaller stages without its drummer, Zach Hill, which seemed at first like a problem: he’s a pure energy driver, a combustion expert. (He’s busy working on a film, for which the band will make the soundtrack music.) But the rapper Stefan Burnett and the keyboardist Andy Morin pulled it off impressively on their own and with samples. Mr. Burnett has the rampaging intensity of an early punk singer — he seems as if he’s inventing new ways to make music challenge and disobey — and the voice of a drill sergeant; he never let up, barking and chanting short, dark and dense lines, rocking back and forth from the waist. Performers at Bonnaroo are often flattering their audiences — it’s both a mainstream-pop festival and one that’s built on smaller, more obsessive passions — but he would flatter nobody.

headline: As Rape Reports Increase in Delhi, a Call for Uncommon Men and Women
abstract: The tide of rising crimes against women in India can eventually be stemmed by uncommon women and men.
lead_paragraph: Last December, a young woman we call “Nirbhaya” was so brutally assaulted and raped by six men on a bus that she died from her injuries two weeks later. She was barely older than my daughter Mira. Grieving, I looked for solace in student memories. I had resisted going to a women’s college at Delhi University, but a few years later at Mount Holyoke, a college for women in Massachusetts, I discovered a world where no one had to remind you to “lean in” because every woman already had her shoulder to the wheel and was moving the needle on everything from microbiology to challenging history with herstory. I was surrounded by women who wrote poetry, discussed politics, dismantled engines, designed buildings, managed newspapers, and danced for the joy of being able to do so. It was a world where women were not less than but equal to – a world, as the playwright Wendy Wasserstein put it, of “Uncommon Women.”The assault happened in New Delhi – the city of my birth and the city where I now live. It is comforting for many to believe that cultures of rape arise in war-torn places like the Democratic Republic of Congo. Now suddenly it was New Delhi that was labeled the “capital of rape.” The latest statistics from the National Crime Records Bureau indicate that a woman is raped in India every 20 minutes and that this horrendous statistic could well be worse because of high levels of underreporting. According to the N.C.R.B., the number of crimes against women reported to the Indian police has increased from 228, 650 in 2011 to 244,270 in 2012. Out of the 24,923 rape cases registered by the police across India in 2012, 706 cases of rape were reported in Delhi, according to the N.C.R.B. In 2011 the number of rape cases reported in Delhi was 572.

headline: A Conversation With: Journalist Naveen Soorinje
keywords: ['Assaults', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Hinduism', 'News and News Media', 'Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A reporter speaks about his time in an Indian prison.
lead_paragraph: On July 28, 2012, Naveen Soorinje, a journalist with the Kannada television network Kasturi Newz 24 in Mangalore, Karnataka, covered an attack by a mob from the right-wing group Hindu Jagarana Vedike on a group of boys and girls having a birthday party at a suburban resort. A cameraman, Seetharam, who goes by one name, filmed the brutal assault, which lasted half an hour.Widely known as “the homestay attack,” it was only one of a rising number of incidents of sectarian moral policing in the developing and modernizing city of Mangalore. But when Mr. Soorinje and Mr. Seetharam were arrested in November, along with 43 others, and charged with conspiracy, rioting and unlawful assembly, the case inspired an intense campaign for media freedom and Mr. Soorinje’s release from jail. Mr. Soorinje was freed on bail on March 23, and the charges against him and Mr. Seetharam were finally dropped on Friday.

lead_paragraph: For a homeowner ready to sell, the all-cash buyer is the dream, a tantalizing oasis away from the strictures of bank loans and the whims of appraisers. And in markets as far-reaching as Long Island City in Queens, Greenwich Village in Manhattan and the Hollywood Hills in California, buyers with cash in hand have popped up in unusually high numbers.

headline: Governor Morton’s ‘Finance Bureau’
abstract: How an Indiana governor overcame a near-rebellion in his own state.
lead_paragraph: President Abraham Lincoln once said that Oliver P. Morton, Republican governor of Indiana, was a “good fellow” but “the skeeredest man I know of.” Morton had just written him a panicked letter about the results of the October 1862 state elections; Democrats had swept the contest, overwhelmingly winning the state offices and 7 of the 11 Congressional districts. They would now control both houses of the State Legislature by wide margins, threatening Morton’s control of the state’s war effort.

abstract: Reviews are mixed for the new musical ‘King Kong,’ which may be the next big-budget spectacle to arrive on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: The new Australian musical “King Kong,” which may be the next big-budget spectacle to hit Broadway, opened on Saturday night in Melbourne to mixed reviews. There were awe-struck descriptions of the 20-foot-tall Kong and the elaborate puppetry that brings him to life, but less enthusiasm for the book by Craig Lucas and the mix of original music and contemporary songs of the score. A New York spokesman for the musical’s producer said on Monday that there was no news about a Broadway run, though the plan has been to bring the show to New York at some point.

lead_paragraph: The adage “what you don’t know can’t hurt you” does not apply to federal securities laws, as Revlon learned from the Securities and Exchange Commission when the company settled an accusation that it deceived its minority shareholders. The larger question is whether the S.E.C. might actually start to police buyout offers from management and controlling shareholders that are rife with conflicts of interest and usually end up favoring the buyer over the minority shareholders.

headline: Nowadays, Fewer Tears at Her AIDS Concerts
abstract: As the nature of AIDS has changed, so, too, have the concerts organized by Mimi Stern-Wolfe since 1990 in recognition of the disease and its costs. This year’s show is Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Mimi Stern-Wolfe organized her first AIDS concert in 1990, after the death of a friend, and with a few exceptions she has made it an annual event – a kind of musical counterpoint to the changing shape of the epidemic. At the first concert, at Middle Collegiate Church in the East Village, the audience was dotted with men emaciated by the then-untreatable virus; listeners wept during the performance or left in tears.

headline: Saying Less and Doing More
abstract: Supporting friends in times of serious trouble, like during an illness, can be difficult.
lead_paragraph: When I received a diagnosis of breast cancer in 2009, my friend Caitlin was one of the first people I called. And when she came to see me, she said the perfect thing: nothing. Instead, she burst into tears, gave me a hug — and then took me shopping for wigs.

headline: More Google Maps for Bikes
abstract: Google Maps has expanded its bike route directions to seven additional countries in Europe, including France, Germany, and Poland.
lead_paragraph: As short-term bicycle rentals like Paris’ Velib bikes expand in cities worldwide, navigating by bike has proposed a new set of challenges, including what’s the least trafficked route between X and Y? Google Maps, which began providing bike directions in the United States and Canada in 2010 and in nine European countries in 2012, just expanded its bike route directions to seven additional countries in Europe, including Germany, France, Poland, Ireland, Luxembourg and Liechtenstein.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London fashion week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: In an online question-and-answer session, Edward J. Snowden said that he had not given any classified materials to the government of China, calling such speculation “a predictable smear.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who has confessed to disclosing troves of highly classified documents detailing American surveillance at home and abroad, said Monday that he had not given any classified materials to the government of China.

headline: For Olivari Olive Oil, a Campaign About ‘Little Things’
abstract: A brand of one of the world’s largest olive oil producers has embarked on a social media campaign to increase its name in the American market.
lead_paragraph: Olivari Olive Oil, a brand of one of the world’s largest olive oil producers, has embarked on an ambitious social media campaign to stake a claim in the United States market.

headline: Nervous Flier? He’ll Hold Your Hand
abstract: John Tangredi is president of the expense management division of Insperity, a provider of human resources and business performance solutions.
lead_paragraph: I’VE been traveling for business fairly consistently for about 20 years. For one thing, my office is in Irvine, Calif., but the corporate headquarters for Insperity  are in Houston. So there’s a ton of back-and-forth travel.

headline: User Satisfaction With Online Brokerages Declines
abstract: Scottrade moved to the top of an annual ranking of customer satisfaction with online brokerages.
lead_paragraph: Scottrade moved to the top of the rankings in an annual study of customer satisfaction with online brokerages, but satisfaction with the self-serve tools over all fell from last year.

headline: The Heart Perils of Pain Relievers
abstract: Researchers see cardiovascular risks in frequent high doses of some common medicines.
lead_paragraph: Common pain relievers like ibuprofen and naproxen — called nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or Nsaids — are the go-to drugs for headaches and pulled muscles, arthritis and menstrual cramps. Their labels have long warned that overuse may increase the risk of heart attack and stroke, but we rely on them as we do on few other medications. And for good reason: They work.

headline: Triple Play: Week 11 Results
abstract: Put your predictive skills to the test each week of the baseball season.
lead_paragraph: Robinson Cano and Prince Fielder, who have made pretty big names on their own, each collected eight hits last week to be the answers to our Father’s Day question.

headline: Snowden’s Questionable New Turn
abstract: Is he seriously suggesting that countries should only spy in times of war?
lead_paragraph: When Edward Snowden first began leaking documents he purloined from the National Security Agency, he seemed to have a clear sense of purpose. He wanted to let Americans know that their government was secretly spying on the phone records of millions of innocent citizens, infringing on their civil liberties, and that it was demanding information on some of the Internet traffic flowing through American computer systems.

lead_paragraph: Reporters who covered the Boston crime boss James (Whitey) Bulger describe how he became one of the most notorious gangsters in American history.

lead_paragraph: The Times’s Henry Fountain describes two unconventional demolition methods pioneered by the Japanese.

headline: Ludo’s Next Bite
abstract: For years, Ludo Lefebvre was a chef without a permanent address as his pop-up restaurant moved around Los Angeles. Now he’s settled at Trois Mec, cooking classic French dishes with a twist.
lead_paragraph: For years, Ludo Lefebvre was a chef without a permanent address as his pop-up restaurant moved around Los Angeles. Now he’s settled at Trois Mec, cooking classic French dishes with a twist.

headline: Depicting the Colors of Space
abstract: The hues assigned to distant cosmic bodies that are telescopically photographed in black and white are not just a matter of artistic license.
lead_paragraph: The Cat’s Eye Nebula — a dying star in the constellation Draco — may appear in images in psychedelic shades of pink and green or in soothing tones of beige and aquamarine. But scientists apply more than artistic license when it comes to assigning colors to distant cosmic bodies that are telescopically photographed.

headline: Tricky Ways to Pull Down a Skyscraper
abstract: Engineers in Japan are perfecting more efficient, and stealthier, demolition methods.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — There are many ways to demolish a building, and some of them are spectacular: blowing it up from the inside so it collapses on itself, or smashing it to bits with a two-ton wrecking ball.

headline: Apple Executive Defends Pricing in Case on E-Books
keywords: ['E-Books and Readers', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Book Trade and Publishing']

lead_paragraph: Just days after Apple introduced the iPad and opened an e-bookstore, the biggest player in the e-book market, Amazon, changed the way it sold digital titles. Steven P. Jobs shot off an e-mail to the Apple executive who had negotiated deals with the publishers.

headline: Opposition to House Farm Bill Spans Political Spectrum
abstract: As the House prepares to vote this week on a five-year farm bill, liberal and conservative critics call it a nearly $1 trillion giveaway to wealthy corporate farmers, with price supports for crops that distort the market.
lead_paragraph: As the House prepares to vote this week on a new five-year farm bill, advocacy groups from across the political spectrum are lining up to oppose it, threatening to derail legislation that died last year when leaders refused to bring it to the floor.

headline: Role Player Has the Hot Hand, and the Spurs Find Him
abstract: Danny Green now has the record for most 3-pointers in an N.B.A. finals with 25, making him an early candidate for the series’ Most Valuable Player award.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Danny Green never hesitated, not with the ball in his hands and his feet behind the 3-point arc. Green, a role player for the San Antonio Spurs, kept launching the ball, and more times than not the ball swished through the hoop and the Miami Heat players continued to shake their heads.

lead_paragraph: Iranians react to the victory of Hassan Rowhani, a moderate who had previously proposed better relations with the West.

headline: With Trois Mec, Ludo Lefebvre Has a Place to Call His Own
abstract: The Los Angeles restaurant embodies the argument that eating sensibilities are changing, prompting a desire for more cultivated dining.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Ludo Lefebvre was always the chef without a restaurant, though it did not seem to have hurt him any. For six years, he commandeered empty spaces across Los Angeles as stages for the pop-up restaurants he called LudoBites, quick runs that lasted a few weeks or months. He built a base of intensely loyal fans who stormed the reservation line at the first whisper of the next LudoBites incarnation.

headline: A Marathon Meant for the Ears, Not the Feet
abstract: New-music acts dominated the annual Bang on a Can marathon in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Stroller-pushing parents, tourists and harried traders in search of coffee were not to be seen at this year’s Bang on a Can marathon. Construction in the World Financial Center’s Winter Garden forced this annual new-music extravaganza to decamp on Sunday to the Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University, where there was none of the random walk-through business that has added touches of surrealism to the proceedings at the Winter Garden.

headline: Prom Memories at Halston Heritage
abstract: At its new Madison Avenue shop, Halston Heritage features dresses with daring silhouettes and jewel tones.
lead_paragraph: SENIOR PROM, the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria, 1990. The song of the night is Madonna’s “Vogue”; chicken paillard with capers is congealing on the plates; and the alpha girls of the class have chosen black Betsey Johnson dresses that barely cover their crotches.

headline: A Barrel of Trouble
abstract: A washed-up monkey, sex in a morgue, a severed arm at the end of a fishhook and other Carl Hiaasen capers make “Bad Monkey” his funniest novel in almost a decade.
lead_paragraph: At the start of Carl Hiaasen’s latest comedic marvel, a visitor fishing near Key West hooks a severed human arm. There is no time for this to register as grisly. A page later the captain of the fishing boat tells the freaked-out tourist reassuringly, “Well, son, we’re in the memory-making business.” You can’t argue with that.

headline: Till Death (or Duets) Do Them Part
abstract: Chris Yon and Taryn Griggs dance like a couple from another planet in their comedic performance “The Very Unlikeliness (I’m going to KILL you)” at La MaMa Moves!, a festival at that theater.
lead_paragraph: In 2008 the dancers Chris Yon and Taryn Griggs moved from New York to Minneapolis. On Friday night they returned to New York to perform Mr. Yon’s piece “The Very Unlikeliness (I’m going to KILL you)” at the Club at La MaMa for the La MaMa Moves! festival. It was good to have these droll comedians back.

headline: Dwarf Galaxy May Be Answer to Predictions
abstract: Known as Segue 2, the galaxy consists of just 1,000 stars.
lead_paragraph: A dim, lightweight galaxy on the outskirts of the Milky Way may be the smallest in the known universe, astronomers say.

headline: After Hours | A Performance Artist’s Heartfelt New Persona
abstract: With his new song cycle and residency, the cabaret extraordinaire John Kelly dispenses with elaborate theatrics to establish a more intimate connection with the audience.
lead_paragraph: Over his 30-year career, the performer John Kelly has used his lean frame and remarkable falsetto-to-baritone voice to conjure a panoply of classical and pop personas, including the Mona Lisa, Caravaggio, Egon Schiele and, most famously, Joni Mitchell. He has often done so through highly theatrical shows with costumes, choreography and elaborate visuals. But last night, Kelly unveiled a new cycle of covers, “Rebel Songs,” in the straightforward dinner-cabaret setting of the NoHo performance venue Joe’s Pub. (He’ll be back June 30, July 7 and July 14.) Save a few flourishes like glittery blue eye shadow, a bespoke black leather kilt and shiny foil hats for his musicians, Kelly took advantage of the format to remind the audience that his knack for setting a mood has more to do with a stray hand gesture, an odd stance or an unexpected modulation in vocal color than with any arty production wizardry.

headline: Outside Review of Clinical Data Finds a Spinal Treatment’s Benefit Overstated
abstract: Independent reviews of clinical trial data concluded that Infuse, a bioengineered bone product, was not significantly better than a traditional bone graft, and that it might pose risks.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have long argued that a heralded spinal treatment sold by the nation’s largest device maker, Medtronic, was no better than an older one and possibly more risky. Now with the company’s help, they have the proof.

abstract: In search of the open road, consider these stunning shoreline drives.
lead_paragraph: Winter and spring were tumultuous, weather-wise. Across much of the country, many have been battling blizzards, twisters, hurricanes and the occasional flash flood.

lead_paragraph: NO place is without international travelers, so the routine at global travel security and emergency response companies that keep an eye on the world is never actually routine.

headline: Rickets Plagued Children of the Medicis
abstract: The bone disease, resulting from vitamin D deficiency and typically associated with the inferior diet and living conditions of the poor, may have been a consequence of the family’s vast wealth.
lead_paragraph: The rich are different from you and me, F. Scott Fitzgerald once wrote. But according to a new study in The International Journal of Osteoarchaeology, children of the Medicis, one of history’s wealthiest families, may have had rickets, a disease typically associated with the inferior diet and cramped living conditions of the poor. What’s more, the family’s wealth may have been to blame.

headline: In Bullies’ Hands, Nuts or Milk May Be a Weapon
abstract: A survey of children with food allergies showed that a third of them reported being bullied with threatening behavior.
lead_paragraph: Any difference can set schoolchildren apart from their peers and potentially make them a target for bullying. But a severe food allergy is a unique vulnerability: It takes only one lunch or cupcake birthday party for other children to know which classmates cannot eat nuts, eggs, milk or even a trace of wheat. It can take longer for them to grasp how frightening it is to live with a life-threatening allergy.

lead_paragraph: 3OH!3

headline: Gathering Many Identities on the Road, Hip-Hop Returns to Its Roots
abstract: An international hip-hop celebration called “Breakin’ Convention” came to the Apollo Theater in Harlem for the first time.
lead_paragraph: New York may be the birthplace of hip-hop, but London has now become one of hip-hop’s proudest homes. Sadler’s Wells Theater in London has been running an international hip-hop celebration called “Breakin’ Convention” since 2004, and for the first time, from Thursday through Sunday, this festival came to the Apollo Theater in Harlem as a co-production. The pun in the title is delicious. As the enthusiastic British D.J. Jonzi D explained on Saturday evening to the audience, this festival, like the art form itself, breaks conventions simply by presenting hip-hop from behind a proscenium arch. The history of Harlem and the Apollo, so central to the history of many black musical and dance styles, makes the wordplay all the more resonant.

headline: Undoing a Skyscraper
abstract: Japanese companies have developed cleaner and quieter techniques to take down high-rises.

headline: A 5-4 Ruling, One of Three, Limits Silence’s Protection
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Self-Incrimination', 'Fifth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Privacy', 'Discrimination', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The cases involved a criminal suspect’s right to remain silent, judges’ discretion in sentencing, and a lawsuit against trial lawyers over privacy concerns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court issued three 5-to-4 decisions on Monday. One limited a criminal suspect’s right to remain silent before being taken into custody. Another granted additional discretion to judges in sentencing. The third allowed a lawsuit against trial lawyers who had solicited clients using information from motor vehicle departments to move forward. The justices also agreed to hear a case on fair-housing laws.

headline: Q. and A.: Is Congress Broken?
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Robert G. Kaiser, a veteran Washington Post reporter and author, explains how the Dodd-Frank bill inspired his pessimism about Congress’s ability to address big problems.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 18, 2008, with the nation on the precipice of a financial crisis, Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson told House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to gather a bipartisan group of lawmakers that very day. Congress quickly passed the bailout, but it was not until July 2010 that President Obama signed a sweeping overhaul of the financial system meant to prevent another Great Recession.

lead_paragraph: Brian Cashman, the Yankees’ general manager, did not have much to be cheerful about when he spoke to reporters on a conference call Monday afternoon. His team is in a rut, losing 6 of 10 games on their recent West Coast trip, and medical issues continue to hound his team.

headline: How Cyberwarfare and Drones Have Revolutionized Warfare
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Aircraft Carriers', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Defense Contracts', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Robots and Robotics']
abstract: Tim Hsia and Jared Sperli write that the next few decades will be dominated by advancements in software and hardware (cyber and robotics, including drones) just as the last decade was dominated by counterinsurgency.
lead_paragraph: Since World War II there have been many advances in military weaponry, communications and technology. In early May 1942, naval forces from Imperial Japan and the allied forces of Australia and the United States fought in the Battle of the Coral Sea. That engagement was the first battle in which naval ships did not shoot upon or even see the opposing force. Aircraft carriers directly engaged one another using aircraft, with their long-distance reach, as their sole offensive weaponry. This new type of warfare, the carrier versus carrier, was an inevitable escalation of the air, radio and radar technology of the day. It was viewed as a revolution in military affairs.

headline: The Home-Cooked Challenge: Addicted to Snack Food, Trying to Change
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Families and Family Life', 'Obesity', 'Parenting', 'Snack Foods']
abstract: Why try to cut processed foods from my family’s diet for a week (or more)? Because we eat too many pre-packaged cookies, chips and snacks.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, I pulled the junk-food bin, took the Pop-Tarts out of the bread drawer and cleared off the cracker and cookie shelf, and our week without prepared foods began.

keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Government Employees']

lead_paragraph: New York City has agreed to settle a federal lawsuit that accused it of improperly withholding some pension benefits from police officers who were called to active military service after Sept. 11, 2001, newly filed court papers show.

headline: Celebrating a Poet of 3 Dimensions
abstract: A new exhibition of Le Corbusier’s work at the Museum of Modern Art tackles the meshing of his buildings with landscape.
lead_paragraph: “Le Corbusier: An Atlas of Modern Landscapes,” newly installed at the Museum of Modern Art, is really two exhibitions. It’s on the one hand a sprawling introduction to the life and work of this Swiss-born giant, on a scale that MoMA, hard though it may be to believe, has never previously organized. A little pruning might have helped. Hypnotic videos sometimes get noisy, distractingly so. But as an omnibus, long overdue, the show is riveting, fun, a landmark.

headline: Once Tallest Standing, Then the Tallest to Come Down
abstract: While it’s no longer a silhouette on the New York skyline, the Singer Building holds the record for tallest building to ever be peacefully demolished.
lead_paragraph: When it was opened to the public in 1908, the Singer Building at 149 Broadway held the record, however briefly, as the tallest skyscraper in the world. Sixty years later, it had the honor of setting a more enduring record – as the world’s largest skyscraper ever to be peacefully demolished.

headline: Yoga, Tents, Pulled Pork and Music That Lingers
abstract: With its 121 shows of many stripes, not counting the sets on the lesser stages, the four-day Bonnaroo music festival had something for everyone.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, Tenn. — My Bonnaroo this year probably wasn’t like anybody else’s. It couldn’t have been: it sprawled without a clear stylistic center. There were 121 shows of many stripes in four days, not counting the sets on the lesser stages, which would add up to about the same number. Vinyasa sessions, local pulled pork, neurotic comedians talking death and colonics. Films and videos, singalongs, dance-alongs. A campground world with solar-powered solo-electric guitar jams, food trucks, illicit this and that. A workshop called “Build a hula hoop! Appalachian Flow Arts.” A 530-acre principality of all-over-the-place-ness.

headline: Bright-Eyed and Bushy-Tailed, With a Serious Streak, on CNN
abstract: “New Day,” CNN’s revamped morning show, is trying to set itself apart by offering a less frivolous alternative to “Today” and “Good Morning America.”
lead_paragraph: There is already way too much happy talk on morning television. So it’s a little worrisome that on the Monday premiere of CNN’s revamped morning show, “New Day,” Chris Cuomo responded to a report on the Supreme Court by his co-anchor, Kate Bolduan, by saying: “My mom says my tie is not on straight. How does it look? Look all right? Is it better now? All right, Mom, better?”

Those of us who did were rewarded with one of the cooler science videos in recent memory, in which aforementioned animals did indeed vanish when they ducked behind aforementioned cloak, which was actually made of a special glass invention. Read on for details.

headline: Five New Musicals Top $1 Million at Box Office After Tony Awards
abstract: The Tony winners “Kinky Boots, “Matilda the Musical” and “Pippin” had their best weeks at the box office so far.
lead_paragraph: In its first week of performances after winning the Tony Award for best musical, “Kinky Boots” had its best run yet at the box office, grossing $1,474,349 through last weekend. Two other Tony winners, “Matilda the Musical” and “Pippin,” also had their strongest weeks so far, as did the audience favorite “Motown: The Musical,” which came up empty-handed at the Tonys ceremony on June 9.

headline: Large Truck Bomb Reported to Kill 60 Syrian Troops
abstract: The bombing near the northern city of Aleppo appeared to be part of an effort by the Syrian insurgency to regain momentum after a series of defeats.

The bombing near the city of Aleppo in northern Syria was said to have killed as many as 60 soldiers.

headline: Nurse Climbing to the Top in Hockey After Selecting a Different Path
abstract: Though Darnell Nurse’s family gravitated to football and basketball, he was encouraged to play hockey because his parents thought it was safer than football. Now, he is expected to be selected in the first round of the N.H.L. draft.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Darnell Nurse is a big, tough 18-year-old defenseman and a top prospect in the coming N.H.L. draft, but his family gravitated to other sports. His father was a professional football player, and his uncle is Donovan McNabb. Nurse’s mother, older sister and aunt played college basketball, and his younger sister is on a Canadian national basketball team.

headline: 60 Years Later, Germany Recalls Its Anti-Soviet Revolt
abstract: Germany commemorated the 60th anniversary of an uprising by East Germans against Soviet rule, seeking a higher pedestal for the little-known revolt.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German president recalls it as an electrifying moment. One of Berlin’s most resplendent avenues is named simply the “Street of June 17” in remembrance. But the heady, short-lived uprising by hundreds of thousands of East Germans 60 years ago on Monday has never lived in history as the more famous anti-Communist revolts that followed — in Hungary and Poland in 1956, in Prague in 1968 and in Poland again in 1980-81.

headline: Maryland: Rape Inquiry at Naval Academy Advances
abstract: As many as three football players at the United States Naval Academy may soon face criminal charges in the case of the alleged serial sexual assault of a female midshipman in 2012.
lead_paragraph: As many as three football players at the United States Naval Academy, in Annapolis, may soon face criminal charges in the case of the alleged serial sexual assault of a female midshipman in 2012. Vice Adm. Michael Miller, the superintendent of the academy, has decided to send the case to Article 32 proceedings, the military equivalent of a grand jury. The decision followed an investigation by the Naval Criminal Investigative Service, the academy said in a statement Monday. The exact number of football players who will face the proceedings has not yet been released, but officials previously said three players were under investigation. The investigation was dropped last year before it was reopened early in 2013.

headline: Maryland: Manning Trial Looks at Address Disclosures
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Prosecutors laid the groundwork for trying to prove that Pfc. Bradley Manning gave WikiLeaks the e-mail addresses of more than 70,000 troops deployed in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors laid the groundwork on Monday for trying to prove that Pfc. Bradley Manning gave WikiLeaks the e-mail addresses of more than 70,000 troops deployed in Iraq, a charge to which he has pleaded not guilty. As Private Manning’s trial at Fort Meade entered its third week, witnesses described how an individual could gain access to the internal directory of contact information for military personnel and how enemies could use that list against the United States. Defense lawyers countered that downloading the e-mail addresses of fellow military personnel was not against the rules. Evidence indicating that Private Manning released the e-mail addresses could damage his image as a good-intentioned whistle-blower who carefully selected which documents to release.

The difference is that the responses this time, rather than being combative or angry, are reflective, generous, kind, eloquent and, more than occasionally, wise.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
