lead_paragraph: 6 P.M. (Cinemax) SAFE HOUSE (2012) Tobin Frost (Denzel Washington, above), a rogue superspy formerly with the Central Intelligence Agency and called “the black Dorian Gray,” is held for debriefing in a Cape Town safe house by an untested rookie, Matt Weston (Ryan Reynolds), after dodging a gun-toting gang and slipping into the American Embassy in this thriller about the very bad things that operatives sometimes do in the name of country and company. Despite cutting among as many as four action scenes at a time, the director, Daniel Espinosa, “maintains a visually coherent, narratively rational sense of time and space, no matter how fast the story shifts about, which it does with increasing speed when that same heavily armed horde that had been chasing Frost breaches the safe house, slaughtering most of the American operatives and sending Frost and Weston running,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “ ‘Safe House’ is essentially and very effectively a rollicking smash-and-crash chase movie that happens to be surprisingly well acted.”

headline: What Paintbrush Makers Know About How to Beat China
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Change your business all the time. Or don’t ever change a thing.
lead_paragraph: As I toured Israel Kirschner’s Bronx paintbrush factory earlier this month, I couldn’t stop feeling amazed that it was still in business. Many days, Kirschner feels the same way. The charming, energetic 69-year-old joked about his ancient equipment (“That could be 100 years old,” he said of a bristle-cleaning machine); his two least-committed employees, his son and daughter (“They come late, they leave early”); and how his business has been increasingly undercut by Chinese manufacturers. After introducing me to his star brush maker, Fermin Gil, a Mexican immigrant who “can just see” when a brush isn’t right, Kirschner handed me a one-inch boar-bristle brush with a wooden handle. A Chinese manufacturer sells it for 30 cents. If he made it himself, he told me, it would cost significantly more.

The declining sun flamed and died around us, a vivid furnace with bars of scarlet spread behind Mount Everest, and the tropic night dashed upon us.” So began an article on the front page of The New York Times in 1930, datelined Jonsong Base Camp. And if time and technology have made the Himalayas more accessible geographically, much else about this dispatch — the breathless prose, the heraldic portraiture — seems more distant and mysterious with each passing year.

headline: A Museum Named Cash
abstract: The Johnny Cash Museum in Nashville includes his guitar, costumes, and, of course, a lot of music.
lead_paragraph: Nashville might be home to members of the Kings of Leon and Jack White, but the  country music scene dominates tourist attractions here, newly expanded with the Johnny Cash Museum.Keeping the memory and music of the Man in Black alive, the 6,500-square-foot downtown museum houses artifacts ranging from his boyhood marbles and high school yearbooks to his custom Gibson J200 guitar, costumes and a reassembled stone wall from his Hendersonville, Tenn., home.

headline: Greeting the Seasons, in Due Time
abstract: At Kajitsu, the chef Ryota Ueshima coaxes a surprising variety of flavors out of meals that Westerners would call vegan.
lead_paragraph: When I eat at Kajitsu, a restaurant that practices an animal-free cooking tradition called shojin ryori, I am never shocked to find that I don’t miss meat or fish. When the Japanese have been working on an idea for hundreds of years, they tend to figure out a few things. To express wonder that Kajitsu’s chef, Ryota Ueshima, can fashion a delicious multicourse meal out of nothing but plants and mushrooms is like being astonished when a French baker makes dessert from flour, butter, sugar and eggs.

headline: Even Pan Chimes In at Early Music Festival
abstract: The biennial Boston Early Music Festival last week drew on home-grown and international talent.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — What most struck a visitor to the biennial Boston Early Music Festival last week, after many years away, was the strength of the home team. It used to be that most star attractions came from abroad, and many still do, this year including Hespèrion XXI, led by that brightest of stars, Jordi Savall.

headline: Gunman Boasted of Killing Man He Taunted With Antigay Slurs, the Police Say
abstract: An indictment charged Elliot Morales with murder as a hate crime in the death of a man whom he allegedly taunted with antigay slurs before shooting him in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: As he lay sprawled on a Greenwich Village street, held down by several police officers who believed that he had just fatally shot a man blocks away, Elliot Morales boasted of the killing, according to the police.

headline: Restaurant Report: Rustic Canyon in Santa Monica
abstract: This Southern California seasonal spot features a menu driven by local ingredients and, as of January, a chef who starred in Napa.
lead_paragraph: At 9:30 on a Wednesday night, it was three deep at the bar at Rustic Canyon, a wine bar and restaurant in Santa Monica. The dining room was buzzing; outside, bundled diners braved the chilly late-winter air. In spite of his status as a cult figure among chefs and epicures, Jeremy Fox, who took over the kitchen in January, claims no credit for the crowds. “The place is really busy and was long before I got here,” he said.

headline: One-Two Punch Looks Dominant as the Mets Sweep
abstract: Mets fans got a promising glimpse of the future as their two young pitching stars, Matt Harvey and Zack Wheeler, defeated the Braves.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — It feels as if their names have been entwined for ages — by coaches and team officials, by columnists and television hosts, by fans and former players — but not until Tuesday did Matt Harvey and Zack Wheeler come together on the same pitching staff.

headline: Three’s a Trend | The Sailor Look Floods Resort
abstract: The nautical theme inspired pieces in the collections of Marc Jacobs, Chloé and Valentino.
lead_paragraph: Gone are the days of referring to the pre-spring collections as “cruise.” Yet several resort collections this season seemed high-seas-ready. Interpretations of the United States Navy uniform were both indirect (a very casual denim ensemble at Valentino) and literal (a boxy tunic with jumper flaps at Marc Jacobs, a nautical sweater at Chloé).

headline: Obama and Putin on the Stage
abstract: Footage from President Obama’s meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday evening.
lead_paragraph: Footage from President Obama’s meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday evening.

headline: Obama and Putin Signal a More Businesslike Path
abstract: At a joint appearance on the sidelines of the Group of 8 meeting, there was tension but also common ground, to the chagrin of human rights advocates.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — At times during their 12-minute joint appearance on Monday evening, Barack Obama and Vladimir V. Putin seemed locked in a frowning contest, their fingers laced tensely in their laps, eyes narrowed, lips pressed tightly together — especially when they noted their continuing disagreement about Syria.

headline: Money and Morals Sharing the Stage With Shakespeare
abstract: “What Are We Worth? Shakespeare, Money and Morals” was billed as a town hall discussion at the Delacorte Theater.
lead_paragraph: The connection between Shakespeare and nuclear waste might seem tenuous, but Michael J. Sandel, the political philosopher, did his utmost to unite the two at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park on Monday night, assisted by readings given by the likes of Alan Alda, Vanessa Redgrave, Christine Baranski and Matt Damon.

headline: Debut of ‘New Day’ Fails to Increase CNN’s Morning Audience
abstract: On its first day, the audience for the revamped show was smaller than that for the previous show.
lead_paragraph: CNN introduced its new morning program, “New Day,” with a bit of fanfare Monday, and won mostly positive reviews for the revamping of the format and the new cast of anchors.

headline: Brazil Cement Giant Is Said to Cancel Planned I.P.O.
abstract: Brazil’s largest cement producer, Votorantim Cimentos, was expected to raise as much as $4.7 billion in what would have been one of the largest I.P.O.’s globally in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Brazil’s largest cement producer, Votorantim Cimentos, canceled its multibillion-dollar initial public offering on Tuesday amid worsening market conditions, a person closely involved with the operation said.

headline: Front Burner
abstract: This week, Chez Panisse reopens; a new tequila with a kick and an online course for would-be bartenders.
lead_paragraph: To Indulge: Just Enough of a Good Thing

headline: Making the Case for a Rise in Inflation
abstract: Some economists are arguing for inflation above the long-favored 2 percent limit, as a way to jump-start the economy.
lead_paragraph: I was in Brazil in the early 1990s, when annual inflation topped 2,000 percent and Brazilians spent their entire paychecks as soon as they got them, buying a month’s worth of food and other supplies before their money lost most of its value. When I moved there a few years later, inflation had been “tamed” to some 16 percent. But you couldn’t buy oranges at the supermarket in packages of less than 20 pounds.

headline: Dispute Ends as Chrysler Agrees to Fix Older Jeeps
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The automaker and  National Highway Traffic Safety Administration resolved their differences, and Chrysler will inspect the cars for possible defects.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — A tense standoff between Chrysler and federal regulators over the safety of millions of Jeep sport utility vehicles was resolved in one last high-level phone call.

headline: A Famed Playwright as Seducer and Thief
abstract: In Sara Farrington’s “Requiem for Black Marie,” it’s Bertolt Brecht’s women who do all the heavy lifting of authorship.
lead_paragraph: Brecht the exploiter: That’s the topic of Sara Farrington’s “Requiem for Black Marie,” an Incubator Arts Project production that considers the playwright as manipulative oaf and the women who love him.

headline: I.B.M. Inflates Its Cloud
abstract: I.B.M. announces it has 100 cloud computing offerings and is targeting executives in areas like marketing and human resources. It shows that the company is changing its sales approach around the public cloud. That may hit hardware sales, but it is a sign of the times.
lead_paragraph: For all the money it has spent, you don’t hear about I.B.M. as a powerhouse of cloud computing-based services. Cloud computing is still a tiny fraction of the company’s $106 billion in annual revenue. Still, I.B.M. has spent more than $4 billion acquiring cloud computing-based services in the last few years, and recently bought a big public cloud.

headline: One Last Pass Through the 31st Century (for Now)
abstract: The animated “Futurama” begins its final season on Wednesday on Comedy Central.
lead_paragraph: Can a show that’s hung around for 14 years — during which it’s been nominated for the animated-program Emmy seven times and won twice — be underappreciated? Did you know that “Futurama” is starting its last batch of episodes on Wednesday night? Case closed.

headline: Humanities Committee Sounds an Alarm
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Humanities', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A report to Congress on the state of the humanities defends a field that is falling out of favor on campuses.
lead_paragraph: A new national corps of “master teachers” trained in the humanities and social sciences and increased support for research in “endangered” liberal arts subjects are among the recommendations of a major report to be delivered on Capitol Hill on Wednesday.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Airbnb Economy, and Netflix-Verizon Slowdown
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Tuesday’s selections include a survey that says staying overnight with Airbnb is cheaper than getting a hotel room, and slow streaming for Netflix movies on Verizon Internet connections.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Christie’s London Auction Brings Modest Art and Modest Sales
abstract: Kandinsky’s “Studie ze Improvisation 3’’ and Modgiliani’s 1916 portrait of the art dealer Paul Guillaume topped the auction.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – A colorful canvas painted by Wassily Kandinsky in 1909 brought $21.1 million at Christie’s here on Tuesday night. In 2008 the same painting brought $16.8 million at a New York auction.

headline: A.M.A. Recognizes Obesity as a Disease
abstract: The decision by the American Medical Association could have implications for health care companies and the pharmaceutical industry.
lead_paragraph: The American Medical Association has officially recognized obesity as a disease, a move that could induce physicians to pay more attention to the condition and spur more insurers to pay for treatments.

headline: Russian Space Center in Kazakhstan Counts Down Its Days of Glory
abstract: Baikonur, Kazakhstan, is set to be replaced as the Russian space launching center, and ethnic tensions and economic challenges are already creeping into the city.
lead_paragraph: BAIKONUR, Kazakhstan — On a sultry desert evening, as bats fluttered about this town’s riverfront park, a man emerged from a reedy marsh carrying a bundle of grass tied with twine.

headline: A Kazakh Spaceport Slowly Declines
abstract: Baikonur, in remote southwestern Kazakhstan, was once the pride of the Soviet Union. Today, nomadic herders from the nearby steppe are moving into abandoned buildings.
lead_paragraph: Baikonur, in remote southwestern Kazakhstan, was once the pride of the Soviet Union. Today, nomadic herders from the nearby steppe are moving into abandoned buildings.

headline: Google Asks Secret Court for Permission to Publish National Security Request Data
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Google escalated its pressure on the government to permit it to publish more detailed data about the requests it receives for the information of foreign users.
lead_paragraph: Google on Tuesday filed a motion with the secret Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, asking permission to publish data on national security requests that were made to it and authorized by the court.

headline: Venus Williams Will Skip Wimbledon
abstract: Williams, who has struggled with back problems and fatigue, announced her withdrawal on Tuesday, making this year’s Wimbledon the first one without her since she made her debut.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — The Wimbledon Championships this year will be without one of its fixtures of the past 16: Venus Williams.

lead_paragraph: A study of 17 years’ worth of F.B.I. reports on shootings by its own agents.

headline: Dish Network Backs Off Bid to Buy Sprint
abstract: Dish Network, a pay TV provider, said that because of new conditions imposed by Sprint Nextel, it would focus on acquiring a stake in Clearwire, a smaller competitor.
lead_paragraph: Dish Network said on Tuesday that it would not submit a new takeover bid for Sprint Nextel ahead of a deadline imposed by the company and would instead focus on its bid for a stake in Clearwire, a smaller wireless operator. That appeared to leave Sprint free to complete the sale of a majority stake to SoftBank of Japan for $21.6 billion.

headline: F.B.I. Shooting Incident Reviews, 1993-2011
abstract: A collection of reports from internal panels at the Federal Bureau of Investigation looking into shootings by F.B.I. agents.
lead_paragraph: A collection of reports from internal panels at the Federal Bureau of Investigation looking into shootings by F.B.I. agents.

abstract: Johnson Gold, a magazine editor, said he draws style inspiration from the unbound style of London’s East End.
lead_paragraph: Johnson Gold, a magazine editor, said he draws style inspiration from the unbound style of London’s East End.

headline: Tech Moves to the Background as Design Becomes Foremost
abstract: As the speed of chips and the size of screens move into the background, design is becoming part of mainstream discussions about gadgets.
lead_paragraph: In the last few decades, the computing industry has passed through several different eras. In the ’90s, the big tech companies were in a race for faster and more powerful computers. Then in the 2000s, the industry moved to mobile in a quest for slimmer phones with brighter screens.

abstract: Accessories highlights from the spring 2014 runways in London.
lead_paragraph: Accessories highlights from the spring 2014 runways in London.

headline: British Commission Calls for New Laws to Prosecute Bankers for Fraud
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: As part of a 600-page report, the British parliamentary commission on banking standards is urging new laws that would make it a criminal offense to recklessly mismanage local financial institutions.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – British lawmakers are calling for criminal prosecutions of senior bankers who cause the collapse of financial institutions, as Parliament is set to undertake a major overhaul of the country’s banking sector.

headline: It’s General Sherman’s Time to Shine, but Not Too Much
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: The deteriorating equestrian statue of Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman in Grand Army Plaza on Fifth Avenue is about to receive a new coating of 23.75-karat gold leaf.
lead_paragraph: General Sherman, still marching through Georgia these many years later, has completely lost his luster.

headline: I.M.F. Courses Offered Online
abstract: The International Monetary Fund and edX have announced a collaboration to offer the fund’s training courses in macroeconomics and finance on the edX platform.
lead_paragraph: The International Monetary Fund and edX, a nonprofit online venture started by Harvard and M.I.T., have announced a collaboration to offer the fund’s training courses in macroeconomics and finance on the edX platform. Until now, edX has worked only with universities. The first two online courses will be offered to small groups of government officials in the coming months, and then will be opened to the public in 2014. The I.M.F. offers policy-oriented courses to central bank, finance and other officials from its 188 member countries, but will use edX to expand its reach.

headline: In Partisan Vote, House Approves Ban on Abortions After 22 Weeks
abstract: The House of Representatives approved a bill that would ban abortions after 22 weeks of pregnancy in a largely symbolic vote.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives on Tuesday approved the most restrictive ban on abortion considered by Congress in a decade, a largely symbolic vote that laid bare the deep ideological differences between Democrats and Republicans.

headline: Irv Gordon has Driven Nearly 3 Million Miles in his 1966 Volvo 1800S
abstract: When he bought his 1966 Volvo 1800S new, Irv Gordon didn’t think about it too much. But after nearly 50 years and 3 million miles behind the wheel of the same car, Mr. Gordon has formed a special bond with it.
lead_paragraph: Irv Gordon’s 1966 Volvo 1800S has already made the Guinness Book of World Records twice; once for eclipsing all other cars on the road when it hit 1.69 million miles in 1998, and again in 2002, when the the car’s odometer rolled past 2 million miles. Mr. Gordon, a retired science teacher from Patchogue, N.Y., reached 2.9 million miles in the car this month, and is now about 30,000 miles shy of 3 million miles, and a third nod from Guinness.

headline: Ex-Senator Feingold Chosen as Special Envoy to African Region
abstract: In choosing Russ Feingold, Secretary of State John Kerry moved to raise the profile of the Great Lakes region of Africa, which has been torn by conflict but overshadowed by other crises.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry on Tuesday selected a former Senate colleague, Russ Feingold, to serve as a special envoy to the Great Lakes region of Africa, promising to raise the profile of a region torn by conflict and yet largely overshadowed in American foreign policy by other global crises.

headline: Labels Don’t Fit Duncan, but Championship Rings Do
abstract: For years there have been questions about Tim Duncan’s true position with the Spurs, but it’s safe to say that he would not have objected to being called a point guard if that would have assured him the fifth championship ring of his career.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It is not an issue that should keep him, or anyone, up much later than an N.B.A. finals game ends, but someday Tim Duncan is going to be remembered as the greatest power forward in league history — or one of its most distinguished centers.

headline: De Blasio Offers Ideas in Policy Book for Election
keywords: ['Elections, Mayors', 'Education (K-12)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Buses', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: To make the case that he should be elected mayor of New York City, in the 69-page document, Bill de Blasio details proposals in 12 areas while summarizing his record as public advocate.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio wants to ensure that all students are reading at grade level by the third grade, and to develop at least 100 community schools modeled after the Harlem Children’s Zone.

headline: Irish Lawmakers Expected to Approve Limited Abortion
abstract: The legislation would allow terminations in cases when there is a real and substantial risk to the life of the mother, including the threat of suicide, and details the circumstances.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The Irish Parliament is expected to legalize limited abortion before its summer break after the publication of final government proposals that would allow terminations in cases when there is a real and substantial risk to the life of the mother, including the threat of suicide.

headline: The Home-Cooked Challenge: Taking Time Now to Save Time Later
abstract: I won’t pretend that avoiding processed foods doesn’t take time. It is not very hard to put together fruit, plain yogurt and granola. It is, however, even less hard to tear open a wrapper.
lead_paragraph: I will not pretend that cooking fresh foods and avoiding the easy, go-to snacks does not take time.

headline: Reception for Obama Is More Sober Than in 2008
abstract: The president’s arrival in Berlin is being greeted with far less fanfare than when he gave a speech as a candidate in 2008.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The last time President Obama paid a visit here, as a candidate in 2008, he was cheered on by 200,000 Germans eager to see the back of George W. Bush and, as one member of that crowd recalled Tuesday, “full of wholly unrealistic expectations of what kind of miracles Obama could work.”

headline: New Effort to Quantify ‘Social Cost’ of Pollution
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'United States Economy', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The Obama administration is making a second attempt to systematically account for the dollar damage from greenhouse gas pollution, even with no consensus on how to forestall global warming or whether to do so.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is making a second attempt to systematically account for the dollar damage from greenhouse gas pollution, even with no consensus on how to forestall global warming or whether to do so.

headline: An Inspiring Limp Into Playoff Lore
abstract: Gregory Campbell, on crutches, rejoined the Bruins before Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals, shrugging off praise for finishing a shift despite a broken leg in the previous round.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — If the Boston Bruins win the Stanley Cup, Gregory Campbell’s gallant shift on a broken leg may be a defining moment.

headline: A Place to Be Seen (and Heard) in Upper Manhattan
abstract: The popularity of La Marina restaurant has continued to grow since it opened, but so have the complaints from neighbors unhappy with the noise and traffic.
lead_paragraph: With the lights of the George Washington Bridge painting the Hudson River and a half-moon hanging over the Palisades, La Marina felt like the place to be last Saturday night. At the year-old restaurant in Fort Washington Park, at the end of Dyckman Street in Upper Manhattan, two D.J.’s, working opposite ends of the property, cranked up the volume. Patrons ordered bottles of liquor, starting at $130 for rum and rising to $12,000 for a methuselah of Champagne, equal to five bottles, to secure a table on the terrace. Dancers let loose on the “beach,” a sand-covered strip flanked with four-poster beds draped in flowing white fabric.

headline: Less ‘Rambo’ Seen in New U.S. Military Culture

abstract: Maj. Gen. Bennet Sacolick said that changes in the armed services had led to opening front-line combat positions to women.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “The days of Rambo are over,” the two-star general in charge of personnel policy for Special Operations Command said on Tuesday in explaining the changes in military culture that led to opening front-line combat positions to women.

headline: Remember, Mattingly Played for the Boss
abstract: As a Yankees player, Don Mattingly saw firsthand the pressure of performing for George Steinbrenner, a pressure not unlike what he faces now as the Dodgers’ manager.
lead_paragraph: Don Mattingly learned about the weight of expectations while playing for George Steinbrenner during the bad years. The Yankees won a lot of games in the 1980s, but not a single division title with Mattingly. Yet because of the way he played, he was beloved, more than many others in Monument Park.

headline: Islamists Press Blasphemy Cases in a New Egypt
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: The number of blasphemy cases, once rare in Egypt, has increased sharply as Islamists assert their new power in public life.
lead_paragraph: DEIR EL GABRAWI, Egypt — Egypt’s prosecutors have been flooded with blasphemy complaints since 2011 as Islamists exercising their new societal clout have pushed for prosecutions and courts have handed down steep fines and prison terms for insulting religion.

headline: Surviving the Next Gulf Oil Spill
abstract: A nickel of every dollar from the BP-oil-spill fines should be used to protect coastal marshes and wetlands to help the gulf survive the next oil spill.
lead_paragraph: FAIRHOPE, Ala. — DOWN here on the Gulf of Mexico, the air is heavy with expectation as we await the arrival of billions of dollars in fines from companies involved in the BP oil-well blowout, which spewed millions of gallons of oil into the gulf over three months in 2010.

headline: Fred T. Shen
abstract: Mr. Shen is a founder and the chairman of Shen Milsom & Wilke, a consulting and design firm.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Shen, 71, is a founder and the chairman of Shen Milsom & Wilke, a consulting and design firm. The company, which has 13 offices worldwide, specializes in the design of multimedia systems, information technology, medical equipment, building security and acoustics. Its current projects include the World Trade Center transportation hub.

headline: Lawmakers in Albany Should Stay Put
abstract: Public financing is at the top of the list of business not finished by New York’s lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: After another run of indictments and arrests of public officials, New York’s lawmakers are planning to leave Albany this week without doing anything about the scandals around them. The list of unattended priorities left for next year is long and shameful. And at the top is campaign finance reform — specifically a system of public financing that would encourage more candidates to run for office and give voters wider choices. It is hard to throw rascals out if there is nobody else on the ballot.

headline: Our Genes, Their Secrets
abstract: Why the Supreme Court’s ruling on gene patents is only a partial victory for DNA-data sharing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE Supreme Court’s unanimous ruling last Thursday, barring patents on human genes, was a wise and balanced decision that clears away a major barrier to innovation in the areas of biotechnology, drug development and medical diagnostics. But the decision is just a first step toward finding the right balance between protecting legitimate intellectual property and securing an open future for personalized medicine.

headline: How to End the Stalemate With Iran
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: America and Iran mustn’t be deluded by false perceptions. If both believe they have the upper hand in negotiations, there will be no nuclear deal.
lead_paragraph: THE stunning election of a pragmatic former Iranian nuclear negotiator, Hassan Rowhani, has offered the Obama administration a once-in-a-lifetime chance to end the atomic stalemate with Iran.

headline: Clues in the Search for a Sunken Ship, Lost in the 1600s
abstract: Experts hope that the search is over for the Griffin, a ship lost in Lake Michigan over 300 years ago that was commanded by a 17th-century French explorer.
lead_paragraph: OFF POVERTY ISLAND, Mich. — Ever since the Griffin, a 40-foot-long ship built by the French explorer René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle, in his quest to find the mouth of the Mississippi River, disappeared somewhere on the Great Lakes 333 years ago, people have been searching for its resting place.

headline: The Taliban Agree to Talk
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: While a public declaration of being interested in negotiating peace is a breakthrough of sorts, any real progress remains a long shot.
lead_paragraph: Update: The Afghan government on Wednesday rejected starting talks with the Taliban, saying it would not meet with the insurgents unless they lowered the profile of the Taliban’s political office in Doha, Qatar, which opened on Tuesday.  President Hamid Karzai also suspended talks on a bilateral security agreement with the United States that would allow American troops to stay after 2014, pointing to American influence in the opening of the Taliban office.

headline: Details on Spying, Not More Assurances
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Editorials']
abstract: President Obama promised transparency, and he can begin with the secret surveillance court.
lead_paragraph: Battered by weeks of criticism about surveillance abuses, President Obama has embarked on a reassurance offensive. The spy programs have been used narrowly, he said on PBS’s “Charlie Rose” program on Monday, and have been effective in stopping several terror plots.

headline: Proper Scrutiny for Drug Settlements
keywords: ['Generic Brands and Products', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission says pay-for-delay practices cost Americans billions annually in higher drug prices. The Supreme Court has given the government the power to ensure more market competition.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission has been battling for years to end a devious tactic used by some drug companies to pay competitors to delay putting cheaper generic versions of their brand-name drugs on the market. The tactic, known as pay-for-delay or reverse payments, results in higher costs for consumers.

headline: Postcard From Turkey
abstract: The protesters in Istanbul have a message for Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan: Butt out!
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Having witnessed the Egyptian uprising in Tahrir Square in Cairo in 2011, I was eager to compare it with the protests by Turkish youths here in Taksim Square in 2013. They are very different. The Egyptians wanted to oust President Hosni Mubarak. Theirs was an act of “revolution.” The Turks are engaged in an act of “revulsion.” They aren’t (yet) trying to throw out their democratically elected Islamist prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. What they’re doing is calling him out. Their message is simple: “Get out of our faces, stop choking our democracy and stop acting like such a pompous, overbearing, modern-day Sultan.”

headline: Three Expected to Plead Guilty in Scheme Involving City’s Payroll Project
abstract: The wife, mother and cousin of the lead defendant, Mark Mazer, were to enter pleas in a case involving more than $40 million in kickbacks.
lead_paragraph: Three defendants accused of helping to conceal kickbacks generated in a massive fraud scheme that involved CityTime, a troubled automated payroll project in New York City, are expected to plead guilty in Manhattan on Wednesday, federal prosecutors said in a new court filing.

headline: NASA’s New Class of Astronauts Gives Parity to Men and Women
abstract: The eight recruits were selected from 6,300 applicants and will start training at the Johnson Space Center in Houston in August.

headline: The Price of Loyalty in Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Alawite Muslims', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Members of the Alawite sect are caught between support for their own increasingly brutal leaders and a rebellion that may want to wipe them off the map.
lead_paragraph: The Damascus neighborhood known as Mezze 86 is a dense, dilapidated warren of narrow hillside streets adorned with posters bearing the face of Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad. The presidential palace is nearby, and the area is crawling with well-armed guards and soldiers. It is next to impossible to enter unless you are accompanied by government officials or well-known locals, almost all of them members of Assad’s Alawite sect. I drove there on a quiet Friday morning in May, and we were stopped several times at checkpoints by young soldiers who examined our documents carefully before waving us on. When we arrived at our destination, in a small parking lot hemmed in by cinder-block towers, I emerged from the car to the suspicious glares of several middle-aged men in fatigues. “They are not expecting foreigners here,” one of the men who accompanied me said. “The rebels are trying constantly to hit this place, because they know who lives here.” He pointed to a damaged roof not far away. “A mortar struck very close the other day. A lady was killed just above us, and another just below.”

abstract: Or is it better to be self-financed? Which of two data companies, financed differently, do you think is better positioned?
lead_paragraph: Steve Blank retired from serial entrepreneurship after working with eight start-ups, including E.piphany, a software company that he helped found and sold in 2005 for $329 million. Today he’s an associate professor in management science and engineering at Stanford University and co-author of “The Startup Owner’s Manual.” Mr. Blank is credited with helping to create the lean start-up movement, which holds that start-ups can be successful without large amounts of cash. As we considered the example posed in our just-published article contrasting the financing experiences of two data companies that went after roughly the same market at roughly the same time, GoodData (venture-backed) and RJMetrics (mostly self-financed), we asked Mr. Blank for his views on an age-old question.

It is either a magical storybook dream, breathlessly chronicled in supermarket magazines, or else, in those same pages a few years later, a train wreck of betrayal and heartbreak. Hollywood marriage, like so much else in modern celebrity culture, is both aspirational and cautionary.

When it came time to answer a German journalist’s question about Mr. Obama's failure to close the American prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, Chancellor Angela Merkel deftly told the president, “Du, glaube ich” — “You’re on, I think” — using the familiar form of the pronoun in German.

headline: Obama Readying Emissions Limits on Power Plants
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Coal', 'Global Warming', 'Clean Air Act', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Carbon Dioxide']
abstract: The move would be the most consequential climate policy step he could take and one sure to provoke legal challenges from Republicans and some industries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is preparing regulations limiting carbon dioxide emissions from existing power plants, senior officials said Wednesday. The move would be the most consequential climate policy step he could take and one likely to provoke legal challenges from Republicans and some industries.

headline: Father and Son Acquitted of Sex Trafficking Charges
abstract: Two men were convicted of promoting prostitution and of money laundering, but acquitted of more serious charges, which required proof of coercive behavior.
lead_paragraph: A novel attempt to use New York State’s sex trafficking law against a father and son from Pennsylvania ended with mixed results on Wednesday, as the men were convicted in Manhattan of promoting prostitution and of money laundering, but were acquitted of the more serious charges of sex trafficking.

headline: HPV Vaccine Is Credited in Fall of Teenagers’ Infection Rate
keywords: ['Human Papilloma Virus (HPV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Gardasil (Vaccine)', 'Cervarix (Vaccine)', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Cervical Cancer', 'Sexually Transmitted Diseases']
abstract: The prevalence of dangerous strains of the human papillomavirus, a principal cause of cervical cancer, has dropped by half in the last decade, officials say.
lead_paragraph: The prevalence of dangerous strains of the human papillomavirus — the most common sexually transmitted infection in the United States and a principal cause of cervical cancer — has dropped by half among teenage girls in recent years, a striking measure of success for a vaccine against the virus that was introduced only in 2006, federal health officials said on Wednesday.

headline: The Success of the HPV Vaccine
abstract: The Times’s Pam Belluck on how the HPV vaccine has helped drastically reduce the number of human papillomavirus cases among teenage girls.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Pam Belluck on how the HPV vaccine has helped drastically reduce the number of human papillomavirus cases among teenage girls.

headline: Google’s Shareholder Bulwark for the Future
abstract: The legal settlement over Class C shares, says the author, is a messy solution for a problem that need not exist in the first place.
lead_paragraph: Google shareholders are getting some modest future-proofing.

headline: Border Raids
abstract: Brooks and Collins review Rick Perry’s traveling salesman act.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, you travel so much that I’m never sure where you are when I’m conversing with you. Do you happen to currently be in any of the places where the governor of Texas, Rick Perry, is trying to steal jobs?

headline: Executive at Monsanto Wins Global Food Honor
abstract: Robert Fraley of Monsanto shares the prize with two other scientists prominent in the field of genetically modified crops.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to agriculture, the World Food Prize is the equivalent of the Oscars.

headline: An All-American Roadside Attraction in West Texas
abstract: Richard Phillips’s latest project, an art installation next to the highway in Marfa, marks the relaunch of the Playboy brand.
lead_paragraph: Over the next few months, motorists speeding through the West Texas desert on Highway 90, just outside the arts town of Marfa, will encounter an unexpected roadside attraction: a white neon Playboy logo hovering above a matte-black 1972 Dodge Charger perched at an 18-degree angle atop a concrete plinth. Playboy Marfa, as it’s being called, is the first in a series of art projects commissioned by Playboy’s new creative team of Neville Wakefield and Landis Smithers meant to reintroduce the brand for a younger generation. It’s the work of Richard Phillips — the artist best known for his hyper-realistic portraits of women, often in the mode of the old-school magazine pictorial — who was a natural fit for the brand, Smithers said. “I loved his idea of this glowing symbol in the middle of nowhere as we — Playboy — are emerging from this period of darkness.”

headline: A Homely Rodent May Hold Cancer-Fighting Clues
abstract: Naked mole rats produce a compound that appears to render them immune to cancer, and researchers say the discovery may lead to treatments for humans.
lead_paragraph: The laboratory of Vera Gorbunova and Andrei Seluanov, a husband-and-wife team of biologists at the University of Rochester, has the feel of a petting zoo. They maintain colonies of several species of rodents — some familiar, like mice and guinea pigs, and some much more exotic, like blind mole rats from Israel and naked mole rats from East Africa.

headline: Spurs Stick to the Plan, With Devastating Results
abstract: Gregg Popovich was second-guessed for removing Tim Duncan in the final 23 seconds of regulation in Game 6, but the move was consistent with his strategy.
lead_paragraph: For half of Game 6 of the N.B.A. finals Tuesday night, Tim Duncan of the San Antonio Spurs dominated more thoroughly than he had in any of his 27 previous finals games. Miami Heat defenders were powerless to dislodge him from his place on the low block and, once there, Duncan bullied and beguiled his opponents with quick turns and authoritative jump hooks. Duncan punctuated his 25-point, 8-rebound first half with a one-handed sledgehammer dunk off a no-look pass from Boris Diaw.

headline: Buyers Are Scarce for Quinn’s Memoir
abstract: Christine C. Quinn’s book, which was released on June 11, has sold only 100 copies.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers are not buying Christine C. Quinn’s story — at bookstores, anyway.

headline: From Jungle to Jungle Gym
abstract: In new books by Jennifer Lloyd, a kindergarten class lists the best things about school and a gorilla detective goes in search of stolen banana muffins.
lead_paragraph: Wiggling, giggling, running and jumping, a classroom of excited kindergartners gather in a circle at the feet of their teacher. It’s the last day of school; seen through a doorway, parents adjust their camera lenses and find their seats for the graduation ceremony. But as Mrs. Appleby, the children’s teacher, tells her students, “We still have time for one last guessing game.”

headline: Image of the Day: June 19
abstract: Devotees gather at the Kamakhya temple in Guwahati, Assam, for the Ambubachi festival which begins on Saturday.

headline: Militants Attack U.N. Compound in Somalia’s Capital
abstract: The Shabab claimed responsibility for the assault in Mogadishu, which government officials said left at least 15 people dead, including 7 attackers.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Militants staged a deadly assault on a United Nations compound here on Wednesday, the latest in a series of attacks that have chipped away at the security gains the Somali capital has experienced in recent years.

headline: Day 2: Sights and Sounds of Wimbledon Qualifying
abstract: The second day of qualifying for Wimbledon included a victory by Tamarine Tanasugarn, 36, an upset by the colorful Dustin Brown and a temper tantrum by Ilya Marchenko of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: ROEHAMPTON, England — After the field of 128 men in the qualifying draw was halved on Monday in Day 1 of Wimbledon qualifying, the women’s field of 96 began play on Day 2 Tuesday on the lawns of the Bank of England Club, with the men to follow.

headline: The Gun Report: June 19, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, a horrible gun incident took place in Des Moines, Iowa. Scott Hazelbaker, 51, accidentally shot and killed his 18-year-old daughter Emily. We included Emily’s death in our Weekend Gun Report, but there’s more. Laura Nichols, a reporter with KCCI in Des Moines, landed an interview with Hazelbaker, who described his daughter as his best friend. “She was just an angel here on earth,” he said. “I miss her so much.” During the interview, Hazelbaker “sat with his head down and tears in his eyes,” according to Nichols.

headline: Updates on the Fed Announcement
abstract: After heightened anticipation about a possible pullback from stimulus, here is how the Fed’s latest policy statement and Ben S. Bernanke’s news conference unfolded.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s policy statement and news conference were awaited with unusual anticipation by economists and investors looking for clues about when the central bank might curtail its stimulus programs. The markets have been in turmoil since the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said at a May 22 hearing that a change could come “in the next few meetings” of the Fed’s policy making board. Here is an account of how the statement and Mr. Bernanke’s appearance unfolded.

headline: Obesity in Teenagers Is Tied to Hearing Loss
abstract: In a new study, obesity in adolescents was linked to an increased risk of hearing loss, independent of risk factors including poverty or exposure to loud noises.
lead_paragraph: Obesity in adolescents is associated with a range of cardiovascular and other health risks. Now a new study adds one more: hearing loss.

headline: Self-Publishing Star Amanda Hocking Sells Next Series to St. Martin’s
abstract: Ms. Hocking had sold more than a million copies of her novels before St. Martin’s Press published her “Watersong” series.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Hocking, who sold more than one million copies of her self-published novels before turning to a traditional publisher, has sold another series to St. Martin’s Press.

headline: Michael Hastings, 33, Winner of Polk Award, Dies
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Polk, George, Awards', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: Mr. Hastings, an intrepid war zone reporter in Afghanistan and Iraq, won a Polk Award in 2010 for his Rolling Stone magazine cover story, “The Runaway General.”
lead_paragraph: Michael Hastings, the award-winning freelance reporter who died on Tuesday at 33, was known for an intrepid journalism that took him to war zones in Afghanistan and Iraq and, most famously, brought down a United States Army general.

Mueller III, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, warned Wednesday that dismantling the National Security Agency’s once-secret program that is keeping records of billions of domestic phone calls by Americans would slow down investigators as they seek to stop terrorist attacks.

headline: Optimistic Fed Outlines an End to Its Stimulus
abstract: Policy makers, more confident about the recovery, said they intended to reduce their monetary stimulus program later this year if unemployment continues to decline.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve, increasingly confident in the durability of economic growth, expects to start pulling back later this year from its efforts to stimulate the economy, the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Wednesday.

lead_paragraph: Sallie L. Krawcheck, a former big bank executive, has emerged as a prominent advocate for Wall Street women in recent weeks, after buying the women’s network 85 Broads in May. But it remained unclear what Ms. Krawcheck was planning to do with the organization.

headline: Private Equity Firm Tied to New York Pension Scandal Raises $7.7 Billion From Investors

lead_paragraph: Four years ago this month, the private equity firm Riverstone Holdings agreed to pay $30 million to resolve its role in a “pay-to-play” pension fund investigation by Andrew M. Cuomo, the New York attorney general at the time. Several months later, Riverstone’s founder, David M. Leuschen, paid an additional $20 million to settle his role in the case.

headline: Making the Best of a Brief Turn

headline: A Stop on a Michigan ‘Garage Crawl’ Reveals a Trove of Corvettes, Exotics and Other Classics
abstract: Sunday’s Eyes on Design show in Grosse Point Shores, Mich., which helps benefit the visually impaired, included a “garage crawl” to some notable collections, including the one owned by Ken Ligenfelter.
lead_paragraph: BRIGHTON, Mich. – “As a kid I’d hop the fence at local dealerships to see the new cars before they were revealed to the public,” said Ken Lingenfelter during a Saturday a tour of his private collection. Mr. Lingenfelter, the son of a General Motors executive, grew up immersed in all things automotive, so when he gained the means, he started buying cars, lots of cars. Many of them were built by the company for which his father had worked.

lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — The seedings for Wimbledon were announced Wednesday, and there were no surprises: the top five seeds mirrored the top five players in the ATP rankings and were unchanged by the formula tournament organizers use to account for prowess on grass courts.

headline: A Symphony at Sea
abstract: Bands, ships and a lighthouse will perform the Foghorn Requiem, a lament for a fading sound, on the North Sea on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: In one of the most offbeat orchestras ever assembled, three brass bands, one lighthouse and more than 50 horn-blowing ships will perform the Foghorn Requiem on Saturday. Stationed off the northern England port of South Shields, the ships along with the shore-based bands and the Souter Lighthouse will sound a lament across the North Sea for the loss of foghorns in the age of satellite navigation.

headline: Four American Men Advance to Main Draw Through Wimbledon Qualifying
abstract: Denis Kudla, Alex Kuznetsov, Wayne Odesnik and Bobby Reynolds all advanced through Wimbledon qualifying to earn a spot in the main draw.
lead_paragraph: ROEHAMPTON, England — Four American men — Denis Kudla, Alex Kuznetsov, Wayne Odesnik, and Bobby Reynolds — qualified for the Wimbledon main draw Wednesday, winning the best-of-five final qualifying-round matches unique to this tournament.

headline: Hitchcock, Finding His Voice in Silents
abstract: Nine of Alfred Hitchcock’s earliest features, all silent, are coming to the Harvey Theater in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Hitchcock may be the most famous film director who ever lived — a favorite of both the pleasure-loving public and theory-addled academics; the subject at once of bizarre biographical fantasies (now available in both book and movie form) as well as of some of the most significant critical thinking of the last 50 or 60 years.

headline: Baking His Own Tart
abstract: Photographing Martha Rose Shulman’s healthy recipes and her delectable desserts.
lead_paragraph: Outtakes is an occasional feature on the story behind the photographs in the Dining section.

headline: The Calorie-Packed Perk
abstract: Small, high-growth tech companies have a reputation for showering employees with perks, many of them calorie-packed.
lead_paragraph: Within my first week of working at a start-up, I acquired a gut. The reason was obvious: there was free food everywhere, it was delicious and I was nervous. Within five days I was heaving my stomach around like a kettle bell and crossly preparing, and then ignoring, cups of green tea.

headline: Smartphone Tools Have Their Place in the Wild
abstract: Apps can help campers find a campsite, plan a camping trip or navigate the way across the countryside.
lead_paragraph: I have some vacation time coming up shortly and I’m planning to make the most of the summery weather by camping and walking in the wild. Unlike the makeshift camping trips of my youth, this outing will be planned carefully, and I’m taking my smartphone, loaded with apps that I think will be useful in the field.

headline: Footage of Aftermath of Attack on U.N.
abstract: Scenes from the United Nations compound in Mogadishu, Somalia after Islamist militants staged a deadly assault on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the United Nations compound in Mogadishu, Somalia after Islamist militants staged a deadly assault on Wednesday.

lead_paragraph: Bank of America Merrill Lynch named new co-heads of its technology, media and telecommunications investment banking group on Wednesday. It poached one from JPMorgan Chase.

headline: An Entrepreneur Retreats Into a Swedish Forest
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Small Business', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Is this what it takes to start a company?
lead_paragraph: Thomas Backlund, 33, is a programmer from Stockholm who is trying to start a business, Blockie.io. As mentioned in this week’s Dashboard roundup of small-business news, Mr. Backlund has quit his job and left his apartment and moved to a Swedish forest in order to save expenses while creating his new venture. We contacted Mr. Backlund by e-mail for a conversation that has been edited and condensed.

headline: Apple and Netflix Dominate Online Video
keywords: ['DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Television', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Many people are getting movies and TV shows over the Internet. By some measures, Apple is No. 1 in online video, but by others, Netflix leads the way.
lead_paragraph: Now that the video rental store is all but dead (see: Blockbuster), many people are turning to Internet services to get TV shows and movies. By some measures, Apple is No. 1 in online video, but by others, Netflix is leading.

headline: Here’s Snow White. Don’t Bring the Kids.
abstract: In presenting Paul McCarthy’s “WS,” the Park Avenue Armory is signaling that it will not fear controversy.
lead_paragraph: In the five years since it converted itself into a contemporary art hall, with one of the largest open exhibition floors in the world, the Park Avenue Armory has helped realize several gargantuan and difficult projects. The Brazilian artist Ernesto Neto remade the space into a science-fiction spider web, swathing it with thousands of feet of Lycra. Ann Hamilton installed swings from the trusses, turning visitors into participants in an ethereal moving sculpture.

headline: The Spirits of Brazil, Weaving Through Jazz Sounds
abstract: A show at Birdland with Stacey Kent, and her husband, the saxophonist Jim Tomlinson, defined them as sophisticated, cosmopolitan jazz impressionists.
lead_paragraph: With her bright, alluring sliver of a voice — a darting musical tongue of flame — Stacey Kent has few of the traits commonly associated with jazz singing. Yet with her lightly swinging delivery, curt phrasing and attraction to Brazilian bossa nova, she is a jazz singer in the iconoclastic mode of the much-missed Blossom Dearie, whom some critics wrongly dismissed as more cabaret than jazz.

headline: The Impulse at Its Purest, Racing Anew
abstract: “Dabke,” a contemporary work choreographed by Zvi Gotheiner, is among the highlights of the new Musa! dance festival at the Baruch Performing Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: The world of the Israeli kibbutz and the broader Middle East comes to us in Zvi Gotheiner’s “Dabke.” Mr. Gotheiner has lived, danced and choreographed in New York since 1988, but he began life in a kibbutz. New last year, “Dabke” strikes me as the most enchanting piece I’ve seen in a long while — a little too long for its own good at 48 minutes, and yet continually surprising, even revelatory, throughout.

headline: Bike-Sharing Comes to Aspen
abstract: Aspen, Colo., says it is the first mountain town to have a bike-sharing program, with a fleet that includes 100 bikes.
lead_paragraph: Never one to fall behind trends, Aspen, Colo., proclaims itself the first mountain town with a bike-share program. Its new We-cycle fleet includes 100 bikes parked at 13 stations around town.

headline: Britain Prepares to Sell Its Stake in Lloyds and Weighs a Breakup of R.B.S.
abstract: The British government is preparing to sell part of its holding in the Lloyds Banking Group and is weighing a breakup of the Royal Bank of Scotland, the chancellor of the Exchequer said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government is preparing to sell part of its holding in the Lloyds Banking Group and is weighing a breakup of the Royal Bank of Scotland, the chancellor of the Exchequer said on Wednesday.

headline: In Harlem, Gershwin’s Brief, Brash, Early Opera
abstract: Gershwin wrote “Blue Monday,” a one-act jazz opera, for a Broadway revue in 1922.
lead_paragraph: Familiar sights and sounds greeted visitors to the Cotton Club in Harlem on Tuesday night. Stepping into the modern-day incarnation of that storied Prohibition-era nightclub, you heard swing standards brightly played by the Cotton Club All-Stars: “In a Mellow Tone,” “Take the ‘A’ Train,” “In the Mood” and so on. Out on the dance floor, nattily garbed dancers cut a figurative rug.

headline: Tapping to Shostakovich, and Other Adventures
abstract: Savion Glover is joined by Marshall Davis Jr. and three female hoofers in his new show at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: Within the first minutes of “STePz,” the playful new Savion Glover show that opened a three-week run at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, all but one of its essential elements are established. As usual for this virtuoso tap dancer, there’s an amplified platform. Unusually, there’s recorded music. Mr. Glover, at his most relaxed and appealing, is joined by Marshall Davis Jr. and three accomplished female hoofers: Ayodele Casel, Sarah Savelli and Robyn Watson. They’re all having a ball.

headline: The Glory and Brutality of a Purebred Texan Clan
abstract: “The Son” spans 200 years, six generations and a great many downfalls in one proudly purebred American family, the McCulloughs of Texas.
lead_paragraph: The words of Edward Gibbon bookend Philipp Meyer’s novel “The Son,” a luxuriantly big book that tells a very Texan story of decline and fall. Mr. Meyer opens with Gibbon’s words about how the vicissitudes of fortune defeat the most magisterial human achievements. That the same quotation can be purchased on mouse pads and coffee cups does nothing if not affirm Gibbon’s wisdom.

headline: Investigation Follows Trail of a Virus in Hospitals
abstract: An international team found that a person can get sick 5.2 days after being exposed to the MERS virus, which has infected 64 people in 38 countries.
lead_paragraph: A man in a Saudi hospital has pneumonia. The patient in the room next door gets sick, and before anyone realizes what is happening he infects seven others, each of whom infects at least one more. An outbreak is born.

headline: Young Dodger Shows Full Day’s Worth of Skill
abstract: Yasiel Puig, a 22-year-old phenom from Cuba who had two hits in each game, took the spotlight as the Dodgers and the Yankees split a doubleheader in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Yasiel Puig introduced himself to the Yankees early in Game 1 of Wednesday’s doubleheader, singling up the middle in the first inning, barrelling around first base and dashing full speed toward second — a 245-pound blur kicking up chunks of dirt in his wake.

headline: Pressed for Time and Looking for Love
abstract: There is an air of erotic effortlessness in John Rando’s production of “On the Town” at the Barrington Stage Company in Pittsfield, Mass.
lead_paragraph: PITTSFIELD, Mass. — The mating season has arrived at the Barrington Stage Company. This theatrical outpost in the Berkshires has recreated the habitat of creatures whose ruling imperative is to find sexual partners fast. You will be happy to know that, nature being generous by and large, most of them get — how shall we put it? — lucky. You, in turn, will surely feel lucky to be in their company for a couple of hours.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Brazil and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Brazil, Somalia, Afghanistan and France.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Brazil, Somalia, Afghanistan and France.

headline: Finding Deals With Paid Upgrades
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Automobile Renting and Leasing', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Customer Relations']
abstract: Hotels, airlines and car rental agencies are more aggressively promoting upgrade opportunities. Here’s some guidance for deciding if they’re worth the price.
lead_paragraph: With all the complaints about escalating fees that travelers have to pay, another pricing trend is on the rise that some customers may actually like: paid upgrades.

headline: Isner Hopes for Improvement at Wimbledon
abstract: John Isner, warming up for Wimbledon, hopes to adapt better to the grass this time around.
lead_paragraph: STOKE PARK, England -– Events don’t get more quintessentially British than the Boodles Challenge, the pre-Wimbledon exhibition tournament tucked away in a well-heeled corner of the English countryside. This is tennis’ version of Royal Ascot, a week in which the spectator experience is as much about the clinking of champagne glasses as feasting on the sight of Richard Gasquet’s backhand.

headline: Now Screening | The Goofy, Cultish World of Master Sommeliers
abstract: A documentary reveals the arduous process of becoming certified as an expert in the field — and the wacky things the wine cognoscenti say.
lead_paragraph: How to make a wine documentary that doesn’t put audiences to sleep? The first-time director Jason Wise opted to focus less on wine itself and more on the characters who uncork, decant, sample and sell it: the sommeliers. His film “Somm” follows a quartet of hotshot American oenophiles as they prepare for a three-part, three-day test on every imaginable nuance of wine that is administered by the prestigious (and exclusive) British organization the Court of Master Sommeliers. Over nearly half a century, this international body has only “knighted” 197 candidates as Masters — about 10 percent of test takers. Dustin Wilson, the wine director of the triple-Michelin-starred Manhattan restaurant Eleven Madison Park and one of the film’s stars, passed just one of three parts — service — the first time he took it in 2010. “Only 16 people have ever passed it their first time,” he said.

headline: Kingdom for Horse? No, but $64 for Parking
abstract: New York City is charging the theater company behind Shakespeare in the Parking Lot fees for the spaces it uses, and insisting on insurance for cars it does not have.

As the unrest has intensified, Brazilian readers of The New York Times have attempted to explain the protests to a curious audience in comments posted on this site in English and Portuguese.

headline: Seattle Opera Names a General Director
abstract: The British stage director Aidan Lang, currently the general director of the New Zealand Opera, would succeed Mr. Jenkins in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Speight Jenkins has been the general director of the Seattle Opera for 30 of the company’s 50 seasons, and given his accomplishments — which include renovating the Seattle Opera House, staging productions of the complete Wagner canon and making the company’s “Ring” cycle an international attraction — it seemed as if he would lead the company indefinitely. But Mr. Jenkins, 76, told the board in 2011 that he would like to step down, and that set in motion a two-year search that ended on Wednesday. The company announced that the British stage director Aidan Lang, currently the general director of the New Zealand Opera, would succeed Mr. Jenkins in 2014. Mr. Lang, 57, has held his position in New Zealand since 2006. He was also artistic director of the Buxton Festival in Britain from 1999 to 2006 and Opera Zuid in the Netherlands from 1990 to 1998. Mr. Lang will join the company as director designate next March and work with Mr. Jenkins, who will remain general director through August 2014. They will work together on the 2015-16 season; Mr. Lang’s first season solo will be 2016-17.

headline: Musical Relics From Paganini and Mozart, Still Sending Blessings

lead_paragraph: The trade in religious relics has ebbed substantially since the Middle Ages, when wealthy collectors and ambitious clerics vied for possession of a saint’s femur or a splinter of the Holy Cross. But on feast days, relics are still paraded through towns across Europe.

headline: Black Sabbath Earns Its First No.1
abstract: The group achieved a similar feat in Britain.
lead_paragraph: It took four decades, but Black Sabbath, the British rock band that arguably spawned the entire heavy metal genre, finally earned a No. 1 album on the Billboard 200 chart this week with it’s latest release, “13,” which sold 155,000 copies, Billboard reported on Wednesday. Released on Vertigo, “13” is the group’s first set of new songs with most of its original lineup — the singer Ozzy Osbourne, the guitarist Tony Iommi and the bassist Geezer Butler — since the 1978 album “Never Say Die!” (The original drummer, Bill Ward, is not involved because of contract disputes.) The group’s only other Top 10 album was 1971’s “Master of Reality,” which rose to No. 8.

In Britain, Prime Minister David Cameron has been promising a destabilizing referendum on the country’s membership in the European Union. Francois Hollande of France has been trying to undermine the E.U.’s negotiations with the United States on an important trade and investment agreement. And the administration of Germany’s chancellor, Angela Merkel, has been trying to delay a much needed banking union for the euro zone.

headline: Twigitecture: Building Human Nests
abstract: From New Age cocoons and backyard playthings of the rich to contemporary art objects, giant nests are having a moment.

Woven from eucalyptus branches, it bloomed high on the side of a cliff overlooking the Pacific Coast Highway, a great whorl of sticks atop four gnarly pillars. The north wind hissed through the gaps in the branches and the fog settled on my face and sleeping bag, but I could see the stars through the nest’s oculus entry and hear the elephant seals miles below honking and braying in a lullaby like no other.

headline: Ceramics That Make the Afterlife More Fun
keywords: ['Ceramics and Pottery', 'Art', 'Nineteen Hundred Seventies', 'Nineteen Hundred Eighties']
abstract: Matthias Merkel Hess immortalizes designs of the 1970s and ’80s in clay.
lead_paragraph: “Hereafter,” a show opening Thursday at Salon 94 Freemans in New York, features the sculpture of Matthias Merkel Hess, who makes ceramic copies of (mostly) household objects. Among the roughly 250 pieces are a Bose Wave radio, a Mr. Coffee brewer, a Black & Decker DustBuster and every single spoon in his home — items the Los Angeles artist considered appropriate for a modern-day tomb, for use in the afterlife.

headline: No Shrinking Violets Here
abstract: Peter Dayton, a former rock musician, turns a floral collage into wallpaper.
lead_paragraph: In May, the artist Peter Dayton created a Warholian room, covering walls, tables and screens in riotous bouquets. Mr. Dayton, a former rock musician, is known for his floral collages, which he creates from photocopies of pictures cut from seed catalogs. For this environment, which was commissioned by the Brooklyn gallery Grey Area and displayed at the Collective .1 design fair in New York, begonias were his chosen bloom. “They’re a bit ambiguous and hard to identify,” he said. The name Grey Area refers to “the undefined space between art and design,” in the words of the gallery’s founders, Kyle DeWoody and Manish Vora, who teamed up with Cavern Wallpaper of Los Angeles to make the wallpaper available commercially. Called Wallflowers, it is sold in color or black-and-white for $338 a roll. A resin-coated wood screen and table with the pattern are also available. Information: (347) 799-1155 or greyarea.co.

headline: Philip Johnson’s Glass House Gets a Store to Match
abstract: Murray Moss chooses items for the new store at the modernist’s home in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not a good design store, but the ultimate Glass House design store,” said Murray Moss about a shop that opens Friday at the Philip Johnson house in New Canaan, Conn. Mr. Moss, the former SoHo retailer who now heads Moss Bureau, a design advisory service, organized and selected merchandise for the space and installed oversize Corian benches. A map of the 49-acre estate, on which Mr. Johnson lived from 1949 until his death in 2005, hangs prominently on one wall. In Mr. Moss’s view, all of the items for sale dignify that modernist masterwork and its architect, be they an Alvar Aalto vase, brass bar tools by Carl Auböck of Vienna or Angelo Mangiarotti’s 1956 Maritime table clock (shown, $285). “These are souvenirs, but they should be of the level of intelligence of the visitors,” he said, adding, “There will be no finger puppets.” Information: (203) 594-9884, designstore.philipjohnsonglasshouse.org.

headline: ‘Shiro Kuramata’ by Deyan Sudjic
abstract: The Japanese designer’s legacy lives on in a new monograph.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese designer Shiro Kuramata died in 1991, when he was just 56, and virtually all of his renowned interiors, for clients like Issey Miyake and Esprit, have vanished. Among his groundbreaking household objects, including an acrylic chair embedded with artificial roses and an armchair made of glued glass pieces, many are confined to museums and private collections.

headline: Nature’s Little Baubles
abstract: An architect uses succulents to decorate blown-glass globes.
lead_paragraph: Succulents, the popular plants that seem to thrive on air and abuse, are jewels in the hands of Andreea Avram Rusu, a Brooklyn architect and designer. Made of porcelain, they adorn her new Gia collection of glass lamps. Why succulents? “It’s incredible, the shapes that you find,” Ms. Avram Rusu said, adding that she cast her ornaments from live specimens and needed plants that were sturdy: “Things with delicate leaves don’t work so well,” she said. The handblown glass globes shade from solid to transparent in an ombré effect. Three shapes are available in a variety of colors, in pendant and table versions. Prices range from $1,800 to $2,400, and custom colors and finishes are available. Information: (718) 389-0350 or avramrusu.com.

headline: Why India Trails China
abstract: A great gap between India and China is in the provision of essential public services — a failing that depresses living standards and is a persistent drag on growth.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — MODERN India is, in many ways, a success. Its claim to be the world’s largest democracy is not hollow. Its media is vibrant and free; Indians buy more newspapers every day than any other nation. Since independence in 1947, life expectancy at birth has more than doubled, to 66 years from 32, and per-capita income (adjusted for inflation) has grown fivefold. In recent decades, reforms pushed up the country’s once sluggish growth rate to around 8 percent per year, before it fell back a couple of percentage points over the last two years. For years, India’s economic growth rate ranked second among the world’s large economies, after China, which it has consistently trailed by at least one percentage point.

headline: Lebanon, Overrun by Syrian Refugees
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A humanitarian crisis is threatening the region’s stability.
lead_paragraph: ZAHLÉ, Lebanon — MY eyes kept being drawn to the shoes. The tiny pink running shoes with Velcro straps, on the feet of the 2-year-old girl sitting quietly on her mother’s lap. She fidgeted only a bit — jostling occasionally with her 7-year-old twin sisters while her father told a United Nations worker what had driven his young family 20 miles from Syria to this small town in Lebanon. They did not merely leave; they fled. And not once, but three times.

headline: A Public Art Project That Will Travel by Train
abstract: The artist Doug Aitken has organized a three-week journey from New York to San Francisco, with 10 stops in between, called “Station to Station: a Nomadic Happening,” which will include not only shows by visual artists but also music, poetry and food.
lead_paragraph: Chartered train trips tend to conjure images of flag bunting, stump speeches and glad-handing politicians.

headline: West Virginia, Still Home
abstract: Residents of McDowell County, W.Va., share memories and hopes for their rural community — in jeopardy because of high unemployment and an exodus of young people.
lead_paragraph: Residents of McDowell County, W.Va., share memories and hopes for their rural community — in jeopardy because of high unemployment and an exodus of young people.

headline: ‘West Virginia, Still Home’
abstract: Residents of McDowell County, W.Va., share memories and hopes for their rural community — in jeopardy because of high unemployment and an exodus of young people.
lead_paragraph: In this Op-Doc video, and a related online interactive documentary, “Hollow,” I share the experiences and memories of hard-working people who live amid the coal fields of McDowell County, W.Va. They are struggling to save their rural community — in jeopardy because of high unemployment and an exodus of young people (since 1950, the county has lost 80 percent of its population).

headline: Preparing for the Pope
abstract: In Latin America, the Catholic Church looks to save its soul.
lead_paragraph: In April, in the sunlit city of Natal, Brazil, two men knocked on Sandra Abdalla’s door to apply for a painting job. Their pitch, as she described it in an e-mail: they were evangelical Christians and therefore more reliable than the competition. They didn’t drink, raise hell or steal, as a Catholic might. In a country that boasts the largest Roman Catholic population in the world — and a quickly rising tide of evangelicals — those are fighting words. Not least to Pope Francis, an Argentine who will visit Brazil next month, in the first trip of his papacy.

headline: Andy Warhol and the Persistence of Modernism
abstract: To continue doing brisk business, arts institutions have had to ignore Andy Warhol’s radical undermining of modernism in the visual arts.
lead_paragraph: The June 20th issue of The New York Review of Books contains a devastating portrayal, by the art critic Richard Dorment, of the activities of The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts and its (now dissolved) sister institution, the Andy Warhol Art Authentication Board. The foundation was established, according to Warhol’s will, to provide for the “advancement of the visual arts,” and was to be funded by the sale of a large number of works the artist left to his estate. The board was assembled for the purpose of deciding whether a given work was an original Warhol. As I’ll explain, that task is hardly straightforward.

lead_paragraph: He waited by an elevator on the 13th floor of Police Headquarters, the final stop Wednesday in a whirlwind of television appearances and newspaper interviews since his line-of-duty injury the previous day: broken teeth, swollen snout.

abstract: A report from the Government Accountability Office noted that on seven of 12 nonstop routes, generally between an American and US Air hub, there was no other nonstop competitor.
lead_paragraph: The planned merger between American Airlines and US Airways will reduce competition in a far larger number of airports than earlier airline mergers, including the one that created the nation’s current leader, United-Continental, according to a report released Wednesday by the Government Accountability Office.

abstract: Besides the former college basketball player Ed O’Bannon, ex-star athletes and even a sports marketing executive all have a stake in a lawsuit against the N.C.A.A.
lead_paragraph: For Sonny Vaccaro, the Ed O’Bannon lawsuit against the N.C.A.A. is an important part of a personal crusade. He wants to see the organization, his nemesis, in court, its inner workings exposed. He prays he will be called to testify. He is not shy about the stakes, with the latest hearing in the case scheduled for Thursday.

headline: British Court Rules Against Sanctions on Iranian Bank
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: The decision raised new questions about the country’s secret courts and was a vindication for the Iranian bank, Bank Mellat, which had spent four years fighting the sanctions designation.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s Supreme Court ruled that sanctions imposed on a commercial Iranian bank were invalid because the British Treasury had sought them improperly through a secret court proceeding in a misuse of Britain’s antiterrorism laws. The decision raised new questions about the country’s secret courts and was a vindication for the Iranian bank, Bank Mellat, which had spent four years fighting the sanctions designation that had banned it from operating in Britain. In Washington, the Treasury Department sharply criticized the British ruling and warned that Bank Mellat, which has been accused of financing Iranian nuclear and ballistic missile activities, remained under sanction by both the European Union and the United States. A Treasury Department statement said Bank Mellat “has no place in the international financial system.”

headline: One-Sided Bill on Asbestos Injuries
abstract: Congress should determine whether there is significant fraud in asbestos claims before enacting a law that makes it harder to obtain fair compensation.
lead_paragraph: Republicans rammed a bill through the House Judiciary Committee last month that would make it harder for plaintiffs injured by asbestos to get fair compensation. The bill is supposedly designed to root out fraud and abuse, but there is no persuasive evidence of any significant fraud or abuse. Before plunging ahead with this misguided attempt to protect asbestos companies from lawsuits, Congress ought to commission an objective study of whether there is even a problem that needs fixing.

headline: Turkey in Turmoil
abstract: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s violent response to street protests in Istanbul damages democracy.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan had many opportunities over the last three weeks to resolve the political crisis in Turkey peacefully and quickly. However, with almost every statement and directive he has made the situation worse, increasing concerns at home and abroad over his authoritarian tendencies and Turkey’s future as a democratic model in the Muslim world.
