headline: A Second Chance for Ex-Offenders
abstract: In another step in the right direction, the E.E.O.C. filed discrimination lawsuits against two companies for denying jobs to people based on criminal records.
lead_paragraph: The federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission took on an important issue last year when it reaffirmed and updated a ruling that barred employers from automatically denying people jobs based on arrest or conviction records. The guidance made clear that an arrest alone was not proof of illegal conduct or grounds for exclusion. It also explained that, when considering an applicant with a criminal conviction, the employer must take into account the seriousness of the offense, the time lapsed since the offense and the relevance of the crime to the specific job being sought.

headline: How to Tweet in Mandarin
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: In the United States, politicians as punch lines is par for the course. In China, the new president as Winnie the Pooh? Oh, no you don’t!
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Lunch had run late, and by the time we got back to our hotel, Hung Huang was already in the lobby waiting for us. Blunt, opinionated and wickedly funny, Huang is one of the country’s top fashion editors. But she is better known for her acerbic posts on Weibo, a microblog, where she has 7.5 million followers. As we introduced ourselves — four journalists on a three-city tour of China — she passed around a picture that someone had texted her.

lead_paragraph: The Boston School Committee on Wednesday approved making condoms available in the district’s high schools. The new policy allows students to obtain condoms, and counseling, from school health centers or trained staff members, unless parents opt them out, and makes sexual education a required part of school health curricula. The district first made condoms available through health centers in some of its schools in the mid-1990s; in the past few years, a coalition of students and community leaders campaigned to broaden access to condoms and sexual health education in the district.

headline: Data You Can Believe In

abstract: How the precision targeting of “persuadable” voters that put President Obama over the top in 2012 could revolutionize the advertising industry.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, senior members of President Barack Obama’s campaign team took a trip to Las Vegas. Nevada holds a special place in Obama-wonk lore as the place where his monthslong strategy of defeating Hillary Clinton by slowly and surely amassing delegates emerged. But the operatives were not there in March for any political reason. They were there to make money — specifically to land what they hoped would be the first corporate client for their new advertising business, Analytics Media Group (A.M.G.). Its bland name obscures its relatively grand promise: to deliver to commercial advertisers some of the Obama campaign’s secret, technologically advanced formulas for reaching voters.

The initiative came not so much from the pants — big Oxford bags, pleated at the waist and puddling over the feet. The effect was rather in the tunic tops, cut on sparse, geometric lines, maybe sliced at an angle, baring shoulders or with flourishes at the neckline. There were no men in frills this season but a defiantly female halter top with a girlie floral pattern.

lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve expects to start pulling back later this year from its economic stimulus efforts, the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said on Wednesday. Yes, there were 11 goals. There were 90 shots on goal. And yes, it was the kind of freewheeling, back-and-forth play that was banned from the N.H.L. in the mid-90s when it was decreed that all games, particularly in the playoffs, must resemble the battle scene from “Braveheart.” The Boston Bruins and the Chicago Blackhawks pitched all that in the Charles River and decided this game would be a race to six goals. headline: 36 Hours in Vancouver, British Columbia
abstract: In this stunning city, even commutes can be attractive. But Vancouver’s appeal doesn’t end with the outdoors.
lead_paragraph: Between the jaw-dropping confluence of mountains and sea, some of the best ethnic food in North America and public transit bliss courtesy of the Canada Line and SkyTrain, Vancouver is much more than an erstwhile Olympic site, or a place to stop over on your way to some other destination. Where else can you find an international brand of exoticism that rivals Hong Kong, Nordic-style order and a limitless array of shops, restaurants and top-notch accommodations? An abundance of outdoor options — whether it is hiking or biking in Stanley Park, kayaking in False Creek or skiing on nearby Grouse Mountain — only adds to the appeal. The city doesn’t take its natural gifts for granted; in recent years it has become so eco-friendly that some stores don’t even offer plastic bags. With its multitude of immigrant communities and northwest Canadian culture of extreme friendliness, Vancouver feels just different enough to be intriguingly foreign but familiar enough to be easily conquered in a weekend.

It’s not that this isn’t going well. It’s that a) I also added the “I Don’t Have an Office Anymore” challenge, in which we remodel the part of the house with the office in it and I work in the kitchen and b) my visible presence serves as a constant reminder that if only I would, I could drive them to the end of the driveway with all their stuff for their lemonade sale, read the words one is struggling with in the book she’s reading (every other one) and c) when three children coated head to toe with mud appear in your doorway with the plan of heading upstairs to clean up, I challenge you not to take a minute to get them towels and redirect them to the hose — and so on.

But instead of a joyous reunion, it was more of a valedictory for her and the children — the school is closing for good.

headline: The Gun Report: June 20, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Look at our first item today. It is nearly unfathomable: two people having a domestic dispute fire a gun and kill their 6-month-old daughter. I know I sound like a broken record, but this is the kind of gun violence that we could—and should—be working hardest to prevent. It does not require new legislation—although legislation that called for gun owners to keep their guns locked in their homes would certainly be welcome. It does not require we spend large sums of money. What it requires is a cultural change, in which gun owners take their responsibility more seriously. Why is this so hard?

headline: Fermi Laboratory Names New Director

lead_paragraph: The Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, the flagship of American particle physics, named a new director on Thursday: He is Nigel Lockyer, 60, currently the director of Canada’s national laboratory for particle and nuclear physics, or Triumf, and a professor at the University of British Columbia, in Vancouver. Dr. Lockyer, who was born in Scotland and raised in Canada, worked as a particle physicist working at Fermilab studying quarks. Dr. Lockyer will take office on Sept. 3. He is replacing Pier Oddone, who has held the post since 2005 and is retiring on July 1. Jack Anderson, Fermilab’s chief operating officer, will serve as interim director until Dr. Lockyer arrives.

headline: A College Where the Exams Are Terrifying
abstract: Pixar’s “Monsters University” tells the story of how Mike and Sulley of “Monsters Inc.” met, became friends and learned to be really scary.
lead_paragraph: What are little boy monsters made of? In Pixar’s “Monsters University,” they aren’t made of slugs, snails and puppy dog tails — they’re monstrous versions of those ingredients, only cuter, fuzzier, brighter, wilder and woollier. A stomping, creeping menagerie, they embody a Popsicle-hued rainbow of seeming diversity, from their googly eyes to their hydra heads and sticky tentacles. In this passable prequel to Pixar’s magical 2001 film “Monsters, Inc.,” anything and every being seems possible. Or so believes the young Mike Wazowski (voiced by Noah Johnson and Billy Crystal), who thinks that if he studies hard enough, he too can become one of his world’s Scarers.

lead_paragraph: My husband and I are in our late 50s and recently wed. We met long after our separations from our previous spouses. My family loves him, and his likes me — except for a sister-in-law (who is married to his brother). She refuses to acknowledge my presence or speak to me. It can’t be about me because she doesn’t really know me. I try to make the best of it at family functions, but it’s still weird and hurtful. Recently, she came to our home for dinner. She brushed past me when she came in and ignored my greeting. Any advice?

lead_paragraph: I’ve just published a book about family food, but in my house, regular family dinner doesn’t exist. In fact, our family dinner has never looked the way it’s supposed to.

headline: Nogales Is Not Falluja
abstract: Republicans are demanding billions for the immigration enforcement strategy that they denounce as a failure.
lead_paragraph: The Times is reporting that a deal has been struck to keep comprehensive immigration reform moving forward in the Senate, by addressing Republican objections that the bill is too weak on border enforcement.

headline: Supporters of Immigration Bill Offer Amendment Focused on Women
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Thirteen female senators introduced an amendment that would make it easier for foreign women to come to the United States under a new merit system in the legislation.
lead_paragraph: Saying the immigration overhaul bill now before the Senate would discriminate against future immigrants who are women, 13 female senators have introduced an amendment that would make it easier for foreign women to come to the United States under a new merit system in the legislation.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: The Mesmerized Stare, and Google’s Weird Questions
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday’s selections include photos of memorable moments with a common technological theme, and Google dispelling an element of its mystique.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Taking a Seat at Soccer’s Table, but Cautiously
abstract: Sunil Gulati of the United States won election to the 25-member executive committee of soccer’s governing body by one vote. Now comes the hard part.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Two months ago, in a ballroom at the Westin Playa Bonita in Panama City, Sunil Gulati became one of the 25 most powerful people in world soccer. So as he sat in a hotel restaurant here Tuesday morning, why was it hard to know whether to offer congratulations or condolences?

headline: Accidents and Accountability
abstract: In “Three Worlds,” from France, a hit-and-run reverberates in many lives.
lead_paragraph: One miscalculation leads to another in “Three Worlds,” Catherine Corsini’s severe, anxiety-producing French drama about the chain of consequences after a hit-and-run accident. The 16th feature by Ms. Corsini, the film is a rigorous moral inquiry that puts its characters — but especially its ambitious young protagonist, Al (Raphaël Personnaz) — through the wringer.

headline: Blazing a Path Out of the Shadows
abstract: Hunan food is often eclipsed by Sichuan, but at Hunan Manor, there is little distraction from the heat.
lead_paragraph: The beef is nearly black and as chewy as toffee. It looks practically torn by hand, hunks of it scattered among the shriveled yellow-white skins of once-green chile peppers that have been blanched and sun-dried until leached of color. They still burn.

headline: Hunan Manor
abstract: Inside the Chinese restaurant just south of Grand Central Terminal.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Chinese restaurant just south of Grand Central Terminal.

headline: Cross Over
abstract: Colum McCann’s wide-ranging new novel, “TransAtlantic,” tells the stories of men and women who chose to leap across the ocean from Ireland to the New World or back again.
lead_paragraph: Colum McCann’s new novel, “TransAtlantic,” lifts off with a roar. The year is 1919, just after the end of the First World War: “It was that time of the century when the idea of a gentleman had almost become myth.” The war, McCann writes, had “concussed the world.” And yet here are two gentlemen, Jack Alcock and Arthur Brown, ready to set off in a modified bomber, a Vickers Vimy — “It looked as if it had borrowed its design from a form of dragonfly” — to fly the Atlantic, from St. John’s in Newfoundland all the way to Ireland. If they succeed, they’ll make history. They will make a brand-new world.

headline: Show Some Spine
abstract: Why is the faceless woman so ubiquitous on book covers?
lead_paragraph: A plague of women’s backs is upon us in the book cover world. We’ve recently seen “Finding Casey,” by Jo-Ann Mapson; “The Unruly Passion of Eugénie R.,” by Carole DeSanti; and “The Headmaster’s Wager,” by Vincent Lam, all showcasing a nape-and-shoulder combo on the jacket. “The Pretty One,” by Lucinda Rosenfeld, features three women with their backs turned; “The Smart One,” by Jennifer Close, has its heroine turned away, undoing her wrap dress; and a bride stands facing a beach on “Beautiful Day,” by Elin Hilderbrand.

headline: New York City’s Unemployment Rate Dips Slightly
abstract: Though it is still higher than the national rate, unemployment in the city fell to 8.3 percent from 8.4 percent in April and is at its lowest level in more than four years.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s unemployment rate dipped to 8.3 percent in May, its lowest level in more than four years, despite a sharp drop in the pace of hiring, the State Labor Department reported on Thursday.

headline: Thrilled to Death
abstract: Stephen King’s lovelorn narrator takes a summer job at a haunted Southern amusement park.
lead_paragraph: The usual portal for wickedness and darkness in modern American horror fiction is youthful sexuality. Surging hormones summon demons. That’s why big-breasted baby sitters, once they’ve tucked the kids in and phoned their boyfriends to tell them to sneak over, had best keep an eye out for slashers on the stairs. That’s why campgrounds full of teenagers in shorts so often lure scar-faced intruders from the woods. Who are these monsters? The thwarted and the spurned, their psyches warped by repression and rejection. They feed for a while on others’ erotic vitality but are ultimately defeated by these same energies in the form of some brave lass or lad who drives a stake or fires a lucky shot, restoring health and order to the world.

headline: Tribune Falls Afoul of Its Own Tax Strategy
abstract: The media company, just out of bankruptcy, is now facing millions of dollars in taxes and penalties.
lead_paragraph: It was perhaps the cleverest corporate tax strategy ever devised: no matter how much money the company made, neither it nor its shareholders would ever owe a penny in federal income taxes.

headline: Facebook Is Betting Longer Videos Are Better
abstract: Facebook introduced a video service on Thursday as part of its Instagram photo app. It will compete directly with Twitter’s Vine service.
lead_paragraph: What’s the perfect length for video shot and shared via a mobile phone — 15 seconds or six?

headline: Why Bernanke’s Remarks Set off Global, Contagious Market Fears
abstract: NEW YORK — As global markets tumbled and the Dow Jones Industrial Average headed for what could be its biggest percentage decline of the year, Rendezvous editor, Marcus Mabry, sat down with Nelson Schwartz and Nathaniel Popper, New York Times business reporters, to find out why.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — It was a one-two punch. On Wednesday, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, testified that the Fed could foresee the day it would stop buying up U.S. bonds to goose the economy. The next day saw reports that Chinese banks had become reluctant to lend to one another, causing interest rates in the interbank market to spike to punishingly high levels.

headline: Ross Stores Fined in Sales of Defective Clothing
keywords: ['Defective Products', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: The Consumer Product Safety Commission said the retailer failed to report that it stocked or sold clothing with drawstrings that posed a risk to children.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Consumer Product Safety Commission said on Thursday that a leading discount department store had agreed to pay a $3.9 million fine for failing to report that it continued to sell defective children’s clothing after the agency warned that the clothes could cause injuries or deaths.

headline: Solid in the Playoffs, Boston’s Rask Shows a Sudden Vulnerability
abstract: Tuukka Rask, who allowed six goals in Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals on Wednesday, had allowed more than one goal just once in his eight previous games.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Minutes after scoring the overtime goal that won Game 4 of the Stanley Cup finals, Chicago defenseman Brent Seabrook uttered nine words that might be greeted with skull-imploding bewilderment in New York and Pittsburgh.

headline: Three Venerable Names From the Art World: Chuck Close, James Turrell and Polaroid Film
abstract: A behind-the-scenes look at Chuck Close’s use of almost-extinct Polaroid film to photograph James Turrell for our cover.

headline: Obama to Pick Bush-Era Justice Dept. Official to Lead F.B.I.
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: James B. Comey, a senior Justice Department official under President George W. Bush, would replace Robert S. Mueller III when he leaves the job on Sept. 3.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday plans to announce the nomination of James B. Comey, a senior Justice Department official under President George W. Bush, to become the next director of the F.B.I., according to White House officials.

headline: Palestinian Premier Submits Resignation After Just Two Weeks in Office
abstract: The resignation of Prime Minister Rami Hamdallah was a sign of continuing internal political disarray amid already complicated American efforts to restart the peace process with Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The newly appointed prime minister of the Palestinian Authority, Rami Hamdallah, submitted his resignation on Thursday after only two weeks in office, a signal of continuing internal political disarray amid the already complicated American efforts to restart the peace process with Israel.

headline: National Parks Raise Guard Against Virus
keywords: ['Norovirus', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Viruses']
abstract: Park officials said that 150 employees and 50 guests at Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks had contracted norovirus, the highly contagious gastrointestinal illness.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — David Breskin was in line for the breakfast buffet at the Old Faithful Inn at Yellowstone National Park this week when he noticed something unusual: hotel employees in gloves were handing out plates and serving eggs and French toast.

headline: A Director Whose World Is the Stage
abstract: In his memoir, “Jack Be Nimble,” the stage director Jack O’Brien focuses mainly on the impact that the charismatic if combustible Ellis Rabb had on him.
lead_paragraph: “Jack be nimble, Jack be quick, Jack jump over the candlestick.” So runs the nursery rhyme whose opening Jack O’Brien has made the title of his exuberant theatrical memoir, and it’s even apter than he may realize. It’s not just that a director as successful as he has had to be nimble and quick-witted to thrive in a precarious profession.

headline: Albanese Takes Mayoral Bid Underground
abstract: Sal Albanese, a Democrat, recently worked New York City’s rails to try to woo some of the many voters who have no idea who he is.
lead_paragraph: “Hi,” Sal Albanese said the other day, greeting a commuter on the Seventh Avenue line. “I’m Sal Albanese.”

headline: High-Mileage Alterations
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: How to go about securing the Landmarks Preservation Commission’s permission to renovate.
lead_paragraph: Walking through his gutted Brooklyn brownstone row house, Arthur Michel points out the stacks of original woodwork that he has set aside and plans to reuse — fireplace mantels, pocket doors and shutters. The 1887 house is in the Park Slope Historic District. Yet the New York Landmarks Preservation Commission was not concerned with goings-on inside, only with what Mr. Michel planned to do with the front windows and exterior ironwork.

headline: Bloomberg Charity to Underwrite Mobile Guides for Museums
abstract: Bloomberg Philanthropies, the charitable foundation of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, has announced it will give $15 million to underwrite the cost of providing mobile guides for museum patrons.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s company, Bloomberg LP, has long provided financial support to museums to help underwrite audio guides.

headline: Devoted To Choir, In Life And Death
abstract: “Unfinished Song” belongs to the school of “The Full Monty” and “Calendar Girls” in its vision of stolid, working-class Britons banding together.
lead_paragraph: To gag or to weep, that is the question. You may do both while watching “Unfinished Song,” a shamelessly sentimental, manipulative comic tear-jerker about a British chorus, the OAPz (for Old-Age Pensioners); a grumpy old man; and his saintly wife.

headline: A Sugar Baron’s Scattered Art Collection
abstract: The Meadows Museum in Dallas has acquired an alphabetized album by the 19th-century sugar tycoon William Hood Stewart.
lead_paragraph: The 19th-century sugar tycoon William Hood Stewart ran a plantation in Cuba with thousands of acres and hundreds of slaves. Stewart invested the profits partly in European paintings.

headline: Loan Modifications, Proactively
abstract: Under a new initiative from the Federal Housing Finance Agency, mortgage servicers must offer delinquent borrowers a plan to help avoid foreclosure.
lead_paragraph: Homeowners who have fallen behind on their mortgage payments should check their mail carefully in coming weeks. Lenders will be offering loan modifications without even being asked.

headline: Oracle to Leave Nasdaq for the Big Board
abstract: Oracle, one of the most prominent technology companies listed on the Nasdaq, is defecting to the New York Stock Exchange.
lead_paragraph: Oracle, one of the most prominent technology companies listed on the Nasdaq, is defecting to a rival exchange.

headline: Fourth Grader Disappears; Exotic Quest Ensues
abstract: In “Bureau of Missing Persons,” a former schoolteacher who had a mental breakdown after losing one of her fourth graders on a class trip, goes on a quest that takes her to a cave in Moscow.
lead_paragraph: “Bureau of Missing Persons,” a new play by Lila Rose Kaplan, is sprinkled with bits of absurdity and magical realism and other charms. But the whimsical frills ultimately do not make up for the underwritten characters, who remain disconnected from one another and ultimately from the audience too.

headline: James Gandolfini: Famous for TV, Marvelous in Movies
abstract: Though he was most closely associated with the television series “The Sopranos,” James Gandolfini had a movie career that also showcased his skills as an actor.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Sept. 13, 2013

headline: Disabilities and Drama in an Irreverent Mix
abstract: Theater Breaking Through Barriers presents six short plays by Bekah Brunstetter, Samuel D. Hunter, Neil LaBute and others featuring characters with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: In a waiting room full of actors, a handsome guy recognizes an attractive woman. In Neil LaBute’s mini-drama “Call Back,” Brad (Jonathan Todd Ross) knows he has met Denise (Mary Theresa Archbold) before, but can’t remember where — or her name. It turns out that they shared a lot more than a casual conversation.

headline: ‘The ABC of It’
abstract: An exhibit exploring the world of children’s literature opens Friday at the New York Public Library.
lead_paragraph: An exhibit exploring the world of children’s literature opens Friday at the New York Public Library.

headline: After French Loss, Djokovic Turns Focus to Wimbledon
abstract: Novak Djokovic is still smarting from his semifinal loss to Rafael Nadal in the French Open, but he says he will be ready for Wimbledon.
lead_paragraph: STOKE PARK, England – Novak Djokovic is hoping to move on from his difficult loss to Rafael Nadal in the French Open semifinals two weeks ago.

headline: Questions of Identity, Images of Crisis
abstract: The Whitney Museum of American Art’s “I, YOU, WE” looks at political art of the late ’80s and early ’90s.
lead_paragraph: “I, YOU, WE,” the Whitney’s latest collection show and the last one for the Breuer building before the museum decamps to the meatpacking district, makes a useful prequel to the New Museum’s recent exhibition “NYC 1993: Experimental Jet Set, Trash and No Star.” Everything here dates from the 1980s and early ’90s, otherwise known as the era of identity politics. And this show is unusually, almost unfashionably, forthright about those politics, foregrounding them with a string of pronouns.

headline: The Woman at Jesus’ Side, and in His Bed
abstract: Mark Adamo based his opera “The Gospel of Mary Magdalene” on a study of texts that led him to conclude that she had been Jesus’ most important disciple — and his wife.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At the end of the central scene in the first act of the composer Mark Adamo’s ambitious new opera “The Gospel of Mary Magdalene,” which had its premiere here on Wednesday night at the San Francisco Opera, Mary takes Jesus, called Yeshua in this work, to bed.

headline: Finding Meaning in the Mundane
abstract: A midcareer survey of Gary Hume paintings at Tate Britain shows he is not nearly as mysterious as his work suggests.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Gary Hume’s paintings don’t give much away. When he depicts a person, it is often little more than an outline; a plant is only a shape rendered in rich colors and varied textures. It’s as if he wants viewers to create their own narrative. Yet walking through the galleries at Tate Britain, where a midcareer survey of his paintings recently opened, Mr. Hume, 51, isn’t nearly as mysterious as his work suggests.

headline: Bedtime With Puritans and Wild Things
abstract: “The ABC of It: Why Children’s Books Matter,” a remarkably rich new exhibition at the New York Public Library, dissects a major part of growing up.
lead_paragraph: The great green room and the purple crayon are here; so are the wild things and the poky puppy, Charlotte’s web and Alice’s wonderland, the very hungry caterpillar and the stinky cheese man. It is a reunion of creatures, characters and creations, gathered from memories of childhood and parenthood, and celebrated in “The ABC of It: Why Children’s Books Matter,” a remarkably rich new exhibition at the New York Public Library.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Pakistan, Singapore, Iraq and Russia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Pakistan, Singapore, Iraq and Russia.

headline: Charlotte Moorman Performs the Cello
abstract: The French conceptual artist Jean Dupuy captures the cellist in performance at 405 East 13 Street. Moorman is wearing a mask of Pablo Casals.
lead_paragraph: The French conceptual artist Jean Dupuy captures the cellist in performance at 405 East 13 Street. Moorman is wearing a mask of Pablo Casals.

headline: Alice Munro Says She Is Retiring
abstract: Alice Munro,  the short story writer, is retiring from the writing life.
lead_paragraph: Alice Munro, right, the short story writer, is retiring from the writing life, she told an interviewer in Canada. Ms. Munro, 81, had just accepted the Trillium Book Award for her latest collection, “Dear Life,” when she told Mark Medley, an editor from The National Post: “I’m probably not going to write anymore. And, so, it’s nice to go out with a bang.” Asked if “you really think this is it for you,” she responded, “Oh yes.” Told that her fans would be disappointed, she said: “Well, tell them to go read the old ones over again. There’s lots of them.” Ms. Munro, an Ontario native who is considered a master of the short story, won the Man Booker International Prize in 2009. In her review of “Dear Life” in The New York Times in December, Michiko Kakutani wrote that Ms. Munro “creates tales that have the scope and amplitude of novels: whole lives are condensed into a handful of pages, the progress of love is charted over the years as passion gives way to restlessness or deeper commitment or something more ambiguous.”

headline: A Brief History of a Legendary New York Art Building
abstract: To mark the opening of an exhibition celebrating the rich creative history of 404 East 14th Street, in New York’s East Village, a few of its famous tenants recall their time there.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t look like much, but the blocklong building at 404 East 14th Street in New York’s East Village was one of the most vibrant artistic hubs in the city during the 1960s. A former button factory, it offered enormous lofts (and $300 rent) that energized its residents to experiment on a larger scale — and host giddy bacchanalias as well. A new exhibit at Tibor de Nagy Gallery brings together the paintings, sculpture, photographs, films, correspondence and poetry of its famous inhabitants, from Claes Oldenburg to Allen Ginsberg. Here, a few of their memories about the building’s glory days.

headline: When My Music Was Your Music
abstract: “Downloaded” documents the development and emasculation of Napster, the music file-sharing system.
lead_paragraph: The sound of dial-up connections may be quaint in Alex Winter’s “Downloaded,” but not the issues in the film, the latest in VH1’s enlightening series of Rock Docs. In tracing the rapid rise and gradual emasculation of Napster, the peer-to-peer file-sharing service that flourished in the 1990s, “Downloaded” tells a fascinating story about how college students harnessed the Internet to enable people to trade favorite songs, and how a blindsided music industry, ignorant of the Web’s potential, effectively shut them down.

headline: Always Growing, and Open to Change
abstract: The centerpiece of this year’s Make Music New York is an all-day performance of Ezra Pound’s translation of a Confucian text that brings together professional and amateur musicians.
lead_paragraph: About 20 men and women assembled in a ballet studio in Chinatown on a recent Monday evening to rehearse a sequence of austere and meticulously choreographed movements in silence. Peering over a piece of paper covered in tiny handwriting, Jamie Benson, a choreographer leading this rehearsal of the Shakedown Dance Collective, called out instructions while the group flowed through a series of arm movements, hand gestures, dips and bends.

headline: Iron Supplements May Reduce Pregnancy Risks
abstract: A large review of studies concludes that taking iron supplements during pregnancy reduces the risk for maternal anemia and for having a baby with low birth weight.
lead_paragraph: A large review of studies concludes that taking iron supplements during pregnancy reduces the risk for maternal anemia and for having a baby with low birth weight.

headline: The Timid Guy With the Slasher Knife
abstract: Elijah Wood stars as a stalker killer in “Maniac,” a remake of a 1980 thriller.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Comedy Listings for June 21-27
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and more in New York.
lead_paragraph: Comedy

headline: First a Bombing, Then a Truth That’s Elusive
abstract: In “The Attack,” a Palestinian, tries to prove that his wife was not a suicide bomber.
lead_paragraph: “The Attack” opens with the image of a man and woman embracing, the world blurred behind them. Her face to the camera, the woman cries as they hold each other, but it’s unclear whether he can see her tears. Her unexplained weeping and the ill-defined backdrop make an apt start for this intelligent, involving movie that’s by turns a murder mystery and a politically charged argument about contemporary Palestinian identity. That it’s also about a troubled marriage becomes evident when the man, a successful Palestinian surgeon living and working in Tel Aviv, is awoken one night and discovers that both his wife and his safe, cosseted world have disappeared after a suicide bombing.

headline: A Young Couple Take a Bite of Southern Noir
abstract: When a woman dies, her identity is used to con someone out of cash in Antoni Stultz’s “Rushlights.”
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday nationwide.

headline: Movie Listings for June 21-27
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in New York, including film series.
lead_paragraph: Movies

headline: It’s Definitely Not ‘Sesame Street’
abstract: Men connect through their troubles — some not so troubling — in “Bert and Arnie’s Guide to Friendship.”
lead_paragraph: Anna Chlumsky, who is doing great work in the sly HBO series “Veep,” is in the cast of “Bert and Arnie’s Guide to Friendship,” but that doesn’t make this utterly humor-free comedy remotely watchable.

headline: How Injustice Infects Democracy
abstract: Is society fair? The documentary “The Lottery of Birth” examines the issue.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Brooklyn.

headline: Rosneft to Send $60 Billion Worth of Oil to China
abstract: The deal came after China lent the Russian state oil company millions in the last 10 years to complete its trans-Siberian pipeline.
lead_paragraph: The Russian state oil company, Rosneft, intends to sign a major contract to supply China with more than $60 billion of crude oil, a deal that could signal a small shift away from Western Europe toward Asia.

headline: Follow the Leader; He’s Deep in the Pack
abstract: The Mark Turner Quartet, which recently recorded an album for ECM, sounded lean and ready at the Village Vanguard.
lead_paragraph: Leadership in jazz isn’t always as clear-cut as it seems. An ensemble discipline, it often involves hierarchies as a matter of course, but the business of directing energy or driving a narrative can be anybody’s game. That’s worth keeping in mind whenever the conversation turns to the saxophonist Mark Turner, who has been one of the most productive and vital artists of the last dozen years, without releasing his own album in that span.

abstract: A selected guide to indie rock, pop, punk, blues and country performances in the New York area.

abstract: Photography dominates in Maiko Endo’s new film “Kuichisan,” a folk tale told in voice-over.

abstract: A selected guide to performances of classical music in New York and the area.

headline: Sipping and Studying, When the Subject Is Bottled
abstract: In the documentary “Somm,” four men prepare for the test of their lives, studying their evaluation of wine.
lead_paragraph: “Somm,” Jason Wise’s documentary about preparing for the master sommelier exam, is less about wine fetishism than about the fetishism of mastery.

headline: This Week’s Movies: June 21, 2013
abstract: The New York Times movie critics on “World War Z,” “Monsters University” and “A Hijacking.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times movie critics on “World War Z,” “Monsters University” and “A Hijacking.”

abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Dance

headline: For Headquarters and Pirates, a Test of Wills and Wits
abstract: In Tobias Lindholm’s drama “A Hijacking,” tension unfolds between pirates and a shipping company.
lead_paragraph: In “A Hijacking,” his assured, intense second feature, the Danish director Tobias Lindholm turns tedium and frustration into agonizing suspense. Unfolding over a span of weary, stressful months, its action mainly confined to the below-deck parts of a cargo ship and a suite of sterile corporate offices in Denmark, the film is at once a probing psychological case study and a ripped-from-the-headlines exploration of modern sea piracy.

abstract: A selected, critical guide to the visual arts in New York and the region.
lead_paragraph: Art

abstract: A critical guide to plays running in New York, with special note of productions in previews.
lead_paragraph: Theater

headline: Panel Adopts New Rules for Taxi of Tomorrow
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: The vote by the Taxi and Limousine Commission is likely to bring more litigation from cab operators who have opposed the plan, which a judge blocked last month.
lead_paragraph: One month after a judge blocked the Bloomberg administration’s initial plans for a near-uniform fleet of yellow cabs, the Taxi and Limousine Commission on Thursday approved an adjusted set of rules in a bid to introduce its Taxi of Tomorrow as scheduled this fall.

headline: These Dead Don’t Walk. They Run.
abstract: The love-scare affair with zombies is exploited yet again in “World War Z,” with Brad Pitt as the hero trying to save the world as well as his family.
lead_paragraph: I know what some of you are thinking. Zombie apocalypse? Really? Again? But if you start complaining about the lack of originality in summer movies, honestly, when will you stop? (The answer in my case is Labor Day or cocktail hour.) And in many ways, when compared with “Man of Steel,” “Iron Man 3” and “Star Trek: OMG Ricardo Montalbán!,” “World War Z” is pretty refreshing.

headline: Lawmakers Approve Use of Lever Voting Machines for Fall’s Mayoral Voting
abstract: As part of the legislation, lawmakers also agreed to delay a runoff, which will occur if no candidate receives 40 percent of the vote in the primary, by one week.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Acknowledging that New York City election officials say they cannot count votes cast on electronic machines fast enough to smoothly administer this year’s mayoral election, the State Legislature on Thursday night voted to allow the city to redeploy its old lever voting machines.

headline: Spare Times for June 21-27
abstract: A listings of walking tours, street fairs, discussions and other cultural events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Midsummer Night Swing (Tuesday through July 13) Dancing feet will fill Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center for the season opener of this alfresco series, which is celebrating its 25th anniversary. The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra with Wynton Marsalis, which has its own silver anniversary this year, will provide the big-band music for the evening.

headline: Spare Times for Children for June 21-27
abstract: A guide to cultural events in New York City for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘Geppetto’

headline: New Light Fixture for a Famous Rotunda
abstract: James Turrell’s nearly hallucinatory play of light and color makes the Guggenheim Museum’s rotunda a meditative spectacle.
lead_paragraph: James Turrell’s exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum will probably be the bliss-out environmental art hit of the summer. This is primarily because of the ravishing “Aten Reign,” an immense, elliptical, nearly hallucinatory play of light and color that makes brilliant use of the museum’s famed rotunda and ocular skylight. The latest site-specific effort from Mr. Turrell, “Aten Reign” is close to oxymoronic: a meditative spectacle.

headline: For American Heroes, a Poke in the Eye
abstract: “Llyn Foulkes,” at the New Museum, is a retrospective of one of American art’s great originals.
lead_paragraph: “Where Did I Go Wrong?” asks the title of a 1991 painted and collaged work by Llyn Foulkes. It’s what Clark Kent is wondering in the work, as with furrowed brow he reads a newspaper with a banner headline blaring “War!” over news of the outbreak of the Persian Gulf war. Rendered as a cartoon cutout, Clark sits on a bulbous rock formation in a desolate Western landscape, his shirt open to reveal his Superman costume.

headline: A Complicated Actor Who Made a Complicated Mob Boss Indelible
abstract: Tony Soprano, the role that vaulted James Gandolfini to fame, became a totemic figure not because he was so special, but because he could be so ordinary.
lead_paragraph: “I feel like I came in at the end of something great,” Tony Soprano told his therapist in the first episode of “The Sopranos,” the series that turned a little-known actor named James Gandolfini into the definitive postmodern mob boss.

headline: Mourning the Loss of a Star as He Was Preparing to Return to HBO
abstract: James Gandolfini’s death came just as he was set to return to HBO in “Criminal Justice,” a mini-series that executives were prepared to convert to a regular series if it caught on.
lead_paragraph: It might have been one of the most talked about television events in recent years: James Gandolfini was coming home to HBO in a new series, his first since his indelible portrayal of the mob boss Tony Soprano on “The Sopranos.”

headline: The East Coast of California
abstract: Exhibitions documenting West Coast artists and art movements — Conceptualism, Ken Price, Llyn Foulkes and James Turrell — are hitting New York.
lead_paragraph: OVER six months in 2011 and 2012, dozens of art institutions in Southern California joined forces in a festival of exhibitions, “Pacific Standard Time,” celebrating the history of contemporary art in Los Angeles. The project was a big success and continues to generate energy. A jolt of it hits New York City this week in an unheard-of convergence here of major California shows.

headline: From Tony Soprano to Chris Christie
abstract: Like the governor, James Gandolfini spoke to his home state through the magnetic torment of his persona.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — THE first time I saw James Gandolfini on the screen, as the comically pathetic heavy called “Bear” in the film “Get Shorty,” I felt a flash of recognition. There was something familiar about the weakness and vulnerability he carried with him beneath his bullying, macho airs. The hurt in his eyes hurt me to look at it. I later learned that we had grown up at the same time not far from each other in suburban Bergen County, N.J. On summer afternoons in the 1960s, my mother used to drop a friend and me off at the movie theater in Westwood, Mr. Gandolfini’s birthplace.

headline: Shopping for Ideas in a Star’s Basement
abstract: The playwright Jonathan Tolins explains how he conceived “Buyer & Cellar,” his play about an underemployed actor working in a basement on Barbra Streisand’s estate.

headline: Xbox Reversal Won’t Stop the Inevitable
abstract: Microsoft on Wednesday reversed a couple of controversial policies about how its new Xbox One game console will operate, both of which would probably have slammed the brakes on the used games business. But that business is likely to fade away anyway as the industry shifts toward digital downloads.
lead_paragraph: It seemed like a spectacular flip-flop: Microsoft on Wednesday reversed a couple of controversial policies about how its new Xbox One game console will operate, both of which would probably have slammed the brakes on the used games business.

abstract: Bicycles, the preferred means of travel, are clogging streets and overwhelming parking spaces in Amsterdam, causing some to say the unthinkable: There are too many bikes.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — About 6:30 weekday mornings, throngs of bicycles, with a smattering of motor scooters and pedestrians, pour off the ferries that carry bikers and other passengers free of charge across the IJ (pronounced “eye”) harbor, clogging the streets and causing traffic jams down behind Amsterdam’s main train station.

headline: Jagr’s Cup Pursuit Keeps Fans in Prague Awake

lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — In the waning hours of a warm and muggy night, sports fans here indulged in two favorite pastimes: watching hockey and consuming some of the world’s finest beer.

headline: Czech Premier Candidate Seen as Honest but Inexperienced

lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — Miroslava Nemcova, the governing party’s candidate to become the next prime minister of the Czech Republic, is a former bookshop owner who has never held a ministerial position, but has a reputation for moral rectitude and can restore confidence in the scandal-hit nation, analysts said Thursday.

headline: A Top Pitcher’s Workload Comes Under Scrutiny
abstract: Tar Heels coaches have been accused of jeopardizing Kent Emanuel’s pro future since North Carolina used him in relief in an N.C.A.A. game two days after he threw 124 pitches in a start.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — A healthy breeze rustled the trees at Boys Town — yes, that Boys Town — as North Carolina pitcher Kent Emanuel signed autographs for young fans near the team bus. Coach Mike Fox likes to practice at Boys Town when the Tar Heels play in the College World Series so players see and learn about the famed home for at-risk youth founded almost a century ago.

keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Federal Trade Commission investigation into the practices of “patent trolls” is necessary because there is little real evidence about the costs and benefits of a rising tide of patent litigation, Edith Ramirez, the F.T.C. chairwoman, said on Thursday.

headline: Stern Skeptical of Proposal to Send Rivers to Clippers

lead_paragraph: A proposed deal that would allow Doc Rivers to leave the Boston Celtics for the Los Angeles Clippers — with players and draft picks changing teams as part of the transaction — violates N.B.A. rules, Commissioner David Stern said in a radio interview Thursday.

headline: Nearing One Year In, Egypt’s Leader Is Besieged by Critics
abstract: As the first anniversary of Mohamed Morsi’s inauguration as president approaches, he faces widespread discontent and grass-roots campaigns that have undermined his ability to wield power.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Across Egypt, angry crowds have barred President Mohamed Morsi’s appointees from their offices, millions have signed petitions calling for his ouster and work crews have fortified the headquarters of the Muslim Brotherhood that propelled him to power to prevent attacks the police have failed to stop.

headline: Collision Over the House Farm Bill
keywords: ['Farm Bill (US)', 'Food Stamps', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: A fight over the $20.5 billion cut in the food stamps program led to a stunning defeat for Speaker John Boehner.
lead_paragraph: The House’s rejection of the farm bill by a 195 to 234 vote on Thursday was a stunning defeat for Speaker John Boehner, who supported the legislation and brought it to the House floor for a vote. Mr. Boehner was unable to win support from 62 Republicans on the party’s conservative fringe, who cast no votes because they believed the $20.5 billion cut in the food stamps program did not go deep enough. Nearly all Democrats also voted no because that draconian cut would have eliminated food assistance for nearly two million people.

headline: Checking Out
abstract: The main factor in workplace discontent is not wages, benefits or hours, but the boss. And the grumpiest, least happy workers are college graduates and baby boomers.
lead_paragraph: In my younger and more vulnerable years I labored for a time in the lard-steamed back room of a Kentucky Fried Chicken outlet, well before the chain was re-branded under the flag of KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut. As assistant night manager, I learned that no wing, drumstick, breast or thigh, no matter how much contact it had with the floor, could not be redeemed as presentable extra-crispy through the wonders of the fryer.

headline: My Abortion, at 23 Weeks
abstract: Second-trimester abortions must remain legal because critical information about fetal health is often not available before then.
lead_paragraph: KIRKLAND, Wash. — I BELIEVE that parenthood starts before conception, at the moment you decide you want a child, and are ready and able to create a safe and loving home for her or him. I support abortion rights, but I reject the false distinction between the terms “pro-choice” and “pro-life.” Here’s why.

headline: Profits Without Production
abstract: So what’s really different about American economy in the 21st century?
lead_paragraph: One lesson from recent economic troubles has been the usefulness of history. Just as the crisis was unfolding, the Harvard economists Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff — who unfortunately became famous for their worst work — published a brilliant book with the sarcastic title “This Time Is Different.” Their point, of course, was that there is a strong family resemblance among crises. Indeed, historical parallels — not just to the 1930s, but to Japan in the 1990s, Britain in the 1920s, and more — have been vital guides to the present.

headline: Judges Order California to Free Prisoners
abstract: A panel of federal judges ordered the state to begin plans to release inmates from its overcrowded prisons, but Gov. Jerry Brown has fought court orders in recent months.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Continuing the more than 20-year battle over California prisons, a panel of federal judges ordered the state on Thursday to immediately begin plans to release inmates from its overcrowded prisons.

headline: How the U.S. Got Broadband Right
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Maintaining a restrained regulatory approach is the only way to continue momentum in broadband innovation.
lead_paragraph: AS senators consider President Obama’s nomination of Tom Wheeler to lead the Federal Communications Commission, some observers have painted a dire picture of the state of Internet availability in America. One legal scholar, Susan Crawford, has argued that “prices are too high and speeds are too slow,” though she supports Mr. Wheeler, a venture capitalist and former telecommunications lobbyist. Other critics have called for new government policies to “fix” the telecommunications industry.

headline: In Ali’s Voice From the Past, a Stand for the Ages

lead_paragraph: I woke up Thursday morning and heard a familiar voice that I thought was part of a dream: Muhammad Ali was discussing why he had refused to be inducted into the Army.

lead_paragraph: A half-century ago, 14 percent of college degrees were awarded to people who majored in the humanities. Today, only 7 percent of graduates in the country are humanities majors. Even over the last decade alone, the number of incoming students at Harvard who express interest in becoming humanities majors has dropped by a third.

headline: The Fed’s Next Move
abstract: Recent statements from the Federal Reserve about the state of the economy were quite optimistic. Maybe too optimistic.
lead_paragraph: The recent announcements by the Federal Reserve have generated huge interest — and, on Wall Street, a sell-off costing the Dow Jones industrial average more than 500 points in two days. Only six weeks ago, the Fed was talking about continued “downside risks to the economic outlook.” On Wednesday, however, it said these risks had diminished since last fall, and that it expected further improvement to drive the jobless rate down to 7 percent by mid-2014, at which point it would end its stimulative bond-buying programs.

The Heat, the N.B.A.’s defending champions, won 27 consecutive games at one point in the regular season and reached the finals for the third straight year with the familiar assortment of furious dunks and heady passes by LeBron James, some deft plays from Dwyane Wade, some strong perimeter offense from Bosh and plenty of 3-pointers from a plethora of role players, including Ray Allen.

Reporters followed breathlessly, evoking comparisons to the pursuit of O. J. Simpson by the police in 1994.

headline: Gyula Horn, Who Helped Part Iron Curtain, Dies at 80

headline: Oil Wealth Ebbing, Russia Needs to Lure Foreign Capital

lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — For more than a dozen years, it has been impossible to miss Russia’s soaring, often ostentatious, energy wealth — the flashiness of Moscow, the 250-foot yachts and the hundred-million-dollar penthouse apartments for the children. And the riches have hardly been confined to the private sector. Last year, when Vladimir V. Putin wanted to shore up support ahead of Election Day, the salaries of government workers jumped; military pay actually doubled.

lead_paragraph: The emergency manager assigned to sort out Detroit’s finances called on Thursday for an investigation into possible fraud and mismanagement of the city’s pension funds. Kevyn D. Orr, the manager, called for the investigation by the city’s inspector general and auditor general as city union representatives were unhappily meeting behind closed doors to hear more details of health care provisions Mr. Orr wants them to accept as part of a deal seen as a last chance to keep the city from filing for bankruptcy. The move, if carried out, would be the nation’s largest municipal bankruptcy. Among the city’s myriad financial problems, its pension funds are underfinanced by about $3.5 billion, a spokesman for Mr. Orr said.

headline: Of Songs, Stories and WikiLeaks
abstract: WikiLeaks and the National Security Agency were topics for Laurie Anderson at her shows for the River to River Festival.
lead_paragraph: Two kinds of drone figured in “The Language of the Future,” Laurie Anderson’s two-part, two-night performance for the River to River Festival on Tuesday and Wednesday: “Stories” on Tuesday and “Songs” on Wednesday (though stories and songs were included on both nights). There were the minimalist musical drones — often double-stops bowed on her electric violin — that have been part of her songs since she emerged in the 1980s. And this week, topically, there were airborne drones: a pair of remote-controlled aircraft, like flying black spiders the diameter of a Frisbee, that darted over the audience during part of “Songs” on Wednesday.

headline: What’s on Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:30 P.M. (Cooking) TRIPPING OUT WITH ALIE & GEORGIA Alie Ward and Georgia Hardstark, the Cooking Channel’s “Classy Ladies,” embark for points of debauchery — first stop, Las Vegas, fueled by absinthe — in their latest foray into cocktail wizardry. They’re inventive, yes, as they recreate drinks and nibbles for post-travel parties back home. But nothing can top the McNuggetini, the potion that made them famous: vanilla vodka shaken with a chocolate milkshake, poured into a martini glass rimmed with barbecue sauce and adorned with a Chicken McNugget. Or, “dinner, dessert and booze in one chalice of multitasking,” Ms. Ward, above left, with Ms. Hardstark, proclaims in the video that led to their stint as go-to gals for frothy drinks packing a punch. “We’re kind of like dudes in dresses,” Ms. Ward said recently in an interview. “We wear vintage, because you can get away with a lot more when you look like Grandma.”

headline: The Civics of Civility
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Turkish protesters remain mobilized because they have seen their government behave with less decency than they expect of themselves.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — I have two ready answers when I’m asked why I’ve lived in Istanbul all these years. The first is that I’m enamored of the city itself: the history of the skyline, the blue expanse of the Bosporus, my neighborhood of wooden houses along a central promenade. The second is that I admire the civility of everyday life here. I enjoy nodding to people on the street, the animated conversations in the shops, the kindness of locals toward someone who was born elsewhere.

headline: The Unusual, Hidden Tennis Courts of Paris
abstract: Paris is full of unusual tennis courts, you just have to know where to find them.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Searching for court time in Paris? You might be able to book one atop a train station, an Aston Martin dealership (with a view of the Eiffel Tower), a chapel, a fire station, a parking garage a stone’s throw from the Pantheon or even a supermarket. There are also courts on the ground floor if you’re afraid of heights. Paris is a compact city. It can be crisscrossed on bike in under an hour. City planners have had to be creative to squeeze courts into the city’s confines. As a result, there are a host of unique courts packed into the most unusual spaces. Here’s a look at some of the most memorable.

keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Shoplifting and Employee Theft (Retail)']
abstract: Plant infringement.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I love plants. While walking through our local shopping center, we noticed a particular plant that we both liked and decided to get it for our patio. We visited two local garden centers; neither had the plant. My wife thought she could grow it from cuttings, so we went back and took about three or four cuttings from one of the many plants that were scattered around the shopping center. The plant was not hurt or damaged in any manner or form, but my gut instinct told me that this was wrong. Was it? JULIAN SOLOMONS, HUNTINGTON BEACH, CALIF.

headline: Max Brooks Is Not Kidding About the Zombie Apocalypse
abstract: The author of “World War Z” may be the son of the master of parody, but he is deadly serious about the undead.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve never seen a zombie movie where someone drank from a puddle and died of explosive diarrhea.”

headline: Who Made That T-Shirt Cannon?
abstract: The coyote mascot who pushed past the “slingshot era.”
lead_paragraph: “It weighed 90 pounds, including the tanks,” says Tim Derk of the T-shirt cannon he helped invent when he worked as the Coyote mascot for the San Antonio Spurs in the 1990s. “It was like carrying a TV set on your back. The gun was probably at least four feet long. It used a cast-iron pipe — the kind that goes into the floor underneath your commode. It just weighed a ton.” Of course, someone else might have tried the stunt before Derk, but when he dressed up as “Rambote” — Rambo meets the Spurs’ Coyote — and sprayed the cheap seats with freebies, few sports fans had seen anything like it.

headline: Autopsy on Gandolfini Finds Actor Died of ‘Natural Causes,’ Family Spokesman Says
abstract: Michael Kobold, a spokesman for the Gandolfini family, said an autopsy on the actor “stated he died of a heart attack, of natural causes.”
lead_paragraph: 11:14 a.m. | Updated

headline: Portrait of the Musician as a Young Reader
abstract: The drummer Questlove on the reading material that shaped his childhood.
lead_paragraph: The drummer Ahmir Thompson, better known as Questlove, a co-founder of the Roots, has written many times about the formative music in his life. Now that he’s an author — of the recently published memoir “Mo’ Meta Blues” — I was curious about what reading material shaped his childhood.

headline: Pride and Perseverance
abstract: In her centenary year, Barbara Pym’s “spry little domestic novels” command a loyal readership.
lead_paragraph: Out to lunch with a friend one day in 1969, the British novelist Barbara Pym was doing what she always did — gathering details of the life around her as if they were jewels dropped in her path by a generous deity. “Why aren’t more of these elderly ladies wearing canvas shoes?” she scribbled in her ever-present notebook. “In the restaurant all those clergymen helping themselves from the cold table, it seems endlessly.” Then she stopped abruptly. “But you mustn’t notice things like that if you’re going to be a novelist in 1968-9 and the 70s,” she scolded herself. “The posters on Oxford Circus Station advertising Confidential Pregnancy Tests would be more suitable.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WHAT DO WOMEN WANT?: Adventures in the Science of Female Desire,  by Daniel Bergner. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $25.99.) When it comes to the study of women’s sexuality, Bergner writes, there are fewer established facts than you would think.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE ART FORGER,  by B. A. Shapiro. (Algonquin, $14.95.) In 1990, 13 works of art were looted from a Boston museum, including a Rembrandt, a Vermeer and several sketches by Degas. Shapiro’s nimble mystery revisits this brazen theft: more than two decades on, a stolen Degas painting seems to resurface and Claire Roth, a talented yet struggling artist, is lured into reproducing the long-missing masterpiece.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: For the title character of his new novel, “Bad Monkey,” which is No. 3 on the hardcover fiction list, Carl Hiaasen wanted “sort of a Lindsay Lohan of monkeys.”
lead_paragraph: PRIMATOLOGY: Readers of Carl Hiaasen’s new Florida mystery, “Bad Monkey” — it enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 3 — won’t be surprised to learn that there is, in fact, a bad monkey in its pages: Driggs, an animal performer who works on Johnny Depp’s pirate movies until he’s caught masturbating on wigs in the costume trailer. “My vision of the monkey was of a show business monkey that just crashed and burned,” Hiaasen said on NPR recently. “Sort of a Lindsay Lohan of monkeys.” He added that he was struck by pop culture’s recent turn toward the simian: “In every movie it seems you go to now, and TV sitcoms and everywhere you look, there’s sort of a gratuitous monkey,” he said. “I wanted a monkey with a back story.”

headline: Charged Images
abstract: Alongside painters like Julian Schnabel and David Salle, Eric Fischl came of age in the frenzied New York art world of the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: When a supposed friend and collector tells the painter-art star Eric Fischl: “You’ve got to face it, man. You didn’t make the cut” — meaning that after rocketing to the top in the art boom of the 1980s, his prices aren’t holding in the ’90s, he’s no longer one of the artists who matter — I felt sucker-­punched myself. Fischl says the collector was just being matter-of-fact, but really? One of the many reasons to read “Bad Boy” (written with Michael Stone) is how vividly it recreates the precariousness and ambivalences of life in the upper tiers of the international art world. But the collector’s jab also alerts us that it’s a rise-and-fall story we’ve been reading, not just a jolly succession of triumphs.

headline: Legend Retold
abstract: An unfinished poem by J. R. R. Tolkien explores the tale of King Arthur.
lead_paragraph: Even in its fragmentary and unfinished form — about 40 pages of text, a bit more than four cantos of what was evidently intended to be a much longer narrative poem — “The Fall of Arthur” is recognizably the work of J. R. R. Tolkien, veteran of the Great War and future author of “The Lord of the Rings.” This is an incomplete but highly compelling retelling of perhaps the most famous and familiar legend in the British tradition, a retelling the author’s son and literary executor, Christopher Tolkien, believes was begun in the early 1930s and abandoned by 1937. Perhaps not coincidentally, that was the year “The Hobbit” was published, offering readers their first glimpse of a fantasy universe that would shape the imaginative life of the 20th century and beyond.

headline: Just Around the Corner
abstract: A looming civil war threatens to engulf the multiethnic Sri Lankan street of Ru Freeman’s novel.
lead_paragraph: Before reading this rich, sensory novel, my literary familiarity with Sri Lanka came mostly from Michael Ondaatje’s rollicking memoir, “Running in the Family.” But it was enough of an introduction, with all its extravagant, hilarious dysfunctions, to pique my interest in the island nation. Ru Freeman’s assured second novel is a much quieter yet rewarding portrait of a community of families on a dead-end road in Colombo, the country’s capital. They are a mixed lot on Sal Mal Lane: Sinhalese, Tamils and Burghers, descendants of European colonizers. Down this road live the comfortably middle class and the dirt poor; the sick, the heartbroken and viciously prejudiced; youngsters vivacious with talent, or misshapen by abuse; and a few residents in their middle and later years who are roused by the arrival of the Heraths, a family with four lively children.

headline: The Beloved Country
abstract: In this memoir, an Afghan family’s attempts to escape the horrors of war show them new ways of seeing their world.
lead_paragraph: In 1992, when the mujahedeen arrived in Kabul, young Qais Akbar Omar “expected to see heroes in uniforms and shiny boots.” Instead, the Holy Warriors had “beards, mustaches and smelly shoes that wrapped up stinky feet.” Omar’s father and grandfather were hopeful, but the liberation was short-lived. Soon, fighting broke out across the city. “It was like when a forest catches fire,” Omar writes; “both the dry and the wet burn.” The family retreated to their basement before the onslaught of rockets and snipers forced them to abandon their home altogether. Piling into their Volga, Omar and his mother, father, three sisters, baby brother, two aunts and seven cousins set out for safer ground.

headline: Natural Lawyer
abstract: Robert P. George argues against liberal secularism.
lead_paragraph: Most of us live our partisan politics through the media, which generally means cross-firing tweets, posts and cable news shows about the latest scandal as interpreted by a rotating stable of Washington strategists, party faithfuls and pundits. But behind the klieg lights, there has always been a less topical, more abstract debate between liberal and conservative academics and philosophers about the nature of human flourishing and the political and social institutions that best promote it.

headline: Bless the Borrowers
abstract: Robert Kuttner champions the cause of indebted students, families and states.
lead_paragraph: Robert Kuttner’s title refers, first, to the “medieval institution” that was the fate of improvident souls in England who could not repay their debts, including Daniel Defoe. In 1692, Defoe was committed to King’s Bench Prison in London, where he began to agitate for a change in the legal system. Forcing debtors to rot, Defoe not disinterestedly pointed out, was injurious to both parties, since “after a debtor was confined in prison both he and the creditor lost through his prolonged distress.” Society responded, eventually, with bankruptcy laws, but it is very much Kuttner’s point in “Debtors’ Prison” that we — America and Europe in the age of the financial crisis — have yet to absorb the principal lesson of Defoe’s “bitter experience.”

headline: When Two Paths Meet
abstract: In Michelle de Kretser’s novel, a Sri Lankan and an Australian seem destined to connect.
lead_paragraph: Deploying flatulence as a plot device takes nerve. Chaucer got away with it in “The Miller’s Tale,” thanks to the bawdy, rowdy nature of the story. In her ambitious new novel, “Questions of Travel,” the Sri Lankan-Australian novelist Michelle de Kretser gets away with it too, when her main characters, Ravi and Laura, finally have an encounter that seems like a prelude to some greater connection — or at least a reckoning or revelation. But the moment passes with Ravi’s gas. This willful non-event is the culmination of de Kretser’s cool play with conventional reader expectations about how much, and how meaningfully, two disparate lives should matter to each other when they finally converge after pages and pages of parallel-track narratives.

headline: Do as I Say
abstract: An 18th-century Englishman tried to train a submissive spouse.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, it would seem that Wendy Moore, a lively English journalist and social historian, has written an account of Victor Frankenstein’s reluctant endeavors to present his monster with the wife the lonely creature so desperately craves. Not so. Moore’s extraordinary subject is the compellingly repellent historical figure Thomas Day, a children’s book writer and ardent abolitionist.

headline: Illiberal Arts
abstract: What’s the point of college? Two books consider the question from different perspectives.
lead_paragraph: More than a century ago, the president of Harvard, A. Lawrence Lowell, issued a warning to America’s colleges and universities. “Institutions,” he said, “are rarely murdered. They meet their end by suicide. . . . They die because they have outlived their usefulness, or fail to do the work that the world wants done.” Most of the institutions he had in mind are still around today, but the doomsday talk is back. William J. Bennett, secretary of education under President Reagan, and Jeffrey Selingo, an editor at The Chronicle of Higher Education, believe our system is self-­destructing. Their tones are different — Bennett and his co-author, David Wilezol, write in an expectant mood of good riddance, while Selingo is sympathetically alarmed — but their views are grimly consistent. College costs are up. Learning and graduation rates are down.

headline: Natural Born Killers
abstract: A criminologist examines the biological roots of violence, and argues that “the seeds of sin are brain-based.”
lead_paragraph: The Italian criminologist Cesare Lombroso makes for an unlikely hero. In the late 1800s, Lombroso proposed that criminals were evolutionary throwbacks who could be identified by primitive features like sloping foreheads and large jaws, and he went on to posit an evolutionary hierarchy of the races, with northern Italians at its apex. Such ideas inspired Mussolini’s racial laws in the 1930s, and are at the core of some of the ugliest social movements of our time.

headline: Inside Story
abstract: The second installment of Karl Ove Knausgaard’s six-volume autobiographical novel.
lead_paragraph: Why would you read a six-­volume, 3,600-page Norwegian novel about a man writing a six-­volume, 3,600-page Norwegian novel? The short answer is that it is breathtakingly good, and so you cannot stop yourself, and would not want to.

headline: Annus Mirabilis
abstract: From Chinese economic reform to the Iranian revolution, Christian Caryl sees 1979 as a crucial doorway into the present era.
lead_paragraph: If Christian Caryl had set out to write a book about 1968, showing how the many convulsions and uprisings of that astonishing year were connected, his task would have been an easy one. It might be difficult to prove cause and effect between, say, the May events in Paris and the chaos at the Democratic convention in August, but as people might have said at the time, something was in the air. It wasn’t mere coincidence that led to youth revolts all over the world. In the case of 1989, such connections are even more obvious.

headline: How Crowdfunding Worked for One Timely Start-Up
abstract: Kara Gorski and Kristin Gembala turned to a crowdfunding platform to raise $10,000 to begin manufacturing a small run of their product — “reconstructed bras for reconstructed girls.”
lead_paragraph: Last fall, I wrote a post about the crowdfunding campaign of a start-up known as braGGs. The company, based in Alexandria, Va., has developed a patent-pending bra for women who have had reconstructive breast surgery — “reconstructed bras for reconstructed girls,” as the Web site puts it.

headline: What I Love | Rick Elice and Roger Rees
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Theater', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The couple share a duplex in Emery Roth’s storied masterwork the Beresford, on Central Park West.
lead_paragraph: The couple share a duplex in Emery Roth’s storied masterwork the Beresford, on Central Park West.

headline: Upstairs at the Beresford
abstract: Rick Elice, the co-librettist of “Jersey Boys,” and the actor Roger Rees live in a memento-filled apartment on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: When the actor Roger Rees and the playwright Rick Elice became a couple in 1982, work kept them in separate cities: first London, then Los Angeles for Mr. Rees, New York for Mr. Elice. Jet lag was chronic, the frequent-flier miles many.

headline: Farm Bill’s Fate in House Bodes Ill for Immigration Reform
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Farm Bill (US)', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The Senate and House are set on disparate trajectories that may well linger beyond this Congress, and could be a dark harbinger for immigration legislation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The story of the 113th Congress was on display during a single afternoon this week.

headline: ‘Despair’
abstract: A clip from the Yeah Yeah Yeahs new song, "Despair," which was shot on the observation deck of the Empire State Building.
lead_paragraph: A clip from the Yeah Yeah Yeahs new song, "Despair," which was shot on the observation deck of the Empire State Building.

abstract: This week, Andrew Delbanco discusses two new books about the state of higher education; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Andrew O’Hehir talks about “The Fall of Arthur,” by J. R. R. Tolkien; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Andrew Delbanco discusses two new books about the state of higher education; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Andrew O’Hehir talks about “The Fall of Arthur,” by J. R. R. Tolkien; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: The Fork Less Taken
abstract: The North Fork of Long Island is designed by nature for exquisite sunsets and private contemplation.
lead_paragraph: The North Fork of Long Island is designed by nature for exquisite sunsets and private contemplation.

headline: On the North Fork, the Un-Hamptons
abstract: It’s an underdog and wallflower compared to its overhyped neighbor to the south, but alluring for its own vistas and virtues.
lead_paragraph: Around 75 miles east of New York City, just past the “Rip van Winkle” revival unfolding in somnolent Riverhead, the Long Island Expressway ends in a blaze of commercial glory at the Tanger Outlets. Soon after that, Long Island succumbs to a severe case of geological split personality and sprouts an intriguing pair of sibling peninsulas. Naturally there’s a bit of a rivalry.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The State of Higher Education
abstract: This week, Andrew Delbanco, Julie Bosman, Andrew O’Hehir and Gregory Cowles.
lead_paragraph: This week, Andrew Delbanco, Julie Bosman, Andrew O’Hehir and Gregory Cowles.

headline: One Coalition Partner Quits Greek Government
abstract: The Democratic Left party withdrew to protest Prime Minister Antonis Samaras’s closure of the state broadcaster, dealing a serious blow to the fragile three-way coalition.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greece’s fragile three-way coalition was dealt a serious blow on Friday, the anniversary of its creation, when its smallest party withdrew to protest Prime Minister Antonis Samaras’s shutdown of the state broadcaster, the latest in a series of unilateral decisions that have enraged his partners in government.

headline: Summer Shows Its Stripes, Woven in Orange, Green and Brown
abstract: Colorful umbrellas have been fixtures of the shoreline on Long Island since Franklin Delano Roosevelt was governor of New York.
lead_paragraph: As the pasty hordes descend on Jones Beach on Long Island for the first weekend of summer, rentals of umbrellas, striped in the traditional orange, green and brown, will suddenly shoot into high demand. For the park, the umbrellas are a modest side business, in place since its Jazz Age opening. For beachgoers, they are a $10 concession to worried mothers and lecturing dermatologists, a bright buffer from the blazing summer sun.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Grading Higher Education
abstract: This week, Andrew Delbanco discusses “Is College Worth It?” and “College (Un)bound.”
lead_paragraph: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Andrew Delbanco reviews two new books about the state of higher education in the United States. Mr. Delbanco writes:

headline: Reasons to Get a Flu Shot
abstract: The flu vaccine is far from 100 percent effective, but researchers have calculated that over the past six years it has prevented millions of illnesses and tens of thousands of hospitalizations.
lead_paragraph: The flu vaccine is far from 100 percent effective, but researchers have calculated that over the past six years it has prevented millions of illnesses and tens of thousands of hospitalizations.
