abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss this year’s Bonnaroo music festival.
lead_paragraph: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss this year’s Bonnaroo music festival.

headline: The Farmers’ Market: Strawberries
abstract: Strawberries are in season at the farmers’ market. Here’s a list of recipes starring these juicy red gems.
lead_paragraph: Strawberries are now in abundance at the farmers’ market. Here are ideas for ways to use them beyond rinsing and popping directly in your mouth (nothing wrong with that).

headline: Remembering James Gandolfini, Remembering Staten Island
abstract: James Gandolfini’s portrayal of Tony Soprano fed stereotypes of Italian-American culture.
lead_paragraph: The first thing I did after hearing the news of the death of James Gandolfini, who died suddenly Wednesday in Italy at age 51, was eat a bowl of shredded wheat. Then I spent 30 minutes on the treadmill. While I was on the treadmill, I thought about Anthony Salvio.

headline: Working to Revive a Movie House That Lived in a Palace
abstract: A nonprofit organization is conducting a fund-raising campaign to help it show films at the United Palace Cathedral in Washington Heights.

headline: The Gun Report: June 21, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: “So, Heidi,” began the email to Heidi Yewman from Michele Kort, her editor at Ms. Magazine. “I wanted to let you know that, in the comments to the gun-nut post below, someone put your address out there. I’ve been super careful NOT to approve any comments that mentioned where you might live.”

headline: S.E.C. Has a Message for Firms Not Used to Admitting Guilt
abstract: By requiring an admission of guilt in some cases, the S.E.C.’s new chairwoman is pressing for more accountability at financial firms.
lead_paragraph: The days of cop-out settlements in big securities cases may be waning.

headline: In Harlem, Looking for Something Not Hotel-Like
abstract: After living out of a suitcase for six years, Esther Joy Stilwell hoped to buy a large apartment that felt like home.
lead_paragraph: As a singer and actress, Esther Joy Stilwell lived out of a suitcase for six years. After her graduation from the University of Oklahoma, she performed throughout the world, touring in “Cats” and Monty Python’s “Spamalot.”

headline: Happy to Be a Puppet
abstract: Sara Mearns, a principal in the New York City Ballet, is a passionate fan of the New York Philharmonic; one of the attractions of “A Dancer’s Dream” was the chance to perform ballet with the power of the full orchestra behind her.
lead_paragraph: Is being an artist a gift or a curse? That question is at the heart of “A Dancer’s Dream,” a sinister and whimsical reimagining of two Stravinsky works, “The Fairy’s Kiss” and “Petrushka,” in which a young woman is blessed (or is it burdened?) by the realization that she is a ballerina.

headline: Animated Family Fun in Macao
abstract: If you see Shrek wandering a resort in Macao, the Las Vegas of Asia, don’t be surprised.
lead_paragraph: If you see Shrek wandering a resort in Macao, don’t be surprised. The Las Vegas of Asia, as it’s often called, is poised to expand its appeal beyond serious gamblers to families with the July opening of the new DreamWorks Experience at Cotai Strip Resorts.

headline: Learning to Spot Frailty
abstract: Six medical groups urge that doctors routinely evaluate older patients for frailty.
lead_paragraph: Doctors should screen all adults over age 70 for frailty, a medical syndrome that affects 5 percent to 10 percent of people in this age group, according to a new consensus statement from six international medical organizations.

headline: After Adversity, a Passion Unchecked
abstract: The violinist Rachel Barton Pine, known for her bravura technique and musical range, has overcome enormous hurdles since a 1995 accident.
lead_paragraph: Asked by a student about her musical inspirations after a recent Baroque master class at Juilliard, the violinist Rachel Barton Pine gestured toward the stickers of heavy metal bands plastered on her violin case. “When they’re onstage, they’re getting everyone headbanging,” she said. “Within classical music my goal is to do the same thing, to give 150 percent and get everyone caught up in the emotions.”

headline: Sprint May Be Off the Table, but Dish’s Deal Appetite May Remain
abstract: What will the Dish deal maker Charles Ergen do next? One option may be going after the newly enlarged T-Mobile US. Another move may be a partnership or alliance with a wireless service provider.
lead_paragraph: Charles W. Ergen is regarded as one of the wiliest negotiators in the business world. But in a little over a week, Mr. Ergen, chairman of the Dish Network, has been dealt two tough hands, one at Sprint Nextel and the other at Clearwire.

headline: He Likes His Horror Personal and Global
abstract: “Under the Dome,” a new CBS TV series based on Stephen King’s thriller about a town trapped by alien or supernatural means, is inspired by some real-life locales and his own environmental worries.
lead_paragraph: LOVELL, Maine — Rosie’s General Store serves breakfast all day, and it’s the type of place where residents of this town of 1,140 will stop in to buy lottery tickets, a loaf of bread or the special jumbo lobster roll. It’s also the inspiration for the Sweetbriar Rose, a diner in Stephen King’s 2009 opus about a small town cut off from the outside world by a mysterious and impenetrable dome.

headline: European Ministers Agree to Stricter Tobacco Laws
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Menthol', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Under an agreement struck by European Union ministers, cigarette packs would have bigger health warnings and menthol cigarettes would be banned.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Cigarette packs in Europe would have to carry bigger health warnings, and cigarettes with menthol or other flavorings face a total ban, under an agreement that European Union ministers struck on Friday after spirited negotiations.

headline: Video: Yeah Yeah Yeahs Perform Atop Empire State Building
keywords: ['Empire State Building (Manhattan, NY)', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: The landmark for the first time welcomed an indie rock band to perform on its observation deck to make a music video.
lead_paragraph: In its 82-year history, the top of the Empire State Building has been the site of countless family outings, marriage proposals and, of course, one very memorable date gone awry. But as near as we can tell, it had never been the site of an indie rock performance, not a preapproved one anyway.

headline: Beyond Tony Soprano
abstract: James Gandolfini’s memorable movie performances suggested a great film career in the making.
lead_paragraph: James Gandolfini’s memorable movie performances suggested a great film career in the making.

headline: Touring, the ‘Wyoming Way’
abstract: WYOamericana Caravan, a 14-date swing through the heart of the rugged American West featuring three Wyoming bands, reflects a new trend of bands’ pooling their resources and nurturing an online fan base.
lead_paragraph: BOISE, Idaho — The pounding on his cargo-van doors started as soon as Jalan Crossland’s head hit the pillow. After a thousand miles of rough road and his fifth straight night onstage, the bone-tired banjo man had kicked off his boots and collapsed on the mattress in his old Dodge 3500 outside Pengilly’s, the saloon here where he and his fellow musicians had jammed well into the early morning.

headline: Just Another Career Criminal Writer
abstract: Ann Biderman is the creator of the new series “Ray Donovan.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On a set so authentically dressed to resemble a boxing gym that you could almost smell the mildewed towels, a man on the floor was howling in pain as two burly-looking goons dragged him by the ankles. Anyone familiar with the work of Ann Biderman, the creator of the series being shot, “Ray Donovan,” would instantly recognize that the scene incorporated three of her favorite subjects: violence, Los Angeles and thugs.

headline: Not Too Young for the Blues
abstract: The teenage blues phenom Quinn Sullivan has a new album, “Getting There,” and is preparing to go on tour.
lead_paragraph: If you ask Buddy Guy who embodies the future of blues guitar, he will point to a 14-year-old boy from Massachusetts named Quinn Sullivan. “Remember that name,” Mr. Guy said in a recent interview. “He sounds like Eric Clapton, B. B. King, me, Hendrix, everybody, man!”

headline: Mediobanca’s Stake Sales Are a Hopeful Sign for Italy
abstract: After nearly seven decades of playing the puppet master of Italian capitalism, the merchant bank that Enrico Cuccia built has announced an official retreat. It is the end of an era.
lead_paragraph: There are many reasons to worry about Italy’s prospects, but Mediobanca is no longer one.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Monsters University’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Monsters University."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Monsters University."

headline: Summer Bean Salads
abstract: Bean salads are a great choice for summer picnics, and most recipes can easily be adapted to accommodate any vegans in the crowd.
lead_paragraph: Bean salads are a great choice for summer picnics, and most recipes can easily be adapted to accommodate any vegans in the crowd. This week the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman turns to summer bean salads:

headline: Food Network Drops Paula Deen
abstract: The network announced Friday that it would not renew Ms. Deen’s contract at the end of June, after she apologized for using racist language.
lead_paragraph: Paula Deen, the self-proclaimed queen of Southern cooking and a sugary mainstay of the Food Network, was dropped by the network on Friday, after a bewildering day in which she failed to show up for an interview on the “Today” show and then in two online videos begged her family and audience to forgive her for using racist language.

headline: For Episcopal Church’s Leader, a Sermon Leads to More Dissent
keywords: ['Episcopal Church', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Bible']
abstract: Katharine Jefferts Schori, the presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church in the United States, has been criticized for her interpretation of Paul’s actions toward a fortunetelling slave girl.
lead_paragraph: Curaçao, the Dutch island off the Venezuelan coast, is nice this time of year. Actually, it’s nice any time of year. The temperature is in the low 80s and the seawater is nearly as warm. It must be a nice place to give a sermon. But for Katharine Jefferts Schori, since 2006 the presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church in the United States, memories of Curaçao will always be associated with the controversy that greeted her upon her return — another controversy in what has already been a rocky tenure as the head of a troubled, shrinking church.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Gettysburg, Pa; Quebec
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Gettysburg 150th, Pennsylvania The Gettysburg 150th anniversary commemoration will observe the Battle of Gettysburg for 10 days from June 28 through July 7 in Gettysburg, Pa. Some 400 events focused on the Civil War are on the schedule: battle re-enactments featuring horse-drawn cannons and cavalrymen on horseback, soldier encampments, living history programs and special tours and exhibitions, including the opening of the Seminary Ridge Museum. Visitors can walk in the footsteps of Confederate soldiers in the mile-long Pickett’s Charge Commemorative March, led by National Park rangers representing each of the assaulting brigades. Gettysburg College is showing a 15-minute film about the Gettysburg Address throughout the summer, and offering Witness to History, a historical walking tour app of the college and town, both free.

headline: A Lifetime of Changes, From ‘Roommate’ to ‘Spouse’
keywords: ['Love (Emotion)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Baby Boomers', 'Homosexuality']
abstract: A Mariel boat lift refugee and a hairdresser find each other and maintain their relationship for 33 years.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Selling Park Avenue Condos at $250,000 a Minute
abstract: A four-minute film produced to showcase 432 Park Ave., features dreamlike sequences, Philippe Petit on a high-wire, and cost over $1 million to make.
lead_paragraph: Harry B. Macklowe flew an Emmy-award-winning film crew to southern England, hired the famed tightrope walker Philippe Petit and bought the song rights to a Mama Cass classic, all for a four-minute movie to market his latest condominium development.

headline: A 1930 Theater’s Beauty Survives
abstract: A nonprofit group that recently held a film premiere at the United Palace in Washington Heights hopes to turn it into a place for special movie events.
lead_paragraph: A nonprofit group that recently held a film premiere at the United Palace in Washington Heights hopes to turn it into a place for special movie events.

headline: Suzuki Faces Possible Air Bag Recall, Complicated by Bankruptcy
abstract: Suzuki faces a possible recall over air bag malfunctions, but having filed for bankruptcy and saying it would stop selling cars in the United States, its ability to cover for any needed repairs becomes uncertain.
lead_paragraph: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether air bag problems warrant recalling about 205,000 Suzuki vehicles, the 2006-11 Grand Vitara and the 2007-11 SX4, according to a report posted on the safety agency’s Web site.

headline: The Art of the Chosen People
abstract: Jew York, a sweeping exhibition of work by Jewish artists at the Manhattan galleries Zach Feuer and Untitled, has no particular agenda, but does offer lots of laughs.
lead_paragraph: Like New York, the art world has a lot of Jewish people. The sole curatorial theme of “Jew York,” a sweeping joint exhibition at the Zach Feuer Gallery in Chelsea and Untitled on the Lower East Side, is works by the chosen people, but it has no specific agenda beyond that. “I just wanted to put everyone in the room together and see what happens,” Feuer explained, “and not make some grand academic statement about Judaism.” Feuer and Carol Cohen and Joel Mesler of Untitled (all members of the tribe) approached the exhibition in a hands-off way that defied stereotypes about both art-world types and the Jewish people. They simply asked artists to submit whatever work they wished. Of the 100 they approached to participate, only four or five didn’t want to be “outed.” (All happened to be of a certain generation that came to prominence during the 1980s.) Several others responded with the news that they were not, in fact, Jewish.

headline: Ireland’s Turnaround May Not Be So Rosy
abstract: An upturn in economic statistics reflected the relocation to Ireland of British company corporate incorporations — but not the companies themselves — for tax reasons.
lead_paragraph: TWO years ago, even as other troubled European economies continued to deteriorate, some economic statistics seemed to indicate that Ireland’s troubled economy had turned the corner and was growing again.

headline: Video: Slow-Moving Burglar Carries a Cane
abstract: The police are seeking help identifying a man who entered a Fort Greene, Brooklyn, apartment on May 24 but was startled and fled when the resident returned home.
lead_paragraph: The plastic brace on the man’s right foot is trailing straps, and there is a cane in his hand. He takes little steps, and his hip rolls each time he sets down his right foot. There is nothing furtive about the man, whose image was captured by a surveillance camera for a few seconds as he hobbled down a sunlit street in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, one morning last month. So why are the police looking for him?

headline: This Week’s Movies: ‘World War Z,’ ‘Monsters University’ and ‘A Hijacking’
abstract: Times critics on “World War Z,” “Monsters University” and “A Hijacking.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics offer their thoughts on “World War Z,” “Monsters University” and “A Hijacking.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Action on Expanded Gambling as Albany’s Legislative Session Sputters to End
abstract: This year’s session began in January with a burst of activity — the passage of strict new gun laws — but ended with more of a thud.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Lawmakers agreed on Friday night to ask voters to authorize expanded casino gambling across New York State, but planned to end their annual legislative session without approving new measures to combat corruption in the capital.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 21.
abstract: Pictures include a canine graduation at Grand Central Terminal, Sal Albanese in Queens, and workers atop St. Patrick’s Cathedral in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Pictures include a canine graduation at Grand Central Terminal, Sal Albanese in Queens, and workers atop St. Patrick’s Cathedral in Manhattan.

headline: Cecil Taylor Wins the Kyoto Prize
abstract: The influential jazz pianist, as this year’s recipient in the category of Arts and Philosophy, will receive a cash gift of approximately $510,000.
lead_paragraph: The improvising pianist Cecil Taylor, a pioneering, influential and highly experimental musician and a longtime Brooklyn resident, is one of this year’s recipients of the Kyoto Prize, awarded each year by the Inamori Foundation in Japan, the foundation announced on Friday. Mr. Taylor, 84, is this year’s laureate in the category of arts and philosophy; different fields across technology, science, art and philosophy are considered on a rotating basis, and there has been a recipient in music every four years. (The last musician laureate in 2009 was the conductor and composer Pierre Boulez.) The prize comes with a cash gift of 50 million yen (approximately $510,000), to be given at a ceremony in Kyoto in November. This year’s other laureates are the electronics engineer Dr. Robert H. Dennard and the evolutionary biologist Dr. Masatoshi Nei.

headline: The Sweet Spot: ‘Cinematic Kryptonite’
abstract: In this week’s episode, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the sour experience of seeing a movie that’s “not very super.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s episode, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the sour experience of seeing a movie that’s “not very super.”

headline: Disappointing Fall for ‘Rock Center,’ a News Program With Big Ambitions
abstract: The NBC show was an ambitious effort to mimic the breadth of “60 Minutes,” but it never generated much of an audience. Friday was its last night.
lead_paragraph: If “Rock Center With Brian Williams” has proved anything in the last year and a half, it is this: However hard it is to gather an audience for any kind of show in prime time, for news programming, the task is even harder.

headline: S.E.C. to Require Admissions of Guilt
abstract: In some settlement cases, the Securities and Exchange Commission will now demand that defendants go beyond the current “neither admit nor deny” standard.
lead_paragraph: In some settlement cases, the Securities and Exchange Commission will now demand that defendants go beyond the current “neither admit nor deny” standard.

headline: In Europe, a Few Coins for a Wealth of Culture
abstract: During three long weekends in Barcelona, Berlin and Brussels, the Frugal Traveler saw as many performing arts shows as he could. The catch? Each show had to cost less than 20 euros.
lead_paragraph: I figured I might someday take an amibitious cultural jaunt through Europe, catching a classical concert at La Monnaie in Brussels, a musical off Las Ramblas in Barcelona, and cutting-edge dance performances in Berlin — all from the best seats in the house. I just imagined it would have wait until I retired as the Frugal Traveler columnist and retrained as, say, a plastic surgeon to the stars.

headline: A Rinse and a Roll on a River in Nepal
abstract: The Bhote Koshi River can dish out icy lessons in humility, even to experienced kayakers.
lead_paragraph: I will admit that after 25 days of third world travel with my future in-laws, my motives for going off to paddle some difficult white water last year were complex. Yes, I’ve been a kayaker for a decade, and the Bhote Koshi River, which pours down the Tibetan Himalayas into Nepal — rated Class V during high water, but in winter “a classic Class III,” according to one outfitter — appeared to be within my abilities.

headline: North Korean Diplomat Blames United States for Tensions but Calls for Peace Talks
abstract: The North Korea ambassador called sanctions part of an American blackmail policy and urged the United States to accept its offer of direct talks.
lead_paragraph: In a mix of diplomacy and bombast, North Korea’s ambassador to the United Nations called Friday for the United States to accept its recently revived proposal for direct peace talks, even as he blamed the Americans for all tensions on the Korean Peninsula starting with the war more than 60 years ago.

headline: Home-Cooked Challenge: Kids in the Kitchen
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Snack Foods']
abstract: How much can children do in the kitchen, and how can parents help them do more?
lead_paragraph: The Home-Cooked Challenge isn’t about what we’re subtracting from our kitchen — or at least, it shouldn’t be. It’s about what we’re adding. I’ve been focused on what’s not here (snacks and other processed and prepackaged foods) mostly because we turn to those easy alternatives so readily. Unless I took the snack foods out, I knew from experience that we’d keep turning to them.

headline: Weekend Fare
abstract: Food-related events around New York.
lead_paragraph: Ramen, takoyaki (fried octopus) and sushi: those are only some of the foods that will be served during Mitsuwa’s Japanese Gourmet Fair through Sunday. The megamarket, located in Edgewater, N.J., will bring together local vendors and some from Japan who will feature more than 100 products.

headline: Image of the Day: June 21
abstract: A prayer meeting in Jammu and Kashmir for the victims of floods that struck the north Indian state of Uttarakhand.

headline: Oracle and Salesforce: a Data-Sharing Deal
abstract: Two of the fiercest competitors in enterprise software will allow data sharing between their products. It is another sign of how much cloud computing is changing the tech world, and what businesses expect of their suppliers.
lead_paragraph: Some of the best trash-talking in tech may be over. The Oracle Corporation and Salesforce.com, two of the more contentious competitors in software, are about to announce a close alliance involving software delivered via cloud computing.

headline: Catching Grief and Little Else, Goalie Moves On
abstract: Goalie Corey Crawford, who allowed five goals on his glove side Wednesday, drew criticism over his technique but said he did not want to think too much about it before Saturday’s Game 5.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Blackhawks goaltender Corey Crawford faced a crush of news media at his locker Friday afternoon. He spoke in French to reporters from his native Montreal, and then in English. The topic, no matter the language, was the same: his glove.

headline: There’s a Fly in My Tweets
keywords: ['Social Networking (Internet)', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning']
abstract: The rise of social media and the field of data science can provide powerful tools to answer public-health questions.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER — MANY important public health questions are difficult and costly to answer. What kind of risks do highly localized sources of pollution, like dry cleaners that use volatile chemicals, pose to the health of nearby residents? Are people with many friends healthier, or do those friendships increase the likelihood of infectious disease? Do frequent visits to public spaces like bars, gyms and restaurants affect a person’s health?

headline: Flooding Inundates Part of Canadian Province
abstract: Heavy rain fell in the past 48 hours, in some places as much as normally falls in six months in the affected area in southern Alberta.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rains have contributed to flooding in parts of the Canadian province of Alberta, where officials said Friday that about 75,000 people have been displaced from their homes. Swollen waterways burst banks, streets were flooded and in at least once instance the wreckage of a house was swept away by raging waters in the Bragg Creek area.

headline: Shares in Gogo Slip in Market Debut
abstract: Gogo shares were down significantly from the in-flight Internet service provider’s initial public offering price in their first day of trading, hitting $15.76 by midafternoon Friday.
lead_paragraph: After a promising debut, shares in Gogo Inc. have hit some turbulence.

headline: Top D.J.’s to Headline the TomorrowWorld Festival
abstract: The goal is to establish a foothold in the United States for the company behind a yearly festival in Belgium.
lead_paragraph: The organizers of one of Europe’s largest electronic dance festivals plan to stage a three-day concert near Atlanta in September, and have secured a lineup that includes most of the top D.J.’s in the world, including Tiesto, Afrojack, David Guetta and Calvin Harris.

headline: Appeals Exhausted, Astor Case Ends as Son Is Sent to Jail
abstract: Anthony D. Marshall, who was convicted of stealing millions from Brooke Astor, was in court Friday to start serving his sentence after exhausting all appeals.
lead_paragraph: Anthony D. Marshall, the disgraced 89-year-old son of the Manhattan society doyenne Brooke Astor, finally surrendered on Friday to begin a prison sentence for stealing millions of dollars from his mother during her final years of life, ending a seven-year legal odyssey that came to define his own waning years.

headline: Billboard Will Not Count Jay-Z’s Sales From Samsung Deal
abstract: Bill Werde, the magazine’s editorial director, argues that a promotional giveaway like the one Samsung and Jay-Z have planned is not equivalent to a million customers forking over their hard-earned cash for an album.
lead_paragraph: Billboard has decided it will not count in its chart tally a million albums that Jay-Z plans to distribute through Samsung as free downloads to owners of its Galaxy mobile phones.

headline: F.A.A. May Relax Restrictions on Electronic Devices on Planes
abstract: The F.A.A. is considering loosening its ban on portable electronic devices during take off and landing.
lead_paragraph: If you’re reading this just as the flight attendants are making the “shut down your portable electronic devices” announcement, take heart. Soon you may not have to speed-read your final words before taking off. The F.A.A. is considering loosening its ban on portable electronic devices during takeoff and landing, Nick Bilton and Jad Mouawad report. That’s right. You and your fellow passengers may be able to keep on texting and e-mailing and shopping and playing video games until you’re above the clouds. A decision is expected in September.

headline: The Sparks Flew Before They Even Met
abstract: The bride, a professional juggler, tosses flaming torches. The groom, a sculptor, sets his pieces ablaze.
lead_paragraph: Lindsay Benner, a professional juggler, honed her talents at Fisherman’s Wharf in San Francisco after graduating college. As the finale to her street performance there, Ms. Benner would select two men from the audience, climb up and stand on their folded arms, then juggle flaming torches above their heads.

lead_paragraph: In this week’s episode, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about the sour experience of seeing a movie that’s “not very super.”

headline: Kids Love the Darndest Things
abstract: These kids are such fans of our “Who Made That” issue, they sent us this photo.
lead_paragraph: The students in Cathy Gabel’s fifth-grade class at Central School in Mamaroneck, N.Y., have become fans of the magazine’s regular ‘‘Who Made That?’’ column, which explores the origin stories of everyday objects. Earlier this year, some of the students wrote to Pagan Kennedy, who writes the weekly column, and were encouraged after receiving a thoughtful response. “Ever since that day,” Gabel wrote to me in an e-mail, they “have felt a deep connection to the article, running to see the magazine section when it arrived on Saturday mornings, barely able to wait until Monday morning to discuss it in class.” They were “thrilled to see an entire issue” devoted to their favorite magazine feature, and sent us this photo of them showing their approval. You can also see this photo on the Reply All page in Sunday’s magazine.

lead_paragraph: Vitoria Rother, 17, student.

abstract: And now for something sorta kinda different.
lead_paragraph: OK, I screwed up: last Friday I was in Toronto, and I gave you a French singer; then I headed for France. I should have saved Zaz for this week, and given you a Toronto band last week. But anyway, here’s Toronto-based Austra. Not at all my to my usual taste, but I’ve featured them once before — they may be electronic, but I do find some of their songs echoing in my head days after:

headline: Love of a Garden Is a Thorn in This Relationship
abstract: The Gotham Chamber Opera performed “La Hija de Rappaccini” al fresco in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The venerable New York Grand Opera Company recently ended decades of summer performances under the skies in Central Park, citing what its conductor, Vincent La Selva, called the increasing unpredictability of the weather.

headline: Tapping Artisanal Beers and Booze at Hotel Bars
abstract: With the rise of artisan distilling and craft brewing, bespoke selections are now the toast of hotel bars around the world.
lead_paragraph: Hotel restaurants have long poured private label wines. But with the rise of artisan distilling and craft brewing, bespoke selections are now the toast of hotel bars around the world.

headline: Secrets, Non-Secrets and Leaks
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Sometimes it seems like the government chooses secrecy for the sake of secrecy.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes you can understand why the government keeps secrets –because those secrets could endanger lives or derail military operations, or simply because they might be embarrassing. No one should have been shocked when the Obama administration was outraged at Edward Snowden’s leaks of documents describing massive surveillance of Americans by the National Security Agency.

headline: As the Baseballs Fly Farther in Japan, the Game’s Commissioner Is Criticized
abstract: After denying that the ball was juiced, Commissioner Ryozo Kato admitted it and said his underlings had not told him about the change.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — If the cover-up is often worse than the crime, the Japanese version of that axiom may apply to Ryozo Kato, the commissioner of Nippon Professional Baseball.

headline: London Symphony Orchestra and Chorus: ‘Der Freischütz’
abstract: LSO Live recently released a vibrant recording drawn from two performances at the Barbican in London.
lead_paragraph: In his last years the eminent conductor Colin Davis, who died in April at 85, had debilitating stretches of poor health. But he was clearly inspired for a concert performance in April 2012 of Weber’s opera “Der Freischütz” with the London Symphony Orchestra and Chorus and an impressive cast. LSO Live recently released a vibrant recording drawn from two performances at the Barbican in London.

headline: Daniel Wohl: ‘Corps Exquis’
abstract: Daniel Wohl’s “Corps Exquis” is a multimedia performance piece.
lead_paragraph: No disrespect to the participants on “Corps Exquis” (New Amsterdam), the deliciously lovely new album by the French-born New York composer Daniel Wohl, but I can’t easily imagine the music on the disc being performed live. In fact, the nine selections on the CD are part of an evening-length, multimedia performance piece, meant to be played by real people in real time. Even so, I have a hard time imagining how these vivid, detailed and engaging compositions might sound in three-dimensional space.

headline: Alan Feinberg: ‘Basically Bull’
abstract: A new recording by Alan Feinberg translates the exquisite chromatic ruminations and intricate counterpoint of Bull’s keyboard works.
lead_paragraph: In 1613 John Bull left England for Flanders, where he soon took up a position as organist at Antwerp Cathedral. If his reputation as a composer and keyboard virtuoso preceded him, so did fame of another kind. “The man hath more music than honesty and is as famous for marring of virginity as he is for fingering of organs and virginals,” wrote George Abbot, the archbishop of Canterbury. Of all Elizabethan composers, Bull had the most picaresque life, punctuated with fistfights, adultery and, possibly, a stint as a spy. But it is in his astonishingly virtuosic and forward-looking compositions that his roaming curiosity reveals itself fully.

headline: Looking Back At California
abstract: New York is having a major California moment.
lead_paragraph: With solo shows by Paul McCarthy, Ken Price and James Turrell on view, New York is having a major California moment, and it expands exponentially with the opening on Sunday of “State of Mind: New California Art Circa 1970” at the Bronx Museum of the Arts. Originating at the Orange County Museum of Art in Newport Beach, Calif., this group show focuses on the blossoming of Conceptual art, performance, video and installation work on the West Coast in the 1960s and 1970s as alternative art spaces and artist-run galleries grew in number and university art departments accommodated avant-garde practices.

headline: A Reunion For ‘Mourner’
abstract: André Gregory directs this production, presented by the Public and Theater for a New Audience.
lead_paragraph: If you saw Wallace Shawn’s “Designated Mourner” the last time it was produced in New York, you are one of a lucky few. That’s because the play, a series of monologues about intellectuals and artists living in an unnamed Western country under a brutal regime, had a production so intimate that it played to an audience of 20. Good news for those who couldn’t secure what was one of hottest tickets that last time, in the summer of 2000: The original cast (Mr. Shawn, Deborah Eisenberg, Larry Pine) is reuniting for a revival at the Public Theater.

headline: Exile in Paris, The Soundtrack
abstract: To honor Dexter Gordon’s 90th birthday (he died in 1990) the Blue Note Jazz Festival is screening “ ’Round Midnight.”
lead_paragraph: Paris was yesterday. So were the soulful ballads that come out of Dale Turner’s sax in “ ’Round Midnight,” Bertrand Tavernier’s 1986 tribute to black expatriate jazz musicians in 1950s Paris — a melancholy slow jam of a film. Its story of a worshipful young Frenchman (François Cluzet), who watches over the alcoholic Dale, could easily be cloying, and sometimes is. But Mr. Tavernier knew what he was doing when he cast the real-life sax man Dexter Gordon as Dale. Tall and elegant, Gordon wanders through the film and Paris like a living, breathing, muttering monument, capturing something ineffable about exile in every distracted glance toward the heavens.

headline: Stravinsky, With Puppets
abstract: In one of the most anticipated events of the season Alan Gilbert teams up with Doug Fitch for “A Dancer’s Dream.”
lead_paragraph: In May 2010, during his first season as music director of the New York Philharmonic, Alan Gilbert showed what a night at the symphony could be if a conductor thinks big. Working with the director and stage designer Doug Fitch Mr. Gilbert presented an exhilarating production of Ligeti’s bleakly satirical opera “Le Grand Macabre,” resourcefully transforming Avery Fisher Hall into an opera house and drawing a dazzling account of this challenging modernist score from the Philharmonic players. The following spring Mr. Gilbert and Mr. Fitch collaborated again on an enchanting production of Janacek’s “Cunning Little Vixen.”

headline: The Rise and Fall Of a Tabloid Dream
abstract: “Anna Nicole,” a made-for-television movie Saturday night at 8 p.m. on Lifetime, is only about 90 minutes long.
lead_paragraph: Excluding commercials, “Anna Nicole,” a made-for-television movie Saturday night at 8 p.m. on Lifetime, is only about 90 minutes long. That seems like a not very generous allotment for the task at hand: telling the story of one of the most eventful, calamitous pop-culture lives of recent years.

headline: Moves From Brazil, By Way of France
abstract: Compagnie Käfig is a French-based troupe of Brazilian dancers that’s bringing two productions for an all-male cast to the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival.
lead_paragraph: Although visually spectacular, the rambunctiousness of hip-hop dance can make it hard to transfer it from the street or dance club, where it can appear unfettered, to the formality of the stage, where its energy must be contained within bounds. One internationally successful attempt to theatricalize hip-hop is Compagnie Käfig, a French-based troupe of Brazilian dancers that’s bringing two productions for an all-male cast to the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival.

headline: Popcast: The Idea of Bonnaroo
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the 12th edition of the music festival in Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: This week: The 12th Bonnaroo music festival, which wrapped up last Sunday in Manchester, Tenn.

headline: Big Ticket | A Floor Full of Light, Sold for $13.5 Million
abstract: A 5,027-square-foot floor-through loft with four exposures, including city and Hudson River views.
lead_paragraph: An elegant loft that commands the entire 15th floor of the Franklin Tower, an 18-story luxury condominium at 90 Franklin Street in TriBeCa, sold for $13.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: For a Fee, Seeking Owners of Unclaimed Money
abstract: Some companies can reunite heirs with unclaimed property, like insurance policies and utility deposits. But it may be cheaper not to lose the assets in the first place.
lead_paragraph: NOT long after his mother died in December 2010, John Sinclair said he began receiving calls from a company that claimed it had found money belonging to her, which it would divulge for a fee. Mr. Sinclair, a social worker outside of Cleveland, said he ignored the calls until a few months ago.

headline: 2004 Showdown Shaped Reputation of Pick for F.B.I.
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: James B. Comey has been lauded for resisting pressure to rubber-stamp a surveillance program that he and others at the Justice Department believed violated the law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If it were not for a now famous scene in a hospital just blocks away from the White House, it is unlikely that James B. Comey would have been standing in the Rose Garden on Friday to be introduced as President Obama’s nominee for the director of the F.B.I.

headline: Food Matters | A Winning Seafood Spot in Venice
abstract: Salt Air, a new dining establishment in the beachfront enclave of Los Angeles, balances tradition and invention.
lead_paragraph: “It might surprise some people, but seafood isn’t represented all that well here,” said the chef Greg Daniels about the Los Angeles waterfront community of Venice. Formerly the executive sous chef at the Jean-Georges restaurant Perry St. in Manhattan, Daniels headed west to change that with Salt Air, a new “beach bistro” that was opened this week by the restaurateur David Reiss and the socialite couple Moise and Carol Ann Emquies on the trendy shopping strip of Abbot Kinney Boulevard.

abstract: Regulator in New York sets tough bank fine. | Regulators are divided regarding consultants. | Consultants may face tighter rein from Albany. | Headhunter for the rich turned on them, says Andrew Ross Sorkin.
lead_paragraph: Regulator in New York sets tough bank fine. | Regulators are divided regarding consultants. | Consultants may face tighter rein from Albany. | Headhunter for the rich turned on them, says Andrew Ross Sorkin.

headline: Umbilical Adventures of Sons and Mother
abstract: The overbearing mother is played by a man in drag in the new production of Sidney Howard’s “Silver Cord,” a hit in 1926 when Freudian theory was all the rage, and later a movie.
lead_paragraph: “The Silver Cord,” a musty 1926 play by Sidney Howard, has little to hold the interest of a modern audience, but the Peccadillo Theater Company’s revival of it at the Theater at St. Clement’s at least gives you a few things to think about during the frequent moments when your attention may wander.

headline: Catsimatidis’s Theatrical Bond With La Guardia
abstract: John A. Catsimatidis, a Republican candidate for mayor, aims to reinforce his similarities with Fiorello H. La Guardia by providing a free one-man show about the former New York leader.
lead_paragraph: Ask anyone running for mayor of New York City which municipal chieftain they most admire, the answer is bound to be Fiorello H. La Guardia, the diminutive firebrand who brought airports, wisecracks and man-of-the-people populism to City Hall during the Great Depression and World War II.

headline: In a Conductor’s Playlist, Some Daunting Chasms
abstract: The third of the conductor Alan Gilbert’s “Playlist” concerts featured the pianist Emanuel Ax as the soloist in a Haydn piano concerto, followed by Christopher Rouse’s Symphony No. 3.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who’s ever compiled a playlist for a radio show, dance floor or iPod knows that the main objective is picking cuts that sound good together. There’s a special joy in hooking up tracks that are intrinsically connected, especially if the glue in the seams doesn’t show. The program Alan Gilbert assembled for the concert that the New York Philharmonic presented on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall — the third installment in the “Gilbert’s Playlist” series — succeeded on both counts.

lead_paragraph: The play is apparently not the thing to catch the conscience of the New York City Department of Transportation, which has billed the Drilling Company for the parking spaces the theater troupe uses for its free Shakespeare in the Parking Lot performances, and has required the company to purchase automobile liability insurance.

headline: In Immigration Reform, Republican Support for Citizenship Hinges on Obstacles
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Polls have found that a majority of Republicans oppose an unqualified path to citizenship, but nearly three in four support a path with several requirements. Linking citizenship to increased border control has not shown the same effect.
lead_paragraph: Two Republican senators reached a deal this week on a plan to strengthen the border security provisions of the immigration overhaul currently working its way through the Senate. Many G.O.P. legislators have said that tough border security measures are needed to garner enough Republican votes to pass a bill that also provides a path to citizenship for immigrants living in the United States illegally.

headline: For CNN, Fame Trumps News on Sunday Nights
abstract: A show from Morgan Spurlock and one with Ridley Scott as a producer are part of a news network’s plan to revamp its prime-time on the weekend.
lead_paragraph: CNN unveils its Sunday-night makeover this weekend, and if the goal was to look a little bit more like every other cable channel, then mission accomplished.

headline: The Calm Before the First Serve
abstract: In a few days Wimbledon will begin, but for now the All England Club is quiet, almost eerily so.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — The reporter sitting next to me said he loved the All England Lawn Tennis Club on days like Friday.

headline: Favorite Summer Dishes: One Vote for Porgy
abstract: Caribbean-style porgy at Má Pêche evokes images of beaches and the sound of waves.
lead_paragraph: Summer has officially hit town. It would be impossible to select the most summery dish in New York City (please feel free to offer your own nominations below), but I believe a strong case could be made for the the Caribbean-style porgy at Má Pêche.

headline: Maurizio Cattelan’s Shocking Window Displays at the Palais de Tokyo
abstract: The supposedly retired Italian art provocateur has transformed the Paris museum with stomach-churning images from his magazine Toilet Paper.
lead_paragraph: When the Italian polymath Maurizio Cattelan announced his retirement from the art world in 2011 on the eve of a major retrospective at the Guggenheim, few people really believed him, and for good reason. The perennial prankster has continued to produce imagery via Toilet Paper, the salacious biannual he creates with the commercial photographer Pierpaolo Ferrari. Since its inaugural issue in 2010, the magazine has regularly published 2-D works with the same eccentric qualities as Cattelan’s sculptures. (An anthology was released last year.) Its spreads are scabrous and surreal, cartoonish and sublime: an eyeball staring from a man’s mouth, a playing card held between a woman’s buttocks, a half-eaten bar of soap. Though much of the work will elicit laughter, Cattelan and Ferrari take it very seriously. “Toilet Paper images are the realization of everyone’s most intimate, hidden and unspeakable desires and urges,” Cattelan said. “What makes a Toilet Paper image is the attempt to say something terrible while staying quiet.”

headline: Family Tragic in Its Own Way, and Comic in All the Others
abstract: James Wesley’s “Unbroken Circle,” at St. Luke’s Theater, stars Eve Plumb in a Texas comedy-drama with a whiff of “August: Osage County.”

She may take courses at Oral Roberts University. But at the end of the day, June relaxes in a designer negligee given her by a male admirer (although her divorce, at least her second, is not final) and enjoys numerous glasses of wine.

Ms. Elsey, 59, started as a railroad clerk in 1985, selling tokens. She was soon promoted to a tower operator and then a train dispatcher. Manuel Antonio López García, crashed Thursday, and all 10 people on board are presumed dead, military officials said Friday. Officials said a team had recovered the body of one of the passengers, Col. Mario Alberto Jirón López, who was in charge of a repair base, as well as other human remains and pieces of the MI-17 military helicopter. After attending a training mission near Lake Managua, in the northwestern region, the group was on its way to Managua, the capital, when the crew reported the need to make an emergency landing. A special commission has been formed to investigate the cause of the crash.

lead_paragraph: Huge crowds of Islamist demonstrators packed a Cairo traffic circle and several surrounding streets on Friday in a show of support for President Mohamed Morsi as he approaches the anniversary of his inauguration as Egypt’s first freely elected leader. Many Egyptians are discontented with Mr. Morsi over his running of the country and the state of the economy, and his opponents are calling for mass protests on the anniversary, June 30, that they hope will drive him from power. Friday’s protesters, most of them from the Muslim Brotherhood and other Islamist groups, marched under a banner saying “No to Violence” and accused the opposition of trying to subvert the democratic process. Egypt’s intense political polarization and violent language from activists on both sides have raised fears that the anniversary protests will unleash new unrest.

lead_paragraph: On Jan. 7, 1863, just six days after the Emancipation Proclamation authorized African-American men to serve in the Union Army and Navy, Dr. Alexander T. Augusta, a freeman born in Norfolk, Va., wrote to President Lincoln requesting to serve as a surgeon “to some of the coloured regiments, or as physician to some of the depots of ‘freedmen.’” The 37-year-old Augusta had attended Trinity Medical College in Toronto; as he explained in his letter, “I was compelled to leave my native country, and come to this on account of prejudices against colour, for the purpose of obtaining knowledge of my profession; and having accomplished that object … I am now prepared to practice it, and would like to be in a position where I can be of use to my race.”

Life preservers, white bamboo walls, palm trees, a wooden captain’s wheel, the server’s red shorts: all accounted for. The people who brought the bar Moby Dick’s to the Hamptons last summer have brought the Hamptons to Manhattan this time. The succinct menu features wood-fired rectangular pizzas and other items from the center grill; the fit and fashionable guests pay in advance and receive a numbered buoy to place on their picnic table. Celebrities seem to blend in, and dogs get their own water dishes. Music wafts pleasantly, and the after-work vibe is so jaunty, you might never want to leave.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Starz) TO ROME WITH LOVE (2012) In this tribute to the Italian cinema of the 1950s and ’60s by Woody Allen, a retired, and overly psychoanalyzed, music promoter (Mr. Allen) travels with his wife (Judy Davis) to Rome, where their daughter (Alison Pill) has lost her heart to an earnest lawyer devoted to left-wing causes (Flavio Parenti). Meanwhile in this shuffled anthology, a young newlywed loses her way to the Trevi Fountain and into the arms of a movie star while her befuddled husband tries to keep his relatives in the dark, substituting a prostitute (Penélope Cruz, above with Alessandro Tiberi) for her at dinner. An ordinary Roman (Roberto Benigni) is plunged into a swirl of media celebrity. And a fledgling architect (Jesse Eisenberg) finds his relationship with his kind, if bland, girlfriend (Greta Gerwig) blown to smithereens when her neurotic actress friend (Ellen Page) shows up for a visit. Alec Baldwin plays the older architect — a ghost? a specter of the younger man’s self? — who witnesses the ordeal. “One of the most delightful things about ‘To Rome With Love’ is how casually it blends the plausible and the surreal, and how unabashedly it revels in pure silliness,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The limitations of ‘To Rome With Love,’ as frothy as the milk atop a cappuccino, are finally inseparable from its delights. Some of the scenes feel rushed and haphazardly constructed, and the dialogue frequently sounds overwritten and under-rehearsed. But this may just be to say that we are watching late-period Woody Allen. Complaining would be as superfluous — though also, perhaps, as inevitable — as psychoanalysis.”

headline: The New New Thing in U.S.-Indian Relations?
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Elections', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: As U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry heads to India, many wonder if India’s relationship with America has failed to live up to its once lofty expectations.
lead_paragraph: Sometime early in the last decade, official Washington discovered India’s “strategic” value. The emblem of this revelation was the Bush administration’s civil-nuclear agreement, unveiled with great fanfare in 2005. The agreement was technically designed to allow peaceful nuclear cooperation with India despite its status then as a nonproliferation pariah, but the real purpose, as one architect of the accord put it, was to “forge the strategic partnership based on common values that had eluded both countries for many decades” and demonstrate how valuable Washington “deemed the U.S.-Indian partnership to be in meeting U.S. grand strategic objectives.”It was an act of faith: two big, diverse, sometimes exasperating democracies, the United States and India would surely find a way to do wonderful things together. India would be an ally in global causes, a counterweight to China, a shining example of democratic development.

abstract: A longer, fuller style of shorts has appeared on the men’s runways this season in the collections of designers like Alexander McQueen, James Long and Kolor.
lead_paragraph: There’s a longer, fuller type of shorts on the runways so far this season, and not the athletic Airtex kind made for shooting hoops. More tailored and often pleated, this version is inspired by the shape of colonial-era Ghurkha shorts, with a fixed waist and a slightly ballooning leg. Alexander McQueen’s airy, cuffed ivory pair evoked “Brideshead Revisited,” while James Long’s black nylon jacquard model had a more techy look. Kolor showed a surfer-inspired floral printed style with a dropped paper-bag waist attached to a more fitted, contrasting waistband, which created a layered effect. Get to work on those gams, guys, because these shorts aren’t for spindly shanks.

headline: Syria Scorecard

When the Ottoman Empire collapsed as a result of its defeat in World War I, the colonial powers Britain and France were right there, for their own interests, to impose their own order on the diverse tribes, sects and religions that make up the Arab East. When the British and French left after World War II, they handed power, in many cases, to monarchs, who, in many cases, gave way to generals, who, in all cases, kept their diverse populations in line with iron fists.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Lifetime) DEVIOUS MAIDS Subtitle this new series, which counts Eva Longoria among its executive producers, “Desperate Housekeepers.” Five maids bound by their personal struggles navigate the upstairs-downstairs attitudes of their Beverly Hills employers in this take on the telenovela “Ellas Son ... la Alegría del Hogar.” The story begins as one of their peers, Flora (Paula Garcés), is murdered in the home where she works during one of the year’s fanciest society events. Marisol, played by Ana Ortiz, works for some troubled newlyweds and tries to learn the truth about Flora’s death. Dania Ramírez is Rosie, who left her son in Mexico to work as a maid and nanny for a couple of uppity actors. Roselyn Sánchez is Carmen, an aspiring singer who would like her pop-star employer to help jump-start her career. And Zoila (Judy Reyes) and her teenage daughter (Edy Ganem, above right with, from left, Ms. Sánchez, Ms. Ramírez and Ms. Reyes) are the maids for an emotionally unstable but very wealthy woman. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley said that despite amusing touches, the show is “relentlessly arch and tongue in cheek in a way that seemed fresh when ‘Desperate Housewives’ began in 2004, but now is less so.” She added: “There is more to these hard-working women than their laundry skills — they are called devious for a reason — but the story lines and dialogue may be a bit too cute and contrived to hold viewers’ interest for long.” It’s the cast, she said, “that commands attention.”

headline: Pregnant, Pill-Free and Panicked
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Babies and Infants', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Once I got pregnant I had to abandon the drugs that made me stable enough to want to be become a mother in the first place.
lead_paragraph: Because I’ve lived so long with anxiety, there were lots of things I figured I’d never, ever do — having children was one of them. In fact, in my 20s, before I’d managed to stumble on the combination of drugs and exercise that allows me to be as sane as I can expect to be, I was so sure I’d never give birth that I got a tattoo of a giant koi fish extending from one end of my abdomen to the other.
