But all of that became background noise behind the Trade That Would Change Everything — or will change everything for five minutes until Brooklyn realizes that Paul Pierce and Kevin Garnett are a combined 147 years old.

headline: 4 Die in Egypt as Unrest Spreads Across Country
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Protesters targeted Muslim Brotherhood offices and the clashes were deadly in the city of Alexandria.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — At least four people are dead across Egypt, including a 14-year-old boy, after antigovernment protesters ransacked Muslim Brotherhood offices on Friday and tens of thousands of supporters and opponents of President Mohamed Morsi held dueling rallies in the capital, Cairo.

headline: The Scene at Ground Zero of Uttarakhand Floods
abstract: Rudraprayag, home to the Kedarnath shrine, is among the worse affected areas in Uttarakhand.
lead_paragraph: RUDRAPRAYAG, Uttarakhand —The flash floods in Uttarakhand have caused damage in all the hilly districts of the state, but no district has experienced as much devastation as Rudraprayag, home to the Kedarnath shrine, which draws thousands of pilgrims every summer.

headline: Everything but the Win for Reynolds at Wimbledon
abstract: “I got to play on Centre Court against the guy who is No. 1 in the world, maybe the greatest of this era,” Bobby Reynolds said. “You can’t put a price tag on it.”
lead_paragraph: Bobby Reynolds did not win at Wimbledon on Thursday, or did he?

headline: Fleet Street Is Dead. Long Live Fleet Street!
abstract: Newspapers may be irredeemably old tech, but so far they have managed to adapt to survive in a communications era dominated by the Internet and broadcasting. Still, as the experience of Britain’s press industry shows, things are not quite what they used to be.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A mundane errand this week took me back to Fleet Street, the birthplace and erstwhile beating heart of Britain’s newspaper industry.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
abstract: Does a relative in prison still receive an invitation? And more answers to readers’ wedding etiquette questions.
lead_paragraph: When a Possible Guest Is in Prison

headline: A New Home for Clemente: On a Pedestal in the Bronx
abstract: This week, Roberto Clemente – the Pittsburgh Pirates outfielder, humanitarian and, some would say, martyr – became what many believe is the first Puerto Rican honored by a statue in a New York City park.
lead_paragraph: Like a bronze god descending from the heavens, Roberto Clemente was gently placed atop a black granite base on Monday morning. A handful of hard-hatted souls watched in wonderment as construction workers secured him. Clemente – the Pittsburgh Pirates outfielder, humanitarian and, some would say, martyr – finally graced the state park in the Bronx that bears his name.

headline: Kerry’s Mideast Diplomacy Intensifies as He Shuttles Between the Two Sides
abstract: After meetings with Israeli leaders, Secretary of State John Kerry headed to more talks with the Palestinians and made plans to return to Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Israel on Friday for his second round of discussions with Israeli leaders in less than 24 hours as the pace of discussions about reviving the Israel-Palestinian peace talks heated up.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.
lead_paragraph: Food & Wine: Carnivores don’t have a monopoly on summer. Vegans can grill, too. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: At Men’s Fashion Week, Back to Babbitt
abstract: If there was any doubt that America has been on designers’ minds, it was put to rest with the red, white and blue checked sports jackets and Western bandannas on the Louis Vuitton runway.
lead_paragraph: If there was any doubt that American tastes and traditions have been on designers’ minds, it was finally put to rest with the red, white and blue checked sports jackets and Western bandannas that Kim Jones showed on the Louis Vuitton runway. Oh … and there was a wood-frame outline of a Shaker building in the background.

headline: Viral Justice
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Social Networking (Internet)']
abstract: Now even Afghanistan’s Interior Ministry is using social media to air footage of abuses.
lead_paragraph: KABUL — Every week now it seems, I see on my Facebook news feed that some poor Afghan cop has been beat up. It’s a sign of progress.

headline: Build a Summer Blockbuster
abstract: Do you have the imagination to produce Hollywood’s next summer blockbuster? Then tell us the three vital elements necessary to propel our fake film pitch into box office nirvana.
lead_paragraph: Do you have what it takes to produce Hollywood’s next summer blockbuster?

headline: June 28: Where the Candidates Are Today
abstract: The candidates’ daily campaign schedules at a glance.
lead_paragraph: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: Uncertainty at the Fed as Markets Oscillate
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Interest Rates', 'Quantitative Easing']
abstract: The president’s all but confirmation that the Federal Reserve chairman would not be reappointed at year’s end complicated an already delicate task.
lead_paragraph: It can’t have been the send-off that the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, was hoping for.

headline: Disappearing in Place
abstract: The Chinese artist Liu Bolin is a master of camouflage, blending his way into large murals like the ones at 5Pointz in Long Island City, Queens, where he recently did a performance.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese artist Liu Bolin is a master of camouflage, blending his way into large murals like the ones at 5Pointz in Long Island City, Queens, where he recently did a performance.

headline: Snowden’s Father Hints Son Could Return to Stand Trial if Conditions Are Met
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Lonnie Snowden told NBC News that his son might agree to return to the United States to stand trial on espionage charges if certain conditions are met.
lead_paragraph: Edward J. Snowden’s father told NBC News that his son, the former National Security Agency contractor who is holed up in a Moscow airport without valid travel documents, might agree to return to the United States to stand trial on espionage charges if certain conditions are met.

headline: Wheelies: The End of an Era Edition
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: Peugeot’s founding family hands over control, and Ford announces a new special edition F-150.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Rosie Perez Came to Our Softball Game. In Spirit.
abstract: A play-by-play of the magazine’s softball game against The New Yorker.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, after The New York Times Magazine lost a crushing softball game on a walk-off home run to New York magazine, its archrival-once-removed, I reflected on my favorite quotation from the Rosie Perez oeuvre: “Sometimes when you win,” she told Woody Harrelson’s character in “White Men Can’t Jump,” “you really lose. And sometimes when you lose, you really win.” She provided no real proof, but whatever, it still helped me feel better — or at least to replace my feelings of loss with feelings of confusion.

headline: Recall of the Wild
abstract: Jon Mooallem explores the haphazard nature of our efforts to protect endangered species.
lead_paragraph: We are wreaking havoc on the planet. Scientists predict that half of all living species will be obliterated by the end of the century, and in this age of man-made destruction it seems obvious we should try to salvage some of what’s left. But as Jon Mooallem discovers in his ambitious and fascinating first book, “Wild Ones,” American conservation today presents a far greater conundrum than deciding what to save or even how to save it. Such efforts force us to reconsider our relationship with other species and to confront what may be our obsolete fantasy of “wilderness.” Most of all, they force us to rethink the human animal.

headline: Tinker, Tailor, Reporter, Thriller
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Mastering the art of writing fiction about spies.
lead_paragraph: Scratch a journalist, especially a foreign correspondent, and more often than not you will find a frustrated thriller writer. We cover riots, revolutions and coups; we get arrested, shot at, tear-gassed, all the while gathering experiences and material that are the very stuff of human drama. It seems a natural progression to use our notebooks to create fiction as well as factual writing.

headline: Made in L.A. | Two Resources for Interior Design on North Highland Avenue
abstract: In a new series, the interior designer and writer David Netto explores the city of angels for inspiration. Here, Netto visits two stores known for their well-curated objects: Blackman Cruz and J. F. Chen.
lead_paragraph: “L.A. is mysterious,” says David Netto, an interior designer and writer. “You have to learn about places from word of mouth.” In a new video series, Netto explores the city of angels and finds inspiration in his surroundings. Here, he visits Blackman Cruz and JF Chen, two cavernous decorating stores on North Highland Avenue.

headline: Method to the Madness
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Exploring the “dark art” of writing about psychological dysfunction.
lead_paragraph: In his tales of Gothic horror, Edgar Allan Poe gave the world a fine collection of neurotics, paranoids and psychopaths. But none are quite as deranged as the narrator of “The Cask of Amontillado.” His name is Montresor, and his story opens with a threat: “The thousand injuries of Fortunato I had borne as I best could, but when he ventured upon insult I vowed revenge.” What a wealth of pathology is revealed in these words; it becomes immediately clear that the “thousand injuries” Montresor mentions are less harmful to him than the “insult” he claims to have suffered.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: PRIVATE EMPIRE: ExxonMobil and American Power,  by Steve Coll. (Penguin, $18.) Bookended by two man-made disasters — the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska in 1989, and the BP Deepwater Horizon blowout in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010 — Coll’s mammoth portrait of Exxon Mobil reveals the corporation’s inner workings and vast influence, and abounds in empire-size figures. (If revenue were counted as gross domestic product, Exxon Mobil would rank among the top 30 countries.)

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: TRANSATLANTIC,  by Colum McCann. (Random House, $27.) This worthy companion piece to “Let the Great World Spin” takes on the lives of men and women who have chosen to leap across the ocean from Ireland to the New World or back again.

headline: In Africa, Competing With Beijing
abstract: Critics are faulting the president for not going to Africa sooner and for lagging behind China in capitalizing on the continent’s potential.
lead_paragraph: As President Obama visits Senegal, South Africa and Tanzania this week, critics are faulting him for not going to Africa sooner and for lagging behind China’s leaders in capitalizing on the continent’s potential. While there is truth to the complaints — there are good reasons to intensify top-level American engagement in Africa — there is also more to the story.

headline: The Agony of Ecstasy
abstract: Tao Lin’s novel follows a young pill-popping writer from Brooklyn to Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: If you’re bookish and you don’t know the name Tao Lin, you’re probably over 30. Among 20-something readers, he’s an established phenomenon, a kind of literary typhoon and tycoon. Not that Lin has made much money from his books (or so, at least, he reports). He seems to be writing for the best reason, the only reason — because he’s a writer. He may well be one of those crazy, splendid people who, as Charles Bukowski put it, if marooned on a desert island would use a stick to scratch stories in the sand.

headline: El Comandante’s Farewell Tour
abstract: In Cristina García’s novel, an aging Cuban dictator contemplates his legacy, and an exiled adversary dreams of revenge.
lead_paragraph: Fictio cedit veritati. Fiction yields to the truth.

headline: Transplant
abstract: Anchee Min’s memoir charts her arduous path from a labor camp in China to art school in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Chicago, the mid-1980s: Anchee Min, newly arrived from Shanghai to study at the School of the Art Institute, was invited to a meeting of the college’s Communist Club. “Tell us about Red China!” urged the ardent American students. “Tell us your firsthand experience!”

headline: Double Vision
abstract: Twin sisters share a devastating secret in Curtis Sittenfeld’s novel.
lead_paragraph: From Shakespeare’s “Comedy of Errors” to “The Parent Trap” and beyond, twins have provided rich fodder for our stories. Mistaken identity makes for great farce, and, paradoxically, identical twinship provides a way to examine what makes us different. Curtis Sittenfeld’s new novel, “Sisterland,” offers an intriguing look at what it might be like to have a double. Not the long lost double from whom you’ve been separated for most of your life, but the double who shares your room, your clothes and, in the case of these psychic sisters, some of your more disturbing thoughts.

headline: Too Large to Fail
abstract: Lionel Shriver’s heroine decides to rescue her obese brother.
lead_paragraph: Pandora Halfdanarson is a dedicated settler: she has settled for stepmotherhood; for marriage to an ascetic perfectionist; for an unlikely career as the owner of a small business, Baby Monotonous. She has settled in New Holland, Iowa, where she makes commissioned talking dolls, each primed with a list of remarks (“I don’t have that many credit cards”; “I owe it to myself to have a few nice things”) guaranteed to razz a customer’s loved one.

headline: Escape From New York
abstract: Why the middle months of 1776 were crucial to the American Revolution.
lead_paragraph: If you know the musical “1776,” you know the plot of Joseph J. Ellis’s breezy new book. It’s a stirring and conventional story. A handful of famous men struggle to create a republic against insurmountable odds. In the long run, their greatest challenge is the problem of slavery. But the most immediate threat is the military might of Britain. Toward the end of June 1776, as the Continental Congress nears a vote on American independence, the first of 427 royal ships carrying 1,200 cannons, 32,000 soldiers and 10,000 sailors appears off Long Island. Things look dire, a point made repeatedly in the musical by a soldier bearing gloomy reports from George Washington, the commander of the Continental Army.

headline: That a Nation Might Live
abstract: At Gettysburg, nothing less than the whole war was at stake.
lead_paragraph: The battle of Gettysburg was a human and environmental catastrophe and, for the United States, almost the beginning of the end of its existence. Any historian contemplating this event faces numerous daunting problems — apart from the fact that thousands of books and articles have already been published on the Gettysburg campaign. The ghastly scale of bloodletting has to be explained. The battlefield contest itself involved the highest possible political and national stakes. And although this may be the most documented battle ever, the historian must use a vast supply of unreliable postwar recollections as sources. Such issues never stem the tide of writers drawn by the intellectual challenge (or by the charms of the subject’s market).

headline: Stand by Me
abstract: Two abandoned children travel to the family’s crumbling Virginia estate in Jeannette Walls’s novel.
lead_paragraph: Ladies, if you want your kid to grow up to be a writer (and who doesn’t?), here are some simple steps you can take to give your progeny a leg up: 1) Be glamorous. 2) Go bonkers.

headline: Small Betrayals
abstract: Set against an international backdrop, Lily Tuck’s story collection traces the emotional terrain of faltering relationships.
lead_paragraph: In “My Flame,” one of the stories in Lily Tuck’s new collection, “The House at Belle Fontaine,” a woman finds out, long after her ex-husband’s death, that he repeatedly slept with his teenage niece. The girl is also dead, having driven drunk. So betrayal, in a not uncommon phenomenon, has a longer life than its perpetrators: the many intervening years cannot prevent the protagonist from feeling “shocked and duped.” Such a bald statement of feeling is rare for Tuck, a writer chary with reports of her characters’ inner lives. We’re not often privy to their reflections; their thoughts tend toward memories that are not especially emotional, or local observations or desires. “She hoped the bus would not be late as it was her day to car pool.” “It might be nice, for a change, to have another female in the house.” “Dr. Harris-Mehta’s white coat, Helen notices, is buttoned up the wrong way and, briefly, she is tempted to reach over and fix it.”

headline: Sightseeing
abstract: A professor and his former student on their island honeymoon.
lead_paragraph: “A tiny, perfect, whittled trinket found bedded in the sand”; “a brightness quivering against the coming rain”; “a modern-day Venus” who inspires “a fin-de-siècle fever”: these are a few descriptions of the young wife in “Orkney,” Amy Sackville’s masterfully self-contained second novel. If they sound dismayingly vague and romantic, that’s because the words belong not to the writer, but to the narrator, Richard, a professor who has recently married his most gifted student. She asks him to take her to the sea, and he gallantly makes arrangements for a honeymoon in the northern Scottish archipelago of Orkney, giving no thought to what she will do once he must return to his academic responsibilities. “We talked once of her working on her doctorate with me,” he muses, “but that would be impossible now.” When he thinks of their future, he imagines “a perpetual breakfast table.”

headline: What Made Him Tick
abstract: The brilliance and self-destructiveness of J. Robert Oppenheimer.
lead_paragraph: By the time I was 300 pages into Ray Monk’s formidable biography of J. Robert Oppenheimer, I couldn’t imagine why anyone in his right mind would have chosen this man as director of the secret laboratory that built the first atomic bomb. If the whole thing had failed, what a harebrained scheme it would have seemed.

headline: Extreme States of Mind
abstract: Frank Bidart’s latest poems look back at the precedents — literary, cinematic and sexual — that shaped him as an adult.
lead_paragraph: Frank Bidart got noticed during the 1970s and ’80s for poems that did not sound like poems at all: a disjointed monologue by a serial killer, another by Ludwig Binswanger’s anorexic and ultimately suicidal patient Ellen West and, later, disquisitions on the history of philosophy, in spiky free verse full of capital letters, italics, white space and unconventional punctuation. Bidart’s extreme typography helped him convey extreme states of mind; it also helped show how his lines ought to sound, read aloud. More recent and more traditionally lyrical books have taken on well-defined topics: “Desire” (1997) was largely about sex, “Watching the Spring Festival” (2008) about beauty.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Lily Koppel’s “Astronaut Wives Club,” at No. 16 on the hardcover nonfiction list, is about the difficulty of being the spouse who stays home while the other commutes to the moon.
lead_paragraph: MOON SHADOWS: Toward the end of “The Right Stuff,” Tom Wolfe’s exhilarating look at America’s early space program, there’s a riff about the pressure facing astronauts’ families: “The Astronaut’s Wife had been converted from an individual to a performer, at least for the duration of the flight — ready or willing or good at it or not. It had become an immutable part of the drill: at the completion of the flight the astronaut’s wife had to leave the house and confront the Beast and all his cameras and microphones and submit to a press conference and answer questions and be the perfect Astronaut’s Wife with merely the entire world watching. It was this grim prospect that truly lacerated one’s heart while Mr. Wonderful was aloft. It was this that gave the test pilot’s wife a royal case of nerves in the space age.”

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Dexter’
abstract: The Showtime series begins its final season by solving some problems and creating some new ones.
lead_paragraph: Showtime’s venerable drama about a serial killer in search of his soul may be called “Dexter,” but it has always been the Dexter & Deb show. The performances of Michael C. Hall as the diffident psychopath Dexter Morgan and Jennifer Carpenter as his ferocious, intensely vulnerable, hilariously profane adopted sister, Deb, are the yin and yang of the series. Dexter’s protectiveness of Deb helps to redeem him; she is, in Ms. Carpenter’s hands, so vivid and appealing that we like him for loving her.

headline: Off the Charts: A Policy That Worked
abstract: Since Nov 3, 2010, when the Federal Reserve announced what became known as QE2, or the second round of quantitative easing, stock prices have risen. Inflation expectations and interest rates are not far from where they were then, despite recent increases. Gold prices soared, but have now fallen back, and the dollar, after losing value in 2011, has recovered.
lead_paragraph: Since Nov 3, 2010, when the Federal Reserve announced what became known as QE2, or the second round of quantitative easing, stock prices have risen. Inflation expectations and interest rates are not far from where they were then, despite recent increases. Gold prices soared, but have now fallen back, and the dollar, after losing value in 2011, has recovered.

headline: Obama Completes First Leg of Africa Tour
abstract: President Obama ended his visit to Senegal and headed to South Africa. His last stop was Tanzania.
lead_paragraph: President Obama ended his visit to Senegal and headed to South Africa. His last stop was Tanzania.

headline: Here Comes the Sunscreen
abstract: Parents applying protective lotion to their (often reluctant) children.
lead_paragraph: Parents applying protective lotion to their (often reluctant) children.

headline: What It Takes to Make New College Graduates Employable
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Closing the gap between what employers need and what colleges produce will require effort from both sides, specialists say.
lead_paragraph: MY older son graduated from high school last week and has started a pleasant job as a summer lifeguard. In four years we expect to attend his college graduation, and we hope the time there leaves him with great experiences, a love of learning and some idea how to get and keep a job.

headline: Queens: The New Frontier for a Brooklyn Blogger
abstract: Jonathan Butler, founder of the Brownstoner blog, answers questions about expanding his brand.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Butler founded the Brooklyn blog Brownstoner in 2004, but he didn’t quit his day job until 2007, when the blog’s popularity had clearly taken off. He has since expanded his other Brooklyn-based enterprises, founding the successful Brooklyn Flea and Smorgasburg outdoor market business with a partner, Eric Demby. In May, Mr. Butler started Queens Brownstoner after acquiring the site QueensNYC.com and rolling it into his brand.

headline: A Celebrity Chef Appeals to a Legacy of Black Forgiveness
abstract: African-American Christians, drawing on both the Jesus narrative and the civil rights movement, have become well-practiced at forgiving their racist tormentors.
lead_paragraph: Well before controversy exploded around Paula Deen, she had decided to title her forthcoming cookbook “New Testament.” The name was intended to wittily refer to the television chef’s adoption of a healthier approach to Southern cooking in light of her own diabetes. Now, however, the biblical reference serves as much more than a pun.

headline: Predictions on Fed Strategy That Did Not Come to Pass
abstract: Many markets are now about where they were in 2010 when the Fed announced its program of quantitative easing.
lead_paragraph: ON the day after Democrats lost control of the House of Representatives in the 2010 midterm election, the Federal Reserve announced it would purchase $600 billion in Treasury securities — a program that quickly became known as Q.E.2, for quantitative easing.

headline: Investors Wary of Alliance Talk for Peugeot
abstract: Shares of the French carmaker PSA Peugeot Citroën fell on Friday after analysts played down the likelihood of a deeper alliance with General Motors.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Would it make sense for one troubled carmaker with huge losses and acres of idle factory space to acquire another troubled carmaker with the same problem?

headline: Equal Status, Kemo Sabe
abstract: Johnny Depp, who has speculated about his possibly American Indian ancestry, plays a revisionist take on Tonto in “The Lone Ranger.”
lead_paragraph: In 1996 a “Don Juan DeMarco”-era Johnny Depp went off into the Mojave Desert to make his first, and so far only, feature-length foray into directing. After the weird and wonderful trifecta of “What’s Eating Gilbert Grape,” “Benny & Joon“ and “Ed Wood,” Mr. Depp was cresting the early summit of his career as a movie star. Though notoriously unsuccessful at the box office, Mr. Depp could have probably collected his usual multimillion-dollar payday for any of the top projects in Hollywood then — much as he did with the coming “Lone Ranger.” What he chose instead was “The Brave,” also a movie about an American Indian, but one who agrees to be the subject of a snuff film.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘The Heat,’ ‘White House Down’ and ‘I’m So Excited!’
abstract: Times critics on “White House Down,” “The Heat” and “I’m So Excited!”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “White House Down,” “The Heat” and “I’m So Excited!” See all of this week’s reviews here.

headline: A Bowl of Cherries
abstract: The Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman offers five new ways to make cherries a part of your meal.
lead_paragraph: Cherries aren’t often the featured ingredient in a dish; they are more likely to be nibbled on as a delicious snack between meals. But now that it’s the peak of cherry season, it’s time to showcase these edible, healthy treats on your dinner table.

headline: Ford and Mitsubishi Issue Recalls
abstract: Ford to recall 12,500 vehicles for a child safety lock problem, and Mitsubishi has called for a recall because of complaints of sunroofs flying off.
lead_paragraph: Ford will recall about 12,500 of its 2013 Explorer, Taurus and Lincoln MKS models to fix a problem with a child safety lock, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. In another action, Mitsubishi said it would recall about 3,200 Outlander Sports from the 2011 model year in the United States because the glass sunroof may come off.

headline: Mom and Dad, Let’s Talk Real Estate
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Wills and Estates', 'Families and Family Life', 'Longevity']
abstract: The future of a family home should be addressed before an illness or accident forces the issue.
lead_paragraph: In this city of 350,000-plus co-op apartments and an aging population, it’s a quintessential New York story. A couple has owned an apartment for decades. Long after the children departed the nest, the parents have stayed, rattling around in quarters too large for their needs. Yet even if the apartment has grown shabbier, its value has soared.

headline: Billy Crystal Reads  for an Audience, Prompting Laughter and a Surprise
abstract: When Billy Crystal read selections from his forthcoming book on Thursday night, the audience was expecting an evening of laughs. They got them — but they also got something they were not expecting.
lead_paragraph: When Billy Crystal read selections from his forthcoming book on Thursday night, the audience was expecting an evening of laughs. They got them — but they also got something they were not expecting.

headline: A Cocktail to Cap a Hot Summer Week
abstract: Take two, say ahh, and don’t call me until Monday.
lead_paragraph: I don’t drink cocktails frequently. But it’s been a long, hot week, and I can’t think of anything more refreshing and relaxing right now than this bracing drink I tried recently at ABC Cocina, the new pan-Latin-tinged small-plates restaurant from the Jean-Georges Vongerichten team.

headline: Image of the Day: June 28
abstract: A grey egret in Guwahati, Assam.

headline: Llodra Is Quizzed After Retiring From Singles but Not Doubles
abstract: Michael Llodra retired from singles on Thursday with a hamstring injury, then advanced with Nicolas Mahut in doubles later in the day.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England – If it was any other Grand Slam event, maybe Michael Llodra would have gotten off lightly. But given the elevated number of journalists from British publications at Wimbledon, he did not escape.

headline: A Man’s Death, a Career’s Birth
keywords: ['Movies', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)']
abstract: A killing at a Bay Area rapid-transit station has inspired Ryan Coogler’s feature-film debut, a movie already honored at the Sundance and Cannes film festivals.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND — It had been nearly a year since Ryan Coogler last stood on the arrival platform on the upper-level of the Fruitvale Bay Area Rapid Transit Station, where 22-year-old Oscar Grant III, unarmed and physically restrained, was shot in the back by a BART transit officer in the early hours of New Year’s Day 2009.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Fall of Raj Rajaratnam and Galleon Group
abstract: This week, Anita Raghavan discusses her new book, “The Billionaire’s Apprentice”; Jon Mooallem talks about “Wild Ones” and endangered species; Adam LeBor on the difficulty of writing thrillers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Anita Raghavan discusses her new book, “The Billionaire’s Apprentice”; Jon Mooallem talks about “Wild Ones” and endangered species; Adam LeBor on the difficulty of writing thrillers; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

abstract: This week, Anita Raghavan, Jon Mooallem and Adam LeBor.

headline: Tight Lips Over Who Started Fires in Sumatra
abstract: Environmental and wildlife investigators said plantation companies, small farmers and people who illegally encroach on concessions to harvest trees and palm oil are all culpable for the blazes.
lead_paragraph: PONTAIN MEKAR, Indonesia — Sitting in a makeshift security post on a hilltop overlooking scorched earth as far as the eye can see, the last thing Hendro wants to talk about is fire.

headline: Who Everybody Is
abstract: The Rock Bottom Remainders, a music group that included Dave Barry, Stephen King and Amy Tan, tells its story in “Hard Listening.”
lead_paragraph: In 1992, a group of authors formed a rock band and made a not-so-glorious noise at a book convention in California. The Rock Bottom Remainders included Dave Barry, Stephen King, Amy Tan and several other best-selling authors. For years the Remainders played occasional shows of 1960s covers.

headline: In Paris, a Plan to Be Friendlier
abstract: A tourism group in Paris has produced a guide to making visitors feel more welcome in the city.
lead_paragraph: Paris is trying to be more tourist-friendly.

headline: Bank of America Hires Veteran Financial Services Banker From Moelis
abstract: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has hired John Binnie, a veteran financial services banker, as a vice chairman of its global financial institutions group, according to an internal bank memorandum.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America Merrill Lynch has hired John Binnie, a veteran financial services banker, as a vice chairman of its global financial institutions group, according to an internal memorandum sent within the investment bank on Friday.

headline: After Protesting Conditions, Dimitrov Is Defeated
abstract: After resuming the match on Friday at 8-9 in the fifth set, Grigor Dimitrov saved three match points before losing to Grega Zemlja on a rainy day at Wimbledon.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — After the rain here abated Friday afternoon, play resumed on the outer courts at Wimbledon around 1:30 p.m., a delay of two hours. What could they possibly be learning in that environment that would keep them safe?

headline: Big Ticket | Park-Centric Luxury for $17.53 Million
abstract: A floor-through apartment with four bedrooms, all with en-suite baths, great views and a key to Gramercy Park was the most expensive residential sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: Three is a charm for the collaboration of Zeckendorf Development and its go-to architect, Robert A.M. Stern, at 18 Gramercy Park South. As a sequel to the jaw-dropping sales they logged by building the billionaire magnet 15 Central Park West, this smaller-scale but equally park-centric luxury condominium represents their first crack at refurbishing a landmark in a fussy historic district, and their third closing of the month again netted the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. Several more of the 16 homes there are in contract.This time the floor-through residence was No. 11 (the previous sales were Nos. 9 and 5). The cost was precisely $17,539,356.25 — the original asking price of $17,225,000 plus transfer taxes. And the closing gift from the sponsor was the usual $350 key that opens the locked gates of Gramercy Park, Manhattan’s only truly private park.

This shirt was not family-friendly.] Amazingly, two older women joined him, one of whom seemed to be his mother. I am all for freedom of speech, but I found the shirt offensive. I was also embarrassed for my family, the other patrons and even his mother. We prevented our daughter from seeing it, but what else could I have done?

headline: Getting Your Feet Wet at Water Parks
abstract: If you’ve never taken the water park plunge, this three-state, five-park tour can get your senses ready for the experience.
lead_paragraph: The first moments inside a water park complex almost always jar your senses. A rush of moist, chlorine-scented air fills your nose. Bright, cartoon colors, not to mention characters, surround you. And then there is the continuous loop of pop tunes vying with an endless whir of water — splashing, spraying, gurgling, rushing, dumping. On this last point, a caution to the uninitiated: if a bell or gong sounds, it is worth glancing up since it is likely to be a warning that some enormous vat of water overhead is preparing to dump its contents, and everyone but you knows it.

abstract: The poetically named Shantala Shivalingappa was born in India, but raised in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The poetically named Shantala Shivalingappa was born in India, but raised in Paris, where she trained in Kuchipudi, a South Indian classical dance style, with her mother, the well-known dancer and choreographer Savitry Nair. Ms. Shivalingappa, who will perform at Jacob’s Pillow this week, is generally acknowledged as one of the greatest current practitioners of Kuchipudi’s flowing lines, percussive footwork and dramatic narratives.

headline: Professor’s Work, Then Beethoven
abstract: The conductor Michel Galante and the Argento Ensemble will perform the American premiere of the original version for soprano and eight instruments of Georg Friedrich Haas’s “Atthis.”
lead_paragraph: The faculty of Columbia University will be bolstered by an important addition when the Austrian composer Georg Friedrich Haas begins a professorship at the school this September. Mr. Haas, a composer associated with the French spectral school, in which timbre and resonance are particularly important, has dazzled with otherworldly pieces like “In Vain,” a psychedelically beautiful soundscape performed in pitch darkness. On Tuesday at the Austrian Cultural Forum, the conductor Michel Galante and the Argento Ensemble will perform the American premiere of the original version for soprano and eight instruments of Mr. Haas’s “Atthis” — a work inspired by the love poems of Sappho. (7:30 p.m. Tuesday, 11 East 52nd Street, 212-319-5300, acfny.org; free.)

headline: Regular Guys at Iwo Jima
abstract: “Sands of Iwo Jima” is too formulaic and jingoistic to be considered great, but maybe it’s just right for Fourth of July week.
lead_paragraph: With support-the-troops sentiment strong these days, occasionally a movie will use real soldiers or veterans in scenes. “Act of Valor” is a recent example. But the precedents for this go back a long ways and include “Sands of Iwo Jima,” the 1949 saga starring John Wayne as the classic irascible sergeant named Stryker. The film is too formulaic and jingoistic to be considered great, but maybe it’s just right for Fourth of July week. It plays on Thursday at 4 p.m. and Saturday at 2 p.m. at the Museum of Modern Art, part of the monthlong exhibition “Allan Dwan and the Rise and Decline of the Hollywood Studios.”

headline: From Brooklyn, an ‘Ode to Joy’
abstract: There is considerable curiosity surrounding “The Bruce High Quality Foundation: Ode to Joy, 2001-2013,” which runs through Sept. 22 at the Brooklyn Museum.
lead_paragraph: The mission is a mouthful — “to invest the experience of public space with wonder, to resurrect art history from the bowels of despair, and to impregnate the institutions of art with the joy of man’s desiring” — but since it’s from the Bruce High Quality Foundation, that brash, Brooklyn artist collective, it won’t elicit so much as a blink from art world insiders. There is, however, considerable curiosity surrounding “The Bruce High Quality Foundation: Ode to Joy, 2001-2013,” which runs through Sept. 22 at the Brooklyn Museum. Included in the show are photographs, videos, paintings, installations — the works (even a 10-foot-tall inflatable rat.)

headline: The Many Sides of a Violist
abstract: A common way to map the reach of the violist and composer Eyvind Kang is to enumerate his affiliations.
lead_paragraph: A common way to map the reach of the violist and composer Eyvind Kang is to enumerate his affiliations. For years he has been a regular collaborator with the performance artist Laurie Anderson; likewise with the jazz guitarist Bill Frisell. He has also done sturdy work with the doom merchant Stephen O’Malley, and provided fine filigree for singer-songwriters like Beth Orton and Laura Veirs. Genre, or any clear iteration of style, is probably the least illuminating handle on him.

headline: An Uphill Battle Daily in Court
abstract: In “Gideon’s Army,” to have its premiere on Monday night at 9 on HBO, Dawn Porter visits the Southern Public Defender Training Center in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: In 1961 Clarence Earl Gideon was arrested on charges of stealing soda, beer and a small sum of cash from a pool hall in Panama City, Fla. Unable to pay for a lawyer, he represented himself at trial, and was later convicted and sentenced to five years in prison. Mr. Gideon appealed his conviction to the Supreme Court, which ruled unanimously that the right to counsel in a criminal case is fundamental to the American justice system. Fifty years after that landmark case, Gideon v. Wainwright, some 15,000 public defenders nationwide represent the majority of the 12 million people arrested annually who could not otherwise afford counsel.

headline: Something Off Key at a Gospel Choir
abstract: Few crucibles test the mettle of adolescents as thoroughly or harrowingly as all-male prep schools.
lead_paragraph: Few crucibles test the mettle of adolescents as thoroughly or harrowingly as all-male prep schools, where lads on the cusp of adulthood bend, warp, grow and sometimes shatter. The hothouse atmosphere of such institutions has proved a fertile environment for dramatists from Robert Anderson (“Tea and Sympathy”) to Alan Bennett (“The History Boys”). Now Tarell Alvin McCraney, the author of the brilliant “Brother/Sister” trilogy, brings his singular sensibility to the subject with “Choir Boy,” which opens on Tuesday at the Manhattan Theater Club.

Then sample a few episodes of “The Many Loves of Dobie Gillis,” which ran from 1959 to 1963 and was one of the first shows to depict life from the teenage perspective.

headline: Wearing a Wire at the Opera, Secretly, of Course
abstract: Even in a house with great acoustics, the demands of radio and HD broadcasts require the (discreet) use of body microphones, the Metropolitan Opera says.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera House has been justly acclaimed for its excellent acoustics. And not just in the choice seats. Many opera buffs assert that the best seats in the house are the most affordable ones: up in the balcony and family circle.

headline: Another Giant Slayer Makes a Quick Exit
abstract: Sergiy Stakhovsky, who bounced Roger Federer in the second round of Wimbledon, had the same fate as most who pull huge upsets in tennis: a quick exit.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Roger Federer is out of Wimbledon, and now, much less surprisingly, Sergiy Stakhovsky is, too.

headline: Daniil Simkin, Standing Out, Reaching Out
abstract: Mr. Simkin, a year into his principal status with American Ballet Theater, is progressing despite his atypical physical presence.
lead_paragraph: There was no shortage of technical prowess during an American Ballet Theater matinee of “Le Corsaire” at the Metropolitan Opera House in early June. In the central roles, the Russian stars Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev were earning thrilled bursts of applause for the height of their jumps and the speed of their multiple turns.

headline: Violence Erupts Anew in Volatile Chinese Region
abstract: A clash between Muslim Uighurs and security forces follows another that left 35 people dead in China’s far western Xinjiang region.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Violence erupted on Friday in China’s volatile far western Xinjiang region, the second time in two days that tensions between the largely Muslim Uighur minority and Chinese security forces have brought bloodshed to the area.

headline: People Will Say They’re in Love, and They Are
abstract: Romances on the stage or behind it can blossom into love, marriage and families.
lead_paragraph: Charlotte d’Amboise, the actress now playing Fastrada in Broadway’s “Pippin,” thought that her romance with Terrence Mann would last about as long as an intermission.

headline: Naughty Revenge, Just Plain Naughty and Not Plain at All
abstract: Tyler Farr, Migos, Farruko, Jon Hopkins and América Sierra have put out new music.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Farr

headline: Movie Review: 'I'm So Excited'
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "I'm So Excited."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "I'm So Excited."

abstract: Suit accuses Jon Corzine of a failure at the helm. | Cost of public projects is rising, and pain will be felt for years. | Bank gains by putting the brakes on traders. | Exit from the bond market is turning into a stampede.

headline: Melissa Clark Answers Your Pie Questions
abstract: A chance to polish your pie-making skills.
lead_paragraph: Now’s your chance to perfect your techniques for making pie crust, topping and summer fruit filling. Melissa Clark of the Dining section will answer your questions in a live chat on all things pie, just in time to bake for the Fourth of July. So join Ms. Clark on Dining’s Facebook Page on Monday, at 4 p.m. Eastern time, and bring your questions. Happy baking!

headline: This Week's Best-Seller Lists
abstract: The Times's Pamela Paul and Gregory Cowles discuss the top-selling books of the week.
lead_paragraph: The Times's Pamela Paul and Gregory Cowles discuss the top-selling books of the week.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Celebrating Orwell’s ‘1984,’ and Uber in Taipei
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday’s selections include a Dutch group decorating surveillance cameras in Utrecht in honor of George Orwell’s 110th birthday, and a taxi app opens for business in Taiwan’s capital.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

headline: Christie’s Marriage Problem
abstract: A Republican governor. In a blue state. With presidential ambitions. How will he navigate same-sex marriage now?
lead_paragraph: Among the questions left unanswered by the Supreme Court’s ruling on the Defense of Marriage Act is whether a majority of the justices actually think all Americans have an equal right to marry. So while the federal government can no longer treat gay and straight married couples differently, the individual states can keep discriminating.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 28
abstract: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

headline: After Political Appointment in Bulgaria, Rage Boils Over
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Nepotism']
abstract: Many Bulgarians are outraged that a figure like Delyan Peevski was placed in a sensitive state position. Although he has resigned, he retains great influence.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — Delyan Peevski’s mother used to head the national lottery and leads a growing media empire with strong political and economic connections in this small, impoverished and notoriously corrupt Balkan nation. So perhaps it was not surprising that the appointment of Mr. Peevski, 32, to head the powerful State Agency for National Security sparked protests that have been attended by thousands every day over the past two weeks and show no sign of losing steam.

headline: As the Tides Shift, a New Flagship Docks
abstract: The new LS 460 feels so last century, but it’s a traditionally engineered  luxury sedan that is still the most Lexus-like of Lexuses.
lead_paragraph: Big flagship luxury sedans are relics. Artifacts left over from a time when social standing was reflected in the length of a car’s wheelbase and how upright its grille stood. A time when Mercedes wasn’t reaching down-market and Hyundai wasn’t aiming for the heights. Back when the sight of a new Cadillac put a company’s employees on high alert that the boss was on site, and not just that some drone in Section G had leased a CTS.

headline: Meet the New Boss ...
abstract: The Lexus LS 460 gets a new face for 2013 and an interior fit for a captain of industry.
lead_paragraph: The Lexus LS 460 gets a new face for 2013 and an interior fit for a captain of industry.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, June 28
abstract: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.
lead_paragraph: More photographs.

headline: “After ‘Before Midnight'”: A Short Screenplay
abstract: Inspired by the long, digressive yet oddly profound conversations in the trilogy.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Riff examines how time exists onscreen — including in the recent film “Before Midnight.” That movie is the third in a trilogy, each produced nine years apart and each following two characters, Jesse and Celine, as their lives overlap and intertwine — often through long, digressive, yet oddly profound conversations. (Here’s more on the films and their co-star and co-writer Julie Delpy.)

headline: When Fuel Economy Improves, but Filling the Tank Costs More
abstract: In many new vehicles, the methods used to squeeze equivalent horsepower from engines with fewer cylinders have automakers pointing customers toward premium-grade gasoline.
lead_paragraph: The math seems so straightforward: as engines get smaller and fuel economy improves, the cost of driving will fall, right?

headline: Splitting Hairs on Required vs. Recommended
abstract: Carmakers recommend using premium gas in some of their models, while it’s required in others. Here is an overview of  the difference between specified fuels
lead_paragraph: Given the price difference between regular-grade and premium gasoline, car buyers should always consider the vehicle’s fuel requirement, as listed in the owner’s manual, as part of the total cost of ownership.

headline: ‘Catfish’ Returns to Average Numbers
abstract: Ratings for the Season 2 premiere of the MTV show “Catfish” can’t match the numbers for the episode that ran after the Manti Te’o story broke.
lead_paragraph: In January, “Catfish: The TV Show,” the documentary series on MTV that follows Nev Schulman and his videographer, Max Joseph, enjoyed a brief moment in the spotlight when when the Notre Dame football player Manti Te’o became the most high-profile example of someone who was “catfished” — that is, the victim of a hoax involving a faked online identity. But so far, any interest from that incident has not translated into higher ratings for the show.

headline: Nice to Meet You ... Again
abstract: Through Facebook and dating Web sites, online reality and its offline counterpart can blur.
lead_paragraph: Are the pixels making us pixilated? In my case, it goes like this: I’ll run into a Facebook friend whom I haven’t seen in more than a decade. Reminiscing about the party we met at in, say, 1998, I’ll recount how all of us revelers had gone up to the roof that night with sparklers.

headline: Empanadas, the Pies With a Passport
abstract: The empanada is the little meat pie that could, a native of Spain that has traveled the world.
lead_paragraph: The empanada is the little meat pie that could, a native of Spain that traveled the world, touching down in Latin America, the Caribbean, Eastern Europe, Africa, South Asia and the British Isles.

headline: Yuvi Alpert’s Holiday in Havana
abstract: The up-and-coming men’s accessories designer, whose collections often take inspiration from his travel, shares pictures and reminiscences from a trip to Cuba.
lead_paragraph: The men’s accessories designer Yuvi Alpert creates pieces that are informed by the ways the modern man moves through the world. There’s an appealing international flavor to his simple, elegant, unbling-y jewelry line Yuvi by Yuvi Alpert (the latest collection shows in Paris this weekend); and Men in Cities, his monthly limited-edition releases of affordable men’s accessories, like wallets, bracelets and neckties, is meant to simplify shopping for guys on the go.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A ‘Thor’ That Wows
abstract: Volume 1 of “Thor: God of Thunder” is No. 9 on this week’s hardcover list.
lead_paragraph: At No. 9 on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week is Volume 1 of “Thor: God of Thunder,” which reprints the first five issues of the latest series devoted to Thor, one of Marvel’s top heroes. The series is written by Jason Aaron and illustrated by Esad Ribic. The first word to describe the result of this creative team is: Wow.

headline: Getting Japan to Spend
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Deflation (Economics)']
abstract: A government strategy to encourage consumption and end deflation has yet to take broad hold, but higher-end shoppers seem to be starting to spend.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Daisuke Horii just collected his summer bonus. It was only slightly more than last year, but enough to compel the 34-year-old shopping mall clerk to Tokyo’s electronics district to look for some high-end speakers.

headline: Taking a Cue From Bernanke a Little Too Far
abstract: Though today’s lower yields provide less of a cushion, bonds still remain the best, if imperfect, foil to stocks.
lead_paragraph: Financial advisers have been fielding calls from shaken investors in recent weeks, particularly retirees, who are nervous that a bond market crash is on the horizon.

headline: French Businessman Investigated on Suspicion of Fraud
abstract: Bernard Tapie is being formally investigated in a corruption scandal that centers on a $535 million state payout to him in 2008, the Paris prosecutor’s office said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Bernard Tapie, a wealthy businessman and erstwhile politician, is being formally investigated on suspicion of fraud in a corruption scandal that centers on a $535 million state payout to him in 2008, the office of the Paris state prosecutor and Mr. Tapie’s lawyer announced on Friday.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A five-bedroom stone- and brick-faced ranch in Plainsboro, N.J., and a four-bedroom wood-frame house in Port Chester, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A five-bedroom stone- and brick-faced ranch in Plainsboro, N.J., and a four-bedroom wood-frame house in Port Chester, N.Y.

headline: Riske Finally Breaks Through at Wimbledon
abstract: American Alison Riske finally got her breakthrough victory at Wimbledon on Friday.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — It took 18 points in the final game of her second-round match at Wimbledon for 22-year-old Alison Riske of Pittsburgh to do something she’d never done before in her career: win a match point at a Grand Slam.

headline: Angst at the A.S.P.C.A.
abstract: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals appears to occupy one of the most fractious places in New York City philanthropy.
lead_paragraph: One of the first times Cindy Adams went to a board meeting of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, tempers flared.

headline: A Vacation Under the Sea
abstract: Two proposed hotels would allow travelers to sleep beneath the sea–and rent submersibles and underwater scooters.
lead_paragraph: Travelers may be able to sleep among the ocean’s depths, surrounded by coral reefs, in two luxury underwater hotels planned for Dubai and the Maldives.

headline: Do You Wanna Know a Secret?
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Privacy', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Research']
abstract: Why we value information more when it’s “classified.”
lead_paragraph: THE revelation that the National Security Agency has been secretly amassing huge amounts of data about Americans’ phone and Internet use has sparked a lively debate about the proper role of secret information in a free and open society.

headline: App Smart Extra: To-Do Lists, File Sharing and Other Home Worker Needs
abstract: Apps that can help home workers making the most of their time and the quiet environment.
lead_paragraph: This week’s App Smart column was all about apps for smartphones and tablets that can help home workers make the most of their time and the quiet environment. This is a handy trick because for some people, like your columnist, many out-of-office working tasks can actually be carried out on a tablet or phone — no PC required.

headline: High-Performance Machines With Zero Horsepower
abstract: Some of the most advanced premium bicycles are designed by, or sold by, automobile companies, including Ferrari, Porsche, BMW and Aston Martin.
lead_paragraph: Imagine your new Lamborghini racing down the road, the wind tousling your hair, the tires straining through a corner, the adrenaline pumping.

headline: Milan Men’s Fashion Week, the Sun Also Sets
abstract: The global fashion juggernaut as we know it got its start in Milan in the ’50s, but are the planets now aligning around a new star?
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Henry James, of course, said it best.

headline: How to Decide Where to Give
abstract: When deciding whether to give money to a charitable cause, do you place more emphasis on metrics or emotion? What causes have you felt driven to support, and why?
lead_paragraph: In a Wealth Matters column published today, Paul Sullivan takes a look at what inspires people to give to charities, and how that inspiration affects the philanthropies they support. Some donors direct their charitable contributions to organizations that can measure the impact of their work, while others, like Mr. Sullivan and his family, place more importance on a sense of personal connection to a cause.When deciding whether to give money to a charitable cause, do you place more emphasis on metrics or emotion? What causes have you felt driven to support, and why?

headline: On Nuclear Waste Bill, Senators Look to Public for Help
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Nuclear Wastes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A group of senators introduced a bill Thursday that would establish a process for choosing a nuclear waste site, based in part on public comments solicited online by the bill’s sponsors.
lead_paragraph: After the Obama administration abandoned plans in 2009 to bury nuclear waste at a repository in Nevada’s Yucca Mountain, a spot chosen by leading senators more than 20 years earlier, a study commission recommended that a new location be picked through “a consent-based process.”

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A one-bedroom on East 51st Street, a Park Ave. co-op with 10-foot beamed ceilings and a Brooklyn three family built in the 1930s.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom on East 51st Street, a Park Ave. co-op with 10-foot beamed ceilings and a Brooklyn three family built in the 1930s.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Syria, the Philippines and Senegal.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Syria, the Philippines and Senegal.

headline: Everyone’s a Dancer at the Philharmonic
abstract: “A Dancer’s Dream,” a telling of “Petrushka” and “Le Baiser de la Fée,” opened at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night without a corps of dancers.
lead_paragraph: In the original 1911 scenario of the ballet “Petrushka,” with music by Stravinsky and choreography by Fokine, the opening scene takes place in the bustling St. Petersburg square during the Shrovetide Fair. There are rowdy crowds, street hawkers, drunken revelers and puppet shows.

headline: Abbott’s All Set for Governor to Make Move
abstract: Greg Abbott, the Texas attorney general, has the cash and organization to become the strongest Republican contender for governor, but Rick Perry has yet to speak.
lead_paragraph: Greg Abbott has a shiny political résumé, an astonishing amount of money in the bank and has geared up for a statewide campaign with careful and deep planning on the ground and in the air.

headline: Take a Phrase, Wrap It in a Song, E-Mail It on Friday
abstract: Bob Schneider, the Austin singer and songwriter, found a surefire way to fill his albums. He created a weekly songwriting game with a strict deadline.
lead_paragraph: Most Monday nights when he’s not on the road, the Austin singer-songwriter Bob Schneider tests at least one new song in front of an audience at the Saxon Pub.

headline: Characters Finding Their Voices by Singing in the Choir
abstract: “Choir Boy,” by Tarell Alvin McCraney, follows students at an all-black high school in the South as they struggle to balance tradition and self-expression.
lead_paragraph: At the all-black Charles R. Drew Prep School for Boys, the official school song is the Presbyterian hymn “Trust and Obey.” But the striving upperclassmen begin a day there by belting out the civil rights anthem “Keep Your Eyes on the Prize.”

headline: In 9/11 Museum to Open Next Spring, Vastness and Serenity, and Awe and Grief
abstract: The National September 11 Memorial Museum at the World Trade Center, scheduled to open in the spring of 2014, is meant to jar its visitors.
lead_paragraph: “You thought it was as bad as it would get, and then it got worse.”

headline: Secret Court Declassifies Yahoo’s Role in Disclosure Fight
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The secret court that oversees national security surveillance requests allowed Yahoo to acknowledge its role in fighting, unsuccessfully, against the government’s collection of information used in the Prism program.
lead_paragraph: In the secret court that authorizes national security surveillance requests, everything is considered confidential — even the existence of communications between companies and the court. But this week, the court drew back the curtain slightly, declassifying the fact that Yahoo was the company that fought the court in a momentous case in 2008.

headline: Where Astros Played, Conventioneers in Suits Could Gather
abstract: The Harris County Sports and Convention Corporation unveiled a $194 million proposal to turn the old Houston Astrodome into a convention center last week.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Ryan Bokros was 8 years old when he attended his first baseball game at the Houston Astrodome. It was 1985. The dome was bursting with people, the famous scoreboard bright with lights and the space bigger than anything he had ever seen.

headline: A Week of Beauty and Joy
abstract: American Ballet Theater’s run of performances of “Sylvia” has been significant for several reasons, not least of which is the star quality of the dancers.
lead_paragraph: If you define a balletomane as someone who cares primarily about dancers, then the balletomane’s peak season is American Ballet Theater’s annual eight-week run at the Metropolitan Opera House. The luminaries include international visitors like Roberto Bolle, Natalia Osipova, Ivan Vasiliev and Diana Vishneva. Next week brings the company debut of the remarkable Danish dancer Alban Lendorf in “The Sleeping Beauty.”

headline: Playing Up the Spicy Aspect of a Summer Fruit Pie
abstract: Chunks of brown sugar spread across a bed of high-acid, tangy plums produce a nicely tart pie.
lead_paragraph: Summer isn’t just fruit-pie season in my kitchen. It’s crumb-pie season, too. Because while in theory one could put a crumbly brown-sugar topping on any kind of pie, tangy, high-acid summer fruit pies work best.

headline: Dipping Into Eastern Modes, Spicing Up the Tarantella
abstract: Canzoniere Grecanico Salentino performed in a whirlwind of tambourine rhythms at Joe’s Pub on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Traditional songs at rocket speed: that’s the music of Canzoniere Grecanico Salentino, who played a breakneck, euphoric set at Joe’s Pub on Thursday night. Songs that may date back millenniums flew by in a whirlwind of tambourine rhythms and the call-and-response of raw voices that also aligned in harmony. Silvia Perrone, a dancer in a bright red dress, twirled and skipped at center stage, barefoot.

headline: Games of Hide and Seek and Experiments for Horns
abstract: TILT Brass celebrated its 10th anniversary on Thursday night at Roulette in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: They can do majestic and they can do scary. They do heroic really well. And they’re experts at wake-up-and-face-Judgment-Day.

headline: Campaigning Hard for Presidential Plays
abstract: Two plays about President Lyndon B. Johnson are considered possibilities for Broadway next season. The producer of one, taking a page from Johnson’s playbook, is trying to muscle out the other show.
lead_paragraph: Lyndon Baines Johnson was a larger-than-life figure, no doubt, but is Broadway big enough for two plays about that president?

headline: Makeshift Thrones Fit for No King, and Angels Unfurling Their Wings
abstract: Rachel Cohen and Jody Sperling’s works include nods to Cervantes and to Loïe Fuller.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Cohen and Jody Sperling call their double bill, which opened at Danspace Project on Thursday, “Wood & Silk: A Shared Evening of Textural Choreography.” You can’t actually touch their work, but the common denominator is an interest in combining moving bodies with various kinds of material. The aesthetic is homemade, and the potentially wondrous alchemy of simple things and imagination comes with the risk of pitiful bareness if the magic doesn’t happen.

headline: Motion Picture Academy Seeks to Expand Membership
abstract: The 276 invitations to join the group that hands out Oscars represents a reversal of recent tightening of the rolls.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Reversing a policy that has more closely restricted membership in the last decade, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Friday invited an unusually large group of film professionals — 276 in total, including the actors Milla Jovovich and Joseph Gordon-Levitt — to join its ranks.

headline: Friday Night Music: Elephant Revival, The Pasture
abstract: A bit of instrumental beauty.
lead_paragraph: Dango Rose directs me to a video from their upcoming album. I like this in particular because you can see Bonnie Paine’s footwork — she’s playing a soundboard as well as the washboard:

headline: Plum Chutney Crumb Pie
abstract: Melissa Clark adds homemade fruit chutney to a plum pie. It’s as easy as making applesauce and brings a layer of complexity to a summer fruit dessert.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark adds homemade fruit chutney to a plum pie. It’s as easy as making applesauce and brings a layer of complexity to a summer fruit dessert.

headline: From Across the Pacific, Good Old American Fare
abstract: Among its 59 features this year, the New York Asian Film Festival offers inventive takes on movie genres Hollywood has largely given up on.
lead_paragraph: A tense and elaborate crime drama ending in a Peckinpah-style shootout. A classic tear-jerker about a woman doing menial labor to support her ungrateful son. A loopy, candy-colored musical. A warmhearted biopic about a national hero.

headline: Art Fatigue in London
abstract: After art sales in New York, art fairs in Hong Kong and Basel and the Venice Biennale, auction houses have struggled to keep buyers focused at the London sales.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The spring auctions here, which ended on Thursday night, were a sharp contrast to those that recently took place in New York. There was not a night in London over the last two weeks when sales reached nearly $500 million, as happened in May at the Christie’s evening sale of postwar and contemporary art in New York.

headline: Snapchat Without the Chat
abstract: The photo-sharing app, which is often used to share unflattering or embarrassing “selfies,” has rolled out SnapKidz aimed at children under 13.
lead_paragraph: It’s like Instagram without the corollary of regret and recrimination: Snapchat is touted as “the fastest way to share a moment with friends.”

headline: Variations on the Plum Crumb Pie
abstract: If you can’t find plums, don’t run around town looking. Substitute blueberries or peaches.
lead_paragraph: In my recent column and video, plums take center stage in a spicy crumb-topped pie. But summer pie should be all about ease. And if you can’t find plums, do not run around town looking. Substitute blueberries or peaches, or a mix of the two. A rhubarb-strawberry combination would work well too, though you might have to increase the sugar to make up for rhubarb’s astringency.

headline: Dylan Lauren: Giving an Active Life a Splash of Color
abstract: Dylan Lauren, 39, is the daughter of Ralph Lauren and founder of Dylan’s Candy Bar.
lead_paragraph: Dylan Lauren, 39, is the daughter of Ralph Lauren and founder of Dylan’s Candy Bar. She lives with her husband, Paul Arrouet, on the Upper East Side.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Urban Druids
abstract: Summer is the time of the solstice and Manhattanhenge, when the setting sun aligns with the grid of the city's cross streets, illuminating facades on both sides with a lacy tracery.
lead_paragraph: Summer is the time of the solstice and Manhattanhenge, when the setting sun aligns with the grid of the city's cross streets, illuminating facades on both sides with a lacy tracery.

headline: Experts and Juniors on Bridge Base Online
abstract: Except in July and August, every Wednesday at 11 a.m. Eastern time, two experts partner with juniors from around the world for an hour on Bridge Base Online.
lead_paragraph: Except in July and August, every Wednesday at 11 a.m. Eastern time, two experts partner with juniors from around the world for an hour on Bridge Base Online. These sessions are arranged by Valerie Westheimer of New York City and Paula Mittleman of Boynton Beach, Fla., and kibitzers are welcome.

headline: Syrian Rebels Claim Big Gains in City Where Protests Began
abstract: The southern city of Dara’a would represent a rare military victory in recent weeks for the insurgency.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rebel fighters in southern Syria claimed on Friday to be in control of most of the city of Dara’a, the cradle of the 2011 uprising against President Bashar al-Assad, after having battled his forces there for two weeks. The assertions, if confirmed, would represent a rare military victory for the insurgency, which has been struggling since it lost the stronghold city of Qusayr near the Lebanon border on June 5.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Recession and Depression', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Jon S. Corzine faces a federal suit over the collapse of MF Global, Ireland slipped back into recession and problems with counterfeit food and liquor have grown.
lead_paragraph: Jon S. Corzine faces a federal suit over the collapse of MF Global, Ireland slipped back into recession and problems with counterfeit food and liquor have grown.

headline: No One’s Seen It, but Netflix Renews It
abstract: Netflix has ordered a second season of “Orange Is the New Black,” a series about an unlikely prisoner, two full weeks before subscribers get to see the first season.
lead_paragraph: Netflix, unlike so many of its rivals on cable and broadcast, doesn’t share any ratings, so we won’t know how popular “Orange Is the New Black” is after the show has its debut on the service. But we can surmise that it is already pretty popular inside Netflix.

headline: Portrait of a Young Model in Paris
abstract: I loved this shot from the backstage at Ann Demeulemeester’s show.
lead_paragraph: I loved this shot from the backstage at Ann Demeulemeester’s show — the romantic gloom of it. The picture captures the mood of the collection, with its lean silhouette, wide-striped trousers, modified cloche hats, and flowers embroidered in jet black.

headline: Berluti Holds a Picnic, Givenchy Misses
abstract: I thought Comme des Garcons was pretty interesting, and surprising—a more aggressive line of attack than we’ve seen from Rei Kawakubo in awhile.
lead_paragraph: I’ll have more to say about Berluti and the clothes of Alessandro Sartori in my review of the Paris men’s shows, but what a fabulous party he and his boss, Antoine Arnault, threw tonight at Hotel Sully — just a wee shack — in the Place des Vosges. Much of the fashion/cocktail action took place in the grass-covered courtyard and then there was a barbecue. Hamburgers, hot dogs, kebobs, salads, and French fries, served buffet style.

headline: Week in Pictures for June 28
abstract: Watch a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a rally in the Village after a ruling on same-sex marriage, umbrellas at Jones Beach and a retirement celebration for a beloved principal.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a rally in the Village after a ruling on same-sex marriage, umbrellas at Jones Beach and a retirement celebration for a beloved principal.

headline: Video of Deadly Clashes in Alexandria, Egypt
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Three people, including an American citizen, were killed in the clashes on Friday, and the local headquarters of the Muslim Brotherhood, of which President Mohamed Morsi is a leader, was set ablaze.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Kareem Fahim and David Kirkpatrick report, violent street battles gripped Egypt on Friday as supporters and opponents of the country’s Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi, held competing protests that devolved into fierce clashes in several cities. The violence was particularly fierce in the port city of Alexandria, where three people, including one American citizen, were killed and the local headquarters of the Muslim Brotherhood, of which Mr. Morsi is a leader, was set ablaze.

headline: 17 Years Have Passed and Date-Krumm Plays On
abstract: Kimiko Date-Krumm, who faces Serena Williams on Saturday, grew up playing with a wooden racket and turned professional in 1989.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England – When Serena Williams was just 15, Kimiko Date-Krumm was competing in the Wimbledon semifinals. It’s such a long time ago that Date-Krumm said  that she can barely remember the tournament and it is doubtful either player could have dreamed that 17 years later they would face each other on Court One for a place in the last 16.

headline: The Wrenching Story of Her Abortion
abstract: Responses to Judy Nicastro’s Op-Ed article.

headline: City Homicides Drop Sharply, Again; Police Cite New Antigang Strategy

lead_paragraph: The number of homicides on record in New York City has dropped significantly during the first half of the year — to 154 from 202 in the same period last year — surprising even police officials who have long been accustomed to trumpeting declining crime rates in the city.

lead_paragraph: It was a busy Friday night in March at Petite Abeille, a Belgian cafe on East 20th Street near Stuyvesant Town. Regulars lined the bar. Everybody knew one another, which made it all the more shocking when one of the women shouted, “My wallet! Someone stole my wallet!”

headline: F.B.I. Will Fight the Mafia With Fewer Investigators
abstract: For the third time in five years, the New York office of the F.B.I. has reduced the number of agents assigned to traditional organized crime cases.
lead_paragraph: The New York office of the F.B.I. confronts an array of challenges — from cyber and financial crime to global terrorism — that would have been unimaginable half a century ago when it first squared off in earnest against the mob. And so, in recent years, more and more agents have been assigned to those modern threats and fewer to the L.C.N., the bureau’s shorthand for La Cosa Nostra.

keywords: ['Detainees', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Adnan Farhan Abdul Latif hoarded medication prescribed for mental illness and died after taking two dozen capsules, according to a military report made public Friday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Yemeni detainee who was found dead last year at the military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, committed suicide by taking an overdose of psychiatric medication, according to a military report made public on Friday.

headline: How Is Your Bond Portfolio Allocated?
abstract: This week’s Your Money column addresses the big sell-off in the bond market, in which a fear of rising interest rates has caused investors to dump their funds.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Your Money column addresses the big sell-off in the bond market, in which a fear of rising interest rates has caused investors to dump their funds.

headline: Pub Fare for High Rollers
abstract: Dan Rooney’s bills itself as authentically Irish, but it’s more Las Vegas than Emerald Isle.
lead_paragraph: A piece of advice for those venturing to eat at Dan Rooney’s, a new restaurant at the ever-expanding Empire City Casino at Yonkers Raceway: after consigning your car to a valet, take the escalator to the second floor, weave your way through the chiming slot machines and, just beyond the case of silver trophies, step out onto the terrace overlooking the racetrack. There, at dusk, one can watch beautifully gaited harness horses as they trot around the same dirt oval where Seabiscuit once outran his competitors.

headline: An Adoptee Returns to South Korea, and Changes Follow
abstract: Jane Jeong Trenka, raised in Minnesota by adoptive parents, has returned to her birth country to lead a movement to change the way Koreans think about adoption.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — ALL her life, Jane Jeong Trenka struggled to belong.

headline: Pikes Peak Veteran Rod Millen Races to the Clouds Once More in an E.V.
abstract: Rod Millen has won the Pikes Peak International Hill Climb nine times in conventional cars. But after last year’s run in Toyota’s all-electric TMG EV POO2, he’s ready for another go.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Rod Millen might have laughed at an offer to race an electric car in the annual Pikes Peak International Hill Climb. Millen, 62, is a nine-time winner in the famed Race to the Clouds, including five victories in the Unlimited division.

headline: Zoilo Almonte Gains Attention for Hot Start and His First Name
abstract: Until the Yankees called up Almonte this month, Zoilo Casanova Versalles was the only Zoilo to reach the major leagues.
lead_paragraph: Baseball has had at least 22 players go by the nickname Heinie. There have been three players named Urban, three named Hideki and three with the first name Rogers. But until Zoilo Almonte was summoned to the Yankees from the minors, there had been only one Zoilo.

lead_paragraph: Ratcheting up the rhetoric over New York City’s stop-and-frisk police practices, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Friday that the Police Department stopped white people too frequently, and nonwhites not frequently enough, in investigating murder suspects.

headline: Making ‘Killer Angels’
abstract: The story behind Michael Shaara’s classic novel about the Battle of Gettysburg.
lead_paragraph: One-hundred-and-one summers after the Battle of Gettysburg, a family of four stopped their Nash Rambler at the site during a 1,000-mile drive from the New York World’s Fair to Tallahassee, Fla. The father was a New Jersey-born former boxer, paratrooper and policeman who became a creative writing instructor at Florida State after enrolling to study opera. Before arriving at the park he had published dozens of science-fiction short stories, but nothing about history. But he had researched several Gettysburg participants for the trip, and he fascinated his daughter Lila and son Jeff with stories of his favorites while the family walked the grounds. They ended up staying for several days, because Michael Shaara was in the early stages of creating his masterpiece novel, “The Killer Angels.”

headline: Hepatitis Threat Forces Another Frozen Fruit Recall
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Hepatitis', 'Pomegranates']
