lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration said on Friday that it had identified another product contaminated with Hepatitis A, which was the cause of a recall of frozen organic berries earlier this month.

headline: In Tight Race, Quinn’s Troops Hit the Streets
abstract: With two months left in an increasingly unpredictable primary, Christine C. Quinn is dispatching a volunteer army unlike any in the race to every corner of New York City.
lead_paragraph: In the Bayside section of Queens, a volunteer had barely begun her sales pitch for Christine C. Quinn’s mayoral campaign when the middle-aged man who answered the door cut her off. “She was the one responsible, in the City Council, for giving Bloomberg a third term,” he barked. “I hold that against her.”

headline: Farmers Look to New Ways of Irrigating in a Drought
abstract: Amid strict limits on the water farmers can pump, a project in the Texas Panhandle aimed at showing farmers how to use less irrigation water is being closely watched.
lead_paragraph: DUMAS, Tex. — Deep in the Texas Panhandle, where the decline of the Ogallala Aquifer has left farmers fearful for their future, Harold Grall is hoping his field of tiny green corn plants will survive with minimal watering.

headline: What Do You Reveal Onstage?
abstract: If a performer’s mind isn’t on the show, the audience can tell.
lead_paragraph: Ah, yes. Back to the songwriting series! I’ve missed writing about songwriting. Maybe you’ve missed me, too, a little. Why do we write songs, by the way? Usually we write for a reason — to express a feeling, to tell that boy what we think of him, or to sing the baby to sleep. Sometimes we write songs to be famous, but not usually. The best songs are useful in our daily lives. So therefore anywhere we sing a song can be a kind of stage.

headline: On Grass, Riske Is in Her Element
abstract: Alison Riske’s game is well suited to the grass courts at Wimbledon.
lead_paragraph: Alison Riske knows how to play on grass. She broke through at Birmingham three years ago, getting through three tough qualifying matches, then making a deep run to the semifinals, where she lost in three sets to Maria Sharapova. The All England Club gave her a wild card that year, but Riske lost a close match to Belgium’s Yanina Wickmayer in the first round.

headline: Shopkeepers and Now Restaurateurs, Too
abstract: The owners of Gifford’s, which opened for business in Kent in February, also run a specialty food store around the corner.
lead_paragraph: The look of Gifford’s, which opened for business in Kent in February, sends a clear signal that this is a different kind of restaurant from its predecessor, the long-running Doc’s Trattoria. The co-owners, Michael Moriarty and James Neunzig, had the interior redesigned with vibrant blocks of color that evoke the work of the artist Josef Albers.

headline: With Pierce and Garnett, Nets Get Upgrade in Scoring and Snarling
abstract: Paul Pierce and Kevin Garnett will give the Nets a new attitude, which, aside from shooting and athleticism, was their greatest need of all.
lead_paragraph: The lights will go up, the “Broook-lyn” chants will resume and, in the giddy haze of opening night at Barclays Center next fall, a brooding, solitary figure will approach the basket stanchion closest to the home team’s bench — and ram his head into it. Repeatedly.

headline: Transit Union Spurns Lhota
abstract: The group, representing about 38,000 subway and bus workers, plans to support William C. Thompson Jr., the former city comptroller, instead of Joseph J. Lhota, the former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
lead_paragraph: In January, when Joseph J. Lhota, the former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, announced his run for mayor, the leader of the largest union of transit workers in the city was asked if the group would consider endorsing Mr. Lhota’s candidacy.

headline: Bhutan Is No Shangri-La
abstract: How a tiny kingdom created a giant refugee crisis.
lead_paragraph: DAMAK, Nepal — BEFORE my family was expelled from Bhutan, in 1992, I lived with my parents and seven siblings in the south of the country. This region is the most fertile part of that tiny kingdom perched between Tibet and India, a tapestry of mountains, plains and alpine meadows. Our house sat in a small village, on terraced land flourishing with maize, millet and buckwheat, a cardamom garden, beehives and enough pasture for cows, oxen, sheep and buffaloes. That was the only home we had known.

headline: Scavenger of Golf Balls Is Found Stabbed to Death
abstract: The body of a man said to be one of two men who was familiar for recovering and selling lost golf balls at a course in the Bronx was found near the grounds on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: For most golfers, every shank, hook and slice is agony. But for the people who scavenge the ponds and rough edges of golf courses, the little white balls that land out of play are as good as cash.

headline: Visit by Obama Is Overshadowed by Mandela Vigil
abstract: As South Africa comes to terms with saying farewell to its revered former leader Nelson Mandela, President Obama faces a delicate diplomatic balancing act.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Nelson Mandela always wanted to go quietly. Despite his stature as a global icon, he sought a dignified withdrawal from public life in recent years; privately he told aides of his desire for a quiet funeral, stripped of pomp.

lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — For two women playing third-round matches Saturday at Wimbledon — Sabine Lisicki and Tsvetana Pironkova — the slick grass has proved a fast track to the business end of tournaments in a way that other tournaments have not.

abstract: For Natalie Gulbis, just competing at the United States Women’s Open is something of an achievement after she contracted malaria during a previous tournament.
lead_paragraph: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. — Her caddie, Greg Sheridan, was the first to grow alarmed at her growing list of symptoms. Something seemed definitely off about Natalie Gulbis’s condition.

abstract: Jarring transitions between the serenity of vast spaces and the grief of destruction and loss will meet visitors to the exhibition space.
lead_paragraph: Jarring transitions between the serenity of vast spaces and the grief of destruction and loss will meet visitors to the exhibition space.

headline: Publisher Drops Book Deal With TV Chef Paula Deen
abstract: Fans had made a to-be-published book by Paula Deen a top seller on Amazon, but the publisher, Random House, joined the list of business partners that have cut ties to the embattled chef.
lead_paragraph: Paula Deen got a rare bit of good news on Thursday: Her new cookbook hit No. 1 on the best-seller list at Amazon.com, as thousands of fans — many of them springing to her defense as she faces accusations of racism — ordered the book months before its October release.

headline: Expect the Unexpected

abstract: There’s nothing like a surprise! This week, the U.S. Senate actually passed something and liberal Democrats in Texas won a huge political victory.
lead_paragraph: Every once in a while, something happens that challenges your entire view of the order of the universe. For instance, this week the U.S. Senate actually passed something. Meanwhile, in Texas, liberal Democrats and the abortion rights movement won a huge political victory.

headline: Dinner Before the Show, or Just Dinner
abstract: Ryan DePersio, who has drawn a following with unfussy Italian cooking, is performing on a far grander stage with Nico Kitchen + Bar, in downtown Newark, next to the New Jersey Performing Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: There are several kinds of dining experiences to be had at the flashy Nico Kitchen + Bar, tucked into the eastern end of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in downtown Newark. You might choose an evening when there’s a performance next door and the place is humming with fans who can pass directly into the theater at showtime. Or you might opt for a quieter night, when the enormous main dining room feels as cavernous and calm as a cathedral. In that case a better choice might be one of the handsome brown banquettes in the bar area, which can be bustling at happy hour but intimate a bit later on. Or maybe lunch, when there are “lots of suits” from the nearby office buildings and government offices, as Nico’s guiding force, Ryan DePersio, put it in a telephone interview after several recent visits.

headline: Horse-Butchering Plan Gains as U.S. Agrees to Inspect
abstract: The Department of Agriculture said it would provide the legally required services to a plant in New Mexico and probably to two others.
lead_paragraph: A plant in New Mexico that plans to slaughter horses to produce meat for human consumption moved a step closer to operation on Friday when the Agriculture Department said it would provide legally required inspection services.

headline: Cultural Revolution Vigilantes
abstract: Why would a memoir about growing up in China spawn such hate?
lead_paragraph: Even now, nearly six months later — during which time Amazon.com has been flooded with hundreds of negative reviews condemning her; a Web site was set up attacking her; and her friends and colleagues have been bombarded with e-mails denouncing her — it is a little hard to understand why Ping Fu’s memoir, “Bend, Not Break,” has aroused such fury in some quarters of the Chinese immigrant community.

headline: Proper Partner

lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — So there’s this guy named Joe Krozel, and he likes to break records. He’s done it a lot (No, I am not going to go count. Just trust me on this) and his thing seems to be looking for new ways to push the envelope.

headline: While N.S.A. Leaker Stays in Hiding, Russian TV Builds a Pedestal for Him

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — While Edward J. Snowden has remained mysteriously hidden from sight during his visit to Russia this week, Russian television has been making him a hero.

headline: Glossy Ibises Are Like 21st-Century Pterodactyls
abstract: The dark, long-necked wading birds, distinctive against a 21st-century skyline, are increasingly common sights in shallow mud flats and wet meadows of New York City.
lead_paragraph: Along the Atlantic coast, summer afternoons arrive on the wings of the glossy ibis (Plegadis falcinellus). These dark birds seem to appear magically, suddenly haunting shallow mud flats and wet meadows where just minutes earlier none had been.

headline: Dangerous Divisions in the Arab World
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Editorials', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Rising sectarianism is fueling hatred and unrest.
lead_paragraph: Even in a region where violence has become all too commonplace, the killing of four Shiite men in Egypt last weekend seemed particularly vicious. According to news reports, a cheering Sunni Muslim mob armed with clubs, swords and machetes raided a house in a Cairo suburb where about 30 people were marking a religious festival and beat, stabbed and lynched the four men. Video footage showed the victims’ bodies, bloodied and motionless, being dragged through the streets. Among those killed was a prominent Shiite cleric, Hassan Shehata.

headline: A Damaging Decision on Generic Drugs
keywords: ['Generic Brands and Products', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Liability for Products', 'Editorials']
abstract: A ruling by the Supreme Court leaves little recourse for people harmed by generic drugs.
lead_paragraph: Consumers grievously harmed by generic drugs may find it virtually impossible to win compensation for their injuries as a result of a Supreme Court decision issued on Monday. By a narrow 5-to-4 margin, the court overturned lower court rulings that had awarded a New Hampshire woman $21 million for pain and suffering and other damages.

headline: American Mayors: Let Them Smoke Pot
abstract: The Justice Department needs to respond to new state laws that legalize marijuana. The status quo is chaotic and untenable.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than seven months since voters in Colorado and Washington State chose to legalize marijuana for recreational use, in contravention of federal drug laws. It has been more than three months since Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. told the Senate Judiciary Committee that he would announce his department’s response to the new statutes “relatively soon.”

headline: Senegal Cheers Its President for Standing Up to Obama on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'United States International Relations', 'Discrimination']
abstract: In Senegal, where gay sex is a crime, President Macky Sall was viewed as something of a hero for trading barbs with President Obama on same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — In Senegal, never mind about same-sex marriage: gay men and lesbians are abused by the police, beaten and sometimes tortured, with impunity. They are threatened by mobs, mocked on the front pages of newspapers and subject to criminal prosecution for being gay. And the persecution is even more severe elsewhere in West Africa.

headline: F.D.A. Approves a Drug for Hot Flashes
abstract: The treatment, which will be called Brisdelle, is the first nonhormonal drug to treat hot flashes to be approved by the Food and Drug Administration.
lead_paragraph: The first nonhormonal drug to treat hot flashes won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Friday, offering a new alternative to menopausal women.

lead_paragraph: This first week of testimony in the George Zimmerman trial has proved to be nothing short of fascinating.

headline: Sex and the H.I.V. Morning-After Pill
abstract: New H.I.V.-prevention drugs may be a boon, but they also raise troubling questions about promiscuity and responsibility.
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY had a serious H.I.V. scare after an episode of unprotected sex. The next day, at Whitman-Walker, a clinic in Washington that specializes in treating gay patients, I began a monthlong regimen of the drug Truvada, a form of post-exposure prophylaxis, or PEP. It has to be taken within 72 hours after potential contact with the virus that causes AIDS. The price tag would normally be $1,200, but I was able to get a subsidy the manufacturer gives to low-income earners.

headline: Masterpieces, Revised by a Playful Restorer
abstract: Kathleen Gilje’s show at the Bruce Museum recreates monuments of art history, changing just enough to produce novel artworks rather than forgeries.
lead_paragraph: Few people in the art world will forget an incident that occurred a little over a year ago, when a parishioner in a church near Zaragoza, Spain, took it upon herself to restore a fresco of Jesus — and ended up ruining it. It’s unlikely that Kathleen Gilje’s exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich will receive as much attention as the hapless Cecilia Giménez, whose story immediately spread on the Internet. But if Ms. Giménez offered a tragicomic lesson in the pitfalls of do-it-yourself conservation, “Revised and Restored: The Art of Kathleen Gilje” shows the work of a skilled practitioner-turned-artist who consciously blurs the lines between restoring art and making something new.

headline: N.F.L. Star and Murder Victim: Where Diverse Paths Crossed
abstract: Aaron Hernandez and Odin Lloyd shared a passion for football and little else. But their lives did cross, and now Hernandez, an N.F.L. tight end, is in jail, charged with Lloyd’s murder.

abstract: New simulators for training young drivers feature technology aimed at teaching them the dangers of talking on cellphones and texting while driving.
lead_paragraph: DES PLAINES, Ill. — The drivers’ education simulator lab here seems straight from the 1970s: A dozen teenagers tucked into low-slung black vinyl drivers’ seats, their steering wheels creaking in unison as a grainy movie plays and a narrator’s grandfatherly voice gently asks, “Are you identifying the potential signs of conflict?”

headline: Jim Hudson, Who Intercepted Pass to Help Jets Win Title, Dies at 70
abstract: Mr. Hudson, whose interception helped defeat the Baltimore Colts in the 1969 Super Bowl, requested that his brain and spine be given to researchers studying sports-related trauma.
lead_paragraph: Jim Hudson, the defensive back whose interception on a trick play helped propel the Jets’ storied upset over the Baltimore Colts in the 1969 Super Bowl, died on Tuesday in Austin, Tex. He was 70.

headline: Celebrating the Evolution, and Craft, of Boat Building
abstract: “From Shore to Shore: Boat Builders and Boatyards of Long Island and Westchester,” to be presented at the Port Jefferson Village Center, highlights the disappearing craft of boat building.
lead_paragraph: IN HIS PLAINTIVE 1989 SONG “The Downeaster ‘Alexa,’ ” Billy Joel gave voice to the plight of Long Island fishermen suffering after a ban on striped bass fishing that went into effect a few years earlier. The ban was one of the factors, along with increased regulation, overfishing and aggressive development on the Long Island coast, that helped cause the waning of the fishing industry, and in turn, a perhaps less obvious decline: that of the boat-building trade.

headline: Sabathia, in Bid for 200th Victory, Veers From Dominating to Defeated

lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Through five innings Friday night, C. C. Sabathia looked as if he might earn his 200th win in grand style. He had not allowed a hit and was pitching as sharply as he had been all season.

headline: Adm. Frank B. Kelso Dies at 79; Tied to Tailhook Scandal
abstract: Admiral Kelso held top naval commands and oversaw the capture of terrorists on the cruise ship Achille Lauro, but his career was tarnished after a sexual harassment scandal known as Tailhook.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Adm. Frank B. Kelso II, who retired under pressure as chief of naval operations in 1994 in the aftermath of rampant sexual misconduct by Navy officers at an aviation convention known as Tailhook, died on Sunday in Norfolk, Va. He was 79.

headline: Events in New Jersey
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Out to the (Extremely) Old Ball Game
abstract: The Hoboken Nine are just one of a number of clubs that play baseball the way it was played decades before Ruth and Gehrig were born.
lead_paragraph: Men in uniform are not traditionally jeered at for being “unmanly.”

headline: Harvey Is Sharp, but Bullpen Is Not
abstract: Matt Harvey was brilliant for seven innings against the Nationals. But then the Mets’ bullpen took over.
lead_paragraph: The futility of the 2013 Mets can ruin any night, even one when Matt Harvey pitches. On another evening when Harvey, the Mets’ ace, was dazzling, the bullpen collapsed and cost him a victory.

headline: Mets’ Wheeler Scouts Harvey and Himself
abstract: The Mets’ Zack Wheeler will make his Citi Field debut Sunday when he starts against the Nationals. Wheeler said watching Matt Harvey has already made a difference in his pitching.
lead_paragraph: The most meaningful games the Mets will play this year are the ones that cast an eye toward future seasons, when the team hopes to contend. For that reason, any Matt Harvey start is worth watching, but so are starts by the prized rookie Zack Wheeler.

headline: Arizona Is Fertile Ground for New York Matzo
abstract: Arizona’s arid wheat fields have become the front line in the competition between two Ultra-Orthodox sects for the most rigorous standards in the production of matzo.
lead_paragraph: YUMA, Ariz. — Here, on a Christian farmer’s land  five miles from the Mexican border, lies the holiest of fields for some of New York’s most observant Orthodox Jewish communities. Wheat harvested on these 40 acres is destined to become matzo, the unleavened bread eaten by Jews during the eight days of Passover.

headline: An Island Lifesaver
abstract: Ben Jones, the only paramedic with the Shelter Island Emergency Medical Service squad, is still going strong at age 90.
lead_paragraph: All ambulance workers have their war stories. Ben Jones has them going back to World War II.

headline: All Eyes on the Elephant
abstract: Books on an elephant named Topsy, immigrant populations in New York and the city’s urban landscapes.
lead_paragraph: In his work “Topsy: The Startling Story of the Crooked-Tailed Elephant, P. T. Barnum and the American Wizard, Thomas Edison” (Atlantic Monthly Press, $27), Michael Daly vividly revives a rollicking pachydermal tale that riveted New Yorkers a century ago and still survives in a gruesome YouTube video.

headline: Rangers Decide to Keep Richards
abstract: The Rangers announced Friday that they would not use their remaining compliance buyout this summer, ensuring that Brad Richards will return to the team for at least one more season.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers announced Friday that they would not use their remaining compliance buyout this summer, ensuring that Brad Richards will return to the team for at least one more season.

headline: Stanzas for a Romantic Season
abstract: It’s summertime, and the longing can be overwhelming for people who think they have found that right someone — but never get a name.
lead_paragraph: Pop songs never seem to mention winter love or autumn love. But summer love — now that’s a genre all its own. Guilt-free and removed from the usual fidelities, summer love is the troubadour of romance: it entertains and distracts us, and then moves blithely on. The following poems were “found” last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are their subject headings.

headline: N.F.L. Won’t Promote Enrollment in Health Insurance Under New Law
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Football']
abstract: The National Football League is not participating in an effort with the Obama administration to help promote enrollment in health insurance plans under the new health care law.
lead_paragraph: The National Football League is not participating in an effort with the Obama administration to help promote enrollment in health insurance plans under the new health care law, a spokesman said. The statement came after two Republican Senate leaders wrote to the heads of six major professional sports organizations, including the N.F.L., expressing concern that they would help encourage people to sign up in the new health insurance programs set to begin next month. Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary for health and human services, has been in talks with various groups to help with enrollment efforts. But the senators, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and John Cornyn of Texas, warned that doing so might not be a good idea. “Given the divisiveness and persistent unpopularity of the health care law, it is difficult to understand why an organization like yours would risk damaging its inclusive and apolitical brand by lending its name to its promotion,” the senators wrote.

headline: Hardaway’s Name Is Familiar, but His Game Is Not
abstract: Tim Hardaway Jr. said it was not fair, or correct, for people to compare him to his father. The younger Hardaway, who is taller, said he planned to make a name for himself with the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Tim Hardaway Jr. stared at his No. 5 Knicks jersey, surrounded by photographers prepared to capture the moment. Hardaway, the Knicks’ first-round pick, then flashed a familiar smile as cameras clicked.

headline: A Night Owl With a Canine Alarm
abstract: How Mark Elijah Rosenberg, the founder and artistic director of Rooftop Films, spends his Sundays.
lead_paragraph: Mark Elijah Rosenberg is the founder and artistic director of Rooftop Films, which has been screening new independent films atop various New York City buildings every summer since 1997. The group has since branched out to farms and boats, among other venues, and has screened films in at least a half-dozen other cities. Mr. Rosenberg, 38, lives in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, with his wife,  Stephanie Frances Skaff, a musician and writer, and their dog, Dizzy.

headline: Taking Back Hernandez Jerseys
abstract: The New England Patriots are offering new jerseys to all fans who want to get rid of the ones they bought with Aaron Hernandez’s name.
lead_paragraph: The New England Patriots are offering new jerseys to all fans who want to get rid of the ones they bought with Aaron Hernandez’s name. Hernandez is being held in jail on a first-degree murder charge. The team has released him and removed all Hernandez jerseys from its souvenir store at Gillette Stadium. The team said fans could go to the store on the weekend of July 6-7 for a free jersey of comparable value. (AP)

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Lifetime) ANNA NICOLE (2013) Agnes Bruckner, above, plays Vickie Lynn Hogan, a Texas high school dropout and single mother who takes a job as a dancer at a topless bar and changes her name. As Anna Nicole Smith, she marries the octogenarian millionaire J. Howard Marshall (Martin Landau) and earns comparisons to Marilyn Monroe in a Playboy pictorial. But her husband’s death brings an end to her financial support, and drinking, pill-popping and drastic weight fluctuations take their toll. Soon her son, Danny (Graham Patrick Martin), dies of an overdose while visiting his mother and newborn sister in the hospital. Not long after, Anna dies. Rounding out the cast are Adam Goldberg, as Anna’s boyfriend Howard K. Stern; Virginia Madsen, as her mother, Virgie Arthur; and Cary Elwes, as Marshall’s son, E. Pierce Marshall.

headline: Shaking Up the Stage
abstract: A theater company called the Apothetae showcases edgier narratives about disability rather than stories of triumph over adversity.
lead_paragraph: Dixon Place, the Lower East Side performance space, has been host for all sorts of odd and eyebrow-raising work, but Gregg Mozgala may have introduced a new kind of discomfort this month with a scene that found him sucking on Sara Buffamanti’s toes.

headline: The Mob and Angela Clemente
abstract: For nearly 15 years, Angela Clemente has sought to prove that the federal government has looked away from dozens of murders committed in New York by those it paid to work as informants.
lead_paragraph: At the end of February, a 300-page report, tersely titled, “New York Systemic Corruption,” was received for review by the Justice Department’s Office of the Inspector General in Washington. In three bound volumes, it detailed a series of oft-made, and explosive, allegations: that in the 1990s, while trying to stem the Colombo family war, federal prosecutors and agents for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York knowingly allowed two moles in the mob to kill while they were on the government’s payroll.

headline: Camping for Feminism
abstract: Activists in New York’s women’s movement lead a weeklong camp for high school students to teach them about the “practical applications of feminism.”
lead_paragraph: On Thursday morning, Courtney Cook, a 17-year-old art student from Winnetka, Ill., who was spending the week with her mother at the Jade Hotel downtown, sat in the Lexington Avenue offices of the nonprofit group Choices in Childbirth and talked about her maternal fantasies. “I’d like to have a baby like right now,” Ms. Cook explained to a group of peers and educators, “but I know it’s not a good time.” Although she doesn’t plan to have a child until she is 30, she had become obsessed with motherhood after hours of watching “A Baby Story,” a reality series on the procreation-obsessed cable network TLC. Such is the extent of her fascination that she keeps pictures of nurseries on her Pinterest board.

headline: U.S. Student Killed in Egypt Protest Was Drawn to a Region in Upheaval
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Andrew Pochter was killed in Alexandria during antigovernment protests, and was working there this summer as an intern at a nonprofit organization.
lead_paragraph: The American student who was killed in Egypt on Friday during street protests in Alexandria was an idealist, an Arabist and a linguist, drawn to the Middle East despite — or perhaps even because of — its political unrest, friends said.

headline: Unable to Visit With Mandela, Obama Honors His Legacy
abstract: President Obama delivered his respects in a private meeting with Nelson Mandela’s family as South Africans gathered at Mr. Mandela’s home to express their emotional bond with him.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The possibility of a meeting between the two historic figures — the first black president of the United States and the first black president of South Africa — was so tantalizingly close. But with Nelson Mandela fighting for his life in a Pretoria hospital, President Obama abandoned his hope for a visit and instead on Saturday used every stop here to talk in emotional and sweeping terms about what Mr. Mandela meant to the world, and to him.

headline: Visit by Obama Is Overshadowed by Mandela Vigil
abstract: As South Africa comes to terms with saying farewell to its former leader Nelson Mandela, President Obama must balance the trappings of a diplomatic visit with respect for a fading hero.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Nelson Mandela always wanted to go quietly. Despite his stature as a global icon, he sought a dignified withdrawal from public life in recent years. Privately he told aides of his desire for a quiet funeral, stripped of pomp.

headline: The Weekend Word: Covered
abstract: Political news from today’s Times and a look at the president’s weekly address, plus the latest happenings in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In Today’s Times

headline: Violence in Restive Chinese Region Prompts Crackdown
abstract: Communist Party leaders vowed to apply high-pressure methods in the far western region of Xinjiang after two outbursts pitting members of the Uighur minority against police forces.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s Communist Party leadership has started a security crackdown in the far western region, Xinjiang, vowing to apply “high pressure” methods after two outbursts of violence there in recent days pitted members of the Uighur ethnic minority against police forces, state television reported Saturday.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Givenchy Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Who’s a Journalist? A Question With Many Facets and One Sure Answer
abstract: The Times was right to correct the mention of Alexa O’Brien in an article about the role of Julian Assange in the case of Edward J. Snowden.
lead_paragraph: Behind almost every correction in The Times, there is a story. In the case of the correction about Alexa O’Brien, the story is a particularly interesting one.

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent articles in the Sports section of The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Acelaland Versus Mayberry
abstract: We are the real America.
lead_paragraph: Hmm. One thing I’ve noticed in recent discussions is that on the right, the Acela — America’s only sorta-kinda high-speed passenger train — has become a symbol of liberal elitism. What’s that about?

headline: The Always-Wrong Club
abstract: From bubbles to currency debasement.
lead_paragraph: Aha. Floyd Norris reminds us of the 23-economist letter from 2010, warning of dire consequences — “currency debasement and inflation” — from quantitative easing. The signatories are kind of a who’s who of wrongness, ranging from Niall Ferguson to Amity Shlaes to John Taylor. And they were wrong again.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Berluti Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the men’s fashion week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Paul Venables, on Asking for the Toughest Jobs
keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The founder of a San Francisco advertising agency says he would advise college graduates starting a career to volunteer for a task their boss hates.
lead_paragraph: This interview with   Paul Venables, founder and executive creative director of Venables Bell & Partners, an advertising agency in San Francisco, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Cahill Returns Not a Moment Too Soon for Red Bulls
abstract: Tim Cahill, the team’s second designated player was away for the entire month of June helping Australia qualify for next summer’s World Cup.
lead_paragraph: The Red Bulls will attempt to avoid on 0-fer, 0 for June, when they face the Houston Dynamo on Sunday afternoon in the club’s first home game since the first day of the month.

headline: Risk for Redskins in Makeover of Team Mascot
keywords: ['Football', 'Native Americans', 'Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Mascots', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Logos']
abstract: The chorus calling for a change in the team’s name broadened last month when 10 members of Congress condemned the franchise for using a “racial, derogatory slur” as its mascot.
lead_paragraph: Few teams in the N.F.L. have faced more pressing off-season concerns than the Washington Redskins, whose star quarterback, Robert Griffin III, hopes to be ready for training camp as he continues to rehabilitate his surgically repaired right knee.

headline: After Fighting Mobile Trend, Intel Now Embraces It
abstract: Intel’s new chief executive, Brian Krzanich, explains how the company initially fought the mobile revolution and is now trying to catch up.
lead_paragraph: Intel, which became a global behemoth by making the chips that drive most of the world’s desktop computers and laptops, missed the mobile revolution. In tablets and smartphones, the company is a bit player.

headline: Dior Homme
abstract: The complete spring 2014 collection shown in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The complete spring 2014 collection shown in Paris.

headline: Christian Dior: Spring 2014 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Mariano Rivera: A Singular Pitcher
abstract: Mariano Rivera, the Yankees’ longtime closer, specializes in only one pitch and throws just one inning at a time. More notable, he has allowed only one base runner per inning in his career.
lead_paragraph: As Mariano Rivera walked to the mound June 19, a Yankee fan might have felt a pang of doubt. A combined 18 walks and hits had pockmarked his previous five and two-thirds innings over eight outings, more base runners, according to the Elias Sports Bureau, than Rivera had ever allowed over any other eight-game stretch in his major league career.

headline: Rangers Have Needs but Not High Picks
abstract: Having traded away their first- and second-round draft choices, the Rangers are still looking to add defensive depth and a goaltender.
lead_paragraph: Gordie Clark, the Rangers’ player personnel director, hopes to add defensive depth and a goaltender in the N.H.L. draft on Sunday.

headline: Egypt, Its Streets a Tinderbox, Braces for a Spark
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: A year after Egypt’s first credible presidential election, the ballot box has failed to deliver on promises of unquestioned legitimacy or the nonviolent resolution of political disputes.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Thousands of members of the Muslim Brotherhood, many wearing hard hats and armed with makeshift clubs, are camped near the presidential palace in anticipation of a battle to defend their ally, President Mohamed Morsi. In three days of protests against him around the Nile Delta, gunmen have killed at least five Brotherhood members and set fire to several of its offices.

headline: For the No. 1 Pick, the Avalanche May Set Aside Sentiment
abstract: Seth Jones is the sentimental choice for the Colorado Avalanche and could also be the first player of African-American heritage to be taken No. 1 over all.
lead_paragraph: Sunday’s N.H.L. draft at Prudential Center in Newark will begin either like a fairy tale, or like a fairy tale overturned. It all depends on whether the Colorado Avalanche take defenseman Seth Jones with the first overall pick or choose the talented center Nathan MacKinnon instead.

headline: Variety: An Alarming Acrostic
abstract: Cox and Rathvon reach out to us from great heights.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I’ll confess, I had never heard of a “ha-ha” before today’s discussion. That may have slowed me down. You just don’t see too many of them in the part of the Bronx where I grew up.

headline: It’s No Secret Lakers Want Howard Back
abstract: The free-agency period in the N.B.A. begins Monday, and the Lakers are having to confront the possibility that Dwight Howard, acquired last summer, will leave.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When two billboards with an image of Dwight Howard accompanied by the word “STAY” went up last week in Los Angeles — one on Hollywood Boulevard and the other across the street from Staples Center — it was rather unbecoming.

headline: President-Elect of Iran Says He Will Engage With the West
abstract: In remarks on Saturday,  Hassan Rouhani also said he would fulfill his electoral promises to allow more freedom for the Iranian people.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s president-elect, Hassan Rouhani, said Saturday that he would engage with the West and fulfill his electoral promises to allow more freedom for the Iranian people.

headline: Kerry Extends Israel Trip Amid Speculation on Talks
abstract: In a hectic day of shuttle diplomacy, Secretary of State John Kerry struggled to close a deal to revive Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In a hectic day of shuttle diplomacy with senior Israeli and Palestinian leaders in two capitals, Secretary of State John Kerry struggled on Saturday to close a deal to revive dormant Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

headline: Best Brother Was Saved for Last, Bobcats Think
abstract: The Charlotte Bobcats, who selected Cody, the youngest of the three Zellers, with the No. 4 pick in Thursday’s draft, will be hoping they have the right brother.
lead_paragraph: The Zeller brothers each took a turn being Indiana’s Mr. Basketball. They reached a combined height of just under 21 feet, and each attended a powerhouse athletic university. But like most of the groups of three or more brothers to make it to professional sports, one will probably stand above the rest.

headline: Actors Today Don’t Just Read for the Part. Reading IS the Part.
abstract: As audiobooks flourish, thanks in part to digital technologies, the industry has given many aspiring actors a steady paycheck.
lead_paragraph: Gabra Zackman is a new kind of acting star: she is heard, but unheard-of.

headline: Horschel’s Mantra: Clothes Make the Man
abstract: Billy Horschel always wants to look good, and now he has become a multidimensional force on the PGA Tour.
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md. — Billy Horschel had a 50 percent success rate during his early days as a professional golfer. It had nothing to do with hitting greens in regulation or keeping the ball out of the rough. It had everything to do with having his wardrobe vetted by his wife, Brittany.

headline: At Wimbledon, Promise, Steeled by Early Trauma for Gómez
abstract: Lucas Gómez, a surprise winner in the Gerry Weber Open junior tournament this month, lost his father at age 10 when their bus was ambushed by a gunman.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Lucas Gómez, the Mexican national junior tennis champion, was humbled at the French Open in early June. He was beaten, 6-1, 6-0, in the third round of the junior tournament by second-seeded Nikola Milojevic of Serbia after expressing strong belief in his ability to win.

headline: Eddie Plank: A Favorite Son of Gettysburg
abstract: In a community known as the site of the Civil War’s most famous battle, an often overlooked pitcher has left a different kind of legacy.
lead_paragraph: GETTYSBURG, Pa. — This week’s commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the Battle of Gettysburg, the turning point in the Civil War, might also bring renewed attention to Eddie Plank, a relatively unappreciated baseball star in the early 20th century who spent most of his life here. The battle, fought on the first three days of July in 1863, stamped Little Round Top, Seminary Ridge and Pickett’s Charge into America’s military lexicon.

headline: The Padres’ Season Doesn’t Add Up
abstract: San Diego heads into July squarely in the race in the sluggish National League West, despite a negative run differential and a pitching staff that ranks high in walks and low in strikeouts.
lead_paragraph: When the San Diego Padres lined up along the third-base line at Citi Field on April 1, they did not look like contenders. Their opening day third baseman was the journeyman Cody Ransom. The right-hander Andrew Cashner, a perpetual ace in waiting, was again a reliever. The starter that day was Edinson Volquez, with Clayton Richard to follow in Game 2.

headline: ‘A Gallant Officer’
abstract: A Civil War widow’s long journey to bring home her husband’s remains.
lead_paragraph: One day during the summer of 1863, in Union-occupied Nashville, Tenn., Anna Rhoads visited the headquarters of Gen. Walter C. Whitaker and requested a meeting with him. Perhaps to her surprise, he granted one.

headline: New Kind of Baseball Bat Is Tapered for Safety and Comfort
abstract: The bat’s knob is slanted on one side, with the raised edge gradually disappearing so that side of the hand rests on a flat surface rather than grinding against the knob during a swing.
lead_paragraph: Bats have not changed much since Honus Wagner became the first player to have his name burned onto a Louisville Slugger. True, they are lighter now, with rounded ends, and since Barry Bonds used it, many players have switched to maple from the traditional white ash. But the general shape is unchanged.

headline: Who Sets the Terms for Interviews?
abstract: Some readers wonder whether reporters are giving news subjects too much control.
lead_paragraph: TAKING a summertime break from the weighty issues of leaks, false balance and anonymous sources — to which I’m sure to return — I am again hanging out the public editor’s shingle. I will do my best here to answer what I call Perfectly Reasonable Questions from those who read The Times closely and with a critical eye.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Our Notions of Gender
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexual', 'Children and Childhood', 'Education (K-12)', 'Bathrooms and Toilets']
abstract: When a child identifies with the other gender, what to do?
lead_paragraph: When a child identifies with the other gender, what to do?

headline: Thomas A. Drake
abstract: The whistle-blower Thomas A. Drake on the importance of freedom.
lead_paragraph: Thomas A. Drake is a former senior executive at the National Security Agency who, in 2006, leaked information to the press about wasteful government spending and alleged snooping on the citizenry.

headline: Stuck Team Bus Gives First Stage a Chaotic Finish
keywords: ['Tour de France (Bicycle Race)', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A team bus that got stuck at the finish line of the Tour de France’s first stage threatened the conclusion of the race.  Some riders, including Alberto Contador, crashed amid nervous confusion.
lead_paragraph: BASTIA, France — The Tour de France’s first visit to Corsica started uneventfully Saturday as riders rode calmly out of a picture-perfect harbor town under sunny skies.

headline: June 29: Where the Candidates Are Today
abstract: The candidates’ daily campaign schedule at a glance.
lead_paragraph: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

headline: David Rogers, Stage Adapter of Offbeat Material, Dies at 85
abstract: Among the works Mr. Rogers produced was the book for a musical based on “Flowers for Algernon” and plays based on “Brave New World” and “The Sting.”
lead_paragraph: “Flowers for Algernon,” Daniel Keyes’s novel about a mentally handicapped man who is temporarily transformed into a genius, has been read by millions and recreated in many forms, including the 1968 film “Charly” (playing the title role, Cliff Robertson won an Academy Award). But singing along with any version was impossible until David Rogers reinterpreted it as the musical “Charlie and Algernon.”

headline: Takin’ It to the Streets
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: What’s behind so many popular street revolts in democracies?
lead_paragraph: THE former C.I.A. analyst Paul R. Pillar asked this question in a recent essay in The National Interest: Why are we seeing so many popular street revolts in democracies? Speaking specifically of Turkey and Brazil, but posing a question that could be applied to Egypt, Israel, Russia, Chile and the United States, Pillar asks: “The governments being protested against were freely and democratically elected. With the ballot box available, why should there be recourse to the street?”

headline: Germans Loved Obama. Now We Don’t Trust Him.
abstract: Germans don’t take kindly to state surveillance.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — IN May 2010, I received a brown envelope. In it was a CD with an encrypted file containing six months of my life. Six months of metadata, stored by my cellphone provider, T-Mobile. This list of metadata contained 35,830 records. That’s 35,830 times my phone company knew if, where and when I was surfing the Web, calling or texting.

headline: Democrats Get a Gift From the Roberts Court
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How the voting rights decision could help sustain the Obama majority.
lead_paragraph: BACK in the days when Republicans were reading polls through rose-colored glasses and imagining a Mitt Romney landslide, one of their most plausible arguments was that many pollsters were simply misreading the likely composition of the electorate. There was no way, this theory ran, that core Democratic constituencies would turn out at the same rates as in 2008, when Obamamania was at its peak. Instead, 2012 was set up to be what the conservative writer Ben Domenech called an “undertow election,” in which reduced turnout among young voters and minorities would drag the incumbent down to defeat.

headline: A Nation of Brewmeisters
abstract: This is a moment to sip and savor: home beer making will be legal in every state.
lead_paragraph: Eighty years after the end of Prohibition, Mississippi has become the last of the 50 states to legalize one of the more innocent offshoots of the era of the Drys — home brewing, a hobby long suppressed in the states but lately generating a frothy head of popularity. Assorted limits remain in states and localities about the amount of beer that can be brewed as well as bans on transporting home brew into the community. But after some moralizing debates this year about demon beer, Alabama lawmakers repealed the total ban in May; in Mississippi, home brewing becomes legal on July 1.

headline: The Talented Justice Kagan
abstract: She offers penetrating legal analysis, but with a down-to-earth writing style.
lead_paragraph: Elena Kagan is the first Supreme Court justice appointed in almost 40 years who wasn’t a judge before she arrived at the court. In a good way, it shows. Since she was sworn in three summers ago, the evidence has mounted that she is achieving a goal that other justices say they strive for and yet seldom attain: writing readable judicial opinions that non-lawyers can understand.

headline: Mandela and Obama
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Apartheid (Policy)']
abstract: What America’s president might have learned from South Africa’s hero.
lead_paragraph: GATHERING valedictory material on Nelson Mandela as he faded in a Pretoria hospital the other day, I came across a little book called “Mandela’s Way.” In this 2010 volume, Rick Stengel, the ghostwriter of Mandela’s autobiography, set out to extract “lessons on life, love and courage” he had learned from three years of immersion in Mandela’s life.

headline: The Best Hope for France’s Young? Get Out
abstract: France is an overcentralized gerontocracy. To succeed, young people should leave the country and come home with new ideas.
lead_paragraph: THE French aren’t used to the idea that their country, like so many others in Europe, might be one of emigration — that people might actually want to leave. To many French people, it’s a completely foreign notion that, around the world and throughout history, voting with one’s feet has been the most widely available means to vote at all.

headline: The End of Car Culture
abstract: Has America passed peak driving?
lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT OBAMA’S ambitious goals to curb the United States’ greenhouse gas emissions, unveiled last week, will get a fortuitous assist from an incipient shift in American behavior: recent studies suggest that Americans are buying fewer cars, driving less and getting fewer licenses as each year goes by.

headline: Souring on Shark Fin Soup
abstract: A campaign to protect sharks has changed Chinese banquet menus.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was a kid, shark fin soup was de rigueur at wedding banquets. Somebody got married, and slurp — there we were, eating the stringy soup at an elaborate 10-course affair in a private party room in Chinatown. It was pleasing, but in the salty, gelatin-thickened way of Thanksgiving gravy. Shark fin itself is virtually tasteless — the soup’s flavor relies heavily on chicken stock, ham and a generous pour of Chinese red vinegar. We ate it because everyone else did, and everyone else ate it for the same reason.

headline: I Love L.A.
abstract: The photographer Lloyd Ziff revisits Los Angeles, the place of his childhood dreams.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Lloyd Ziff revisits Los Angeles, the place of his childhood dreams.

headline: I Love L.A.
abstract: Maybe you are a little crazy to come to Los Angeles, but it can still be magic.
lead_paragraph: Frank Lloyd Wright said, “Tip the world over on its side and everything loose will land in Los Angeles.” Oscar Levant said, “Behind the phony tinsel of Hollywood lies the real tinsel.” I say, “I love it all.” I love the real tinsel and the phony tinsel, too.

headline: Why Healthy Eaters Fall for Fries
abstract: American consumers, even otherwise healthy ones, keep choosing caloric indulgences rather than healthy foods at fast-food restaurants.

Charming as American optimism may be, its 21st-century incarnation as the search for authenticity deserves pause. The power of this new version of the American dream can be felt through the stridency of its imperatives: Live fully! Realize yourself! Be connected! Achieve well-being!

Tarr, who as director of the Selective Service System in the later years of the Vietnam War sought to make the lottery system for the military draft fairer by reducing the number of student and medical deferments granted to young men, died on June 21 at his home in Walnut Creek, Calif. headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Showtime) RAY DONOVAN If Hollywood honchos need anything fixed, Ray Donovan (Liev Schreiber) is the man they call. Working with two associates — Avi (Steven Bauer, above center with Mr. Schreiber and Katherine Moennig) and Lena (Ms. Moennig) — he cleans up messes for studios and law firms, primarily Goldman/Drexler, led by his confidant and mentor, Ezra Goldman (Elliott Gould), and his partner, Lee Drexler (Peter Jacobson). But Ray’s life is a mess. His wife, Abby (Paula Malcomson), a hard-core Boston Southie, is still adjusting to living in the Los Angeles suburbs. His brother Bunchy (Dash Mihok) was abused by a priest and has the alcohol problem to prove it. Another brother, Terry (Eddie Marsan), boxed too long and developed Parkinson’s. And the ghost of their little sister, who committed suicide when she was a teenager, haunts them all. Now Ray’s father, Mickey (Jon Voight), a gangster with the Irish mob, has been unexpectedly released from prison. The Season 8 premiere of “Dexter,” which finds Deb (Jennifer Carpenter) giving Dexter (Michael C. Hall) the silent treatment, leads in at 9.

headline: ‘Monsters University’ Holds Off ‘White House Down’ at Box Office
abstract: Disney’s animated “Monsters University” topped the weekend box office for the second week, pulling in about $46 million, beating out the “The Heat,” the top new film, as well as the action film “White House Down.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Big guns and heavy star power took aim at the weekend film box office, but “Monsters University,” an animated frolic from Disney’s Pixar unit, was still standing when the dust settled. In its second weekend, “Monsters University” had about $46.2 million in North American ticket sales, and about $171 million in domestic sales to date. headline: Via Stravinsky, a Girl and a Doll, Rapturous and Mechanized
abstract: The New York Philharmonic’s “Dancer’s Dream” had two Stravinsky scores behind diverse dances, employing different sides of the New York City Ballet principal Sara Mearns.
lead_paragraph: The story told by the New York Philharmonic program “A Dancer’s Dream” last week was curious, even chilling. In a program note, the director-designer Doug Fitch called it “a kind of über fairy tale,” amalgamating themes shared by fairy tales around a single young woman “who slips into the world of her own imagination and is swept away by muses to become a ballerina.” Yes, but a ballerina of a particularly restricted kind. That heroine was played by the New York City Ballet principal Sara Mearns, and the program’s particular fascination was that it extended her in two directions we’ve never seen before. She began, in Stravinsky’s “Baiser de la Fée” (“The Fairy’s Kiss”), as a child; she ended it, however, in his “Petrushka” as a dancing doll.

headline: Brick Announces Lineup for Game Play Festival
abstract: The Brick Theater in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has announced the lineup for its annual fusion of live theater and video games.
lead_paragraph: The Brick Theater in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has announced the lineup for the 2013 Game Play festival, its annual fusion of live theater and video games. Among the shows to be presented are “Legendary, Maybe,” in which digital puppeteers use characters from World of Warcraft and Far Cry 3 to adapt stories written by the Roman historian Livy; “No Oddjob,” a one-man show written and performed by David Lawson that explores what happens when video games seep into your dreams; and “That Cute Radioactive Couple,” a comedy inspired by post-apocalyptic games like Fallout and BioShock, written and directed by Charles Battersby. The festival begins on Friday and runs through July 28. A complete schedule is at bricktheater.com.

headline: A Peacock in Spite of Himself
abstract: Bruno Mars, the R&B producer-singer-songwriter, synthesized styles across decades in his show at Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: “This is R&B 101,” Bruno Mars announced Saturday night at Barclays Center, fixing a stare on one woman in the audience. He cued the band to crescendo, and then to stop on a dime, leaving empty air just as he exhaled a silky “damn.” Afterward he paced the stage with an exaggerated peacock strut while encouraging his bandmates to try to outsuave him. “I don’t mean to toot my own horn,” Mr. Mars said when they were done, his megawatt smile turned up to gigawatt, “but, ‘Beeeeep!’ ”

headline: ‘Crazy Rich Asians’: Guilty Pleasure, or Cult of Opulence?
abstract: Kevin Kwan’s novel follows a family blinded by bling and fancy designer names.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when Ming vases qualified as big-ticket Asian artifacts. But in Kevin Kwan’s “Crazy Rich Asians,” a dizzily shopaholic comedy of crass manners, the only Ming status symbols worth talking about are Leo Ming’s climate-controlled clothes closet where the shoes are kept 15 degrees warmer than the fur and cashmere, and Leo Ming’s private plane.

headline: Belgian Wins a Day After a Bus Blunder
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)']
abstract: Before Jan Bakelants of Belgium won Stage 2 in Corsica, a bus driver who had become stuck at the Stage 1 finish received support from colleagues.
lead_paragraph: AJACCIO, Corsica — Near the start line in Bastia, Corsica, on Sunday morning, fans and journalists milled about in the bright sun as they waited for the team buses to arrive. Typically, they would have been hoping to catch a glimpse of their favorite riders or chat with a team manager for the latest scoop.

abstract: A performance piece by Third Rail Projects takes place outdoors in Lower Manhattan around a pop-up camper.
lead_paragraph: You never feel quite the same way about a public place once you’ve seen dance happening in it. Space and architecture that are usually governed by ordinary pedestrian activities become transformed by movement — sometimes by music and drama, too.

headline: Museums Faulted on Restitution of Nazi-Looted Art
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Museums', 'Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Jews and Judaism', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Critics assert that museums have backtracked in recent years on returning art to the heirs of Jews whose property was seized by the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: Not until 1998, when 44 nations including the United States signed the groundbreaking Washington Principles on Nazi-Confiscated Art, did governments and museums formally embrace the idea that they have a special responsibility to repair the damage caused by the wholesale looting of art owned by Jews during the Third Reich’s reign.

headline: Trumpeting a Michelangelo (Cue the Trills of Dissent)
abstract: Scholars hear new evidence that a restored statue from a church in Spain could be a long-lost work by Michelangelo.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE — It was a traditional celebrity sighting — the craned necks, the jostling elbows, the syncopated symphony of snapping cellphone cameras. But in this case, the object of intense scrutiny was a slightly larger-than-life statue of the young St. John the Baptist. Newly restored, it was being presented in a museum here as a lost work by Michelangelo.

lead_paragraph: It’s a good thing the earth is flat, because that means the Honor, the yacht that is the focus of the new Bravo reality series “Below Deck,” is bound to sail over the edge someday. That would presumably relieve us of the obligation to pay any further attention to the people on it.

headline: Jennifer Lopez Faulted for Turkmenistan Show
abstract: Ms. Lopez has drawn scrutiny for singing “Happy Birthday” to the country’s president, who was in attendance.
lead_paragraph: The singer Jennifer Lopez has drawn scrutiny for performing at an event on Saturday night in Turkmenistan and singing “Happy Birthday” to the country’s president, Gurbanguly Berdymukhammedov, who was in attendance. According to The Associated Press, a publicist for Ms. Lopez, above, said in a statement on Sunday that said she would not have appeared if she had known that there were human rights issues in Turkmenistan. Mr. Berdymukhammedov has been criticized by human rights organizations for a pattern of oppressive rule since he became president in 2006. The statement also said that despite Mr. Berdymukhammedov’s presence, the event was not political. It was hosted by the China National Petroleum Corporation, which made the birthday request toward the end of the concert, and Ms. Lopez “graciously obliged.” Her fee for the performance was not disclosed.

headline: Oops, Forgot Where I Hid All the Loot
abstract: A bank robbery and amnesia are central elements of the Bollywood comedy “Ghanchakkar.”
lead_paragraph: The comedy-caper “Ghanchakkar” forgoes Bollywood’s signature song-and-dance sequences but runs at signature length, almost two and a half hours. The movie fills the time usually allotted for musical interludes with plot and more plot, but also with character.

headline: In Conservative Wyoming, Signs of a Thaw on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Law and Legislation', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: A bill to create domestic partnerships, introduced by State Representative Cathy Connolly, advanced further than anything like it in state history.
lead_paragraph: LARAMIE, Wyo. — For State Representative Cathy Connolly, Wyoming’s only openly gay legislator, this winter brought a rare moment of promise: her bill to create domestic partnerships advanced further than anything like it in the history of this deep red state — sailing through committee and onto the floor of the full House. Victory seemed possible. But when a crucial vote came, the bill failed.

headline: Alain Mimoun, a Top Runner, Dies at 92
abstract: Mimoun was a French Olympian and a brilliant distance runner who was hailed for the grandeur of his achievements and for embodying the amateur ideal.
lead_paragraph: Alain Mimoun was a virtual unknown in international track and field when he won a silver medal for France in the 10,000-meter race at the 1948 London Olympics. The Algerian-born Mimoun soon became one of the world’s most brilliant distance runners.

headline: The Rev. Norman Eddy, a Minister in East Harlem, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Eddy, a Yale-educated minister from Connecticut, settled in East Harlem in 1951 and helped start myriad organizations that have sustained his work.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Norman Eddy, a Yale-educated minister from Connecticut who settled in a blighted East Harlem neighborhood in 1951 and helped start a pioneering drug treatment program, a tenants’ group, a housing project, a credit union and the myriad self-help organizations that have sustained his work there for over 60 years, died on June 21 in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Journalism, Even When It’s Tilted
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: The question of who is a journalist is important, partly because when it comes to divulging national secrets, the law grants journalists special protections that are afforded to no one else.
lead_paragraph: In a refracted media world where information comes from everywhere, the line between two “isms” — journalism and activism — is becoming difficult to discern. As American news media have pulled back from international coverage, nongovernmental organizations have filled in the gaps with on-the-scene reports and Web sites. State houses have lost reporters who used to provide accountability, so citizens have turned to digital enterprises, some of which have partisan agendas.
